He shrugged off Mrs. Thatcher's low ratings, citing his own underdog status in polls four months before a landslide election in 1988 and the recent errant surveys that forecast victory for Nicaragua's Daniel Ortega in February. ``I'm enough of a politician to know that people can be down one moment and then soaring like an eagle the next,'' said Bush, who met with Mrs. Thatcher last Friday in Bermuda. Mrs. Thatcher, who begins her 12th year in office next month, has seen her popularity plummet, partly due to an unpopular new method of taxation. The White House on Tuesday released a transcript of the interview Bush gave the reporters on Monday. On another issue, Bush said he is ``very happy'' with the custom of keeping the supreme command of NATO in the hands of an American general. It ``contributes to the view that we have an important role to play'' in Europe, he said. Bush said he hopes his meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand in Key Largo, Fla., on Thursday will ``narrow any differences that might exist'' between France and the United States on the future of NATO. Bush said there have been reports of ``a little drift and a little separation'' between the two allies on NATO. ``The best way to find that out is simply to sit and talk as we will do there,'' he said. ``It is my conviction that NATO will have a perhaps even more important role to play in the stability of Europe,'' Bush said. Mitterrand's view ``doesn't exclude that, but (he) has a keen interest in a role for CSCE,'' said Bush, referring to the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which spans both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. ``I don't think we're ... egregiously apart,'' Bush said. Asked if he could envision a French supreme commander of NATO, Bush said, ``We're very happy with the present arrangements.'' Although France belongs to the 16-nation alliance, it does not participate in its integrated military structure. ``I don't want to have this coming out in a chauvinistic sense, but I think the American people have to feel ... the American presence is wanted'' in helping defend Europe, he said. Asked if the special U.S.-British relationship would endure under a Labor government, Bush replied, ``I haven't given any thought'' to dealing with Mrs. Thatcher's opposition. ``We do have a special relationship and it'll continue, I'm sure,'' he said. But he voiced the hope of steering clear of ``the bubbling cauldron of domestic politics inside the U.K.'' ``I think at least in this country, people see (Mrs. Thatcher) as a very courageous, principled leader who fights for her beliefs and has survived many ups and downs,'' he said. On another issue, Bush said, ``I think it's premature for a three-way free trade agreement'' among the United States, Canada and Mexico. The United States and Canada already have an agreement. Bush said, ``the sensitivities on this question in Mexico are such that we ought to let President (Carlos) Salinas set the pace here.'' Bush praised another ally, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, crediting his leadership with securing progress on long smoldering trade disputes with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister: Brazil Will Not Sign Nuclear Arms Treaty
DOC.TEXT: Brazil has no intention of building nuclear weapons but it will not sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty because that would hurt the nation's advances in nuclear technology, the foreign minister says. ``Brazil is a country without enemies that strongly rejects the idea of building atomic weapons, but we will not sign the treaty because we want to reach our objectives without foreign controls,'' Foreign Minister Francisco Rezek said Tuesday. Both Rezek and the nation's nuclear energy chief refused comment on a report released Tuesday by the private Carnegie Foundation for International Peace in Washington that Brazil and Argentina engaged in smuggling to expand their nuclear weapons capabilities. International environmental and political groups have pressed Brazil to sign the 1967 world nuclear treaty. A recent ministry statement, however, said the treaty is ``an unjust instrument that intends to perpetuate two classes of nations in the world ... those that can and cannot develop nuclear programs.'' Rezek said the new administration of President Fernando Collor de Mello also rejects any form of foreign restrictions on Brazilian installations for uranium enriching, considered a major step toward building an atomic bomb. Jose Luiz de Carvalho Santana, the new president of the National Commission of Nuclear Energy, also denied that Brazil would use nuclear technology for military purposes. ``Never have we imagined building atomic bombs,'' Santana was quoted as saying in an interview with the Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper. ``The constitution prohibits nuclear activities for non-peaceful ends, and that is why Brazil will never make an atomic weapon.'' Brazil has only one nuclear power plant on line, the Angra I plant in Angra dos Reis, 100 miles southwest of Rio de Janeiro. The plant was built by the Westinghouse Co. Santana said all Brazilian nuclear installations were under international safeguards and would be open for periodic inspection by the International Atomic Energy Agency, including the controversial Aramar Nuclear Center. The center, kept secret until 1987, is run by the Navy Ministry in Ipero, 75 miles west of Sao Paulo in southeastern Brazil. Two years ago, the government enriched uranium at Atamar as part of a program to build nuclear submarines. The annoucement by former President Jose Sarney that Brazilian scientists had successfully developed fuel-cycle technology prompted speculation that Brazil also wanted to build atomic weapons. The Brazilian Society of Physics recently said the Aramar Center is now capable of processing uranium for an atomic bomb, and it warned in a report to Congress about increasing militarization of the country's nuclear program. Physicist Luiz Pinguelli Rosa, the author of the report, said the government was treating the nuclear program on military and strategic merits, and not for scientific or energy purposes. ``It is worrisome to know that civil society has no type of control over the parallel nuclear program developed by the armed forces,'' Rosa wrote. In response, Santana told Folha da Sao Paulo that Brazil's nuclear program was coordinated in part by civilians and that the armed forces participated in the experiments as in any other scientific sector. Santana said the Nuclear Commission was studying the possibility of transferring uranium enrichment technology to the private sector for commercial use.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Adviser Says Soviets Would Stay Strong After START Treaty
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union would have a completely modern, formidable nuclear force even after carrying out cutbacks under a START treaty with the United States, a senior adviser to President Bush said today. The cutbacks, now being negotiated in Geneva, would trim the size of the Soviet arsenal, Edward L. Rowny told the Reserve Officers' Association. But, in the meantime, Rowny said in a prepared speech, Soviet strategic forces _ long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines _ are being systematically upgraded to provide for a powerful arsenal after the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, The retired Army lieutenant general, who also served as an adviser to President Reagan, added: ``The USSR is intent on retaining its claim to the status of a superpower equal to the United States that only first-rate nuclear forces can provide.'' He said the Soviets were upgrading their strategic nuclear weapons far more aggressively than the United States. For instance, Rowny said, the Soviets are making their land-based SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles more accurate and more powerful while continuing to deploy SS-24s with 10 warheads both in silos and as mobile weapons. ``And the factory at Votkinsk continues to turn out the single warhead SS-25 at a prodigious pace,'' he said. ``The force of Soviet ballistic missile submarines and strategic bombers continues to be modernized.'' On the other hand, Rowny said, the United States is unable to deploy the Peacekeeping ICBM on railroad cars, while the B-2 bomber and development of a mobile ICBM ``are threatened by an untimely tally of the peace divided.'' Rowny's remarks seemed to be aimed at Congress, which is reluctant to approve all the weapons requested by the Bush administration while U.S.-Soviet tensions appear to be ebbing. ``I will be the first to acknowledge that in today's world, the threat of war between the US and USSR has declined dramatically,'' Rowny said. ``But it has declined because America is strong, not weak.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Probes Brake Defect Reports in GM Cars
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. says it is cooperating with an intensified federal investigation of faulty brakes in more than 1 million GM large sedans, which consumers blame for 74 accident-related injuries. The National Highway Traffic Safety administration said Tuesday it was upgrading the probe from a preliminary evaluation, which involves paperwork, to an engineering analysis in which the possibly defective parts are studied. The studies could lead to recalls. The GM engineering analysis was announced by the agency in its monthly report of auto defect investigations. The probe covers GM H-body cars, including the Pontiac Bonneville, Buick LeSabre and Oldsmobile 88, manufactured in the 1986 through 1988 model years. An estimated 1.08 million are on the road. There have been 892 complaints of brake problems, agency spokesman Tim Hurd said. Of those, 187 have included reports of accidents blamed on faulty brakes. Seventy-four injuries have been reported. GM spokesman John Anderson said the company was cooperating with the agency but that he could not comment further. In other new engineering analyses, the agency is examining: _70 reports of loose gear shift levers in 1986-87 Ford Rangers with manual transmissions. An estimated 399,000 of the pickup trucks are on the road. _109 complaints of gasoline leaks in GM's C and K model trucks from the 1984 through 1986 model years. An estimated 1.6 million are on the road. _Seat belt cuts in the 1990 Chevrolet Lumina. The probe was begun as a preliminary evaluation after a seat belt was cut during a routine agency crash test, but discontinued when no evidence of safety defect was found. It is being reopened because Indiana state police reported a cut seat belt in an accident involving a 1990 Lumina, Hurd said.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Orphan's Custody Question Decided
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS thruout last name of couple who got custody to Lewis, sted Louis.
DOC.TEXT: A 10-month-old boy orphaned when his parents died in the quake-triggered collapse of Interstate 880 was placed permanently with his mother's cousin Tuesday, peacefully ending a family feud over him and his sizeable estate. Alameda County Superior Court Judge Roderick Duncan said James Henry Brown IV will live with Arthur and Tonia Lewis on their 50-acre hog and cattle ranch near Chowchilla, about 120 miles southeast of San Francisco. Attorney Simone Campbell, appointed by the court to represent the child's interests, said she was delighted the matter was resolved. Brown's mother, 18-year-old Michele Richard, and his father, James Brown III, died on the Oakland freeway Oct. 17 while en route to a Berkeley fishing pier. Since then the boy has lived alternately with both maternal and paternal grandparents, all of whom asked the court to award them custody. ``In their heart of hearts, they all wanted Jimmy,'' Campbell said. For about the past month, the boy has lived with the Lewises. Alameda County's Public Guardian's Office already has been designated to oversee the boy's estate. He is to receive $100,000 in damages for his parents' deaths, but the settlement is likely to reach close to $1 million by the time the issue is finally resolved. Before Tuesday's hearing, the grandparents and the Lewises met alone and agreed to a visitation schedule, Duncan said. The judge said he hoped the case serves as an example to others in similar legal battles ``in which the children are always the victims.'' James' new family is due back in court for a progress report Sept. 18.

DOC.HEAD: Three Networks Get Lowest Ratings in History
DOC.TEXT: The good news for NBC: It won its fifth consecutive season in the prime-time ratings. The bad news: It did it with the lowest ratings in history. The season-ending arithmetic indicated cable TV is continuing to make inroads against the three major networks' audience shares. Ten years ago, they had 90 percent of the audience; in the latest count, they're down to 65 percent. Network officials differed Tuesday on whether cable and Fox Broadcasting, or Nielsen's methods of estimating audience size, caused the drop. ``The primary cause of that (drop) is probably basic cable, with a little bit of Fox on the three nights that they're on the air,'' NBC research vice president Robert Niles said. David Poltrack and Larry Hyams, research executives at CBS and ABC, respectively, said TV viewing generally is down, not just at the major networks, and that the drop may result from methodology, not competition. Citing declines in daytime viewing that he called unprecedented, Poltrack conceded that ``at this point we have no answer'' on the cause of the drop either in daytime or at night. But ``the largest amount of that loss is from a decline in homes using television,'' not from cable and other forms of competition, said Poltrack. He said CBS has asked Nielsen for a check of its methods of audience measurement, which include instant-data ``peoplemeters'' in 4,000 homes, and diaries that viewers must fill in. Second-place ABC, whose recent ``Twin Peaks'' series has gotten respectable ratings, gained more viewers last season, even though its share of the TV audience remained flat. The A.C. Nielsen Co. each year reports a larger number of homes with TV. Last year, a ratings point represented 904,000 homes. This year, the number was up to 921,000, which meant ABC's audience increased by more than 200,000 homes. CBS finished in third place for the third year with its worst ratings ever. In the 30-week season that ended Sunday, ABC averaged a 12.9, the same as in 1988-89. CBS averaged a 12.2, down 4 percent. NBC had a 14.6 _ 9 percent below last season. NBC officials noted that NBC's ratings last season had the added boost of telecasts of the Summer Olympics, the World Series and the Super Bowl. Only Fox Broadcasting, which doesn't yet consider itself a network and only has three nights of regular programs, showed a ratings rise. Boosted by its midseason cartoon hit, ``The Simpsons,'' it had a 6.5 rating, up from last season's 5.3 average for two nights of shows, according to Fox estimates. ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' on ABC was the season's top-rated new series, coming in fifth overall. Of the midseason shows besides ``Twin Peaks,'' NBC's new ``Carol & Company,'' starring Carol Burnett, has shown ratings promise. It has won its time period in all three of its Saturday broadcasts to date.

DOC.HEAD: Rocky Road to Parliament for Leader of Freedom Fighters in 1956
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The long road to a seat in a freely elected Hungarian Parliament was rutted with prison, the threat of the gallows and self-exile for Bela Kiraly, who led freedom fighters against Soviet tanks in 1956. For the 78-year-old Kiraly, victory at the polls on April 8 capped a perilous journey that saw him change continents and professions three times. The ramrod career army officer fled after the failed 1956 revolt and began a new life in the United States as a history professor. He returned last year to help cement democracy in his homeland and plans to sell his home in Highland Lakes, N.J. ``My life moves like a sinus curve _ up and down,'' said a reflective Kiraly. ``The old soldier never dies, he just fades away, but he always has a last hurrah. This is my last hurrah.'' While he had been prepared to live out his life in the United States, Kiraly always considered himself a Hungarian. ``The fact that I came back and among the circumstances that I did somehow just makes my whole justified,'' Kiraly said. ``The predominant sentiment in my heart is, `I'm proud to be Hungarian.''' Thirty-four years ago, when Kiraly slipped into Austria, the revolution had failed and the Soviets were hot on his trail. There was no thought of returning. The former brigadier general had spent years on death row for treason before Communist leaders paroled him and others as part of a futile attempt to defuse growing popular outrage. He joined the revolt shortly after it broke out Oct. 23, 1956. As the head of the National Guard of freedom fighters, Kiraly was high on the list of men wanted by the post-revolutionary Hungarian government. Staying would have meant the gallows, as it did for Premier Imre Nagy, Defense Minister Pal Maleter and other leaders of the uprising. Their execution in 1958 shocked the Western world. Kiraly then made a vow that seemed to make his exile permanent. ``I set the precondition not to cross the frontier of this state until and unless my friends, who became martyrs, received the proper acknowledgement and honor in Hungary.'' Kiraly was invited back to Hungary on June 17 to speak at a reburial ceremony for his friends. The Hungarian Communist leadership had been the only one in Eastern Europe to reject its monopoly on power without massive popular pressure. In the process, it embraced the 1956 revolution as legitimate, rehabilitated the leaders of the uprising and moved their remains from weed-rankled unmarked plots to proper graves. As ranking Communist officials stood with heads bowed, Kiraly invoked Hungary's ``glorious day.'' Hundreds of thousands listened to his words, some sobbing in catharsis. For Kiraly, it ranked as one of the most memorable moments in a remarkable life, along with his election to Parliament in his home town of Kaposvar, about 90 miles southwest of Budapest. But not all the good times were in Hungary. Kiraly said he felt an near-unparalled sense of accomplishment in 1964 when the students of the City University of New York elected him teacher of the year. He speaks glowingly of the United States. ``It was a very generous land. I never felt any sense of confrontation there between being a decent American citizen and remaining a Hungarian,'' he said. ``America will never be a closed book for me.'' Kiraly's most vivid memories are still firmly rooted in 1956 Hungary, and his face assumes a faraway look as he talks about the heady days of near victory and the despair of defeat and self-exile. ``Nothing compares to the election as head of the freedom fighter forces,'' he said. ``And those days will remain indelibly etched in my mind forever.''

DOC.HEAD: Ralph David Abernathy, King's Chief Lieutenant, Dead at 64
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, who shared 17 jail cells with Martin Luther King Jr., marched with him in Selma, cradled his bloody head in Memphis and broke with his followers over a tell-all memoir, is dead at 64. Abernathy died Tuesday at Crawford Long Hospital while being prepared for a lung scan to locate a suspected blood clot, hospital spokeswoman Tisha Burland said. The cause of death was not immediately known. As King's chief lieutenant, Abernathy was at his side at almost every key battle of the civil rights movement of the 1950s and '60s and took his place as leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference after King's 1968 assassination. But the fame and adulation enjoyed by King never quite extended to Abernathy. In a 1986 interview, he lamented that during a visit to a school in Connecticut, ``not a single student knew who I was.'' In 1989 he was reviled as a traitor to the cause for writing about King's alleged marital infidelity in his autobiography, ``And The Walls Came Tumbling Down.'' Abernathy wrote that King spent time with two women and had a violent argument with one in the 24 hours before his assassination. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, was among those who praised Abernathy on Tuesday. She issued a statement from Zimbabwe, where she was attending celebrations of that country's 10th anniversary of independence. ``When our home was bombed and our lives were threatened, he was there,'' she said. ``His strength as a tactician and a counselor to Martin during our struggle has been eloquently recorded in Martin's own writings and in the annals of the American civil rights movement.'' King's son, Fulton County Commissioner Martin Luther King III, called Abernathy's death ``a very tragic loss to our nation.'' President Bush hailed Abernathy as ``a great leader in the struggle for civil rights for all Americans and a tireless campaigner for justice.'' The Rev. Joseph Lowery, who succeeded Abernathy as president of the SCLC, described Abernathy on Tuesday as ``a faithful servant of the cause of liberty and justice.'' Abernathy had been in the hospital since March 23 for treatment of a sodium deficiency and had suffered strokes in 1983 and 1986. At the time of his death he was pastor of West Hunter Street Baptist Church. Born in Linden, Ala., the son of a farmer, Abernathy joined with King in 1955 to lead the Montgomery, Ala., bus boycott that lifted King to national fame. For the next 13 years King and Abernathy were virtually inseparable. ``We were known as the civil rights twins,'' Abernathy once recalled. ``We always sought to complement each other. I never tried to be a copy of him and he never tried to be a copy of me.'' They co-founded the SCLC in 1957, and Abernathy was in a nearby cell when King wrote his famous ``Letter from the Birmingham Jail'' in 1963, setting forth the goals of their movement. Later that year, Abernathy was at King's side for the ``I Have a Dream'' speech that climaxed the march on Washington, the biggest demonstration in U.S. history. He was in Sweden when King received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1964, and the two led the Selma-to-Montgomery march for voting rights in 1965. And on April 4, 1968, in Memphis, Tenn., Abernathy took King's bloody head in his hands moments after an assassin's bullet cut him down. But in his autobiography, Abernathy said he felt other King aides saw him as ``no more than an appendage to Martin ... who never played an important role.'' King had directed that Abernathy succeed him at the SCLC despite Abernathy's reluctance. Abernathy led the 1968 Poor People's Campaign that brought thousands to Washington. But the SCLC lost its leadership role in the civil rights movement as key aides such as Andrew Young and Jesse Jackson left to follow their own paths. Abernathy stepped down from the SCLC leadership in 1977 and slipped back into King's shadow while other black leaders stepped to the fore. In 1986 he was excluded from a planning group for the first Martin Luther King Jr. national holiday. After publication of his autobiography, Abernathy was criticized in a statement signed by 28 prominent blacks, including Young, Jackson, Lowery and Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. His alma mater, Alabama State University, rescinded its decision to name a dormitory after Abernathy. His friend Hosea Williams branded Abernathy a ``Judas.'' On Tuesday, Williams called him ``one of the truest human rights leaders America has ever produced.'' ``By giving unselfish leadership and through suffering and sacrificing, Dr. Abernathy has earned the second most important place in history,'' Williams said. Abernathy's survivor's include his wife, Juanita; two sons, Kwame and state Rep. Ralph David Abernathy III; and two daughters, Juandalynn and Donzaleigh. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: `Roseanne' Finishes First in Nielsen Week and Season
LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: ``Roseanne'' was the No. 1 show last week and for the 1989-90 season, dethroning ``The Cosby Show'' after a four-year reign. The comedy starring Roseanne Barr as a wisecracking mother helped boost ABC into a first-place tie with NBC for the week. NBC still finished as the top-rated network for the fifth straight season, but hits such as ``Roseanne'' and ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' have pushed ABC ever closer to breaking NBC's grip on the No. 1 position. ABC and NBC each received an 11.9 average for the week ended April 15. CBS lagged with an 11. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. For the season, NBC was No. 1 with a 14.6 average, followed by ABC with 12.9 and CBS with 12.2, according NBC figures. ``Roseanne'' had a season average 23.4 rating and ``Cosby'' a 23.1, according to figures released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. ``Cosby,'' starring Bill Cosby as a good-natured father, had been No. 1 for four seasons. The season-ending analyses produced an odd debate over whether ``Roseanne'' was the season's top-rated show. David Poltrack, a research expert at CBS, denied that ``The Cosby Show'' had been bested by ``Roseanne.'' He included in his ratings average a special Sunday broadcast of ``Roseanne'' that he said had dragged the show's total ratings down. ``Roseanne'' is regularly broadcast Tuesday nights. By his reckoning, the NBC and ABC shows had identical ratings of 23.1. But he said Cosby won with an average 38 percent audience share, compared with a 35 percent average for Roseanne Barr's series. After much hoopla and initial high ratings, ABC's new nighttime soap opera `Twin Peaks'' dropped to 13th place last week with a 16.2 average after ranking fifth for its two-hour premiere April 8. For the first time in its history, the alternative Fox network landed three programs in the top 30. ``The Simpsons'' placed 16th; ``Married ... With Children'' ranked 18th, and the debut of ``In Living Color,'' a black version of ``Saturday Night Live,'' was 29th. All three shows air on Sunday night. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 22.1; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 19.7; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 18.8; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 18.6; ``Coach,'' ABC, 17.8; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 17.7; ``Cheers'' special repeat, NBC, 17.6; ``Golden Girls,'' NBC, 17.3; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 17.2; and ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 17.1. ABC's ``World News Tonight with Peter Jennings'' held onto the No. 1 network news spot with a 9.8 average. CBS and Dan Rather finished second with 8.6 and NBC's Tom Brokaw was third with 8.3.

DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,249.06, up 787.46 points, or 2.77 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Division Settles with SEC
DOC.TEXT: In a settlement of a federal regulators' allegations, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. has agreed to pay $5.6 million to customers for stock sold in partial tender offers without prior client approval. The New York-based securities firm and a managing director, Michael Dreitlein, agreed to settle _ without admitting or denying wrongdoing _ an administrative action alleging they violated Securities and Exchange Commission anti-fraud and record-keeping rules. The action, announced Tuesday in Washington, was brought by the SEC's New York Regional Office. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette's Pershing Division was making $4.3 million in tender offer profits from the ``unauthorized and undisclosed'' sale of shares from customer accounts between January 1982 and April 1988. A tender offer is an offer to buy a corporation's shares _ often as a means of acquiring the concern _ usually at a premium price.

WASHINGTON (AP) _ A District of Columbia judge has dismissed a lawsuit against Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., alleging that Frank's relationship with a male prostitute constituted a public nuisance. The suit alleged that Frank was aware his Capitol Hill apartment was being used by Stephen Gobie for his prostitution business. Superior Court Judge Harold Cushenberry dismissed the suit on the grounds that the plaintiffs had no right to bring it and that any alleged nuisance was clearly not continuing. The one-page decision, dated April 10, was released by Frank's office Tuesday as Frank, in Boston, was announcing his candidacy for a sixth term. The suit was filed two ministers of Washington churches and financially backed by the Conservative Caucus, which has long opposed many of Frank's liberal views. In his one-page order, Cushenberry wrote that he ``concluded that an ongoing statutory violation is required'' to seek an injunction against Frank blocking the alleged nuisance and that the plaintiffs ``have failed to allege the `special damage' that must be pleaded in order for a private party to prosecute a public nuisance claim.''
DOC.HEAD: Maker of ``Boo Pumpkin'' Recalls Potentially Hazardous Toy
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturer of a Halloween toy cited for potential hazards by a consumer group is recalling the novelty items. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Tuesday that Rhode Island-based Easy Aces, Inc. recalled 40,000 of its ``Boo Pumpkin'' toys because parts can break off ``and pose a fatal choking hazard to yung children.'' The two-inch, pumpkin-shaped toys were sold nationwide between August and November 1989. When the pumpkin is squeezed a latex balloon shaped like a ghost pops out and a squeaker sounds. Consumers should return the toys to the stores where purchased for a full refund, the commission said.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Expected to Go Private Under New City Council
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Gavriil is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Forces bent on ending Moscow's reign as the capital of communism have taken over the city council and want to start by removing the giant bust of Lenin from their meeting hall. There's certain to be a fight over whether the plaster bust will stay or go, and some wonder if, with all the procedural wrangling, the newly elected council's majority will be able to carry out any of its goals. Members did agree on one thing Tuesday: to remove the fancy sturgeon from the buffet at the House of Political Enlightenment, where their sessions are held. The Russian delicacy is unavailable to the ordinary consumer, and deputies decided it would be unsuitable to feast on it themselves. The key figure in the economic revolution brewing in this city of 9 million is Gavriil Popov, an outspoken economist and lawmaker whom the council was expected to elect mayor today. Popov, rotund and steely haired, has pushed for free-market reforms to replace central planning. He was always in the minority, until the Democratic Russia bloc took control of more than 60 percent of the 495 council seats in March balloting. ``We'll be trying to bring in a program of the privatization of the economy,'' said Lev Balashov, a member of the bloc. Popov refused to be interviewed during a break in Tuesday's session, but his bloc's plans are laid out in Kommersant, a new business newspaper with a capitalistic slant. It said that under Popov's administration Moscow's reforms would far outpace the country as a whole, and the city would ``become a testing zone for economic reform'' nationwide. The newspaper said the Democratic Russia bloc wants changes that would create a virtual free market in agricultural produce and remove private businesses known as cooperatives from a tangle of regulations. It also wants incentives to attract foreign capital, including easing rules on long-term leasing of buildings and allowing firms to pay in part with services to ease city problems. There has been no Kremlin reaction to the proposals. The city is largely independent when it comes to funding. Radicals are banking on being able to do more to change the economy, however. They say President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who began instituting reform after coming to power in 1985, increasingly supports a market economy. Moscow clearly needs help, as Pravda reported Tuesday: ``Public transport works badly, the housing program is on the point of breaking down, the health system is in a depressing state, the list of food and goods shortages is lengthening, the ecology is getting worse, financial prospects are unclear and the crime rate is growing.'' But the new city council's first session, which began Monday, raised doubts about how effective it would be. Legislators bogged down for hours in procedural wrangles typical of Soviet bloc parliaments. ``Most of these people are activists,'' said Boris Kagarlitsky, a sociologist and member of the Democratic Russia bloc. ``They can't tell the difference between a public rally and a council session.'' With such inefficiency, ``the prospect for Moscow is a disaster,'' Kagarlitsky said. ``There are two possible outcomes _ either chaos or catastrophe within six months. ``They'll have problems with electricity, with food shortages, and probably the city can go bankrupt.'' Members of Moskva, or Moscow bloc, which includes 95 council deputies who basically follow the Communist Party line, also predict that the city is doomed under the radicals. Vladimir Gruzdev of Moskva said many feared the city would return to ``early, uncontrolled capitalism,'' and lose the social guarantees of communism. Members of Democratic Russia and Moskva disagree on just about everything, and Moskva deputies have repeatedly walked out of the hall in protest. However, they have agreed _ for now _ to leave the bust of Lenin scowling over the proceedings. Balashov said he was sure it would be gone by this time next year.

DOC.HEAD: Valley's Suspicion of Church Turns to Anger After Fuel Spill
DOC.TEXT: Art Wilmer and his family lived in a quiet mountain cabin near Yellowstone National Park _ until a 750-person bomb shelter was erected nearby. ``This winter we'd go out in the middle of the night and hear the roar of the diesel engines,'' he said Tuesday. ``It's like living next to an industrial park.'' The engines belonged to the Church Universal and Triumphant, a religious group building a giant, underground fallout-shelter complex in a high mountain meadow north of Gardiner to prepare for the possibility of global catastrophe. Residents of the Yellowstone gateway community, ringed by 10,000-foot mountain peaks, have eyed the church with curiosity and suspicion since it bought a 12,500-acre ranch from the late millionaire publisher Malcolm Forbes in 1981. That suspicion has turned to anger with construction of the church's complex and last week's news that more than 30,000 gallons of gasoline and diesel fuel have leaked from underground tanks near the fallout shelter. ``People are getting tired of what the church has been doing,'' said Wayne Hoppe, who lives east of Gardiner, which has a permanent population of about 600. ``They're just literally tearing this country to pieces.'' State health officials in Helena said Tuesday they would seek a court order stopping construction of the church complex just north of the park. Church spokesman Murray Steinman responded, ``We believe that we've done everything that we were asked by the state to do and we will continue to do it. Our essential message is we're going to cooperate, cooperate, cooperate.'' After buying the Forbes ranch, church officials said they had no plans for extensive development. The church has since bought 18,000 more acres, moved its headquarters here from Southern California and sponsored several housing developments. Hundreds of followers have moved into the area, and many have built fallout shelters at housing developments near Emigrant, a ranching community 30 miles north of Gardiner. The church is led by Elizabeth Clare Prophet, who claims she receives and passes on to members messages from a group of souls known as the Ascended Masters. She warned her followers that March and April would be dangerous times. Gardiner residents accused the church of lying about its development plans, which many see as a threat to the environment. ``Their religion doesn't matter; they can howl at the moon for all I care,'' said Bill Hoppe, Wayne Hoppe's son and an outfitter. ``I'm not against them living in Park County. But, by God, they've got to be truthful. They haven't said one truthful thing for nine years.'' Steinman said church officials have ``communicated what we were doing when we knew what we were doing. I don't want (residents) to get the idea that we don't care.'' Wilmer said he and his family recently moved from their cabin into Gardiner because of constant traffic on the narrow, twisting dirt road leading to the fallout shelter. ``We just decided, `Hey, this is too much stress,' so we moved out,'' he said. ``It was like a frenzy. My wife almost had a head-on with some big trucks.'' Hoppe and others also accused the state of failing to aggressively regulate church developments. ``I think the church is laughing at the people of Montana and the people of Park County and our governor,'' he said. Local officials estimate 2,000 to 3,000 church members live in the valley. ``A lot of people used to say, `Hey, we're doing our thing, let them do theirs,''' Wilmer said. ``Now, they're realizing that exercising its freedom is going to take away ours.''

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Policeman Hospitalized After Reported Suicide Attempt
DOC.TEXT: A suspended Hispanic policeman convicted of manslaughter in the deaths of two black men was listed in stable condition today after a reported suicide attempt. William Lozano, 30, was rushed to Coral Reef Hospital on Tuesday night, said hospital President Kenneth Sample. Hospital officials refused to give further details beyond the condition officer's condition. The emergency call came in to police as an attempted suicide, but it was unclear what was wrong with Lozano, Metro-Dade police spokeswoman Myriam Royle said. Police and rescue units who went to his home found him awake, she said. Lozano in January 1989 fatally shot an unarmed motorcyclist fleeing from police. The biker's passenger died in the resulting crash, and the deaths touched off three days of rioting in Miami's black neighborhoods. The Miami police officer testified he thought the motorcyclist was trying to run him down. Lozano was convicted and sentenced in January to seven years in prison but is free on bail while on appeal. The officer's mother; older brother, also a Miami police officer; and former partner were at the hospital, but the family refused to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Surges, Dollar Rises Marginally
DOC.TEXT: Share prices soared on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday, while the dollar rose marginally against the yen. The dollar ended trading at 159.87 yen, up 0.04 yen from Tuesday's close of 159.83 yen. It opened higher at 160.13 yen and ranged between 159.80 yen and 160.18 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 787.46 points, or 2.77 percent, ending the day at 29,249.06 in the market's ninth-largest single-day increase. The Nikkei had slipped a marginal 1.58 points on Tuesday. Traders said the index surged in the afternoon because many market players shared the view that both stock prices and the yen had bottomed out. ``As the yen weakened below the 160-yen level, which many investors had feared, they felt the market had gotten over one negative element and started buying,'' said Takahiro Kishishita, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co. As long as the yen stays around 160, the stock market will remain stable, Kishishita said. Currency dealers said the dollar's strength followed its upswing in New York Tuesday. The rise was spurred by the release of data showing continued strength in the U.S. economy, including a 0.7 percent rise in industrial production in March, they said. Expectations that February trade figures due out later Wednesday in Washington would show a dramatic improvement over January's $9.3 billion deficit also supported the dollar, dealers said. ``Many investors have been buying the dollar based on an expectation of smaller U.S. trade deficit,'' said Koichiro Amaya, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. But Amaya said the dollar will continue to move narrowly around the 160-yen level because some investors, who have already overbought the dollar, are selling the U.S. currency whenever it nears 160.20 yen. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 85.76 points late in the morning from Tuesday's 85.90-point finish. That boosted the yield to 7.415 percent from 7.385 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Claim to Find Gene Linked to Alcoholism
DOC.TEXT: A claim by scientists to have found a gene that may make people prone to alcoholism should be regarded with extreme caution, says a leading researcher. Dr. Henry Begleiter of the State University of New York Health Science Center said such research is usually done on living members of the same family, not cadavers, as was done in the study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``I would be _ at the very, very least _ extremely cautious ... to report that the gene had been identified,'' said Begleiter, who is studying 800 families in the nation's largest research project on the role of heredity in alcoholism. In the new study, scientists reported finding a particular gene on a chromosome previously linked with alcoholism to be far more common in alcoholics than non-alcoholics. If verified, the finding would represent the first specific identification of a genetic root for alcoholism and would give added weight to the argument that alcoholism is a disease and not a moral weakness. Alcoholism afflicts about 18 million Americans and tends to run in families. Environment also has been implicated as a contributing factor. Scientists exploring possible genetic factors have named three of the body's 46 chromosomes as possibly playing a role. But no one previously isolated one of the 100,000 genes on those chromosomes as likely culprits. The gene pinpointed in the new study has two forms, each of which governs formation of a nerve cell called the dopamine D2 receptor, believed to play a key role in experiencing pleasure. The researchers looked at both forms of the gene _ the ``A-1 allele'' and the ``A-2 allele'' _ in brain tissue from the cadavers of 70 subjects, 35 alcoholics and 35 non-alcoholics. ``We found a very high association of the A-1 allele with alcoholism and a very high association of the A-2 allele with non-alcoholism,'' said Dr. Ernest P. Noble, the study's co-leader and director of the Alcohol Research Center at the University of California, Los Angeles. The A-1 allele was present in 69 percent of the alcoholics and in 20 percent of non-alcoholics, the researchers reported. Such a high correlation was surprising, given that alcoholism comes in a number of forms and is almost certain to have a number of causes, they said. ``We really can't say that indeed we found the alcholism gene per se,'' said Kenneth Blum, the study's co-leader and chief of the Addictive Diseases division in the Department of Pharmacology at the University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio. But, he added in an interview Tuesday, ``We think that in the age-old question of nature vs. nurture, this finding has added to the nature side, to the disease concept, rather than (to the concept that alcoholism) is just moral weakness or willful misconduct.'' Scientists at the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, of which Noble is former director, wrote in an accompanying editorial that the study is ``provocative and promising but must be regarded with caution.'' Reasons for caution include a lack of complete information on the subjects' medical histories and uncertainty over whether genetic differences between the groups are linked to traits unrelated to alcoholism, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Peyote-Eaters Say Court Ruling Won't Halt Age-Old Ritual
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `We have ...' to CORRECT northwestern to Western.
DOC.TEXT: American Indian peyote-eaters say ritual use of the psychedelic cactus is unlikely to stop despite a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that religious beliefs are no excuse for using illegal drugs. The court Tuesday upheld the decision of Oregon officials who denied unemployment benefits to two drug counselors fired for eating peyote as part of their religious practices. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the court's 6-3 majority, said it ``would be courting anarchy'' to let a few do what is illegal for everyone else. Dissenting justices said the ruling permits religious oppression of Indians, a view supported by American Indian spiritual leaders. ``We have been doing this all these years before the Constitution was here. I don't see why we can't continue,'' said Emerson Jackson, president of the Native American Church of North America. The umbrella group claims at least 250,000 members belonging to 70 church chapters that practice the peyote ritual in 23 Western states. The Oregon drug counselors, Galen W. Black and Alfred C. Smith, were fired after breaking a policy of ADAPT, the non-profit rehabilitation organization they worked for in Douglas County, Ore., by eating small amounts of peyote as part of a Native American Church sacrament. Smith is an American Indian; Black is not, but belongs to the church. The two were fired in 1983-84 and denied unemployment benefits. They did not use peyote on the job. Oregon officials see the case as a drug-abuse issue. ``We have always insisted the state is not required to pay people for using illegal substances no matter what their religious beliefs might be,'' said Oregon Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer. ``The court said our law does not discriminate against religions.'' But defenders of peyote rituals see the case as a clash of cultures. ``The Native American Church is the most persecuted bona fide religion in the United States,'' said Steven Moore, attorney for the Native American Rights Fund in Boulder, Colo. ``The irony is that it's one of the first. It's been here for 10,000 years.'' The small, button-shaped cactus contains mescaline, a mild hallucinogen. It grows mainly in the deserts of Mexico and southern Texas. Archaelogical evidence indicates the plant was used by Indians 10,000 years ago, said Omer Stewart, a retired University of Colorado anthropologist and author of the book ``Peyote Religion.'' Today, the psychedelic cactus is dried into chewy strips, ground into powder or made into a bitter tea. It's not likely to attract a wide following of casual users, said Stewart, who has studied the ritual use of peyote since 1937. Jackson, a Navajo ``peyote priest'' from Window Rock, Ariz., calls the peyote-induced hallucinations ``teachings'' from the Holy Spirit. He likens peyote to the sacramental wine used in Roman Catholic communion, ``except that alcohol is habit-forming and peyote is not.'' He travels around the West as a ``road man,'' administering peyote in fireside rituals of chanting and drumming that last all night. The rituals build cultural ties and reduce the alcoholism that plagues Indian reservations, said Ralph Metzner, academic vice president of the California Institute of Integral Studies in San Francisco and author of ``The Psychedelic Experience.'' Peyote also serves healing and psychotherapeutic roles, Metzner said. ``In our more segmented approach, we have doctors, counselors and priests. They have peyote.'' Congress repeatedly rejected attempts to ban the ritual use of peyote. Jackson is confident that peyote use will continue. His concern for now is finding enough peyote, which the church buys in Texas from dealers regulated by state and federal governments. ``We're getting more members,'' Jackson said, ``and the supplies are going down.''

DOC.SECOND: PM-Christian Science Trial, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0411,0250
DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Ordered Open in Trial of Christian Science Couple
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with jury selection ordered opened; PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Prosecutors argued ...'
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts' Supreme Court overruled a judge and ordered jury selection open to the public today in the case of a Christian Science couple charged with manslaughter for not seeking medical care for their son. Superior Court Judge Sandra Hamlin on Tuesday had ordered jury selection closed on the grounds publicity would have a ``chilling effect'' on prospective jurors. But Supreme Court Associate Justice Neil L. Lynch overruled him on a challenge by The Boston Globe. David and Ginger Twitchell are charged with manslaughter for relying on faith instead of medicine to heal their 2{-year-old son, Robyn, who died in 1986 of a bowel obstruction. Prosecutors argued that the child's life could have been saved if he had received conventional medical treatment. Defense attorney Rikki Klieman contended that the Twitchells, far from acting recklessly, sought the only real cure dictated by their beliefs. Founded in 1879 by Mary Baker Eddy, the Church of Christ, Science, believes that disease, like sin, can be healed by spiritual means alone. The case is being closely watched by the church, which contends its doctrine is under attack. The U.S. Supreme Court typically has refused to hear such cases, and there has been little consensus in similar cases heard around the country.

DOC.HEAD: Chilly in Midwest, Windy in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Freezing cold gripped the Midwest today and strong gusts whistled through the Northeast. Much of the rest of the nation enjoyed fair weather. A low of 28 was reported today in Detroit and 18 in snow-swept Sault Ste. Marie, Mich. Temperatures also dropped to freezing in Chicago and Cleveland. Strong winds buffeted the Northeast from Boston to Buffalo, N.Y. On Tuesday night, winds to 75 mph gusted through Virginia. Today's forecast called for showers from northeastern Nevada to Montana, while showers changing to thunderstorms are expected in a crescent from Arizona to Texas. A surge of cold dipped into western portions of the central Atlantic states and northern portions of the western Gulf of Mexico states late Tuesday. Frost and freezing temperature warnings were posted in Indiana, Illinois and Missouri. The high temperature in the Lower 48 states Tuesday was 92 degrees at Laredo, Texas.
