DOC.HEAD: Contras Tone Down Demands After Meeting with Chamorro
LaserPhoto TEG6
DOC.TEXT: Contra rebel leaders have softened demands the Sandinista army be dismantled before they disband, but it remains unclear whether agreement can be reached by the time the new government takes office. A top aide to President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro said after talks late Tuesday involving the Contras and the Sandinistas that the possibility of Nicaraguans finally living in peace is ``enormous.'' The Sandinistas, defeated at the polls in February, had predicted a fresh outbreak of fighting unless the thousands of Contra fighters who have since flooded into the country from Honduras lay down their arms. Sandinista and UNO negotiators said they expected to sign a cease-fire agreement with the Contras today. Contra negotiators did not comment after leaving the talks, which focused on who should hold arms when her United National Opposition coalition (UNO) takes office a week from today. The rebel delegation arrived for talks Tuesday saying the Contras would not lay down their arms until the military _ built and dominated by the Sandinistas during their decade in power _ is dismantled and replaced by a police force. The Contras have said Nicaragua should follow the example of Costa Rica, a stable democracy that dismantled its army in 1948. But after the 6{-hour meeting, the rebel delegation appeared flexible. Chief Contra negotiator Oscar Sovalbarro said demands that the Sandinistas disarm ``are aspects that must be negotiated.'' Maj. Gen. Joaquin Cuadra, deputy defense minister and chief of staff of the Sandinista army, said that ``with political will,'' the Contras could be dismantled by the time Mrs. Chamorro takes office. But UNO negotiator Leopoldo Navarro said the participants would have to be flexible about the April 25 deadline demanded by the Sandinistas. Early in the day, the Sandinista press had expressed concern that a new round of war could break out. It quoted the general secretary of the Sandinista Labor Federation as saying Sandinista workers would seize ``strategic points'' in Managua if the Contras refuse to disarm. The union claims 100,000 members. One pro-Sandinista daily, El Nuevo Diario, said in a front-page headline: ``Either the Contras Demobilize before the 25th or a General Strike Explodes.'' But after the meeting Antonio Lacayo, Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and a leading aide, struck an optimistic tone: ``There are enormous possibilities of assuring peace in Nicaragua.'' The negotiations were the first involving UNO, the Contras and the Sandinistas since Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition defeated the Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections. Mrs. Chamorro will take office for six years and her administration is counting on a peaceful Nicaragua to deliver on her key campaign promise of reviving the economy. Under a protocol agreement signed by UNO and the administration of outgoing President Daniel Ortega, Mrs. Chamorro pledged to respect the army's ``professionalism'' but said officers would be barred from serving as political party leaders, as is now the case. Both Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro have called on the Contras to disband. The Contras and UNO signed an agreement on March 23 for the Contras to disarm but set no firm date. A UNO spokesman, Luis Sanchez, said the Contra demand to cull the army of Sandinista officers had not been discussed Tuesday and there were no plans to take up the issue. La Prensa, the newspaper owned by Mrs. Chamorro's family, reported Tuesday that Bernard Aronson, the assistant U.S. secretary of state for the region, was expected to visit Thursday for talks with the Sandinistas and UNO. Washington backed the Contras in their nine-year war with the Sandinistas but now supports Mrs. Chamorro's call for their dissolution.

DOC.HEAD: Bottling Compay Reportedly Will Pay $67.5 Million in Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: A bottling company has agreed to pay $67.5 million to the families of 15 students killed when their school bus was knocked into a murky, water-filled pit by a Coca-Cola truck, according to a published report. The crash Sept. 21 in the southern Texas town of Alton killed 21 students in Texas' worst school bus accident. Valley Coca-Cola Bottling Co. has agreed to pay $4.5 million for each of 15 deaths, the McAllen Monitor reported Tuesday. An unidentified lawyer told the newspaper, ``We have an agreement in principle. It's just a matter of taking this before a court for approval and I don't see a problem with that.'' Ramon Garcia and David Hockema, lawyers for several victims' families, refused to discuss the negotiations. The soft drink company agreed two months ago to pay $1.5 million to the family of one of the dead, the only wrongful-death settlement completed so far. Of the 60 students injured, three cases have been settled, each for $250,000.

DOC.HEAD: Chippewa Spearfishers Met By Protests; One Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Chippewas exercising their rights under 19th century treaties to spear fish off the reservation were jeered by hundreds of protesters when they took to their boats for the first time this season. One arrest was reported Tuesday night, when the tribe's Lac du Flambeau band, the most avid spearfishers, were met by opponents at numerous lakes and reservoirs as in years past. Some protesters blew whistles at the spearfishers. ``It's not as bad as last year, but it's still bad,'' said Matt Valliere, a member of the Lac du Flambeau, one of six Chippewa bands. The arrest came at Lake Nokomis, where 500 people, mostly protesters, gathered. Observers said a man, who was not immediately identified, was taken into custody while arguing with spearfishing supporters. To the south, about 300 people gathered at Big Eau Pleine Reservoir near Mosinee. Again, the crowd was mostly opposed to the annual spring off-reservation spearfishing outings during the spawning season. The Lac du Flambeau spearfish with battery-powered spotlights mounted on boats. The state's Chippewa bands have the right to spear fish off the reservation in northern Wisconsin under treaties that ceded the northern third of the state to the U.S. government. Since 1983, federal courts have upheld the treaties. Non-Indians argue that spearing during spawning depletes game fish from lakes. Opponents also contend the treaties give Indians unequal rights. One protester at the Big Eau Pleine Reservoir questioned the Chippewa claim that the fish are used to feed their families. ``Who do you sell them to? What is the going rate right now?'' asked Candy Radant of Wausau, who called Indian treaties ``garbage.'' The six Chippewa bands are eligible to spear about 41,000 walleye this spring in a season that runs into early May. Last year, non-Indian rod-and-reel anglers took more than 600,000 walleye from Wisconsin lakes. The St. Croix Chippewa band opened the 1990 spearfishing season April 10. The Mole Lake followed a few days later. The Lac Court Oreilles and Bad River planned to start spearfishing by Wednesday night. Attorney General Donald Hanaway spent nearly two hours at the Lake Nokomis boat landing, where protesters blew referee-style whistles. ``I'm really just here to observe,'' Hanaway said. A new law prohibits harassment of anyone exercising rights to fish and hunt. More than 200 protesters were arrested during demonstrations last year.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``When our home was bombed and our lives were threatened, he was there. His strength as a tactician and a counselor to Martin during our struggle has been eloquently recorded in Martin's own writings and in the annals of the American civil rights movement.'' _ Coretta Scott King, Martin Luther King Jr.'s widow, on the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, who died Tuesday at age 64.

``We could have an epidemic situation in 10 years. Every six months the number of AIDS carriers is doubling.'' _ Dr. S. M. Bhadkamkar, the top health official in Bombay, India, where specialists say about 10,000 prostitutes are believed to be infected with the virus, five times higher than three years ago.

``This court seems to find it difficult to step outside of a white, middle-class mindset.'' _ Jack Trope of the Association on American Indian Affairs, who blamed the Supreme Court for abandoning its role as protector of minorities by permitting states to punish people who use illegal drugs in religious rituals.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Soar, Dollar Creeps Up
DOC.TEXT: Share prices soared on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today on expectations that declines in the stock market and the value of the yen had bottomed out. The dollar closed marginally higher against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 787.46 points, or 2.77 percent, ending the day at 29,249.06. Wednesday's gain was the market's ninth-largest single-day increase. The Nikkei slipped 1.58 points Tuesday. ``When the dollar opened this morning, as feared, above 160 yen, many investors felt that the yen had hit bottom. They thought the market had overcome negative factors,'' said Toshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. The surge in prices picked up in the afternoon afer the dollar fell from the day's high of 160.18 yen to below 160 yen, further reassuring investors, Inoue said. Participants bought a variety of issues, including electronics, steels, shipbuilding and trading houses. A drop in bond yields also helped boost share prices, other traders said. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 86.14 points as of 4 p.m., up from Tuesday's 85.90-point finish. The yield fell to 7.335 percent from Tuesday's close at 7.385 percent. Buying by arbitrageurs trying to take profits out of the price gap between the spot and the futures markets, as well as several rounds of index-linked buying by investment trust firms, also pushed prices higher, traders said. Inoue said many institutional investors, however, remained on the sidelines prior to the release of the U.S. trade figures for February later today in Washington. Trading was thin with first section volume estimated at 450 million shares, up from 423 million shares Tuesday. Since closing at a record high of 38,915.87 at the end of last year, the Nikkei has lost 9,666.81 points, or 24.8 percent. Much of the decline has been attributed to a softening of the yen against the dollar. The dollar has risen 16.47 yen since the Dec. 29, when it closed at 143.40 yen. In currency dealings, the dollar ended at 159.87 yen, up 0.04 yen from Tuesday's close at 159.83 yen. It opened higher at 160.13 yen and ranged between 159.80 yen and 160.18 yen. After opening higher following its overnight upswing in New York, the dollar moved narrowly ahead of the announcement of the U.S. trade figures, said Kozo Shinomiya, a Fuji Bank dealer. Participants bought the dollar, anticipating a substantial improvement from January's $9.3 billion deficit, dealers said. ``After opening above 160 yen, which was one psychological barrier, many investors started selling the dollar for profit-taking partly due to a feeling of accomplishment,'' Shinomiya said. He said the dollar mainly fell toward the end of the afternoon session, when selling for profit taking increased. ``Participants were also afraid of dollar-selling market intervention by the Bank of Japan around 160 yen,'' he said. The central bank was not seen intervening in the market today. The bank does not officially comment on its interventions.

DOC.HEAD: Cabbies Make Procession of Fear Past Funeral Home
DOC.TEXT: Scores of taxis made a slow procession past the funeral home where the fifth driver slain in five weeks lay, in a plea by cabbies for more protection. ``We're just trying to be heard by somebody, to do something to stop these killings,'' Luz Rivera, a taxi dispatcher, said of the cabs that snarled traffic Tuesday. ``We're sorry about this, but we need help.'' Five drivers have been slain in the Bronx in five weeks. A wake was held Tuesday at a Manhattan funeral home for the latest victim, Rafael Montes De Oca, 38, who was robbed and shot to death Saturday night at the wheel of his cab. Drivers began the procession outside the office of the latest victim's employer, Seaman Car Services, and cruised slowly to the funeral parlor three miles away. No arrests have been made in the killings, which have prompted dozens of drivers to quit their night-shift jobs in fear. Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli disputed speculation by other investigators that three of the slayings were the work of a serial killer.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher Allegedly Told Pupils to Jump Classmate
DOC.TEXT: A teacher has been suspended without pay while authorities investigate allegations she had her students beat up a 12-year-old classmate because ``if I hit him, I'll go to jail.'' The boy's guardian and aunt, Vershunda Polley, said he was jumped at Ronald McNair Elementary School last week after disrupting class and accidentally punching the teacher in the eye in a scuffle the day before. The boy told The Dallas Morning News that upon arriving at school he found a lock had been removed from his desk and his spiral notebook torn up. Then, the boy said, ``the whole class surrounded me and jumped on me.'' The boy said he crouched while classmates punched and kicked him. He was not injured, he said. Two students said teacher Pamela Lewis stood nearby and held the door shut for about five minutes, breaking up the attack when another adult entered the room. The newspaper reported today that Ms. Lewis, 42, could not be reached for comment. She has taught at the school for two years. ``My teacher told us that (the boy) was going to pick us out one by one and fight us,'' one girl in the class said. ``She told us to jump him and if we didn't jump in, don't come back into her classroom. ``She told us, `You have to hit him, because I can't. If I hit him, I'll go to jail.''' Ms. Polley, who filed a complaint with police, described her nephew as a ``wild'' fifth-grader. ``After school, three kids came over to apologize,'' Ms. Polley said. ``They said that she told them to get in one good punch or kick. ... The kids were saying, `I didn't want to hurt you.'''

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Michael Todd Friant places no stock in the stories about rude New Yorkers since a limousine driver returned his wallet _ money included _ with only a library card as a clue. The 13-year-old left the wallet in the car last month while in New York with a theater group from Amarillo College. Driver Tom Hagan tried to mail the wallet to the Amarillo Public Library, asking their help in finding the boy. But the envelope containing the wallet mistakenly ended up at the Harrington Cancer Center, probably because the library card says, ``Amarillo Public Library, member of the Harrington Library Consortium.'' The Cancer Center recently contacted Todd, who was surprised to find the $2 he had inside the wallet was returned as well. ``I didn't think anybody in New York City would take the time to send it back,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed In Unrest, ANC Delegation Expected Soon
By BARRY RENFREW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Five blacks died in factional fighting, including three women burned to death in ``necklace'' killings after blazing tires were put around their necks by mobs, police said today. Senior officials of the African National Congress are expected to arrive in South Africa on April 28 to prepare for talks four days later with the government on ending white-minority rule, a newspaper reported today. Police said five people were killed Tuesday in clashes between rival black factions in the eastern province of Natal. Hundreds of people have been killed in Natal in recent months in the fighting. Mobs killed three women in the Port Shepstone area in ritual ``necklace'' killings. Two men were killed in separate incidents. Police did not give any reason for the killings. The Natal fighting pits the ANC-backed United Democratic Front against the conservative Inkatha political movement. The rival groups oppose apartheid, but differ over plans for a future South Africa. Business Day newspaper reported Tuesday that five senior ANC members were expected to arrive April 28 to prepare for talks with the government. The leaders include South African Communist Party chief Joe Slovo and ANC foreign affairs spokesman Thabo Mbeki. The five leaders, based at ANC headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia, would assist ANC leader Nelson Mandela in preparing for talks in Cape Town on clearing the way for full-scale negotiations on sharing power with the black majority, the report said. President F.W. de Klerk said Tuesday that the government will insist in the talks that the ANC renounce violence in its struggle against apartheid. He said the ANC's advocacy of armed struggle would hold back any negotiations on power-sharing between the white minority and the 28 million blacks. ``The ANC's continued commitment to armed struggle, even if it were merely rhetorical, constitutes a further obstacle _ alongside the reality of the violence _ which has to be removed,'' de Klerk said. In a speech to Parliament, De Klerk reiterated his views on the constitutional system he hopes to negotiate with the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups once obstacles to talks are removed. De Klerk said the government will propose black-white power-sharing through a one-man, one-vote system. However, he said other reforms would ensure that white domination will not be replaced with black domination. The president also condemned right-wing white groups, saying they promote ``a psychosis of violence,'' and criticized Andries Treurnicht, leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party. ``The irrevocability of the process which has been initiated and its urgency place an enormous responsibility on the shoulders of every leader in our country,'' de Klerk said. He said political leaders must moderate their statements, ``in the realization that negotiation is a process of debate and agreement, of giving and taking.'' ``If the quest by anyone is for victory before negotiation, negotiation becomes meaningless,'' de Klerk said.

DOC.HEAD: Trading Quiet, Gold Mixed In Anticipation of U.S. Trade Figures
DOC.TEXT: The dollar showed modest gains in quiet trading today as dealers awaited the release later in the day of U.S. trade figures. Gold prices were mixed. ``The market is nearly flat,'' a Milan trader said. ``People have squared off their positions and are sitting tight until the trade figures are release.'' Traders said speculation that the February trade deficit could swing significantly lower than the $9.25 billion deficit reported in January was one factor keeping investors on the sidelines. Some traders said high expectations could pave the way for the dollar to decline after the trade numbers are released. ``Even something around $8 billion won't be so good ... (since) expectations are being raised,'' said a trader in Frankfurt, who added that trading was ``dead'' in advance of the trade data. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.04 yen to a closing 159.87 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 159.70 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6788 West German marks, up from 1.6770 _1.4915 Swiss francs, up from 1.4900 _5.6400 French francs, up from 5.6370 _1.8905 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8885 _1,234.00 Italian lire, up from 1,232.00 _1.1630 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1680 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6345, compared with $1.6340 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $374.90 a troy ounce, up from $374.05 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $374.70. In Zurich, the bid price was $374.90, down from $374.00 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 48 cents to close at a bid $375.87. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.09 a troy ounce from Tuesday's $5.07.

DOC.HEAD: Sniper Report Sends Giants Scurrying for Cover
DOC.TEXT: Police found bullet shells but no gunmen on a hillside overlooking Candlestick Park after reports of snipers sent the San Francisco Giants scrambling to a far corner of the outfield. The Giants stayed in a corner of the ballpark not visible from the hillside Tuesday night until police declared the area safe. The incident occurred before the Giants' game against the Los Angeles Dodgers and delayed afternoon traffic into the ballpark for about 45 minutes. Four witnesses had reported seeing snipers, one wearing a motorcycle helmet, on the hill, police said. Sgt. William Herndon said officers found two empty cases of 9mm shells on the hill but were unable to locate any suspects. Lt. Tony Novello said snipers may have been shooting at two police officers patrolling outside the stadium. ``It's a common occurrence in this part of town. There is a lot of sniping, almost every night,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pan-Africanist Congress Leader Freed Last Year Dies in Car Accident
DOC.TEXT: Japhta Masemola, founder of the military wing of the Pan-Africanist Congress who was freed in October after 27 years in prison, has died in a car accident, his sister said today. He was 58. Masemola was freed along with seven African National Congress leaders in October as a prelude to President F.W. de Klerk's legalization of the two organizations. The groups had been banned since 1960. ``We just couldn't believe it ... to die after getting freed after 27 years in prison. He wanted to do so much,'' said Dorah Maodi, a sister of Masemola who shared a house with him in Atteridgeville township near Pretoria. She said he was driving Tuesday night to Ga-Rankuwa Hospital northwest of Pretoria to get treatment for his foot when the accident happened. He died at the hospital. Masemola was already in prison when he was sentenced to life on July 2, 1963. He was regarded by many blacks as the second-longest-serving political prisoner after ANC deputy president Nelson Mandela, who was freed Feb. 11. Masemola was sentenced for blowing up power lines and smuggling young men out of the country for guerrilla training. He trained as a teacher and joined the ANC Youth League in the early 1950s, supporting Mandela and other league leaders in their attempts to set the ANC on a more confrontational road. But when activists led by the late Robert Sobukwe broke away from the ANC in 1959 over the issues of land ownership, socialism, workers' power and other policies, Masemola joined the new Pan-Africanist Congress. He became PAC leader in Transvaal province. When both organizations were banned the next year, Masemola founded the PAC's military wing, Poqo. It carried out sabotage attacks on government installations before Mandela formed the ANC military wing.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Hearing for Zsa Zsa Gabor's Shelter Work
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor has been ordered to appear at a hearing to decide whether the actress completed work at a women's shelter as part of her sentence for hitting a policeman. A judge ordered the May 1 hearing because the shelter's director failed to document Miss Gabor's 120 hours of community service, Deputy District Attorney Elden Fox said Tuesday. But a shelter staff member who refused to give her name told the Los Angeles Daily News that the director mailed the documentation to Municipal Court Judge Charles G. Rubin on Friday. Vera Davis, executive director of the Lower Income Elderly United Community Assistance Program, has said Miss Gabor worked about 50 hours at the shelter and served the rest through guest appearances and in planning a celebrity auction at her Bel-Air mansion to benefit the shelter. Rubin asked for documentation after Ms. Davis sent him a letter stating Miss Gabor completed her sentence but offered no details, Fox said. The prosecutor had said substituting appearances and the auction was unacceptable. Miss Gabor has said she put in much more than the required 120 hours and plans to continue working to help the shelter. Miss Gabor was convicted Sept. 29 for slapping Officer Paul Kramer during a traffic stop. She also was convicted of driving without a license and having an open container of alcohol in her Rolls-Royce. She was sentenced to four days in jail, but that portion of the sentence is being appealed.

DOC.HEAD: Report: British Government Knew Previously of Big-Gun Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with British government comment. Pickup 5th graf, `Customs seized...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: British government agencies might have allowed the sale of arms components to Iraq before customs agents seized Iraq-bound steel pipes that could be used for a huge gun, a newspaper said today. ``Sources indicated that the Department of Trade and Industry and the Ministry of Defense may have known the military potential of the order, raising the specter of government departments conniving to break Britain's embargo on arms trade with Iraq,'' The Independent newspaper said. The report, based on unidentified British Civil Service sources, also said Customs officers were under intense political pressure by the government not to prosecute the suppliers. ``Government officials want the makers of the steel pipes ... to be protected from court proceedings which could reveal the extent of the government involvement in the deal,'' it said. A senior government source described The Independent report as ``absolute rubbish.'' Government sources acknowledged there were ``some military aspects to all this,'' but they did not elaborate. Customs seized eight forged steel tubes last Thursday at the port of Middlesbrough in northeastern England as they were about to be shipped to Iraq. Officials say the tubes could be used as part of a giant artillery gun to fire shells hundreds of miles. The makers of the tubes, Sheffield Forgemasters, denies this, and Iraq says the pipes were meant for the petrochemical industry. The Financial Times, Britain's leading business daily, reported today that the British and Belgian governments have evidence a Belgian defense company, PRB, was contracted by Iraq to help produce a booster-assisted shell for a long-range artillery gun. PRB is owned by the British munitions company Astra Holdings. The Financial Times said contracts for the suspected gun components and the projectile were coordinated by companies associated with ballistics expert Gerald Bull, a Canadian-born American murdered in Brussels March 22. The company Walter Somers, a subsidiary of Eagle Trust, said Tuesday it was now concerned that hydraulic gear sent to Iraq in October could be used as part of a shock absorber, possibly a hydraulic recoil mechanism, in a huge gun. Eagle Trust chairman David James said: ``Our engineers are now wondering whether they have been misled up the garden path by the Iraqis.'' James said Walter Somers decided to re-examine its contracts with Iraq following Bull's murder. He said Bull and his Brussels-based company, Space Research Corp., acted as agents for various Iraqi orders and were the source of technical data and drawings related to them. Belgian police said Bull, 62, was shot twice in the head and that the gunman used a silencer. The motive was not robbery because $20,000 was found in the victim's pockets, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Burger Chain to Spend $100 Million on Recycled Materials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 8, He said, to fix typo in ``mop.''
DOC.TEXT: When the kids munch a Big Mac sometime later this year, they may be doing it while sitting on a bench made of recycled plastic. The paper bag to carry it home may be made out of an old newspaper. McDonald's Corp., announced Tuesday that it plans to spend $100 million a year, about one-fourth of its construction budget, on recycled materials when building new outlets or renovating existing ones. It dubbed the program McRecycle USA. ``We think there need to be markets created for recycled materials,'' Edward H. Rensi, president of McDonald's USA, said in a telephone interview from Oak Brook, Ill. ``We decided to create a market.'' Rensi said that in addition to seeking out recycled products when building new restaurants, the company plans soon to use recycled newsprint for carryout bags at about 500 of its outlets. If it works, the use of the newsprint will be expanded. ``They're not going to be as white as we necessarily would like, but they're going to be fully serviceable, the printing on them is just fine, and to be able to use ... newsprint is just fantastic,'' Rensi said. He said McDonald's will seek out suppliers of recycled building materials through a toll-free telephone number. The uses of recycled materials are numerous and not expected to cost significantly more, Rensi said. ``We have a lot of opportunities.'' He said some of the possible uses of recycled plastics and other materials are as barriers to keep cars from going onto the curb in parking lots, building insulation, mop buckets, menu boards, chairs, tables, signs and playground equipment. McDonald's builds about 375 new restaurants each year and renovates an additional 1,000 of its 8,500 outlets annually. Earlier this year, McDonald's announced a pilot program in some of its New England outlets that promotes the recycling of polystyrene food containers and other plastics. ``We think (the program) is working very well, but it can work a lot better because we've only got 250 restaurants on the program right now. We hope to add about 25 restaurants a week and get up to 500 very soon,'' Rensi said. Eventually the company hopes to expand the program to all of its restaurants. But Rensi said McDonald's, which serves 22 million people daily worldwide and is one of the largest users of plastic food containers, has no plans to shift away from using plastics, which do not degrade in landfills. A number of communities have begun to consider barring the use of polystyrene containers by fast-food restaurants because of growing concerns about shrinking landfills. Rensi maintained, however, that the polystyrene containers can be recycled, while coated paper used in food packaging often cannot. ``Paper does not do the kinds of things people think it does,'' he said. ``You put it in a landfill and it doesn't biodegrade. Food packaging particularly doesn't biodegrade because it's wrapped in some kind of a compound ... and you can't recycle it. It's cost-prohibitive. ``We'd rather use more plastic than less. And we think ... if public opinion ever catches up to science, consumers are going to applaud us for sticking to it,'' the McDonald's executive added.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Computers Threatened by Virus
DOC.TEXT: Computer viruses are spreading through China's computer networks and could cause severe losses to data bases, the official China Daily said today. The Public Security Ministry has discovered six viruses, including one called ``Jerusalem'' that appeared on Friday, the report said. It said thousands of computers have been infected by an external virus, a program that can reproduce itself indefinitely and either slow down or destroy other programs in a system. The computer center at one Beijing university suspended operations because its 50 terminals were infected. Production at a Beijing chemical factory was slowed for a month when a virus attacked company computers, it said. The ministry said other viruses have appeared with such names as Vienna, Brain, 648, Hemp and Yankee Doodle. It urged a complete check of China's computers and disks and asked people to immediately report any evidence of tampering with computer programs. China, a nation of 1.1 billion, has only about 300,000 computers. Only a few state organizations, such as the police, the military and the State Statistical Bureau, have on-line systems connecting computers. The Public Security Ministry said in November that as many as 10 percent of the computers checked had been affected by viruses. It said the viruses had been contained in imported software.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister-Designate Names Cabinet Ministers
DOC.TEXT: Nepal's prime minister-designate nominated eight cabinet ministers today to form this Himalayan kingdom's first opposition-led government in almost 30 years. Prime Minister-designate K.P. Bhattarai, acting president of the once-outlawed Nepali Congress Party, said he would retain the posts of defense and foreign minister in the new government. Bhattarai said he had sent a list of his nominees to the palace for approval by King Birendra, who on April 8 lifted a nearly 30-year ban on political activity in response to pro-democracy protests. Bhattarai, 65, who spent 14 years in prison for political agitation, said he did not expect the king to block the nomination of any of his nominees. ``It is not a question of his agreement,'' Bhattarai said. ``It is a question of my wanting.'' Bhattarai's cabinet nominees included three Congress Party members, three United Left Front members and two independents. The king wielded almost absolute power until he was forced to make concessions by opposition groups. Earlier this week, Prime Minister Lokendra Bahadur Chand was dismissed after he was besieged in a building by pro-democracy demonstrators. The opposition has said it wants the 44-year-old king to act as the constitutional monarch of a parliamentary democracy, with lawmakers holding the real power. The king will name two of his own nominees for the cabinet on Thursday. Later that day, Bhattarai and his ministers will take their oaths of office. The interim government headed by Bhattarai is expected to remain in power until free general elections can be held. Bhattarai said the vote will be held by April 1991. The pro-democracy movement was led by Bhattarai's centrist Nepali Congress Party and the United Left Front, a coalition of left-wing groups, including the Communist Party. Birendra's father, King Mahendra, banned political parties in 1961 after two years of Western-style party government headed by the Nepali Congress Party. Mahendra dismissed the government, accusing it of corruption and inept administration. Afterward, the country was controlled by a partyless political structure known as the panchayat, or council, with the king as the head of state. The monarch nominated one-fifth of the National Assembly's 140 members, and approved the nominations of others running for election, according to political observers. Nepal, a predominantly Hindu nation of 17 million, is one of the world's poorest nations, with a per capita annual income of $150.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Orphaned by Quake Awarded to Cousin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to ADD that visitation arrangements were made before court hearing.
DOC.TEXT: A judge awarded custody of a 10-month-old boy orphaned by the October earthquake to a cousin, ending months of family squabbling over the child and the $1 million he stands to collect. Superior Court Judge Roderic Duncan on Tuesday placed James Brown IV with his mother's cousin instead of with his maternal grandmother or paternal grandfather, who had accused each other of being unfit to raise the baby. The child will live with Arthur and Tonia Lewis on their 50-acre hog and cattle ranch near Chowchilla, about 120 miles from San Francisco. Duncan said that before the hearing, the grandparents and the Lewises met and agreed to a visitation schedule. The judge last month had awarded temporary custody to the Lewises and also removed the money issue by putting a guardian in charge of the boy's estate. Lewis attended the court hearing and smiled broadly when he signed the custody settlement. But Lewis, cousin to the baby's dead mother, declined to comment, saying only that the boy is ``doing wonderfully.'' The child is scheduled to receive $100,000 in damages for his parents' deaths, but the settlement may reach upwards of $1 million by the time the case is finally resolved. The custody fight started shortly after the Oct. 17 earthquake, which claimed the lives of Jimmy's unmarried parents, 18-year-old Michelle Marie Richard and 20-year-old James Brown III. They were among the 42 people killed in the collapse of the Nimitz Freeway; all told, 68 people died in the 7.1-magnitude quake. Richard's mother, Anita Williams, 35, and Brown's father, James Brown II, 37, sought custody of the infant and the compensation he was getting from the state. Both had been taking turns caring for the child. Ms. Williams is raising her own children on welfare; during court proceedings, she was accused of consorting with drug abusers. And Brown is on parole after going to prison for theft. By Tuesday, two others had filed for custody _ James Brown II's brother and the infant's paternal grandmother. But the three grandparents and the uncle finally agreed to give him up to the Lewises, who also have a 5-year-old daughter and have been unable to conceive other children. ``It's absolutely wonderful,'' said S. Simone Campbell, the child's attorney, who recommended that the Lewises get custody. ``We got the lawyers out of the room and left the families to work it out.'' Campbell said the Lewises, who both work on the farm, were the first choice because they could be with Jimmy all day. ``All of their jobs allow them to constantly be by Jimmy,'' Campbell said. ``He doesn't have to be in day care. It's better than with the other families.'' Afterward, Ms. Williams' attorney, Don Foley, said his client was comfortable with the decision ``but still disappointed. She has made a decent adjustment. He's still part of her life.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested After Hijacking Plane to Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to ADD byline.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A mentally ill man who claimed to have a bomb hijacked an Aeroflot jetliner to Lithuania today, but he was arrested without incident when the aircraft landed in the republic's capital, officials said. The hijacker wanted to help Lithuania by turning over the state-owned Tu-134 jet to the Baltic republic, said Marijonas Misiukonis, Lithuania's internal affairs minister. Moscow recently threatened Lithuania with an economic blockade after the republic delcared independence. No explosives were found after police took the man into custody in the capital of Vilnius, said Valery Akolsin, spokesman for the Soviet Ministry of Civil Aviation. No injuries were reported among the approximately 70 passengers aboard Flight 2443, which was en route from Moscow to Leningrad when the hijacking occurred. American, Japanese and Cuban tourists were among the passengers, Vilnius Radio said. The number of crew members was not immediately known. The radio said the man, identified as Igor Kalugin, claimed to have acquaintances in Lithuania. Kalugin boarded the flight at Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport, then shortly after takeoff told the cabin attendent he was carrying a bomb in a parcel and demanded the plane change course, Akolsin said. ``He called for the stewardess and claimed that he had an explosive device in his lap, and pointed to paper wrapped around an object he was holding tightly against himself,'' Akolsin said. The aircraft's three-man cockpit crew agreed to Kalugin's demands after consulting with authorities on the ground and receiving permission to land in Vilnius, the spokesman said. After the plane landed, it taxied to a remote section of the airport, where Kalugin, still clutching the parcel, was put into a car and driven from the airport, according to a tower dispatcher. The other passengers were taken off the plane and transferred to a special hall for foreigners while authorities searched the plane for explosives. After finding none in a 90-minute search, authorities allowed the plane to resume its journey to Leningrad, Akolsin said. Akolsin said Kalugin was a registered patient at a psychiatric clinic in Moscow. Misiukonis also said he was registered in Moscow as being mentally ill. Vilnius Radio said the man, about 46 or 47 years old, was employed as a fireman at a Moscow theater.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: the schools.
DOC.TEXT: The court, in an opinion by Justice Byron R. White, did not bar judges from ordering tax increases, however. White said the judge could have ordered, in a less specific way, Kansas City school officials ``to levy property taxes at a rate adequate to fund the desegregation remedy, and could have enjoined the operation of state laws that would have prevented (the school district) from exercising this power,'' White said. The court's vote on that point was 5-4. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia dissented, decrying the court's ``casual embrace of taxation imposed by the unelected, life-tenured federal judiciary.''
