DOC.HEAD: Conferees Foresee Terrorism's Ever-Rising Tide
DOC.TEXT: Airports will never be safe from terrorist acts, which are on the rise and getting bloodier, despite new bomb detection systems developed by the federal government, the FBI's chief bomb technician says. ``The numbers just keep going up, and we don't see anything that's going to negate that trend,'' Robert Quigley, the head of the FBI's Bomb Data Center, said Tuesday. ``I don't think airports will ever become a hard target, because they have to have a level of free (public) access anyway.'' There were 4,368 terrorist incidents around the world last year, up from 3,734 in 1988, Quigley said. Bombings rose to 1,930 in 1989 from 1,622 in 1988. The figures came from a private research company. In one of the most notorious incidents, a bomb said to be concealed as a radio felled Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988. All 259 people on board, as well as 11 people on the ground, were killed. ``We don't see it will end ... not in my lifetime,'' said Quigley, who along with a host of other bomb and security experts gathered Tuesday at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to discuss the status of airport safety. Still, Raymond Salazar, the director of civil aviation security for the Federal Aviation Administration, said he thought it was ``definitely possible'' to stem the tide of terrorism. No anti-terrorism policy will ever be 100 percent effective, Salazar said. But terrorists won't win if the civilized world launches a multipronged effort _ based on cooperation among local governments, law enforcement and intelligence _ against them. ``I think it's definitely possible if all those things come into play,'' he said. The arsenal against terrorists now includes automated explosive-detection systems developed by the FAA, Salazar said. He estimated the FAA spent about $60 million over 10 years to develop the systems, which use neutrons _ uncharged atomic particles _ to detect explosives. The systems are already being used in New York City and Miami, and should be deployed in about 40 cities worldwide over the next two years, he said. Critics have called the new systems ``too large, too slow, like trying to stuff an elephant into a horse's stall,'' Salazar said. ``To these critics I say, you have to start somewhere. You can't wait for perfect while you have good available.''

DOC.HEAD: Prague Prosecutor Threatens to Outlaw Communists in Prague
DOC.TEXT: The Prague prosecutor has threatened to outlaw the Communist Party within the city limits just as campaigning is about to begin for Czechoslovakia's first free elections, a newspaper said today. In a letter to the Communist Party's Central Committee, Prosecutor Tomas Sokol drew a parallel between communism and fascism, which is illegal in Czehoslovakia. He set an April 30 deadline for the party to clarify its views. ``As of May 1, the political activity of your party will be judged with a view to committing the criminal act of propagating fascism or similar movements,'' the Svobodne Slovo daily newspaper quoted Sokol as saying. The Justice Ministry had no immediate comment, and a spokesman for President Vaclav Havel also declined comment. The Communist Party said it would make an official comment later. All Communist deputies, about 40 percent of Parliament, reacted by failing to attend a debate on the fate of Interior Minister Richard Sacher, accused of not dealing harshly enough with the disbanded secret police. The accusations were made by the Civic Forum, which led last winter's pro-democracy revolution and now dominates the government. The Communist move forced the debate to be postponed. Sacher heads the People's Party, part of a Christian Democratic coalition that poses some of the toughest opposition to Civic Forum in the June 8 elections. But the Communists, who still claim 1 million party members in a nation of 15.5 million, also pose tough opposition to Civic Forum, and placed second in recent opinion polls. In his letter, Sokol said fascism and communism had in common ``destruction of all democratic rights'' and ``the method of terror and social demagoguery.'' According to Czechoslovak law, propagation of fascism is punishable by up to eight years in jail if committed publicly using the media. ``A deadline of April 30 was set to clarify the true essence of your ideology as well as settling of all administrative matters connected with the liquidation of your exposure in ... Prague,'' the letter said. The Communist daily Rude Pravo today protested publication of the letter in the Czechoslovak media. ``Does this letter ... have any connection with the fact that the elections campaign starts in a couple of days? ... Is this a contribution to the newly formed objective justice, the culture and decency of the campaign,'' the daily said in an editorial.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Wants To Know How Doctor Wanted In Camarena Murder Got To States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead; ADDS 1 graf of background at the end on a Mexican convicted in Camarena case.
DOC.TEXT: Mexico has demanded that Washington explain how U.S. agents seized a Mexican doctor charged in the murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena, following reports that the doctor was kidnapped by bounty hunters. The physician, Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, was delivered to Los Angeles this month to face charges in Camarena's 1985 torture and murder. The Los Angeles Times reported today that Alvarez was kidnapped in an unauthorized operation arranged by officials of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration's office in Los Angeles. Citing unidentified Mexican sources close to the case, it said a bounty of up to $50,000 reportedly was offered to the four kidnappers and two pilots who took Alvarez from Mexico to El Paso, Texas, where he was arrested on April 3. Frank Shults, a DEA spokesman in Washington, refused to comment on how Alvarez arrived in the United States but said the arrest had violated no laws. The Times quoted the Mexican sources as saying American officials told them the kidnapping was carried out without approval from Washington. Mexico's Foreign Ministry said in a statement Tuesday night that Mexican diplomats in Washington would ask the State Department ``about the location and conditions'' under which Alvarez was apprehended. It said Mexico was concerned about reports alleging he ``could have been arrested illegally in Mexico with the participation of U.S. authorities.'' Leftist politicians and newspaper columnists have been calling the case an affront to Mexico's sovereignty for two weeks, but this was the first expression of concern from the Mexican government. On Tuesday, the country's Congress asked for an investigation and U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh told a news conference in Washington that he has asked for a full report on the incident. Thornburgh was to fly to Mexico today to attend a conference on drug enforcement. Alvarez, 42, is one of 19 Mexicans who have been indicted by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles on charges of kidnapping, torturing and killing Camarena, a DEA special agent. Charges against suspected participants in the murders in Guadalajara of Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, have strained U.S.-Mexican relations. U.S. law enforcement officials say the Mexican government failed to respond to their requests to extradite several defendants. Mexican officials say the United States had never requested the extradition of Alvarez or anyone else indicted in the case. A Jan. 31 indictment in Los Angeles contained the latest round of charges in the case. Besides Alvarez, it named Manuel Ibarra Herrera, former director of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police, and Miguel Aldana Ibarra, former head of the Mexican office of Interpol, the international law-enforcement agency. The call in Mexico's Congress for an investigation into case was initiated by leftist parties and then backed by the opposition National Action Party. National Action congressman Jesus Rodriguez del Valle questioned whether Mexican ``federal police or DEA agents were directly involved, and if they received compensation.'' U.S. prosecutors allege that Camarena was abducted by drug traffickers and tortured by Mexican officials about DEA activities in Mexico. Alvarez, a Guadalajara gynecologist, allegedly observed Camarena's torture and administered drugs to revive the American so he could be subjected to more questioning. The Mexican doctor pleaded innocent on April 10, when he was arraigned on the charges in U.S. District Court in Los Angeles. Alvarez's lawyer, Robert Steinberg, said his client had been kidnapped but that he would not raise the abduction as a legal issue because prior rulings in similar cases said, in effect, ``too bad, but they're here.'' Alvarez is to face trial in Los Angeles on May 1 along with four other defendants in the case, including Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros. Matta Ballesteros, a convicted drug trafficker, unsuccessfully challenged his 1988 arrest in Honduras and deportation to the United States. Steinberg said Alvarez was taken from his Guadalajara office on April 2 by four or five men who identified themselves as Mexican federal police and who said Alvarez was under arrest for performing illegal abortions. The group drove north to an unidentified town, where they spent the night. The next day, Alvarez was placed on a plane that flew him across the border to El Paso. He was taken off the plane by a DEA agent and placed under arrest. Rene Verdugo Urquidez was convicted in California in 1988 of taking part in the kidnapping, torture and murder of Camarena and his pilot. He was arrested by Mexican authorities who were paid to turn him over to U.S. agents. He is serving a sentence of 240 years plus life.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Killed in Clashes, Activists Open Fire On Army Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with one more dead; CORRECTS death toll; Pickup 8th, `The gunman...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops fatally shot a Palestinian during clashes in a Gaza Strip refugee camp today, and Arabs fired automatic rifles at an army post in the West Bank, Arab reporters said. Also today, the army said a Palestinian from the West Bank village of Hableh was killed this week when a bomb he was apparently preparing exploded. No one was wounded in the West Bank shooting, which took place in the heart of the crowded shopping district of the city of Nablus, Arab reports said. It was the second rifle attack on an army post in a week. The army had no reports of shooting in Nablus. In the Khan Yunis refugee camp in the occupied Gaza Strip, troops opened fire to disperse sone throwers, hitting 20-year-old Gazi Abed Rabbo Abu Mustafa in the abdomen, an Arab reporter said. Mustafa was taken to nearby Nasser Hospital where he died, the reporter said. The army confirmed Mustafa's death and said he was known by security forces as an inciter and had been wounded in the leg during earlier protests he organized. Mustafa's death brought to 674 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians during the 28-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. At least 207 other Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, mostly on suspicion of collaborating with Israel, and 43 Israels have died in the violence. The victim killed by the explosion on April 16, Yousef Faud Attal, 25, had been wanted by security forces for two years on suspicion of attacking Israelis and Palestinians accused of collaborating with authorities, the army said. The gunmen involved in the Nablus shooting did not mask their faces when they opened fire at the rooftop army post from an alley in the crowded shopping district, an Arab reporter said. The army immediately closed the area, arrested three people during searches and sealed two shops near the army post, the reporter said. PLO chief Yasser Arafat has urged Palestinians not to use guns against Israeli soldiers, arguing it would give Israel an excuse to adopt even harsher measures against the uprising. Radical factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Moslem fundamentalists favor the use of guns. In another development, an Israeli military court Tuesday imposed a five-month suspended sentence on an army officer convicted of brutality in the beating of a 14-year-old Nablus boy, the army spokesman said. Second Lt. Benyamin Yunes pounded the boy's forehead with his helmet and hit him after taking him into custody during a stone-throwing incident, the spokesman said. Trial is continuing for two co-defendants in the case. The daily Maariv said that one of them acknowledged extinguishing cigarettes on the youth.

DOC.HEAD: Former State Democratic Chairman Acquitted in Bribery Case
DOC.TEXT: A former state Democratic Party chairman said he was ``thoroughly vindicated'' by his acquittal on charges that he took part in a scheme to bribe Dominican Republic officials to release drug planes. U.S. District Judge James Kehoe on Tuesday acquitted Alfredo Duran before the defense presented its case. The judge said the government failed to prove the charges against him were a crime under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The case went awry in the past month after one of the defendants was revealed to be a Drug Enforcement Administration informant, and a chief prosecution witness turned out to be an attorney who failed to inform clients he was secretly cooperating with federal investigators. ``I feel that I have been thoroughly vindicated,'' said Duran, 53, who could have faced a maximum five years in prison. ``I was ready to take the stand in my own defense. I am very happy.'' Democratic Party officials at the time of the November indictment called it a political vendetta by U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen, a former Republican state senator whose wife is a Republican congresswoman. Duran's defense attorney, Donald Bierman, played down the political angle in the case. Duran was state party chairman from 1976 to 1980. ``I think that it was a very poorly thought-out prosecution, but I don't personally believe it was political,'' said Bierman. Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for Lehtinen, again denied any political motivation behind Duran's indictment, saying such charges showed a misunderstanding of the grand jury system that brought the indictment.

DOC.HEAD: Canadians Ground Training Flights After Fighter Jet Collision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Canadians grounding training flights; Picks up 13th graf, `Maj. John ...'
DOC.TEXT: Canadian military authorities today grounded F-18 training flights until investigators learn why two fighter jets collided in an accident that renewed German demands for an end to such NATO exercises. Tuesday's crash left one Canadian pilot dead and another injured, and showered parts of Karlsruhe with flaming debris, crushing several cars and damaging buildings in the southwestern city of 285,000 people. West German media said it was a miracle no civilians were killed. The collision of the two Canadian fighters reminded Germans of the 1988 military jet disasters at the Ramstein U.S. Air Force base and in the central West German city of Remscheid. Both accidents killed German civilians as well as NATO pilots. The accident rekindled debate over the dozens of military training flights that criss-cross West German skies each day. West Germans have said they would like to see the missions sharply curtailed as East-West relations improve. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of the opposition Social Democrats, today demanded an immediate end to the NATO practice flights over densely populated areas. Friedel Laepple, interior minister for Saarland state and a Social Democrat, demanded a stop to all military training flights over West Germany. The West German government was also concerned and used some of the most pointed language to date after a military crash. The Defense Ministry in Bonn said it has ``urgently asked the Canadian air force to quickly and comprehensively clear up the causes of the accident.'' In a statement, the ministry said it asked the Canadians to examine whether ``interceptor training with F-18s'' should be stopped until the reasons for the accident are known. The Canadian Forces today announced all F-18 air-to-air training flights were grounded until the cause of the collision is determined. A spokeswoman for the Canadian Forces in Lahr, Baerbel Newman, said both flight recorders had been found, but the cause of the collision was not known. Maj. John Paul Macdonald, spokesman for Canadian Forces in Lahr, said the Canadian Air Force F-18s collided at about 9,800 feet. Burning debris, ripped from the jets in the collision, rained down on Karlsruhe streets. West German television quoted witnesses as saying the engine of one jet smashed into a building near a gas station. Karlsruhe officials said about 50 damage reports were filed. In Canada, the father of the dead pilot told Canadian Press that his son, Capt. Timothy Kirk Leuty, 30, was nearing the end of his stint in West Germany as a member of the 439th Squadron based in Baden-Soellingen. ``We were really looking forward to his coming home,'' Stan Leuty said from his home in Meaford, Ontario. ``He was due to leave in June and he was going to be based in Cold Lake, Alberta, when he got back.'' The other pilot, Capt. Reginald deCoste, 35, of Jonquiere, Quebec, ejected safely and landed on a highway, breaking both heels. He was listed in good condition at an area hospital, Macdonald said. The two pilots had taken off from Baden-Soellingen Air Base near Rastatt, about 25 miles southwest of Karlsruhe, police said. The Canadian Air Force has 48 F-18s at the base. Thousands of Canadian soldiers are stationed in West Germany as part of a multinational NATO force. They routinely take part in Allied military manuevers, including air training.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Rattles Northern California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Richter readings on two other quakes, quote from Watsonville police, power outages, add background on October's quake anniversary. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Tuesday's quake...' Subs final graf with more on great quake also occurring April 18.
DOC.TEXT: A series of strong earthquakes struck Northern California today, rattling the nerves of residents in a 100-mile area from San Francisco south to Salinas on the anniversary of the catastrophic 1906 quake. The hardest quake struck at 6:54 a.m. and measured a preliminary 5.4 on the Richter scale, Allen Lindh of the U.S. Geological Survey said. The UC-Berkeley Seismographic Station measured the quake at a preliminary 5.5 on the Richter scale. Both agencies said the quakes hit just east of Watsonville, about 60 miles south of San Francisco, in the Loma Prieta area, where the October 17 quake measured 7.1 on the Richter scale. The two other strong quakes today included one at 6:38 a.m. that measured a preliminary 4.5 on the Richter scale, centered four miles east-southeast of Watsonville, and another 4.5 quake at 6:41 a.m. Watsonville police dispatcher Bob Spidle described the first quake, saying: ``It bounced. We've had lots of calls, but I've had no reports of any damage.'' Pacific Gas & Electric Co. reported power loss to 6,500 customers in the Watsonville area. San Francisco police said they received many calls from worried residents, but no damage and no injuries were reported. Only the night before a rally featuring displays on earthquake safety had been held to mark the six-month anniversary of the Oct. 17, 1989, quake, which killed 68 people and caused billions in damage. And survivors of the Great Earthquake that destroyed San Francisco in 1906 had gathered at dawn to commemorate the occasion. On Tuesday, Southern California quivered from a series of aftershocks from a February earthquake, and a small temblor hit rural, eastern Indiana. There were no damages or injuries reported from those two areas. Tuesday's quake measured 4.6 on the Richter scale and was centered three miles west of Upland, said Robert Finn, spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. Upland is 40 miles east of Los Angeles. The 3:32 p.m. quake was the strongest in a swarm of minor tremors in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains. Three smaller tremors followed within two hours, all in the same area, Finn said. The shocks were in an area of the San Antonio Canyon fault that was not ruptured in the Feb. 28 quake, which measured 5.5 on the Richter scale and inflicted some serious damage to older buildings. Indiana's Tuesday morning quake shook buildings, rattled windows and woke up residents, but caused no damage, Jay County authorities said. Michael Hamburger, seismologist and geology professor at Indiana University, put the quake's magnitude at 2.5 to 3 on the Richter scale and its epicenter in eastern Jay County, about 65 miles northeast of Indianapolis. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage. The San Francisco earthquake of April 18, 1906, which occurred before the Richter scale was devised, has been estimated at 8.3 on the Richter scale. The quake and subsequent fire were blamed for an estimated 700 deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Judge Exceeded Authority in Kansas City Desegregation Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that a federal judge may not personally raise property taxes to pay for school desegregation but can order school officials to do so. By a 9-0 vote, the court said U.S. District Judge Russell G. Clark abused his discretion when he personally imposed a school district tax hike in Kansas City, Mo. But in a victory for civil rights forces, the court upheld most of the steps Clark ordered school officials to take to racially desegregate the schools. In a 5-4 vote, the court said the judge could order officials to raise taxes to pay for the ordered desegregation remedies and could instruct them to ignore state laws limiting the anount of school taxes. Writing for the court, Justice Byron White used sweeping language that could affect school-desegregation cases nationwide. ``A local government with taxing authority may be ordered to levy taxes in excess of the limit set by state statute where there is reason based in the Constitution for not observing the statutory limitation,'' White wrote. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia dissented, decrying the court's ``casual embrace of taxation imposed by the unelected, life-tenured federal judiciary.'' Clark went too far, the court said today. ``Local officials should at least have the opportunity to devise their own solutions to these problems,'' White wrote. White's opinion was joined by Justices William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. Through the last three decades, the court has given federal judges sweeping power to take whatever steps necessary to end racial segregation in public schools. Those steps have included the forced busing of students, teacher reassignments, and even the partial merger of separate school districts. But the court in January split 5-4 in limiting federal judges' power to stamp out civil rights violations as it overturned fines against Yonkers, N.Y., councilmen who blocked a housing desegregation plan. The court said the judge who imposed the fines had exceeded his authority, and should have waited to see whether potentially bankrupting penalties against the city would force adoption of the desegregation plan. In arguments before the justices last October on the Kansas City case, Missouri lawyer H. Barton Farr III, representing the state, called a tax increase ordered by an unelected judge ``taxation without representation.'' When it comes to federal courts, Farr said then, ``There is no power to tax, period.'' Today's decision rejected that argument. Before 1954, Missouri law required schools to be racially segregated. In the following 35 years, the percentage of black students in Kansas City's school district rose from 22.5 to about 75 percent. Black parents sued in 1977 over the decline of what had become predominantly black schools, alleging that black students were being denied equal educational opportunities. Clark ruled in 1987 that the school district's ``physical facilities have literally rotted,'' and ordered state and district officials to upgrade them. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld most of Clark's order, saying, ``There are still vestiges of the dual school system lingering in the (city school district), and the district and the state have not met their obligations to disestablish that system.'' The judge's orders called for two major remedies: _A ``magnet school'' plan by the 1991-92 school year in which every high school and middle school and about half the elementary schools in the district will feature distinctive themes such as foreign languages, performing arts or math and science. _A capital improvements program costing some $260 million, to be completed by next fall. The state was ordered to pay three-fourths of the remedial costs; the school district one-fourth. School district voters had rejected six proposals since 1970 to increase taxes for education. Clark nearly doubled the local property tax _ ordering the school district to raise the tax from $2.05 to $4 per $100 of assessed valuation to help finance the capital improvements. ``The court must weigh the constitutional rights of the taxpayers against the constitutional rights of (black) students in this case,'' Clark said. ``The balance is clearly in favor of the students who are helpless without the aid of this court.'' The 8th Circuit court upheld the tax hike in 1988. Today, the nation's highest court struck down the specific tax hike ordered, but left open the option of some tax hike being imposed by the school district under court order. The case is Missouri vs. Jenkins, 88-11150.

DOC.HEAD: Grenade Fired At School Bus, Killing 11 Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with police confirmation, increases death toll, adds new quotes from soldier. Pickup 13th graf, `Meanwhile, rival...'
DOC.TEXT: Battling Christian forces hit a school bus at a crossing gateway between east and west Beirut today, setting it on fire and killing at least 15 people, 11 of them children, police reported. ``Many of the pupils yelled for help as we tried to extinguish the fire. At least one teacher also was among the dead along with the driver,'' a soldier on the scene said. A police spokesman said the bus was hit at 2:30 p.m. while trying to cross to Christian east Beirut. The spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said the bus from Mraijeh elementary school, a new private school in south Beirut, was hit by an incendiary rifle grenade, which ignited the fuel tank. ``It couldn't be determined who fired the rifle grenade,'' the spokesman said. It was not immediately clear why students from predominantly Christian east Beirut were attending primary school in south Beirut, a Shiite Moslem stronghold. But many students are among the estimated 30,000 people who commute across the line daily. The radio station of Christian Gen. Michel Aoun said the bus was fired at by rival gunmen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. ``Geagea's fire burned out the children,'' the broadcast said. Geagea's command could not be reached by telephone from west Beirut to comment on the report. However, the pro-Geagea Voice of Lebanon radio station called the hit ``mysterious.'' The gutted wreckage of the yellow bus lay on the pavement in the Aoun-controlled sector, a few yards east of the museum crossing that links Beirut's eastern and western sectors across the dividing Green Line. The army private, one of the soldiers serving under Aoun, said he and his colleagues ``doused off the burning bus with water and we evacuated the victims to nearby hospitals.'' The attack followed intermittent skirmishing and a powerful explosion that reportedly demolished two floors of Aoun's defense ministry. News reports said three soldiers were killed. Aoun's command said two were killed. It was not immediately clear what caused the blast. Aoun has been locked in bloody power struggle with Geagea for more than two months. They have been battling since Jan. 30 for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. The fighting has killed 877 people and wounded 2,388. Meanwhile, rival Shiite Moslem militias fought a 90-minute gun battle this morning in Syrian-policed west Beirut, and one person was killed and four wounded, the police spokesman said. The clash between the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal, Arabic for ``Hope,'' subsided after about 100 Syrian soldiers moved in to stop the confrontation. Police said 12 people have been killed and 52 wounded since the latest round of Amal-Hezbollah clashes broke out in west and south Beirut Tuesday. The police spokesman said most of the casualties were civilians, including children, caught in the cross-fire of fierce street battles across densely populated residential districts. Amal, in a communique, blamed the confrontation on Hezbollah, charging that the fundamentalist faction wanted to ``block efforts being exerted to release the (Western) hostages held by Hezbollah.'' It did not elaborate. Hezbollah has repeatedly denied involvement in the abduction of the 18 Westerners, including eight Americans, missing in Lebanon. However, Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for the underground hostage-holding factions that follow the teachings of the late Iranian revolutionary patriarch Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. There now appears to be a power struggle in Iran between government officials who support the release of the hostages and radical hard-liners who view hostage-taking as a way to punish the ``corrupt'' West. The police spokesman said that despite Syrian patrols, fighters from Amal and Hezbollah maintained their rooftop positions in Beirut, threatening a renewal of all-out fighting. Rival Shiite fighters also skirmished in southern Lebanon's Iqlim el-Tuffah province early in the day, but no casualties were reported, the police spokesman said. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting on and off for more than two years for Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the nation's largest sect. By police count, more than 1,000 people have been killed and 3,000 wounded in the clashes.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: Blackmun dissented.
DOC.TEXT: Robert Olson was convicted of murder, armed robbery and assault in the July 18, 1987, holdup of a gas station in Minneapolis in which the station manager was shot to death. Olson was sentenced to life in prison plus six years. He said he had been duped into driving the getaway car for the crime. The Minnesota Supreme Court had overturned Olson's conviction and granted him a new trial. Today's decision upheld the state court ruling. Police, acting on an informant's tip, went to a home where they believed Olson was staying with the two women who lived there. After surrounding the home, police telephoned and asked to speak to Olson. A male voice was heard to say, ``Tell them I left.'' Police officers then rushed into the home, found Olson hiding in a closet and arrested him. Olson made an incriminating remark to police that was used against him at his trial. Today's decision means Olson must be retried, and that the incriminating remark _ the result of an unlawful arrest _ cannot be used as evidence. ``The issue is whether the arrest violated Olson's Fourth Amendment rights. We hold that it did,'' White wrote. The Fourth Amendment bans unreasonable police searches and arrests. White added: ``We stay in others' homes when we travel to a strange city for business or pleasure, when we visit our children or more distant relatives out of town, when we are in between jobs or homes, or when we house-sit for a friend. We will all be hosts and we will all be guests many times in our lives. From either perspective, we think that society recognizes that a house guest has a legitimate expectation of privacy in his host's home.'' The court in 1980, invoking the phrase ``A man's home is his castle,'' ruled that police almost always need warrants before arresting people in their homes. Today's decision extends the reasoning of that 1980 decision to house guests as well. MORE

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Virus Found in 1 in 3,000 Teens Applying for Military
DOC.TEXT: The AIDS virus was found in almost one in 3,000 teens who applied for the military over a 42-month period, with the infection rate about equal among young women and men, researchers reported today. ``The data presented in this study suggest that HIV is a real and immediate threat to teenagers throughout the United States,'' the researchers from the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Washington, D.C., wrote in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. The study looked at 1,141,164 teens applying to enlist in the U.S. military between October 1985 and March 1989, all of whom were tested for the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS. Of that number, 393 were HIV positive. Overall, 48 of 150,043 female applicants tested positive, or .032 percent, and 345 of 991,455 males, or .035 percent, the researchers said. But women aged 17 and 18 tested positive more often than their male counterparts _ 28 of 102,576 women, or .027 percent, compared with 177 of 763,872 men, or .023 percent _ an unusual phenomenon among any age group. For example, the male-female ratio among adults with full-blown AIDS is 9.3-1, the researchers said. The probable explanation, the researchers said, is that females aged 17 and 18 ``are more likely to have older, infected sexual partners than males.'' The study found that results varied widely in different regions, with the most populous states accounting, proportionately, for the highest number of infected teen applicants. HIV prevalence was greatest among minorities from densely populated counties, the study said. Fifty-two of the 90,821 teens who tried to enlist in California tested HIV positive, followed by 45 of 62,244 in New York and 38 of 73,789 in Texas. Nine states _ Alaska, Colorado, Maine, Montana, North Dakota, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, South Dakota and Wyoming _ had no HIV-positive applicants, the study said. The researchers reported that the prevalance of HIV infection among teen applicants appeared to decrease over the study period, but cautioned that more research is needed to verify that finding. They urged greater educational efforts to stop the spread of HIV and AIDS. The virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring.

DOC.HEAD: Supplies Flow Normally to Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead; inserts 2 grafs after 6th graf, `President Bush ...' to UPDATE with Baker comments today, ADDs 2 grafs at end with plane hijacking.
DOC.TEXT: Oil and natural gas flowed normally into Lithuania today, officials of the breakaway government said, despite threats by Moscow to halt the supplies to curb the republic's independence drive. Lithuanian officials said they had expected the Kremlin to begin cutting oil and natural gas supplies early today to enforce Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's threatened economic embargo. Soviet troops were seen near a pumping station at an oil refinery in northwestern Lithuania this morning, but there was no change in the supply of fuel at the facility, according to a report on Lithuanian television. Lithuania's energy minister said oil supplies were normal and he had not been informed of any planned reductions. On Friday, Gorbachev threatened to impose an embargo of critical supplies unless Lithuania rescinded within 48 hours several laws meant to bolster its March 11 declaration of independence. Lithuanian leaders have made no move to meet Gorbachev's demands, but say they are willing to negotiate. Gorbachev refuses to meet with them until they rescind their declaration of independence. President Bush said in Washington the United States was considering ``appropriate responses'' if supplies were cut. But he also said he did not want to damage superpower relations. Secretary of State James A. Baker III today told the House Ways and Means Committee that U.S. support for perestroika, Gorbachev's economic reform program, was at risk. ``Our bilateral commercial contacts with the U.S.S.R. may be more directly in their interest than in ours. And those contacts are being put to risk by Soviet actions in Lithuania,'' Baker said. Lithuania's parliament, the Supreme Council, met today to forge an official response to the Soviet leader, and they were still debating the tone of the resolution into the afternoon, said Rita Dapkus of the legislature's Information Office. Also under sharp discussion was the composition of a delegation to send to Moscow, she said. Worried Lithuanians flooded the Baltic republic's government with phone calls and stocked up on fuel. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said he believed any hardships would strengthen the republic's resolve to split from the Soviet Union. Lithuanian gas officials received a telegram late Monday from the acting general director of the Soviet Union's western gas network saying natural gas supplies would be ``sharply reduced from the 17th of April.'' But Runya Kontouteite, a spokeswoman for the Supreme Council, said by telephone that natural gas was flowing normally this morning. She said that a check with the central pipeline duty officer indicated there were no signs of any fall in the pipeline pressure. In addition, oil supplies were being received normally at a major refinery in the town of Mazheikiai, which produces high-octane gasoline for export, Kontouteite said. Lithuanian TV reported that residents saw Soviet troops in several armored vehicles stopped for a time near a pumping station at the Mazheikiai refinery, but there was no interruption of service, said broadcaster Edwardas Potashinskas. The presence of soldiers at the site was unusual, he added. Nearly all Western journalists were forced by the Soviet government to leave Lithuania last month. Leonas Asmantas, minister of fuel and power engineering, told Vilnius Radio that the supply of oil ``is normal'' and he had received no official document from anyone informing him of a cutoff. Asmantas said he did not think the Soviet Union would take the step of reducing oil supplies. ``Perhaps economic pressure will be applied in some other forms but not in the supply of fuel,'' he was reported as saying. Sales of gasoline to motorists have tripled this week as residents reacted to the threat, but stocks were adequate and no rationing was anticipated, Asmantas said. In his ultimatum Friday, Gorbachev said Moscow would demand hard currency from Lithuania for materials the Soviet Union sells abroad for convertible currency. Oil and gas, which Lithuania receives at subsidized prices, are the Soviet Union's biggest earners of foreign currency. Lithuanian officials were discussing shifting some oil and gas from industrial production to use in homes and hospitals if the cuts occur, but had not publicly discussed a conservation program. The republic uses 18.5 million cubic meters of natural gas a day, including 1.1 million cubic meters for homes. The Kremlin forcibly annexed the three Baltic republics _ Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia _ in 1940. Estonia and Latvia also seek to restore independence, but are moving more cautiously. Gorbachev says Lithuanian independence can be discussed only within the framework of Soviet law. A law passed this month would let republics secede if they gain approval of two-thirds of their residents in a referendum and wait a maximum of five years. DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Lawyer Can Collect Big Part of Client's Award in California Case
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that a lawyer who wins a civil rights case can collect a big chunk of a client's award under an agreement made when the attorney was hired. By a 9-0 vote, the court ruled against a California man awarded $2.12 million and then ordered to pay 40 percent of the judgment to his lawyer. Justice Byron R. White, writing for the court, said federal civil rights law permits such contingent-fee arrangements. The case stems from a federal lawsuit by Juan Francisco Venegas against Long Beach police officers. Venegas won a suit in which he said his murder conviction was based on perjured evidence. Venegas hired Michael Mitchell to represent him in the suit and agreed to pay the lawyer 40 percent of any award he won. A federal court also awarded Mitchell $75,000 in legal fees, a sum to be paid by the police officers. Mitchell and Venegas parted ways in 1986 when the lawyer asked for an additional 10 percent of the judgment to represent Venegas on appeal and Venegas refused. The lawyer then filed a court motion to place a lien on the judgment to recover his 40 percent fee, or $406,000. A federal judge gave MItchell a partial victory, ruling he may be entitled to the contingent fee but leaving the matter to a state court to decide. Mitchell won a bigger victory before the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeals court last year sent the case back to the federal judge to reconsider the lawyer's bid to enforce a lien on the $2.12 million award. Today, the Supreme Court agreed with the 9th Circuit court that under federal civil rights law, Mitchell is not limited to court-awarded attorneys' fees when there is a contingency fee agreement with a client. The case is Venegas vs. Mitchell, 88-1725.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. April 14 The Arizona Daily Star, Tucson, Ariz., on the tuna industry pledge: Most of the U.S. tuna-canning industry celebrated Earth Day a little early this year _ or else it moved to protect the tuna market _ with its pledge not to buy tuna caught in fishing nets that also catch or injure dolphins. The announcement ... by the nation's three largest tuna canners _ owners of the Star-Kist, Chicken of the Sea and Bumble Bee brands of tuna _ should prevent thousands of dolphins from dying in fishermen's nets this year. ... But consumers can't live on the word of big business alone. Congress must enact legislation to hold industry to its promise. It is not as if the tuna industry's change of heart was motivated by environmental enlightenment. On the contrary; it was consumer consciousness _ including a letter-writing campaign and tuna boycott _ that moved the industry to crack down on fishing practices deadly to dolphins. ... Under the recent announcement, called the most important step to protect dolphins since the 1972 Marine Mammal Protection Act, the canning companies will rely on the reports of observers stationed on board tuna fishing vessels for making decisions about whether to buy a particular catch of tuna. American consumers should seek more than pledges from the tuna-canning industry, however. Greenpeace urges monitoring to ensure companies keep their promises about not supporting unsafe fishing methods. It also wants Congress to pass legislation introduced by Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., and Sen. Joe Biden, D-Delaware, to create a tuna-can labeling system to identify ``dolphin unsafe'' tuna. The cost to consumers will be only a few additional cents per can. It's a small price to pay to protect the sea mammal.

April 12 The Bulletin, Bend, Ore., on AT&T and Planned Parenthood: AT&T, the communications giant, decided the other day to quit giving money to Planned Parenthood. Directors of the foundation which AT&T supports should reconsider their decision. A spokesman for AT&T admitted the foundation made its decision because of pressure brought by ultra conservatives upset with Planned Parenthood's involvement with the abortion issue. Not that AT&T's funds went to finance abortions, or even to pay Planned Parenthood employees to mention the operation. No. AT&T's money went to finance a program aimed at reducing the number of unplanned pregnancies that seem to fall most frequently on the nation's poorest, least educated teen-agers. AT&T's decision to withdraw its support for a worthy program based on the rantings of what it admits is a tiny minority poses a serious threat for a whole variety of charitable organizations. If an outfit as large as AT&T ... can be bullied into submission by a handful of nuts, what can be expected from smaller, less well-heeled businesses? ... Its position on abortion aside, Planned Parenthood offers a variety of valuable services. ... In an age of concern about the Earth's booming population, it would be a shame to see the agency lose that support.

April 12 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on double-hulled tankers: Conoco Inc., a Houston-based oil company, in one bold stroke is proving the truth of two old adages, ``We can learn from our mistakes,'' and ``An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.'' Conoco (is) ordering two new oil tankers. But unlike the single-hulled Exxon Valdez which, after running aground, dumped 11 million gallons of petroleum into Alaskan waters last year, these new ships will have double hulls. The folks at Conoco are well aware that this type of construction will increase the cost of their new seagoing acquisitions by as much as 15 percent, somewhere into the $70 million to $90 million range. But they are also aware that a Coast Guard study has found that if the Exxon Valdez had been of double-hull construction, its petroleum loss after running aground would have been reduced by as much as 60 percent. Truly, Conoco has learned from Exxon's experience and with what has been learned is making a powerful statement that at sea and on land it is better to prevent oil spills than clean up after them.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: after them.
DOC.TEXT: April 17 Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal on cutting U.S. troop strength: With the pain and consternation at the Pentagon in the aftermath of the outbreak of peace, it is difficult to distinguish trial balloons from real plans among the resulting announcements and leaks. Nonetheless, the disclosure that the Army proposes to cut troop strength by 25 percent by 1997 is a reasonable strategy, if world events stay on their trend toward peace. The Department of Defense should not be so quick, however, to reduce strength in the Reserves and National Guard. The proposal is to reduce active duty personnel from 764,000 to 580,000 and Reserve and National Guard forces from 776,000 to 645,000. With a downsized regular Army, the strategic importance of a reserve of trained and organized manpower takes on greater importance.

April 15 Grand Forks (N.D.) Herald on the legacy of the Vietnam War: The (Vietnam) war put a tarnish on our national nobility. American policymakers couldn't convince Americans that the war was right, and the rest of the world was equally doubtful. The foundation of American moral leadership was cracked, and it hasn't been completely repaired. Then, there were the thousands who first found political power through opposition to the war. The Civil Rights movement had shown the way, and the Free Speech Movement ... had trained new cadres. But it was the war that energized so many young people, that brought them into the streets and later into the political process. This politicization would have happened in any case, but the war made it happen in a particular way, and that way has had a profound influence on how today's world works. The years of that war _ the longest war in American history _ were years that molded the nation. We don't know yet just how. The war is a part of the nation's unfinished business _ the divisiveness, the bitterness, the doubt, the grief. These all remain. It is understanding and acceptance that still elude us. ... Perhaps, the longing for them in the nation's soul is as great as the grief in the nation's heart and the doubt in the nation's mind.

April 13 Philadelphia Daily News on Lithuania: It would be quite a picture. The Seminole nation _ in full tribal regalia _ pleads with Mikhail Gorbachev to pressure President Bush for the return of their half of Florida, which the white man stole. The photo op would be spectacular, but Gorbachev would never buy it. Nor would he intervene if the people of California tried to secede from the United States. Fortunately for all of us, President Bush has taken the same _ and proper _ position regarding independence movements within the Soviet Union. Quietly and firmly, Bush makes it clear that the use of military force to squelch the independence movements in places like Lithuania, Estonia or Latvia would not sit well with Americans. But he refuses to repeat the mistakes of 1956, which saw the Eisenhower administration seemingly supporting the Hungarian revolution only to find itself helpless when the Soviet tanks rolled into Hungary to crush the revolution. Some feel, even today, that the anticipation of American intervention helped inspire that uprising _ and the brutal Soviet overreaction. But 1990 is not 1956. Gorbachev has demonstrated in word and deed that he wants to encourage peaceful and democratic change throughout the Soviet spheres of influence. ... As they prepare for the arms control summit next month, Bush and Gorbachev know it would be insanity to abolish one form of mass destruction while inviting another form of carnage. Their cautious, yet consistent, approach to the promotion of peaceful change is encouraging, and deserves the support of everyone who wants the process to continue.

April 15 Los Angeles Daily News on Lech Walesa the politician: Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa injected more excitement into Eastern European politics ... when he bluntly ``confirmed'' his interest in becoming president of Poland, in remarks attributed to him by the official Polish news agency PAP. About 24 hours later, however, Walesa executed a remarkable about-face, although he didn't quite describe it that way. ``Today on radio and TV, I hear that Lech Walesa agreed to be president. I didn't say so at all,'' Walesa insisted. ... Walesa has picked up a decidedly American political trait _ not allowing himself to be pinned down about future plans. Walesa claimed that he had been ``cajoled'' into making a statement about his presidential ambitions and was misunderstood. ``I simply did not guard my tongue enough somewhere,'' he said. Obviously, Walesa has developed another skill that American politicians long have been famous for _ how to make excuses.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: make excuses.
DOC.TEXT: April 15 Lawrence (Kan.) Journal-World on President Bush, broccoli and Earth Day: It's an interesting commentary on American priorities, that a recent survey showed President Bush's distaste for broccoli drew six times more public attention than Earth Day. In the survey, conducted by The Times Mirror Center for the People and The Press, 76 percent of the respondents correctly identified the vegetable President Bush had refused to eat. By contrast, only 13 percent knew that April 22 is being observed as Earth Day to honor the environment. The broccoli story was humorous enough _ the president putting his foot down like an unhappy schoolboy and Barbara Bush promising to eat his share of the broccoli for him. But in significance, the Bush and the broccoli stalk story pales in comparison to an event such as Earth Day, which focuses on one of the world's greatest challenges: preserving the environment. Perhaps the poll doesn't say anything about American priorities. Perhaps the broccoli story just tickled people's funnybones. But it's too bad that the nation's media and the people it serves can't pay as much attention to the cutting of millions of trees in the world's rain forest as it does to the cutting of a stalk of broccoli for the president.

April 14 The Daily Tribune, Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., on returning the census forms: The (census) forms were mailed in March and were supposed to be sent back by April 1, which was proclaimed Census Day. Well, two weeks later, the Census Bureau is saying that many people haven't sent in their completed forms. ... Nationwide, the response rate is a dismal 57 percent. Census officials are mobilizing their troops to go door to door to those households that haven't responded. Let them come, you say? Well, consider this. The Census Bureau had hoped to get back 70 percent of the forms without begging in person. To send out census workers door to door will cost an extra $10 million for each percentage point below that 70 percent budgeted goal. That's a lot of money, and who is going to pay for it? Taxpayers. We're already going to pay a budgeted $2.5 billion for this head count, which occurs every 10 years. There's no reason to add to the bill by being too lazy to fill out the form and send it in. This census is very important. It will determine how much money is distributed to states and local governments. And, it will determine how many representatives we have in Congress. It's nothing to ignore. If you want as much money as your municipality is entitled to, send in your form. You'll be saving Uncle Sam the trouble and expense of having to come looking for you.

April 17 The News-Leader, Springfield, Mo., on U.S. Supreme Court's refusal to hear a case involving a school board ban on dancing in Purdy, Mo.: Tradition lives in Purdy, where dancing is a sin to a majority. Now the tiny community of 928 residents and its school board are free to continue a century-long tradition of banning social dances, despite the hopes of a minority that school dances be permitted. The decision does nothing to explain the Supreme Court's rationale. By simply refusing to hear the case, the court let stand a 5-4 ruling by the U.S. Court of Appeals in St. Louis late last year. The lower court opinion rejected the argument that a ban on dancing amounted to an endorsement of the fundamentalist views of the majority in Purdy. ... Using the rationale of the appeals court and by its refusal to grant a full hearing, the courts have delivered a powerful message that leaves the majority to impose its beliefs _ however sincere they may be _ on the minority. The minority of Purdy students and their parents asked for nothing of the school board that would infringe on the rights of any students. But the board, and now the courts, did exactly that.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Leningrad Player Wins New York Open Chess Tournament
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Khalifman, a 24-year-old from Leningrad, U.S.S.R., has won the 1990 New York Open Chess Tournament, taking the $20,000 first prize. Khalifman, in his first tournament in the United States, was the only one among 63 entrants in the prestigious international section to score 7 points. The nine-round event ended Tuesday. The field included 32 grandmasters _ the highest title holders in chess short of world champion _ and 21 international masters, who are one level below grandmaster. Eleven countries were represented in the competition at the Penta Hotel, where players competed for a total purse of $48,600. Khalifman, an international master, clinched first place by defeating 21-year-old Grandmaster Ferdinand Hellers of Sweden in a 46-move, five-hour game. ``He sacrificed a pawn, but it was a very unclear sacrifice,'' Khalifman said. ``I made some good moves and my chances became better and better. My pawn advantage was enough to win.'' Gata Kamsky, 15, of Brooklyn, who defected from the Soviet Union with his father during last year's New York Open, tied with four others for second place. Kamsky, Grandmaster Helgi Olafsson of Iceland, and Leningrad International Masters Leonid Yudasin and Vladimir Epishin each finished with 6{ points, one-half point behind Khalifman. They earned $4,825 apiece. Competitors earn one point for each win and one-half point for each draw. Khalifman, Kamsky, Yudasin and Epishin also each won an international grandmaster norm, one of the achievements necessary to win the grandmaster title. Kamsky, unlike the others, does not yet hold an international title. Khalifman said he hopes the international chess federation next month would grant him the grandmaster title, which he believes is overdue. ``I already have four GM (grandmaster) results _ I am ready to become a grandmaster,'' he said. It normally takes three norms to qualify for the title. International Master Patrick Wolff of Belmont, Mass., also earned a grandmaster norm. Wolff tied for sixth place with Grandmasters Joel Benjamin of Brooklyn and Smbat Lputian of Armenia. Each earned 6 points and earned $1,033.33. Former World Champion Mikhail Tal of Riga, Latvia, earned 5{ points and finished in a tie with 10 others for ninth place. Each of them won $518.18. In Monday's penultimate round, Kamsky drew loud applause from spectators in the otherwise silent ballroom as he defeated Tal in 45 moves. Tal, who was competing in his first New York tournament, held the world title in 1960-61. Former World Champion Anatoly Karpov, who will be challenging World Champion Garri Kasparov for the world title in New York in October, dropped by during the fourth round of the international competition.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow-Leningrad Flight Hijacked to Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: A mental patient claiming to have a bomb hijacked an Aeroflot jet to Lithuania on Wednesday and demanded to meet with officials there, but he surrendered after the plane landed, officials said. The Moscow man commandeered the Tu-134 while it was bound from the Soviet capital to Leningrad with about 70 people aboard, including some American tourists, news reports said. Lithuania's internal affairs minister, Marijonas Misiukonis, said the hijacker wanted to help the republic by giving it the government-owned plane. Lithuania is involved in a standoff with the Kremlin over its declaration of independence March 11. ``Shortly after takeoff, he called the stewardess and claimed he had an explosive device in his lap, and pointed to paper wrapped around an object that he was holding tightly against himself,'' said Valery Akolsin, a spokesman for the Ministry of Civil Aviation. The official news agency Tass quoted the hijacker as saying: ``Either we fly to Vilnius or I blow up the aircraft. I belong to the caste of immortals and have nothing to lose.'' ``His request was complied with after the pilots consulted authorities on the ground and obtained permission to land the plane in Vilnius,'' Akolsin said. Vilnius is the capital of Lithuania. Tass said the hijacker, identified as Igor Kalugin, demanded that a meeting be organized with an unidentifed aide to Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. After the plane touched down it taxied to a remote section of the airport. Authorities drove up to the jet, and Kalugin, still clutching the parcel, surrendered, said a tower dispatcher quoted by Vilnius Radio. Tass said he was taken into custody. Akolsin said Kalugin was a registered patient at a psychiatric clinic in Moscow. Misiukonis also said Kalugin was registered in Moscow as being mentally ill. Vilnius Radio reported that American, Japanese and Cuban tourists were among the passengers. They were taken to a special hall for foreigners at the airport while the jet was searched, the dispatcher said. No explosives were found, and after about 90 minutes, the jet resumed its journey to Leningrad, the aviation ministry spokesman said. The radio said Kalugin, 46 or 47 years old, was an employee of a Moscow theater and claimed to have acquaintances in Lithuania. Misiukonis told Vilnius Radio that Kalugin did not put up a struggle when he was arrested and that no weapon was found.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Consume Record Amount of Alcohol
DOC.TEXT: Japanese drank a record amount of alcohol last year, with each adult consuming an average of 18 gallons of beer and four gallons of sake, a government report said Wednesday. The National Tax Administration Agency said a total of 2.3 billion gallons of alcoholic beverages were consumed in 1989, up 3.7 percent from the previous year. It said wine consumption totaled a record 34.3 million gallons, up 21.7 percent from the previous year. Imported wine accounted for about half of the total consumption, it said.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 140 Dead in Heavy Rains and Floods in Kenya, Tanzania
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain and flooding killed more than 140 people in Kenya and Tanzania in recent weeks, police said Wednesday. In the latest deaths, seven people died when their canoe capsized on Lake Victoria during a tropical rainstorm, and five drowned when their family car was swept down a fast-flowing river Saturday, police said. The latest deaths raise to 44 the number of Kenyans who have drowned since the annual rainy season began six weeks ago. In neighboring Tanzania, more than 100 people have been drowned and 25,000 left homeless by floods in the last two weeks, according to police in the capital of Dar es Salaam.

DOC.HEAD: Pepsi to Begin Production in Burma Despite Political Conflict
DOC.TEXT: Pepsi said Wednesday that it signed an agreement to operate in Burma, despite calls by dissidents and human rights groups not to invest after a military crackdown. The agreement was signed last month with a private partner, and Pepsico International has a 35 percent share in the venture, said Barry Shea, company vice president for southeast Asia. The company will ship soft drinks to Burma and is building a $3 million factory on the outskirts of Rangoon, the Burmese capital, which should be completed by the end of the year, he said. Shea was unwilling to comment on the human rights issue. ``Obviously we like to stay out of politics,'' he said. The military government seized power in September 1988 by crushing a mass uprising for democracy. Hundreds of people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Hits China's Western Border
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck a remote area near China's northwestern border with the Soviet Union, the official news agency said Wednesday, but no deaths or injuries were reported. The State Seismological Bureau said the quake Tuesday registered 6.4 on the Richter scale and hit West Wuqia in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. Zhu Lingren, deputy director of the Xinjiang regional seismic bureau in Urumqi, said an investigative team had not reached the affected area. West Wuqia is 60 miles from the Soviet border. The Richter scale gauges the energy released by an earthquake as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of 6.4 could cause severe damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Reportedly Tightens Surveillance on Foreigners, Students
DOC.TEXT: North Korea has tightened surveillance of foreigners and students to keep word of reform in other Communist countries from spreading, media reports said Wednesday. Yonhap, the South Korean news agency, quoted intelligence sources as saying North Korea was closely watching about 2,000 foreign technicians, students and diplomats. North Korea has been maintaining a one-on-one surveillance system for its college students who once studied in the Soviet bloc. Security officials have been stationed inside university campuses since leaflets criticizing President Kim Il-sung were found and a ``small-scale'' campus protest erupted in the capital early this year, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-American Protests Lead to Battles With Police in Seoul
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of students shouting anti-U.S. and anti-government slogans demonstrated Wednesday to protest a recent political move that gave President Roh Tae-woo a majority in the National Assembly. In Seoul, about 1,000 students at Konkuk University fought riot police with rocks and firebombs. ``Let's destroy the merger!'' students yelled. ``Let's drive out the Yankees!'' Riot police firing tear gas dispersed the protesters. There were no arrests or injuries reported. Also Wednesday, more than 20,000 students staged peaceful street protests at 19 campuses in Seoul and at colleges in Kwangju. They were marking the anniversary of the April 19, 1960 student-led civil uprising that toppled South Korea's first authoritarian government. Thousands of riot troops were deployed to block violence. Protests reportedly erupted in other cities, but no overall figures were immediately available. Traditionally, police do not intervene in peaceful protests marking the anniversary. During Wednesday's protests, students demanded the immediate withdrawal of U.S. troops from South Korea. They urged protests against Roh's government and an end to U.S. influence in South Korea. Radical students, a powerful minority, claim the merger in January of Roh's party with two opposition groups into a giant governing party was a premeditated scheme by conservatives to prolong their power. They also accused Roh of ignoring popular wishes for political and economic reforms. Roh has introduced broad reforms since he took office in February 1988 and sent his authoritarian predecessor into rural exile. Radical students demand the withdrawal of American soldiers from the country, saying they prevent reunification of North and South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Mimic `Marries' Couple at Jefferson Memorial
LaserPhoto WX9
DOC.TEXT: The bride shivered in the wind, a tuxedoed accordionist played ``Hail to the Chief'' and a make-believe George Bush arrived 20 minutes late to officiate Wednesday morning at a gag wedding outside the Jefferson Memorial. The fake ceremony was staged by Gary Butler and his bride, Marilou Brown _ who were married for real Tuesday night by a suburban Fairfax County, Va., magistrate _ as a practical joke on about 50 of their friends. The ``wedding'' guests gasped and then giggled as John Simmons, a Bush look-alike from Washington's Gross National Product comedy troupe, stepped from a white stretch limousine surrounded by phony Secret Service agents in dark glasses, waved to the crowd and took his place behind a flower-bedecked altar on the lawn. Over the roar of airplanes, helicopters and rush-hour traffic, the Bush mimic announced he was playing minister to the couple as ``captain of the ship of democracy.'' He called the newlyweds ``two points of light in this kinder and gentile nation of ours'' and led them in the Pledge of Allegiance. As Butler recited his vows, the bogus Bush advised the bride to ``read his lips.'' He wished them mutual fidelity in ``a perfectly monotonous relationship.'' It's the second marriage for Butler, 41, and the third for Ms. Brown, 42. Both are bankers _ and Republicans _ who've been friends and drinking buddies since they met seven years ago. Butler said they decided to ``try something different, something novel'' this time around, for their friends' amusement. Butler is an ardent admirer of Thomas Jefferson, the former president. He and his new wife courted during evening strolls around the floodlit Jefferson Memorial. ``It's very romantic,'' he said. They decided to be married there, but the red tape of two Virginia residents getting a wedding license in the District of Columbia proved too much. So they were married privately in Virginia and invited friends to a public ``wedding'' the next morning at their favorite trysting place. ``We couldn't get Tom Jefferson to marry us, so we got the next best thing, George Bush,'' said the bride. After Wednesday's reception, the Browns flew to a ski resort near Salt Lake City to spend their honeymoon at a three-day bankers' conference.

DOC.HEAD: Opening Arguments Begin in Trial of Second Bensonhurst Defendant
DOC.TEXT: The accused gunman in an alleged racial attack repeatedly fired into the heart of his teen-age victim, a prosecutor said in opening arguments today. The murder trial of Joseph Fama got under way today after a one-day delay because his attorney was ill. Fama and the alleged ringleader, Keith Mondello, are being tried together, but separate juries are hearing the cases. The prosecutor said 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins was shot and killed after he was pursued by a mob and backed into a doorway. ``Joseph Fama took out that .32-caliber gun and fired it repeatedly into the heart of Yusuf Hawkins,'' said assistant district attorney Edward Boyar. Fama and Mondello, both 19, are charged with murder and other crimes. If convicted, they face 25 years to life in prison. Opening arguments in the trial of Mondello were delivered Monday. Hawkins was shot to death after he and three of his pals, all black, crossed paths with a mob of mostly whites in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section. The four blacks had gone to look at a used car. On Tuesday, prosecutors showed jurors a videotape in which Mondello admitted to being part of the gang but asserted that racism played no role in the attack. ``No matter what color they were, if someone was coming to beat my friends up we would do anything to protect ourselves,'' Mondello said in a television interview taped five days after the Aug. 23 killing. Mondello said the gang gathered to battle a gang of blacks they believed were coming to look for trouble in their neighborhood. ``I was told that 25 blacks were coming to beat me and my friends up,'' he said. ``The only reason baseball bats were on the scene was because we wanted to protect ourselves. And we didn't know if they were going to be armed.'' In the interview, Mondello denied knowing that one of the whites was carrying a gun. Prosecutors played the taped interview, they said, to show Mondello was a liar who had changed his account of the attack. After his arrest, Mondello told investigators that before the attack a man identified only as ``Frank'' put an object in his car that Mondello soon learned was a gun.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Warns Soviets Anew Their Moves In Baltic Are Risky
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 8th graf pvs, The Soviets ... to UPDATE with White House and congressional reaction; picks up 9th graf, On Friday...
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today again warned the Soviet Union that its actions in Lithuania could disrupt relations between the superpowers and hurt the restructuring of the Soviet economy. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, testifying before the House Ways and Means Committee, said U.S. support for perestroika was at risk. After listing benefits he said the United States gets from smoother ties with Moscow, Baker cautioned the Kremlin: ``Our bilateral commercial contacts with the U.S.S.R. may be more directly in their interest than in ours. And those contacts are being put to risk by Soviet actions in Lithuania.'' The administration is providing no direct aid for the economic reconstruction efforts of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. And, Baker stressed, ``We must avoid the siren song calling for direct aid to Moscow.'' The superpowers are negotiating a new trade agreement that could open American markets more widely to Soviet exports by reducing U.S. trade barriers. Baker did not specify which commercial ties could be harmed if the Soviets suppress the independence movement in the Baltic republic. But Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas and others in Congress who have taken a hard line toward Moscow are suggesting a suspension of the trade talks. The administration's cautious approach drew support from Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., one of the most liberal members of Congress. He said others ``would love an excuse to jump-start the Cold War.'' But the New Yorker told Baker, ``The measured response you have given to date is going to prove to be the correct one in the long sweep of history.'' The Soviets evidently have not followed through on an announcement that natural gas and other supplies to Lithuania would be reduced. Lithuania's energy minister said today that oil supplies were normal and that he had not been told of any planned reductions. Likewise, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said there was no sign of a cutoff. ``Essentially it's a matter of watching and waiting to see what happens,'' he said. Fitzwater added, ``We've been going through this process now for a month or two. There's all kinds of maneuvering going on back and forth between the Soviet Union and Lithuania. Therefore we don't try to spend a whole lot of time reading the tea leaves about what might happen or they think is going to happen or so forth.'' On Friday, Gorbachev threatened to impose an embargo of critical supplies unless Lithuania rescinded within 48 hours several laws meant to bolster its March 11 declaration of independence. Lithuanian leaders have made no move to meet Gorbachev's demands, but say they are willing to negotiate. Gorbachev refuses to meet with them until they rescind their declaration of independence. Baker called on Moscow again to ``engage in a dialogue, and not merely talk about having a dialogue'' with Lithuanian leaders. He said dialogue, ``not economic boycotts or threats to invoke presidential rule,'' would be the solution to the problem. Despite the warning, Baker said good relations with Moscow serve U.S. interests in several ways, including arms control agreements and working together on regional conflicts around the world. ``It's in our interest to lock in major reductions in Soviet strategic forces and to create a more stable, predictable and secure relationship that reduces the risk of nuclear war,'' he said. Committee chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., said how the Soviets handle the situation in Lithuania ``will have a strong bearing'' on U.S. economic policy toward Moscow. President Bush said Tuesday that he would take ``appropriate responses'' if Moscow followed through on the threatened reduction of fuel supplies. And yet, Bush showed a reluctance to move against the Kremlin. ``I want to be sure anything we do is productive,'' he said. ``There's been dramatic change in the world and I don't want to inadvertently take some action that would set it back.'' The president gave no indication what options he might be considering. Other U.S. officials told The Associated Press the U.S. policy simply is to watch and wait and see what the Soviets might do in Lithuania. These officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, questioned that Moscow would cut gas supplies since the pipeline to Lithuania goes on from there to Kaliningrad, a Soviet city. Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine met Tuesday with Bush at the White House and said afterward: ``I think it's a very serious matter, a very serious, delicate situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians In Poland Worry and Hope For Families Across Border
DOC.TEXT: Had Josef Stalin's hand shaken a little, this town might have been in Lithuania. But the postwar boundary between Poland and the Soviet republic was drawn just to the east of Punsk, and thousands of ethnic Lithuanians are today Polish citizens. Now this Lithuanian-speaking national minority _ by far the majority in Punsk and the surrounding rolling farmland _ is on the outside looking in as the independence-seeking republic faces down Moscow. ``They are worried, scared, full of hope ... There is a lot of concern here because of their families. They are praying a lot for them,'' said the Rev. Ignacy Dziermiejko, the bilingual parish priest who wears a little Lithuanian flag pinned to his cassock. Residents of Punsk put up Lithuanian and Polish flags after watching the March 11 television broadcast when Lithuania's parliament declared independence from Moscow. Tensions heightened April 3 when the Soviets, without warning, shut the nearby border crossing between Poland and Lithuania, the republic's only road into another country. For the Lithuanians in Poland, the border closing meant no more visits with relatives on the other side, and an abrupt halt to contacts eased less than three years ago when the border was opened. For four decades, the Communist regimes in Moscow and Warsaw officially ignored the existence of the many ethnic minorities east and west of the border. At times, they repressed the minorities' efforts to maintain their own cultural, linguistic and religious traditions. There are 260,000 ethnic Poles living in Lithuania, part of which was Polish territory before World War II. About 5,000 ethnic Lithuanians make up 80 percent of the population of Punsk, named for the Lithuanian word for a place for hay. Another 5,000 live in the province, and there are an estimated 10,000 more ethnic Lithuanians spread across Poland. On a recent spring day, the bells at the 109-year-old Roman Catholic church in Punsk rang out in support of Lithuania as residents drafted a letter to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and spread word of a planned weekend demonstration. Masses are still said in Lithuanian at the church in Punsk, and Poland's only Lithuanian grammar school is here. The Baltic Lithuanian language _ completely unrelated to Slavic Polish _ is taught at the local high school. Poles and Lithuanians say they generally mix peacefully in this tranquil rural region. They are less and less willing to be manipulated, as they once were by governments exploiting ethnic differences for political ends. Poles here express a healthy respect for the way the Lithuanians ``stick together'' to protect their interests. And the Lithuanians appreciate the relatively better life in Poland, despite the country's considerable economic problems. For Lithuanians crossing the border, said one, ``Poland is the West.'' Both groups watch the events unfolding in Lithuania warily. To some in Poland, which last year became the first East bloc country to have a non-Communist government, the tense confrontation brings into question the Soviet government's resolve toward introducing democratic reforms. ``Nothing has changed. It took three minutes to close the border _ one phone call from Moscow,'' said Maciej Surel, a Polish businessman in the nearby heavily Lithuanian town of Sejny. An exhibit of paintings by Andrzej Strumillo, a well-known Polish artist of Lithuanian heritage, was turned back at the border crossing April 4. The paintings were en route to the Lithuanian city of Kaunas for a long-planned cultural exchange. ``It should be a warning to the United States that the Soviets can break a bilateral agreement,'' said Strumillo, who paints at a renovated farmhouse in Sejny. Strumillo's name shares a typically Lithuanian ending with that of the legendary Lithuanian ruler Jagiello. Jagiello's 1386 marriage to a Polish princess led to a gradual merger between Poland and Lithuania. But in 1795, when Poland was partitioned, Lithuania came under the control of Czarist Russia. Poland and Lithuania both returned as independent states after World War I. In 1920, Poland took the heavily Polish city of Vilnius by force to earn the lasting bitterness of Lithuanian patriots. Under the Hitler-Stalin pact, the Red Army swept through Lithuania and eastern Poland after the Nazis invaded Poland in 1939. The post-World War II border placed much of eastern Poland inside the Soviet Union and left Lithuania a Soviet republic.
