Foreign dignitaries representing 30 countries included South African black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, South African church leader Archbishop Desmond Tutu and Coretta Scott King, widow of slain U.S. civil rights leader Martin Luther King.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Unveil Alternative to Bush 1991 Budget
DOC.TEXT: House Democratic leaders announced today a fiscal 1991 budget which would cut defense spending to pay for new domestic programs and reducing the deficit. ``The world is changed greatly,'' said Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. ``The tasks this country has borne for the last 40 years ... have been crowned with great success'' and it was now time to address domestic priorities, he said. In the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, the Democrats propose $295 billion in military spending, compared to $303.3 billion proposed by Bush. The cuts would escalate sharply over five years for a total cut of $251 billion, compared to what it would be if the military budget kept pace with inflation. Of that total, $145 billion would go toward reducing the federal deficits and $106 billion would go to domestic programs. Other deficit reduction in the plan was unclear Wednesday, as Democratic leaders declined to provide details. The budget would call for $13.9 billion in tax increases, the same total proposed by President Bush. House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said he was proposing no domestic spending cuts deeper than those proposed by President Bush, and in many cases reductions he was proposing were rejected. Panetta said the budget recognized the shift the United States must make ``from military confrontation to economic leadership ... from a Cold War economy to a peacetime economy.'' Panetta's plan will be presented Thursday to the Budget Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Fires, Bombs, Wrecks, Poisonings Set Indians Wondering
DOC.TEXT: Fires, bombings and poisonings have killed more than 280 people in recent days, the result of lax safety regulations, ethnic violence and an overcrowded transportation system. During fire safety week this week, a train explosion burned 100 passengers to death in the east. Blazes in the capital destroyed 600 shops, 1,300 shacks and the capital's only convention center. In faraway Assam state, a wildfire ripped through 1,000 houses and three saw mills. A food poisoning outbreak during a marriage engagement party killed 150 people near Lucknow, in the north. Another outbreak near Rajkot, in the west, hospitalized 400. The connection between them all, said the respected Indian Express newspaper in an editorial Wednesday: ``They were eminently avoidable.'' ``These events reflect a general attitude,'' the Express said. ``We heed no law, we abide by no norm.'' The paper added another item to the list, a recently banned carcinogenic chemical that it says is still being used to manufacture soft drinks. The string of disasters has set India wondering. Asked one leading social scientist, Bhabani Sen Gupta: ``What is going on?'' With 880 million people on a land mass about one-third the size of the United States, India is prone to major disasters. Population density reaches more than 1,600 per square mile in New Delhi and five times that in the slums of Bombay and Calcutta. More than 10 million people ride trains every day and passenger cars are jammed, with people often perching on the roofs. Colorful buses, their cabins dedicated to any one of a pantheon of Hindu gods, also move millions a day. The weight this number of people places on India's railway and road network is a recipe for trouble. The two national wire services, Press Trust of India and United News of India, routinely move stories of buses careening down ravines, killing scores. Add ethnic violence to this overtaxed infrastructure and the formula can become explosive. In the far northeastern state of Assam last Thursday, extremists from the Bodo tribe bombed railway lines, a road and a major bridge, killing 25 people and cutting the already isolated state off the Indian heartland. The Bodo tribe, which worships spirits believed to inhabit rocks and trees, wants a separate homeland. A day earlier, a bomb exploded on a crowded commuter train in the bustling western metropolis of Bombay and injured 31. A militant Moslem group, Mujahedeen Kashmir, fighting for the secession of Kashmir from India, claimed responsibility. More than 250 people have been killed in that fight since the government launched a crackdown in January. On Friday, a bomb blew up a crowded bus in New Delhi, killing six people and wounding dozens more. A bomb blast killed a woman in a village 70 miles north of Bombay on Tuesday. There were no claims of responsibility in either incident. Eight bombs were found planted on a northern railroad track Tuesday. ``I think the educated Indian has to ask himself whether we're not going mad,'' said Sen Gupta in an interview. Most of this week's disasters appear unrelated to terrorism, but that, he said, could give even more cause to worry. ``We have only ourselves to blame then,'' he said. ``Life has become cheap in India.'' The train disaster in Patna that left 100 dead was apparently triggered by a leaking gas cylinder. But after the fire started, none of the passengers could stop the train because the alarm chain had been removed, media reports said. In India, transporting explosive substances on passenger trains is against the law. But, as the National Herald newspaper observed, ``If the passengers are able to violate the laws with impunity, it is because of the indifference of the railway authorities.'' The Times of India blamed pesticides in the food for the food poisoning deaths near Lucknow. It said stringent regulations controlling the use of the deadly substances were routinely ignored. Problems were compounded by a physicians' strike in the area. In New Delhi, the fire in the government's main convention center, which broke out during a conference of police chiefs, came two years after the fire department declared the building unsafe. Nothing had been done to repair it. Firetrucks rushed to the scene still draped in bunting that read, ``Fire Services Week April 15-21,'' a week dedicated to fire safety nationwide. The blaze in the Sardar Bazaar, which gutted 600 shops, occurred in a crowded area, whose residents and merchants had long demanded better water pressure. So had the inhabitants of the shantytown in Badola village, just outside New Delhi. On Wednesday, all major newspapers called for reforms. But one chief editor reported that none of his colleagues were really optimistic much could be done. Said the Express: ``No disaster, however terrible, seems to make a difference.''

DOC.HEAD: Ammo in Economic Arsenals of Lithuania, Soviet Union
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here's a look at what is at stake economically for Lithuania and the Soviet Union if the Baltic republic is isolated:
IN THE SOVIET ECONOMIC ARSENAL _ Lithuania receives all of its oil, gas and diesel fuel from the Soviet Union, paying subsidized prices. At world market prices, Lithuania would run a deficit of $700 million for oil alone. _ It also receives all of its metals, cotton, tractors and automobiles from the Soviet Union. _ It receives 58 percent of its sugar from Cuba, via the Soviet Union. _ It receives 37 percent of its concentrated fertilizer from the Soviet Union. Cotton, 100 percent. _ It received 400,000 tons of grain from the Soviets in 1989. _ It has only four to five days' supply of newsprint, and the Soviets could cut off the supply, thus shutting down its newspapers.
IN LITHUANIA'S ECONOMIC ARSENAL _ The republic sends to the Soviet Union 1.5 percent of the nation's total production, including household electrical meters (100 percent); television set components (70 percent); and tractor components (30 percent). _ It produces much more meat (530,000 metric tons in 1987), eggs (1.2 million metric tons in 1987), milk (3.1 million metric tons in 1987) and other dairy products than it consumes, so it could cut off the rest of the Soviet Union from its surplus. _ Textile products are shipped to factories in the Soviet Union, including one plant in Leningrad that employs 18,000 workers. _ If the Soviets shut down an oil pipeline to a major refinery in the town of Mazeikiai, that would also mean the republics of Estonia, Latvia and Byelorussia would be cut off. A shutdown of a natural gas pipeline also would interrupt the flow to Kaliningrad, part of the Russian republic west of Lithuania. _ Lithuania might demand world prices for exporting oil, gas and other products through its Baltic ports, including Klaipeda.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Angered By NATO Crash, Opposes Continued Cold War-Level Training
DOC.TEXT: Officials angered by another NATO air collision over a West German city called Wednesday for cuts in training flights that continue despite relaxed East-West relations. Canada suspended all interceptor training flights of its F-18 jets pending an investigation into the Tuesday collision, which killed one pilot and showered parts of the city of Karlsruhe with flaming debris. ``In times of East-West detente, our people can no longer be told that military air maneuvers must continue at their present extent for the sake of defense preparedness,'' said Lothar Spaeth, the Christian Democratic governor of Baden-Wuerttemberg state, which includes Karlsruhe. The government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who heads the Christian Democrats, has given its full support to NATO and the alliance's stated need for continued air maneuvers. But the Defense Ministry in Bonn said it had ``urgently asked the Canadian air force to quickly and comprehensively clear up the causes of the accident.'' The ministry, in a statement to the news media, said it asked the Canadians to examine whether ``interceptor training with F-18s'' should be stopped until the reasons for the accident are known. The Canadian Forces said it was complying with the Defense Ministry's request. In interceptor flights, two jets simulate a chase. The Canadians said air-to-ground training of the F-18s, in which the aircraft simulate support for ground forces, will continue. A spokeswoman for the Canadian Forces in Lahr said the flight recorders from both planes in Tuesday's collision had been found but the cause of the crash was not known. One Canadian pilot was killed and another broke both heels after ejecting safely and landing on a highway after the accident Tuesday. He was listed in good condition in a hospital. Two West Germans were slightly injured by debris. West German news media said it was a miracle no civilians were killed in Karlsruhe, a southwestern city of 285,000 people. Burning debris crushed a number of cars and damaged buildings. In 1988, military jet crashes at the Ramstein U.S. air base and in the city of Remscheid killed German civilians as well as NATO pilots. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of the opposition Social Democrats, demanded an immediate stop to NATO practice flights over densely settled West German areas. Friedel Laepple, interior minister for Saarland state who is also a Social Democrat, demanded a general halt to all military training flights over West Germany. Each NATO country has responsibility for training its own pilots in West Germany, where more NATO forces are based than in any other country. Tuesday's crash was NATO's first major air accident since the hard-line Communist government in East Germany fell in October. The new government will negotiate a merger with West Germany, which would eliminate one of the most heavily guarded borders in the world. Soviet troops have begun pulling out of Eastern European nations since a wave of democratic reform swept across the region last year, and superpower arms reduction talks have accelerated.

DOC.HEAD: San Andreas Fault Alive And Well 84 Years After Great Quake
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, ``One or ...'' to CORRECT to `faze' sted `phase'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-NorCal Quake, Bjt
LaserPhotos FX1,2
DOC.TEXT: On the 84th anniversary of the Great Quake, folks who live in the earth-churning San Francisco region had plenty reason to pay close attention to the pulse of the San Andreas Fault. They got a chilling reminder when a series of earthquakes rumbled through Northern California on Wednesday, shattering nerves but little else. The tremors along the San Andreas hit about 90 minutes after 150 survivors of the 1906 quake and subsequent inferno gathered in the predawn darkness to talk about the time the earth shook and the sky glowed. The group has held a reunion every year since 1924 at Lotta's Fountain on Market Street, where they observe a moment of silence at 5:13 a.m., when the estimated 8.3-magnitude quake struck on April 18, 1906. Some survivors were just a few days old 84 years ago, others were old enough to remember camping in city parks while fires raged throughout the city. One man recalled how he was tossed from the first floor window of the orphanage he lived in as the children were evacuated. The reunion organizer, Taren Sapienza, said some survivors weren't bothered by Wednesday's earthquakes. They were en route to paint gold a fire hydrant that continued to work after the 1906 quake and helped save a neighborhood. ``One or two of the survivors commented that it didn't faze them at all as they had experienced THE big one,'' said Sapienza. The Great Quake killed hundreds, perhaps thousands, destroyed about 30,000 buildings and left 225,000 homeless. About 400,000 square miles were believed rattled when a 270-mile zone of the 650-mile fault slipped. In a titanic shrug of the plates that separate the North American continent from the Pacific Basin, the western side of the rupture moved north, while the eastern side moved south. One geologist said it was as though ``San Francisco and Los Angeles were being drawn closer together.'' For decades it was believed that about 700 people died in the quake. But in recent years, research by San Francisco City Archivist Gladys Hansen documented at least 2,500 deaths, and she indicated the real toll may be much higher. Mrs. Hansen reached her conclusions by examining public records, obituaries and clippings from old newspapers and letters from people telling her of relatives who died. She found many quake victims died in other cities after an estimated 250,000 people evacuated San Francisco on boats and trains within three days of the catastrophe. Nearly every city from Eureka near the Oregon line south to Salinas near Monterey sustained damage. All over the city, refugees fled with what belongings they could gather. Whole families harnessed themselves to wagons to haul their household treasures to safe areas. Soup kitchens fed the homeless in Union Square. In a New York City newspaper, a reporter wrote that ``the gayest, lightest-hearted city of this continent is no more...'' Opera singer Enrico Caruso was in San Francisco at the time, booked at the Grand Opera House in the role of Don Jose in ``Carmen.'' He was asleep at the Palace Hotel when the quake hit. He got to the street in his night clothes. ``... I run into the street,'' he said later. ``I see buildings shaking. That night I sleep on hard ground.'' Caruso fled the city, vowing never to return.

DOC.HEAD: Court Hears Arguments on Testimony in Child-Abuse Cases
With AM-Scotus Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Sixth Amendment to the Constitution guarantees that a person accused of a crime may see his accuser face-to-face. Now, the Supreme Court is debating whether that applies when the accuser is a sexually abused child. In two cases argued before the court Wednesday, the justices focused on the rights of the defendents more than on the rights and possible traumatization of children. In a 1986 case in which a Maryland day-care center operator, Sandra Ann Craig, was convicted of abusing a 6-year-old girl, the child testified by closed-circuit television. That is the practice in many states. The conviction and 10-year sentence were overturned by a higher state court on grounds that the judge should have questioned the girl and other children in Mrs. Craig's presence, however briefly. The state court stopped short of invalidating the Maryland law that allows young children to testify by closed-circuit TV, outside the presence of the defendant. ``This woman could be sentenced to 15 years on the basis of the testimony of a child she wasn't even in the room with,'' Justice Antonin Scalia said about Mrs. Craig. Scalia noted that the judge permitted the televised appearance on the basis of testimony of a social worker that the child would be upset. Maryland Attorney General J. Joseph Curran Jr. argued that a social worker had told the trial judge that if the child were forced to testify in front of Mrs. Craig, she ``would probably stop talking, withdraw, and curl up in a ball.'' ``That's something of an emotional trauma, but this women is going to jail for 15 years,'' Scalia said. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said: ``I suppose it's possible a rape victim or a victim of a Mafia-type crime would be so terrified, the same argument could be made.'' But William H. Murphy, representing Mrs. Craig, suggested that substituting a television appearance for live testimony was an experiment at the expense of his client. ``This is a bad experiment,'' he said. ``The truth-seeking function is not served. ``We take the position there is much more to the right to confrontation than was permitted in this case,'' Murphy said, adding that televised testimony acts ``to deprive a defendant of one of the tools'' of his defense. In the second case, the issue was whether the right of Laura Lee Wright of Boise, Idaho, to confront her accuser was violated by the testimony of a pediatrician who had examined a 2-year-old girl allegedly abused by the girl's father, Robert Giles. Mrs. Wright and Giles were convicted of sexually abusing Mrs. Wright's two daughters. The 5-year-old child was not Giles'. Mrs. Wright was sentenced to 20 years in prison, but the Idaho Supreme Court threw out her conviction in June and ordered a new trial. The state court ruled that the trial judge wrongly allowed a doctor who examined the 2-year-old to testify about what she told him. Giles' case was not addressed by the Supreme Court. Idaho Attorney General Jim Jones told the high court that the girl's older sister testified about sexual activities and that her statements were corroborated by the doctor's testimony. The 2-year-old told the doctor: ``Daddy does do this with me, but a little more with my sister than with me.'' The girl was referring to Giles, according to court documents. During that argument, Scalia interjected: ``I wouldn't want to be a defendant in such circumstances. I get no shot at the child.'' Decisions are expected by July.

DOC.HEAD: Father Finds Son's Body Five Weeks After Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st and 5th grafs, `Reeves, who ...' with 1 graf each to DELETE age from first graf
DOC.TEXT: A coroner admitted Wednesday he mistakenly identified the remains of a pet rabbit as a year-old boy killed with his mother in a fire. ``It was the body of something,'' said Dr. C. Dupha Reeves, Wayne County coroner. ``Because I was told a mother and child died in the fire, I assumed it was the body of the child. I misidentified it.'' Gary Rotondo discovered his son's body last week when he returned to his mobile home after the Feb. 28 fire. He had thought the remains of his live-in girlfriend, Vickie Lee Evans, 18, and their son, John, had been cremated. Police have reopened their investigation into the deaths. Reeves, who is 80 and was first elected coroner 26 years ago, said he did not go to the fire scene on the day of the blaze. He saw the bodies later at the Newark-Wayne Community Hospital, but did not do an autopsy or try to identify the remains through records or fingerprints. He said it would have been impossible to make an accurate identification because, ``There was nothing left of them.'' Rotondo's father, Paul, said police told him an autopsy would now be performed on the remains even though only a badly burned torso was found. He said the boy's X-rays and records were on file at the hospital. Autopsies are not required by New York state law, but several pathologists say they should be performed in fire cases. ``Once you have burned, charred remains, distinguishing between animals and humans, superficially, externally, can be difficult,'' said Dr. Michael Baden, co-director of the state police forensics unit. Wayne County is about 15 miles east of Rochester.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Workers Allege Abuse by U.S. Border Patrol
DOC.TEXT: A human rights group said Wednesday that U.S. Border Patrol agents have mistreated and even killed Mexicans trying to illegally enter the United States. But Border Patrol representatives said the agents are defending themselves along an increasingly violent U.S.-Mexican border, where they facndits and aliens who try to force their way into the United States. Violence along the border was the subject of a hearing sponsored by the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on human rights and international organizations. ``It is clear that somete attack from bahing is wrong on our borders,'' said Rep. Gus Yatron, D-Pa., the subcommittee chairman. ``I wish I could say that violent confrontations between Americans and undocumented immigrants are isolated, but, unfortunately, they are not,'' Rep. Jim Bates, D-Calif., said. He said the American Friends Service Committee, a Quaker humanitarian organization, has documented 20 people in the last four years who were shot and killed near San Diego by the border patrol, an arm of the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service. The committee also released a report on 380 cases of alleged human rights violations between May 1988 and May 1989. They occurred near San Diego; Rio Grande, Texas; Tuscon, Ariz.; El Paso, TexasP) _ A children's advocacy group said Wednesday it wants the government to investigate whether a long-range microphone marketed in a line of high-tech toys is an illegal eavesdropping device. ``Part of it is just a pretend spy kit,'' said Peggy Charren, president of Action for Children's Television. ``The problem is that the listening device works. It is not then a toy; it is an eavesdropping device.'' Tyco Industries Inc. manufactures the ``Spy-Tech'' toy line, which includes the microphone, an undercover vest, binoculars, an intruder alert, periscope, fingerprint kit, walkie talkies and a hidden camera. The toys, each sold separately, are designed for children 8 years and older. Charren said ACT this week would ask the Federal Communications Commission and the Federal Trade Commission to investigate the microphone, which picks up sound up to 100 feet away. That group wants the FTC to investigate Tyco's print and broadcast advertisements for the product. ``We find this criticism so amazing,'' said Jim Alley, senior vice president for marketing at Tyco. ``We've developed a toy line that is totally non-violent ... it's safe, it's fun and non-violent.'' Alley said there was only a ``remote possibility'' the microphone, which sells for under $20, could be used for eavesdropping because ``it only works in line of sight. ... It won't work through walls, it won't work through windows and it won't work through doors.'' Alley said the full-size hand-operatied red boom mike can't be concealed. The television advertisements for the microphone show two children honing in on the sound of a man's whistling, but Charren warned it could be used for other listening. ``That message of listening to somebody when he doesn't know you're listening is one anybody can get from the advertisement,'' she said. Rudolph Brewington, a privacy advocate and Washington-based free-lance journalist, said in an April 10 letter to Tyco president Richard Grey that sale and advertisement of the toy ``amounts to gross corporate irresponsibility.'' The company is ``providing the means and encouragement to young children to surreptiously spy on their unsuspecting playmates, friends, families and neighbors,'' Brewington said. He contends the device violates both U.S. criminal law and postal regulations that prohibit the manufacture, distribution or sending through the mail devices that are ``primarily useful for the purpose of the surreptitious interception of wire or oral communications.'' An aide to Rep. Ronald Dellums said the device would be illegal under a bill proposed by the California Democrat. ``If a child was listening in on three of its playmates across the playground that would be illegal,'' said George Withers, legislative director for the congressman's Capitol Hill office. The proposal, the Privacy Assurance Act of 1989, would require that all participants in a conversation consent to its interception by listening or recording devices in instances not involved in law enforcement cases. The bill, which has been referred to the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime, would also require that sound- or voice-activated recorders emit an audible beep-tone to alert a speaker that his communication is being recorded.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Says Wheat Production Could Increase Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Wheat production could rise sharply this year and help replenish dwindling U.S. stockpiles, an Agriculture Department report said Wednesday. The wheat inventory on March 1 was the smallest in 15 years and could be down to 442 million bushels by the start of the new marketing year June 1, according to USDA estimates. That would be the smallest June 1 wheat reserve since 1975. Analysts said that despite the tight supply situation, 1990 wheat prices through mid-March dropped about 10 percent, reflecting prospects for a larger harvest this year. ``Winter wheat acreage seeded last fall was up nearly 4 percent from a year earlier, and 71 percent of the crop was reported in good or excellent condition as of mid-April,'' the report said. Farmers who normally plant spring wheat indicated in a survey announced by USDA on March 30 that they intend to reduce their acreage this year. As a result, the new report said, the total wheat acreage may be up only 1.2 percent from last year. ``But some of last year's wheat area was counted twice because farmers reseeded damaged winter wheat acreage with spring wheat,'' the report said. ``Thus, this year's area increase is understated.'' Additionally, the report said, winter wheat states say that ``this season's winterkill has been lower, so harvested area may post larger gains than planted area.'' The larger harvested acreage, assuming per-acre yields recover, points to a 1990 U.S. wheat crop ``substantially larger'' than last year's 2.04 billion bushels. Production dropped to about 1.8 billion bushels in 1988, largely reflecting drought losses. Wheat market prices in the 1989-90 marketing year that soon will end are forecast by USDA to average in the range of $3.70 to $3.75 per bushel, compared with $3.72 in 1988-89 and $2.57 in 1987-88.

DOC.HEAD: Yellowstone Wildlife Manager Watches Church Developments Warily
DOC.TEXT: Development near Yellowstone National Park is ``taking bites out of an ecological cookie,'' and an apocalyptic group's giant fallout shelter is biting a critical section, a park manager says. In addition to the church development, where 31,000 gallons of fuel leaked last week, a gold mine recently opened just north of Yellowstone and a large platinum mine operates 30 to 40 miles north of the park. There also is talk of another gold mine opening near the park's northeast corner. And in the summer of 1988, forest fires scorched about a third of Yellowstone. ``If we can't hold the line in Yellowstone National Park on these kinds of issues ... I'm not so sure we can save these kinds of islands,'' said Stu Coleman, chief of resource management for America's oldest national park. The fuel spilled at the Church Universal and Triumphant's 12,500-acre ranch, and Gardiner officials worried there may be more spills. The church, whose members are preparing for a global nuclear catastrophe, has brought in heavy machinery to build the huge underground shelter complex in a high mountain meadow a few miles north of Yellowstone. Park managers and local residents learned of the construction last summer, and immediately expressed fear about potential environmental consequences. Those fears were realized last week when diesel fuel and gasoline spilled from three of 35 tanks buried next to the shelter. State officials fear the remaining 32 tanks also may have been damaged by shifting ground during the spring thaw. Church officials have brought in more equipment to clean up the spill. State health officials said Tuesday they will seek a court order to halt construction at the site. The department plans to file its lawsuit on Friday. The spill occurred near a Yellowstone River tributary that is a spawning stream for cutthroat trout. But the tributary enters the Yellowstone downstream from the park, so any pollution would not directly affect park waters. Of more concern is the impact of the complex and the cleanup on the wild forest that stretches from the 2 million-acre park past the shelters and far north into Montana. The southern Gallatin Range is considered critical habitat for the federally protected grizzly bear. It is home to elk, moose, deer, bald eagles and other species that inhabit the park. But increased human activity, like the extensive construction at the shelter site and the intensive cleanup, will drive the bears away, Coleman said. ``Grizzlies don't like to be in areas where people are,'' he said. Coleman said the shelter is a prime example of potentially damaging private development near park boundaries, nibbling away at a protected ecosystem. ``I kind of liken development to taking a bite out of an ecological cookie,'' he said. ``When someone wants to take a bite out of the most important part of the cookie, then that's reason for concern.'' The church bought its ranch from publisher Malcolm Forbes in 1981. Since then, it has bought 18,000 more acres, moved its headquarters here from Southern California and sponsored several housing developments. Hundreds of followers have moved into the area, and many have built fallout shelters at housing developments near Emigrant, a ranching community 30 miles north of Gardiner. The church is led by Elizabeth Clare Prophet, who claims she receives and passes on to members messages from a group of souls known as the Ascended Masters. She warned her followers that March and April would be dangerous times. The group owns some of the area's best winter range for elk, deer, bison and antelope, Coleman said. During winter, these animals migrate out of the park into lower valleys and rangeland north of Gardiner. ``It's kind of hard because we don't own all that pasture, and we're trying to take care of the animals on that pasture,'' Coleman said. In late 1986, church developments near Gardiner were halted when the state conducted a two-year environmental review. As part of the review, the church agreed to mitigate the impacts of its projects on wildlife. But construction of the shelter was not included. Church officials said they didn't decide to build the shelter until after the review was completed in March 1989. State officials said they'd been duped, and decided earlier this year to reopen the review. Church officials have said they won't occupy the fallout shelter area, except in case of emergency, and so don't expect to have a significant effect on wildlife. They have often labeled park officials' comments as hypocritical, pointing to six major developments in the park, including hotels. ``Two wrongs don't make a right,'' Coleman responded. He said park officials have tried to adjust the placement of developments in wildlife areas.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Refuses to Rescind Laws, But Asks Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania refused Wednesday to bow to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's ultimatum that it rescind independence-oriented laws, but offered to pass no more such measures if the Kremlin starts immediate talks. There were no signs that Gorbachev's threatened economic sanctions against the Baltic republic had been implemented, with critical oil and gas supplies flowing normally at its refineries and pipelines. Soviet Deputy Oil and Gas Minister Aklim Mukhamedzyanov told the Tass news agency that reports of an energy cutoff to Lithuania ``are completely groundless.'' He said the Soviet Council of Ministers issued no such orders. After Lithuania's Supreme Council legislature approved its official response to Gorbachev, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis warned him that an oil and gas embargo would hurt other republics as well as Lithuania. ``An economic blockade would influence Latvia, Estonia and the Kaliningrad region of Russia,'' Landsbergis was quoted as telling a news conference. ``That would resemble an angry man beating himself,'' Eduardas Potasinskas of Lithuanian TV quoted Landsbergis as saying. But anticipating a possible Soviet embargo, the Supreme Council urged Lithuanian factories and consumers to ``prepare themselves for spiritual endurance and strict economy on all consumption.'' It did not annouce specific conservation measures. At the end of two days of sometimes heated debate, the Supreme Council drafted a letter to Gorbachev promising that if talks began before May 1, it would not pass any more measures to implement its March 11 declaration of independence. That offer represented an effort to compromise with Moscow, but was unlikely to be accepted by the Soviet leadership. In their resolution _ titled ``On the Expansion of Relations Between the Republic of Lithuania and the U.S.S.R.'' _ members of the Supreme Council reaffirmed their declaration of independence, and also appealed to Gorbachev not to use violence against Lithuanians or impose the economic sanctions he threatened on Friday. Gorbachev said that unless Lithuania rolled back several laws supporting the declaration of independence, he would impose an embargo on key supplies to the Baltic republic of 3.8 million residents. He did not spell out what materials would be cut off, saying only that they would be those goods the Soviet Union sells abroad for hard currency _ meaning oil and natural gas. Lithuania is entirely dependent upon the Soviet Union for all its oil and gas, and petroleum products are the Soviet Union's most profitable export. Lithuania's energy minister, Leonas Asmantas, said Wednesday that oil and gas were being delivered as usual. The day before, Asmantas reported receiving unofficial information that crude oil supplies and natural gas would be reduced Wednesday. In addition, Lithuanian gas officials said they received a telegram from a regional Soviet energy official stating that supplies of natural gas would be curtailed sharply on the orders of the government. Lithuanian TV reported that residents saw Soviet troops in several armored vehicles stopped Wednesday morning near a pumping station at the Mazheikiai refinery in the northwestern part of the republic, but there was no interruption of service, Potasinskas said. The presence of soldiers at the site was unusual, he added. Sales of gasoline to Lithuanian motorists have tripled this week as residents reacted to Gorbachev's threat with panic-buying, but stocks were adequate and no rationing was anticipated, Asmantas said. Gorbachev's 48-hour deadline passed Sunday night amid the three-day Easter holiday in the heavily Roman Catholic republic. The Supreme Council did not convene until Tuesday, although Landsbergis and other leaders held an emergency meeting Monday to assess the impact of an economic embargo. It was the latest in a series of ultimatums Gorbachev has issued since Lithuanians declared their independence. In most cases, such as a demand that they surrender their private firearms, he has not reacted when they refused to give in. In addition to the threats, the Kremlin has sent tanks and military vehicles through Lithuania's capital, Vilnius, rounded up Lithuanins who deserted from the Red Army, seized buildings and barred Western journalists from Lithuania. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said action by Moscow against Lithuania could doom commercial relations between the Soviet Union and the United States. ``It's very difficult to see some of the commercial aspects of our relationship surviving the use of force or coercion'' against Lithuania, Baker said. In a separate letter to Gorbachev, the Lithuanian legislature expressed ``regrets on the position and methods chosen by the U.S.S.R.'' ``On our part, as earlier, we are prepared to discuss any issues, taking into consideration all justified interests of the Soviet Union, foremost those of its citizens and those of a strategic nature,'' the letter said. Legislators said they were forming a delegation led by Bronius Kuzmickas, vice president of the Supreme Council, to travel to Moscow for possible talks. A previous delegation met with Gorbachev adviser Alexander N. Yakovlev but made no headway toward settling the dispute. Lithuania picked up support Wednesday from neighboring Poland, with the Solidarity delegation to the Polish parliament adopting a resolution expressing concern over the ``growing pressure'' being exerted by Moscow. The delegation also suggesting that Warsaw assist in negotiations between the republic and the Kremlin.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Lithuanian Parliament's Resolution
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Wording in point No. 2 is cq.
DOC.TEXT:
Here is the text of the resolution adopted Wednesday by Lithuania's Supreme Council, or parliament. The resolution was translated into English by the parliament:
Resolution of the Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania On the Expansion of Relations Between the Republic of Lithuania and the Soviet Union The Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania, in confirming its loyalty to the acts of March 11, 1990, and consistently striving for the consolidation of the independence of the Republic of Lithuania, being convinced that solutions satisfactory to both the Soviet Union and Lithuania can be found only by an avenue of dialogue, resolves: 1. Not to adopt new political legislative acts during the period of preliminary parliamentary consulations between Lithuania and the U.S.S.R., if they were to begin, until May 1, 1990. 2. To invite the Soviet Union to refuse to use any type of coercion, as well as economic, against the Republic of Lithuania and its citizens. 3. To suggest that the Soviet Union begin consultations concerning negotiations with a delegation empowered by the Republic of Lithuania. 4. To send a delegation empowered by the Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania and led by the Vice-President of the Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania, Bronius Kuzmickas, concerning the conditions of negotiations. 5. To urge industrial organizations and citizens of Lithuania to already prepare themselves for spiritual endurance and strict economy on all consumption.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Endorse Use Chemotherapy to Treat Advanced Colon Cancer
DOC.TEXT: A chemotherapy combination that includes a drug used to deworm farm animals was endorsed Wednesday by a panel of experts as a standard treatment after patients in a late stage of colon cancer undergo surgery. Twelve cancer specialist assembled by the National Institutes of Health recommended that all physicians offer the drug combination of 5-fluorouracil, or 5-FU, and levamisole to patients who have been surgically treated for stage III colon cancer. The recommendation, in effect, endorses as standard treatment a chemotherapy that was tested in a National Institute of Cancer clinical trial that ended in October. That national trial among 1,300 patients found that 5-FU and levamisole reduced death and cancer recurrence by up to a third. Levamisole is a drug widely used to remove worms from the intestinal tract of cows, horses, goats, sheep and even elephants; 5-FU is a standard cancer drug that has been used for about 30 years. ``The battle has not been won'' in colorectal cancer, said Dr. Glenn D. Steele Jr., a Harvard professor who chaired the panel of specialists. ``Many, many answers still need to come in before we are even close to winning the battle once someone is diagnosed with colon or rectal cancer.'' One of the unanswered questions, he said, is how exactly levamisole works to reduce the recurrence of colon cancer. The precise action of the drug in cancer treatment is not known. ``It's a little disquieting to not understand why it works,'' said committee member Dr. David P. Winchester, a Chicago physician and a director of the American College of Surgeons. But Steele said the consensus panel said it felt there was enough clinical evidence to merit recommending the combination for stage III colon cancer. The panel also recommended that surgery alone be used to treat patients in stage I of the disease, suggesting the use of both chemotherapy and radiation for stages II and III of rectal cancer. The experts also called for more clinical drug trials to better define treatment combinations for patients at all disease stages after surgery. Post-surgical therapy for colorectal cancer patients has been an area of intense study among physicians worldwide for decades, but clincial drug trials have failed until recent years to show the additional treatment to be of any benefit. Because of poor results and severe toxic reactions to some chemotherapies, many patients are treated only with surgery. For late stage patients, the cancer almost invariably returns. Colon and rectal cancer is the third leading cause of cancer death in the United States. There are more than 150,000 new colorectal cancers diagnosed annually. Of the new cases, the panel said, about 55,000 colon cancer patients and 20,000 rectal cancer patients are defined as high risk. About half of that high risk group will die within five years. In its report, the committee said that 5-FU and levamisole appears to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence by 41 percent and lower the overall death rate by 33 percent. ``Overal survival percentages at 3{ years were estimated to be 71 percent vs. 55 percent for the control group,'' the report said. The control group received no chemotherapy. Side effects from 5-FU and levamisole, the committee said, ``were well tolerated.'' The panel said it found that patients at stage I of colon cancer had a survival rate of 80 percent to 90 percent after five years with surgery alone. Thus, the experts said post-surgical therapy for this early stage of the disease was not recommended. Levamisole is available for human consumption in the United States only from the National Institute of Cancer. The NCI started providing the drug free to the physicians of stage III colon cancer patients in October after ending the national trial of the drug. The drug, manufactured by a Belgium company, is expected to be available for general prescriptions this summer, said NCI spokesman Dr. Mike Hamilton. He said the delay is caused by a manufacturing problem with packaging. Steele said the consensus panel recommended that physicians adopt a standard scale for evaluating the stages of colorectal cancer. The scale uses the size and spread of the primary tumor, the involvement of lymph nodes and the presence of metastasis, or spread to distant organs, to classify the disease stage. The scale ranges from stage zero to stage IV.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Threat Lessens, Third World Challenges Increase
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has a ``significantly decreased'' capability of winning a conventional war against NATO because of Moscow's eroding confidence in its Warsaw Pact allies, the Joint Chiefs of Staffs said Wednesday. The chiefs, in their first international threat assessment since the Berlin Wall was opened in November, said the likelihood of a conventional war escalating into a nuclear one ``continues to decline.'' The annual study, prepared by Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the joint chiefs, is supposed to present a ``big picture'' for the military in planning defense strategies and budgets. Congress was given a classified version of the report last month. The report comes amid calls from lawmakers for sharp cuts in Pentagon spending in light of reduced superpower tensions and repeated warnings from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney that caution should be used as fiscal constraints force changes in the nation's defenses. The study expresses a restrained sense of optimism about the revolutionary changes that have swept across Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``A dramatically different security environment is emerging that is principally characterized by a diminished Soviet threat, reduced defense resources and an increasingly complex world,'' the study stated. ``These realities imply a reshaping of U.S. security policy, strategy, force posture and capabilities.'' But the study also tempers such observations with warnings that the United States must be ``wary and ready'' in case Soviet reforms are reversed or U.S. security interests are challenged by threats from other sources, such as drugs, terrorism, regional conflicts or Third World nations armed with ballistic missiles. ``The challenge is to reconcile enduring objectives and tasks with repostured and restructured forces without foreclosing options for hedging against new or renewed threats,'' concluded the study, which is formally titled the ``Joint Military Net Assessment.'' The report says that while the transformation of domestic and foreign Soviet policies ``is incomplete and may be reversible,'' there is a ``broad agreement that the Soviet leadership has decided to reverse a 20-year pattern of growth in military spending and force posture.'' The study notes that while the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact have ``significant force advantages, unilateral force reductions and political change in Eastern Europe are eroding the Soviets' capability to conduct successful, sustained conventional operations against NATO. Additionally, their confidence in the reliability of non-Soviet Warsaw Pact forces ... is diminished.'' Thus, the study states, ``the Soviets have to consider the prospect that they would have to conduct a theater offensive against NATO primarily on their own. ... Consequently, their capability to accomplish theater strategic objectives is significantly decreased.'' In the unlikely event that such a war did occur, ``the potential for termination of such a conflict on terms favorable to the United States is much improved,'' the study said. It also said that ``the probability that NATO would need to resort to the use of nonstrategic nuclear forces is assessed to decrease'' as conventional-force reductions produce a better balance between the armies of Eastern and Western Europe. But the foundation of the U.S. strategy of deterrence remains its triad of nuclear weapons, the study said. ``Investment in a ballistic missile defense system is needed as a minimum to counter the possibility of a Soviet missile attack against the United States and the potential caused by the proliferation of advanced missile systems among Third World nations,'' the report said. Yet in the same paragraph, the study added: ``In any case, the risk of nuclear deterrence failing is assessed to be low and at this moment to be decreasing.''

DOC.HEAD: Union: Air Traffic Control Center Short on Chairs
DOC.TEXT: After being plagued for years by a shortage of controllers, Chicago's air traffic control center has enough people, but members of the controllers union said Wednesday there's another problem: not enough chairs. During one shift last week at the Chicago Air Route Traffic Control Center in suburban Aurora, one controller sat on a wooden box because no more chairs were available, said union chapter Chairman Jim Poole. The center handles more than 2 million planes a year, including cross-country flights and flights into and out of O'Hare International, the nation's busiest airport. The lack of chairs poses no danger to air safety and no controllers have been injured, said officials with the Federal Aviation Administration and the union, the National Air Traffic Control Association. But FAA spokesman Mort Edelstein said there's a nationwide problem with broken chairs. ``We bought 10,000 of these chairs from 1985 to 1986. Five percent to 9 percent are considered not usable today, and about 20 percent are considered broken but usable,'' Edelstein said. ``The agency has had difficulty getting replacement parts for broken chairs,'' he said. ``They have to go to Oklahoma City for the parts, and there's a backlog of orders.'' Ron Downen, a union representative at the Aurora center, said there were at least 12 broken chairs among the 121 chairs he counted in the control room on a shift this week when 143 people were on duty. The center employs about 400 controllers, said FAA spokesman Mike Ficocello. Not all the controllers on the shift were handling planes because of lunch breaks, rest breaks and training sessions, so all working controllers had chairs, Downen said. But bad weather or computer troubles could require more controllers at radar screens at once, threatening a chair shortage, he said. ``We need more chairs before the thunderstorm season hits,'' said Kevin Christy, another union area representative. The FAA believes the center has enough usable chairs, said spokesman Bob Buckhorn in Washington. ``We do have a problem in maintenance, and we're expediting a program to ensure those broken chairs are either fixed or replaced,'' Buckhorn said. ``Anywhere we find a shortage of chairs, we're taking steps to correct that. ``It's not interfering with the operation of the center,'' he said. The chairs were designed to reduce fatigue and aid posture, and were the best chairs available that met controllers' requirements, Buckhorn said. But Christy said the chairs aren't as sturdy as the ones they replaced. ``They get hard use because they're sat in 24 hours a day, rocked back and forth, rolled across the aisles,'' Christy said. ``But the chairs weren't built to last. They don't even look sturdy. ``The arms are falling off, the wheels are getting stuck and the backs break off. They're comfortable, but they replaced chairs we had years ago that were comfortable, too, and could stand a lot of abuse.'' The FAA has had trouble in the past filling vacancies at the center because it is one of the busiest in the air traffic control network. But a program giving controllers at busier centers extra pay has largely eliminated the problem.

DOC.HEAD: Black Schools Urged to Produce More College Instructors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs to UPDATE with Ag Department program
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials challenged presidents of historically black colleges and universities Wednesday to inspire 10 percent of their students to seek collegiate teaching careers. ``We've got to do something about faculty members in higher education institutions,'' said Leonard Haynes III, assistant education secretary for post-secondary schools. ``If you would just put a target of 10 percent of your student body and cause them to want to go on to get a masters and doctorate, we will solve the shortage of black Ph.D.s in a period of five to seven years,'' said Haynes, alluding to statistics that show only four blacks nationwide received doctorates in mathematics in 1988. Haynes told the conference that ``too many of our students now are from the `Now Generation.' ``They want everything right now. They don't want to pay for it. They don't want to work for it. They just want. That's going to kill us ... unless we correct it.'' Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said black institutions now graduate 40 percent of all black Americans receiving baccalaureate degrees. ``Black colleges have produced tens of thousands of outstanding minority teachers over the years, and can help to develop new programs for effective teaching in America's culturally and ethnically diverse classrooms,'' said Cavazos. A 1988 Education Department survey of faculties in higher education institutions found that whites accounted for 89 percent of the 489,164 fulltime regular faculty members and 90 percent of the 175,589 part-time regular faculty members. Asians comprised 4 percent of the fulltime faculty, blacks 3 percent, Hispanics 2 percent, and American Indians 1 percent. The Agriculture Department, meanwhile, said an agreement was signed with Southern University and A&M College, Baton Rouge, La., as part of a campaign to attract more black students to USDA careers. Officials said the department's Agricultural Marketing Service will oversee about $500,000 in appropriated and private funds next fiscal year for teaching, research and recruitment of black graduates of Southern University. Deputy Secretary Jack C. Parnell said USDA will hire about 600 interns this summer from the 16 historically black land-grant universities chartered under the 1890 Morrill Act and from Tuskegee University in Alabama.

DOC.HEAD: Families Gather for Memorial Service for Iowa Dead
DOC.TEXT: Families of the 47 sailors killed in the USS Iowa explosion last April 19 began arriving here Wednesday for a memorial service, and some voiced support for the Navy's handling of the disaster a year ago. At a news conference, family members said they believe the Navy's controversial conclusion that the battleship explosion was likely caused by sabotage by a disgruntled gunner's mate who died in the blast. ``I'm in total agreement with the report. I think the Navy did a thorough job. ... I don't believe there was any cover-up,'' said John Hague, whose stepson, Lt. j.g. Philip Buch, died in the explosion. The news conference was attended by five people representing three families. Other families of the victims have said they disagree with the Navy's findings. According to the Navy, Gunner's Mate Clayton Hartwig was suicidal and disgruntled at his treatment by the Navy. That assessment was based on a psychological profile done by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Navy theorized Hartwig slipped a chemical detonator between the bags of powder in the center 16-inch gun in gun turret No. 2. Seconds before the turret was scheduled to fire a training salvo off the coast of Puerto Rico, the explosion occurred, sending a fireball racing down the six decks of the turret. The blast instantly killed most of the men inside the giant gun. Hartwig's sister, Kathy Kubicina, has crusaded to clear her brother's name. She has been joined by other family members of victims and some legislators in questioning the Navy's investigation. Earlier this year, a subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee issued a report saying the Navy's conclusions were not supported by the facts. ``I found it deplorable that the Navy would stretch the facts to force a conclusion that blamed it on a sailor,'' said former Secretary of the Navy John Lehman. Lehman brought the World War II battleship out of retirement as part of the buildup to a 600-ship Navy under President Reagan. Kathy Miller, whose son Todd Miller died in the explosion, said she was upset that Ms. Kubicina appeared to be speaking for all the parents when she challenged the Navy's report. ``She does not speak for all of us. You're going to have 47 different opinions about what might have happened. But the point is not to rehash it any longer. We can't be hostage to our grief,'' she said. The families were to meet privately Wednesday night and again Thursday after a private memorial service. Hague, a resident of Las Mesa, N.M., said one item on the families' agenda is a request that the Navy to donate the ship for a museum. ``We need to do something positive to help us deal with our grief. This has been my therapy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Foresees Action on Global Warming; Critics Hail ``Common Ground''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, responding to criticism of his global warming policy, told an international conference Wednesday he has ``never considered research a substitute for action.'' The president's remarks at the close of the 18-nation White House conference were warmly received by many of the same delegates who a day earlier criticized the administration for failing to deal directly with global warming. ``We came here to find common ground and we've found common ground _ that research and action are inseparable,'' Padraig Flynn, environnment minister from Ireland and an official of the European Community, told reporters. Bush opened the conference Tuesday saying more research is needed before costly programs are set up to fight global warming. But he closed the conference by challenging his critics _ many of them European delegates and environmentalists observing the conference _ over global warming. He said the United States is ``leading the search for response strategies and working through the uncertainty of both the science and the economics of climate change.'' ``But there is one area where we will allow for no uncertainty, and that is our commitment to action, to sound analysis and sound policies,'' he said. ``Above all the climate change debate is not about `research versus action' for we have never considered research a substitute for action,'' Bush told the senior government officials from around the world. ``To those who suggest we're only trying to balance economic growth and environmental protection, I say they miss the point,'' Bush said. ``We are calling for an entirely new way of thinking, to achieve both while compromising neither.' The two-day conference was marked by discord over whether there should be specific commitments to reduce so-called greenhouse pollutants, especially carbon dioxide. The United States maintained the conference was aimed at focusing on the need for additional research into global warming and its economic impact, not on developing action plans. But after Bush's remarks, many of the European delegates expressed hope that the U.S. position emphasizing research had shifted closer to their own views: that industrial nations along must reduce the manmade pollutants, such as carbon dioxide, which scientists fear are causing a warming of the Earth. Hans Alders, the Dutch environment minister and one of the strongest critics of the U.S. policy, said he was heartened by Bush's closing remarks. ``At the beginning, there were remarks only about the need for more scientific research and economic knowledge,'' said Alders. ``Now you get the impression he is saying we need action now and we need more information. And I agree with that.'' Rafe Pomerance, an environmentalist observing the conference for the World Resources Institute, said the administration ``got a very strong message from the European governments.'' Senior administration officials called the two-day conference a success because it allowed a frank exchange of ideas on the scientific uncertainties about global warming and the question of economic cost of both action and inaction was discussed. But disputes over the narrow focus of the conference agenda and other matters prevented agreement on a conference summary report and left a U.S. proposal for an ambitious international research effort, including creation of a special institute for global warming, not even considered. A draft of the U.S. proposal was briefly circulated Wednesday morning, but then quickly withdrawn when it raised the ire of many of the delegates. Michael Deland, chairman of the president's Council on Environmental Quality and a conference co-chairman, said the document was distributed by mistake. ``That was a complete misunderstanding,'' said Allan Bromley, the president's science adviser and another conference co-chairman. But Bromley prior to the conference had said the United States had hoped such a proposal would win the endorsement of the conference.

DOC.HEAD: Goetz Advises Latest Gunman Not to Surrender
DOC.TEXT: Subway gunman Bernhard Goetz volunteered some advice Wednesday to the man who fatally shot a robber on a train last week: Don't surrender to police. ``I think the guy has nothing to gain by turning himself in and everything to lose,'' said Goetz, whose own case attracted national attention as a symbol of vigilantism. Police reported no progress Wednesday in identifying the man who fired on a group of four attackers late Thursday on a Manhattan-bound subway train in downtown Brooklyn. One of the four was killed; the others were not injured. Witnesses told police the gang beat and robbed the victim, described as a white man about 50 years old, before he pulled out a gun and opened fire. He fled at the next stop. Goetz shot and wounded four teens on Dec. 22, 1984, on a Manhattan subway train. He claimed they were about to mug him; they said they were panhandling. Goetz surrendered to police in New Hampshire nine days later, setting off a legal nightmare that continues to this day. He was acquitted in 1987 of attempted murder, but convicted of a weapons possession charge. He served 8{ months in jail. Goetz filed a new motion Wednesday in state Supreme Court, the Bronx, seeking to dismiss a $50 million civil lawsuit against him filed by Darrell Cabey, who was paralyzed and brain-damaged in the 1984 shooting. A hearing is set for April 27.

DOC.HEAD: GM Expediting Electric Car Production, Smith Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A longer version is on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is expediting development of an electrically powered car in recognition of consumer demand for a cleaner environment, chairman Roger B. Smith said Wednesday. The nation's largest automaker intends to be the first to mass-market the vehicle, Smith said in a speech to the National Press Club. GM unveiled a prototype vehicle, the Impact, in January. He refused to say when or where the car would be built or to reveal technical information about the vehicle, saying he did not want to tip off competitors. In the 1970s, GM announced it would produce a 1985-model electric car, but it dropped that project long before production. Smith said the goal is to manufacture a car that would match today's safety and performance standards without the air pollution of an internal combustion engine. Generation of the electricity, of course, would create other pollution if fossil fuels were used in the power plant. ``We have set an aggressive schedule for ourselves in order to pull along the technological developments that we still need,'' Smith said. Still needed is a better battery, and Smith said that may require joint development by automakers, utilities, battery manufacturers and the federal government. Though obstacles remain, ``when we look at the strict clean-air legislation that's now being proposed for many areas of the country, we're convinced that the Impact has a bright future.'' Smith defended the automobile industry's environmental record: The average vehicle's weight has dropped by 27 percent, aerodynamic efficiency has improved by one-third, transmissions and air conditioning are more efficient, engines are electronically controlled and burn less fuel while emitting 75 percent to 96 percent less pollution than the cars of 1970, the year of the first Earth Day. ``The truth is that no one understands the importance of the environment better than we,'' Smith said. His remarks were sharply criticized by environmental groups. ``For him to come here today and declare himself an environmentalist is the height of hypocrisy,'' said Bill Magavern, staff attorney for the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, at a news conference after Smith's speech. Many of the improvements Smith mentioned resulted from laws and regulations that the industry fought, said Robert Dewey of the Environmental Action Foundation. ``The company's CEO says one thing and their lobbyists say another,'' Dewey said. Automakers lobbied against new tailpipe standards sought by environmentalists in a pending update of the Clean Air Act. The industry also is gearing up to fight a Senate bill to boost cars' minimum fuel efficiency from 27.5 miles per gallon to an average of 40 mpg. Smith said, ``We do oppose things that are not practical, things that are not environmentally sound, over-regulation and things that do not add to the welfare of our people.''

DOC.HEAD: Imprisoned Soul Star to Counsel Youths on Drug Abuse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Expands third item in AM-People, a0631
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CF1, LaserColor
DOC.TEXT: Imprisoned soul singer James Brown was all smiles when he stepped on stage Wednesday, not to sing, but to discuss his new job counseling youths about drug abuse. Brown, 15 months into a six-year sentence for aggravated assault, starts Thursday with the Aiken-Barnwell Counties Community Action Commission in a work-release program. ``A lot of people know me, know my reputation and what I've been involved in. I hope that together that we can bring a turnaround to some of the problems that we have out there and make the people aware that there is a place to go to get the help,'' Brown, 56, told a news conference at the University of South Carolina. The ``Godfather of Soul,'' a two-time Grammy award winner, said he chose the job from more than 400 offered because he wanted to give something back to the community. ``I could have been in television, I could have been in a whole lot of other things, but I want to be a part of something that shows our concern and that we care,'' he said. Brown was transferred last week from the State Park Correctional Center in Columbia to the minimum-security Lower Savannah Work Center near Aiken. The self-proclaimed ``Hardest Working Man In Show Business'' will have an office and assistants, work from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. and be transported by commission officials, said George Anderson, executive director of the private, non-profit agency. Brown will earn $11,500 a year but his paychecks will be turned over temporarily to the state Department of Corrections because inmates can only keep $50, said department spokesman Francis X. Archibald. Anderson said Brown will talk to school principals, students and parents, address meetings and publicize the agency's programs, which also include education and nutrition for pre-schoolers, family services and job training. He said Brown's music reputation can help focus attention on the area's poverty. But he cut short the news conference before Brown, who has been arrested several times for drug use and possession, could answer questions about his credibility as an advocate against subtance abuse. ``There's no foregone conclusions on my part that Mr. Brown has serious problems of the kind or nature that you allude,'' Anderson told reporters. Brown will address his message to the poor communities of the mostly wealthy Aiken County, which also is home to the Department of Energy's Savannah River nuclear weapons production plant. At the news conference, Brown jokingly answered reporters' queries: ``Oh, you want me to say I feel good. OK, I feel good.'' It was a reference to ``I Got You (I Feel Good),'' one of his 114 charted singles, which also include ``Papa's Got a Brand New Bag'' and ``I'm Black and I'm Proud.'' Brown is serving concurrent six-year sentences in Georgia and South Carolina for failing to stop for police, aggravated assault and weapons violations stemming from a high-speed chase that crossed state lines. The incident began when a gun-toting Brown stormed an insurance agency next to his office and claimed strangers had used his bathroom. Tests showed Brown had used the illegal drug PCP. He had several previous drug arrests. Brown becomes eligible for parole in South Carolina in May 1991, and in Georgia in March 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Akaka Seen as Likely Successor To Matsunaga
DOC.TEXT: Gov. John Waihee is expected to fill the Senate seat of the late Spark Matsunaga within about a week, and Rep. Daniel Akaka is considered the leading candidate for the job. Waihee said earlier he would announce his selection after a ``decent interval'' following Matsunaga's funeral. Services were held in Honolulu Wednesday, with private burial to follow on Thursday. ``The governor won't let the seat go vacant very long,'' press secretary Carolyn Tanaka said Wednesday. ``Maybe there will be an announcement within a week.'' Waihee, a Democrat like Matsunaga, has hinted that he wouldn't mind leaving one of Hawaii's two House seats vacant for a while if that was what it took to fill the Senate seat. Speculation by political observers centers on Akaka. Waihee acknowledged to news reporters that the Democratic congressman would be a logical choice, and Akaka has said he would consider the appointment, if offered. The interim successor named by Waihee will serve until a special election in conjunction with the Sept. 22 primary and Nov. 6 general elections. The winner of that election will serve the remainder of Matsunaga's term, which continues through 1994. Hawaii's other U.S. House seat is held by Republican Patricia Saiki, who has expressed interest in Matsunaga's Senate seat. Matsunaga, 73, died Sunday at a hospital in Toronto where he had been undergoing treatment for cancer.

DOC.HEAD: School Bus Hit During Christian Faction Fighting; 15 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-8 pvs `Gen. Michel' with 1 graf to UPDATE with Geagea's forces denying responsibility. Pick up 9th pvs, `Aoun and...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI2
DOC.TEXT: A rifle-fired grenade slammed into a schoolbus and exploded during Christian factional fighting Wednesday, killing 11 schoolchildren and at least four other people. ``The driver was burning as the bus hit the sidewalk,'' mumbled one dazed witness. ``Many of the pupils yelled for help as we tried to extinguish the fire. At least one teacher also was among the dead along with the driver,'' said a soldier at the scene. A police spokesman said the bus was hit while crossing into Christian east Beirut in the afternoon. It was bringing children back from school in south Beirut. The grenade ignited the fuel tank. ``It couldn't be determined who fired the rifle grenade,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations. Gen. Michel Aoun's radio station accused gunmen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia of firing at the bus, but Geagua's command denied responsibility. Aoun and Geagea have been involved in a bloody power struggle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave for more than two months. The showdown has killed 892 people and wounded 2,388 since it started Jan. 30. Most victims have been civilians. The police spokesman said the bus belonged to the Mraijeh Elementary School, a new private school in south Beirut. It was not immediately clear why students from predominantly Christian east Beirut were attending school in south Beirut, a Shiite Moslem stronghold. The gutted wreckage of the yellow bus straddled a curb in an Aoun-controlled area, a few yards east of the gateway. It is the only crossing linking Christian east Beirut and Moslem west Beirut. The smell of incinerated metal hung in the air as flies buzzed in the darkened interior of the bus. A torn, striped green and blue sweater lay on the blackened springs of the burned out bus. The wheels of the bus had melted. Sheets of paper from a grade book lay scattered on the driver's seat. The names of the students were burned off. Only their grades remained, written neatly in red and blue ink. The army private, one of the soldiers serving under Aoun, said he and his colleagues ``doused off the burning bus with water and we evacuated the victims to nearby hospitals.'' The bus was hit a few hours after a thunderous blast ripped through Aoun's Defense Ministry in east Beirut's suburb of Yarze, killing at least two men. Aoun's forces said in a communique the Defense Ministry blast occurred when soldiers were moving confiscated ammunition, but they did not say if it was an accident. Moslem radio reports said the explosion was aimed at Aoun's troops. The rival Christian factions dueled intermittently throughout the day with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades in east Beirut and the Kesrouan highlands, the police spokesman said. Aoun opposes the government of President Elias Hrawi, formed last fall under terms of an accord aimed at ending Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun says he opposes the plan because it lacks a timetable for the withdrawal of Syria's estimated 40,000 troops backing Moslems and the Hrawi government. Geagea has recognized Hrawi's authority. In other Beirut violence Wednesday, rival Shiite Moslem militias loyal to Iran and Syria fought a 90-minute gunbattle in west Beirut. Police said one person was killed and four wounded. Police, in an updated casualty count, said 12 people have been killed and 52 wounded since the latest round of the Amal-Hezbollah clashes broke out Tuesday. The police spokesman said most of the casualties were civilians, including children caught in the cross-fire across densely populated residential districts. Amal and Hezbollah have been fighting on-and-off for more than two years for mastery of the 1.2 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect.

DOC.HEAD: Survivor of Capsized Fishing Boat Says `Voices' Kept Him Going
DOC.TEXT: A commerical fisherman whose boat capsized said Wednesday he frequently heard voices and prayed a lot during the five days he spent floating in a wooden box without food. Nathan Neesmith, 32, of Darien, told reporters he didn't know why the 34-foot boat Casie Nicole sank early Thursday. ``All I know is water came in, and it came in fast,'' said Neesmith, still appearing fatigued on his third day of hospitalization. Neesmith said that as he drifted in the Atlantic, he splashed water on his face and tried to avoid drinking the salt water. He felt at times he would not survive. ``I heard people talking to me,'' Neesmith said. ``I drifted along. I heard people yelling out, `Nathan!' I'd jump up and look around. I thought it was somebody. Here I am looking around, and it was only the good Lord keeping me awake.'' Earlier Wednesday, the Coast Guard said it suspended its search for three missing crew members, including Neesmith's brother and nephew. Neesmith was rescued Monday about 20 miles east of Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was in fair condition Wednesday at Memorial Medical Center in Savannah, where he was being treated for hypothermia and dehydration. Dr. Carl Boyd, director of the trauma center, said he expected Neesmith to make a full recovery and to be released this weekend. The boat was found Monday night by a Coast Guard plane about 45 miles off the coast, said Petty Officer 2nd Class Brett Farrell. A subsequent search turned up only a life vest and a sleeping bag, about five miles from where Neesmith was rescued, said Petty Officer 2nd Class Anthony Brown of the Coast Guard rescue station on Tybee Island. Neesmith said he and his companions were about 65 miles offshore when the boat began taking on water. He left the others with food and a raft, and set out to get help. He said he was confident the others will be found. ``People are praying for us all over the world, and if they can be found we're gonna find them ... we're sure gonna try anyway,'' Neesmith said. The Coast Guard said the search was suspended pending any new developments. Missing were Neesmith's brother, Billy Joe Neesmith, 23; his nephew, Keith Wilkes, 18; and Franklin Brantley, 23, all of Darien.

DOC.HEAD: Execution Date Set for Prejean
DOC.TEXT: A man sentenced to death 12 years ago as a teen-ager is to go to the electric chair on May 18, a judge decided after the U.S. Supreme Court rejected his latest round of appeals. Dalton Prejean, a two-time killer who has been on death row longer than any inmate in Louisiana, is to die for the 1977 murder of state Trooper Donald Cleveland. Prejean's case has been championed by death penalty opponents who say he should be spared because he is nearly retarded, with an IQ of 76, and because he was a teen-ager at the time the trooper was killed. Prejean is now 30. The U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay last November but on Monday the high court rejected his most recent appeal. State District Judge Hugh Brunson set the execution date Tuesday. Prejean has been in prison since the death of Cleveland, who had stopped an automobile in which Prejean was a passenger because of a broken taillight. Prejean was 17 at the time and already had served time in a reform school for murdering a taxi driver when he was 14. Defense attorneys claim that Prejean suffered mental retardation from beatings he received as a child. They also said he feared for his life when Cleveland stopped the auto. Prejean told the Louisiana Pardon Board last November that he regretted shooting Cleveland and that ``I can't give back a human life that was very valuable (but) to kill me will not solve the problem.'' The board voted 3-2 to spare Prejean's life, but Gov. Buddy Roemer rejected the recommendation. Some people who served on the jury at Prejean's 1978 trial said this week the execution should go on. William Sayre of Monroe said he was galled by the numerous stays of execution granted Prejean over the years. ``We voted that he should die for what he did,'' said Sayre. ``He shot that officer in cold blood.'' Several jurors said they didn't know during the trial that Prejean had killed a taxi driver at age 14. He was released from a juvenile detention center six months before the trooper was killed. Eugene Koontz of Monroe, another juror, said it was unfair that the jury didn't have the information about the earlier crime. ``It's time for this to end,'' said Koontz.

DOC.HEAD: US Officials Voice Hope, Skepticism Over Hostage Reports
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with White House comment, rejection of demand that diplomat go to Damascus in top 12 grafs, picking up in 10th graf pvs, The Islamic
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Hostages Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III appeared to welcome on Wednesday reports that a pro-Iranian group would free an American hostage, but the White House rejected the group's demand that a senior U.S. diplomat fly to Damascus to take part. Diplomatic sources also said an American would be freed on Friday in the Syrian capital. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which is believed to hold three of the eight American captives, demanded that Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly hurry to Damascus ``to coordinate some final steps to guarantee success within 48 hours.'' But Baker said, ``At the present time, the Middle East is not on his agenda.'' And presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We would not anticipate him becoming involved in hostage release in any way.'' Fitzwater said that Kelley was in Bonn, West Germany, ``on other business. He's expected to return to the United States in a day or two.'' Kelly, who heads the Bureau of Near East and South Asian Affairs, is attending a conference of U.S. ambassadors in Bonn. He is a former ambassador to Lebanon, where all eight Americans are believed to be held. ``Of course we're always hopeful,'' Baker said while reiterating a longstanding U.S. demand that all eight Americans held in Lebanon be released unconditionally. At the White House, Fitzwater said of the reports, ``We've had this happen before. We've gone right up to the moment of supposed release and it never happened. So we've long since learned not to be too optimistic.'' Like Fitzwater, Baker said, ``We've seen reports like this before.'' In this case, he added, ``I don't want to say anything that might adversely affect any chances there are for release of any hostages.''
