A U.S. official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said: ``When we see this hostage walk out, we'll believe it.'' The Islamic Jihad did not say which of the three Americans it is holding would be freed. Its statement was accompanied by an instant photograph of Jesse Turner, of Boise, Idaho. The group also is believed to hold Alann Steen and Robert Polhill. All were abducted from the grounds of Beirut University Campus on Jan. 24, 1987. They are among 18 Westerners, including the eight Americans, believed held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. Earlier Wednesday, David Denny, a State Department spokesman, called the unconditional release of all hostages in Lebanon ``an important humanitarian issue.'' He said he could not predict any release at this point, and said ``nothing would be served by speculation.'' The spokesman added: ``We would, of course, welcome the release of any hostage, as we continue to urge the release of all of them.'' U.S. officials in making statements about the hostage situation usually rule out any U.S. negotiations with the abductors for release of their captives. Baker and Denny made no reference to this point in their remarks. Meanwhile, a senior U.S. diplomat said the Bush administration would ``respond to positive actions'' by Iran regarding release of the hostages but would not reward the Tehran government for using its influence to free the captives. Iran is understood to have considerable influence with the Islamic Jihad. ``We are prepared to deal with the Islamic Republic without nostalgia for the past,'' said Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Edward Gnehm. ``We remain willing to talk directly to authorized Iranian government representatives,'' he said. Gnehm did not refer to the reports about a possible hostage release. The United States, Gnehm said at a seminar on the Persian Gulf, believes Iran has significant influence over the hostage holders and could do much more than the recent statements by Iranian officials regarding the need to free the hostages. ``We're looking for actions, not words,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Opposes Sanctions Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is seeking to defeat proposed legislation that would impose economic sanctions against Iraq, a top State Department official said Wednesday. Nonetheless, the United States has ``real doubts'' about recent Iraqi actions, including alleged attempts to buy nuclear bomb detonators and to assassinate government opponents, said Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Edward Gnehm. ``We would like Iraq to take action to allay our concerns,'' Gnehm said at a seminar on the Persian Gulf. U.S.-Iraqi relations have been strained in recent weeks by a series of events, among them a warning by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that his country would use chemical weapons against Israel if attacked. The administration has criticized Saddam for making ``inflammatory'' statements. Anger at Iraq prompted calls in Congress for economic sanctions. Rep. Howard Berman, D-Calif., is about to introduce a bill denying Iraq any economic and military assistance. The draft legislation has drawn considerable support from House Democrats, but several leading Senate Republicans have voiced reservations and suggested the administration talk to Saddam but not threaten him. Gnehm said the administration's ``policy on sanctions is to oppose them.'' He added, ``Our objective will be to see that it (the bill) doesn't pass.'' The administration is particularly opposed to a provision in the draft bill that would ban credits and loans by the government's Export-Import Bank for Iraqi agriculture, he said. The administration is also concerned about a resolution expected to be adopted Thursday by a House subcommittee condemning human rights violations in Iraq. The measure was prompted by the hanging last month of an Iranian-born British journalist accused of spying for Israel and the United States. Last fall the United States and Iraq held high-level talks to discuss expanding and improving their ties, which have been strained at times since their renewal in 1984 after a 15-year break. ``Since then, a series of disappointments have raised real doubts in our mind about Iraqi intentions,'' Gnehm said. In particular, he cited last month's exposure of an Iraqi ring allegedly trying to smuggle nuclear triggers for atomic bombs, an alleged plot by an Iraqi diplomat at the United Nations to kill two political opponents, and Saddam's threat to Israel. ``Iraq is an important country, with an important role to play in the region,'' Gnehm said. But ``they cannot flout our laws ... without us reassessing our relationship.'' He said the United States is improving its methods for tracking countries that violate U.S. export-control laws, including allies like Israel and Egypt who have also been accused of trying to smuggle devices to enhance their nuclear and ballistic missile capabilities.

DOC.HEAD: Planned Parenthood Administrator Resigns Over Proposed Amendment Language
DOC.TEXT: The medical director for Planned Parenthood's state chapter said Wednesday he resigned the post because a pro-choice amendment to the Massachusetts constitution ``goes too far.'' Dr. Stanton Goldstein said he left the job because he could not join the group in backing abortion rights ``at any time in cases of rape or incest or to protect the life and health of the mother.'' ``I cannot support an amendment that legalizes destructive procedures of a healthy fetus in the third trimester,'' he said. ``I was in an administrative role in an organization that stood for something politically that I could not agree with.'' Goldstein stepped down Tuesday but will remain a staff doctor with the pro-choice organization's two Massachusetts clinics, whose administration he had overseen during the past five years. The longtime pro-choice activist said he believed many people would find the proposed amendment broader than acceptable. ``It goes too far for me,'' he said. ``I as a physician believe that a destructive procedure in the third trimester is either unethical or immoral ... and therefore I am entering the public debate.'' Nicki Nichols Gamble, executive director of the state office of Planned Parenthood, said she expected debate and disagreement but regards ``the proposal as a fairly moderate one that captures the status quo.'' She said the organization would stand behind the proposed amendment, which must be approved by a constitutional convention and could go before voters in 1992. The language was adopted last September after months of discussion among members of a ``Coalition for Choice,'' which included Planned Parenthood, the League of Women Voters, the Civil Liberties Union and the National Organization for Women. Coalition members initially filed seven different versions of the amendment proposal _ some more and some less restrictive. A compromise was reached after extensive polling to test public support for each version. Susan Newsom, associate director of Planned Parenthood, said the language ``is not the first choice for a lot of people.'' But she said the number of abortions performed after the second trimester was ``tiny.'' Of 38,200 abortions performed in the state in 1986, nine were late trimester abortions, according to the most recent figures by the state Department of Public Health. Goldstein, however, put a different spin on the historically low figure. ``I have several questions,'' he said. ``If the number of abortions performed after the second trimester is so `tiny' then why are we legislating for it? Is it so `tiny' because it has not been legal up till now?''

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Says Hundreds Of Naval Accidents Went Unreported
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Navy suffered 1,596 accidents involving ships, submarines and aircraft in the 1980s, and nearly two-thirds of them were not publicly reported, according to Greenpeace USA. The environmental advocacy group said its study of previously unreleased Navy records showed that 1989 was, ironically, one of the Navy's safest years despite the April explosion which killed 47 sailors aboard the battleship USS Iowa and several other headline-provoking accidents in the wake of that tragedy. Greenpeace, citing data obtained from the U.S. Navy Safety Center under the Freedom of Information Act, said the Navy registered 106 accidents last year, the fewest of any year in the decade except 1988, when there were 83. The most, 248, occurred in 1981, it said. The Navy did not dispute the figures, though a statement from Cmdr. Mark Baker, chief of the Navy Information Office, put the count of ``major'' accidents last year at 69. By ``major,'' he referred to what the Navy calls Class A accidents _ involving loss of life, or property damage exceeding $1 million. The Greenpeace figures, according to author Joshua Handler, counted Class B accidents as well _ property loss exceeding $200,000 _ and a few ``significant'' Class C accidents involving property damage of under $200,000. ``The Navy has been unrelenting in its pursuit of safety and this has resulted in continued improvement during the decade of the 80s,'' said Baker. ``Our goal continues to be to make the Navy as safe as possible.'' A string of accidents last year led the Navy to take the unprecedented step of ordering a two-day freeze of its operations so officers and sailors could concentrate on safety reviews, inspections and lectures. The Greenpeace report, released Wednesday, said the Iowa explosion and the sinking of a Soviet Mike-class nuclear submarine earlier in April made naval accidents a running news story in 1989, ensuring press coverage of many of those which followed. ``But 991 U.S. naval accidents went unreported by the news media in the 1980s, almost two-thirds of the total for the decade,'' it said. ``Government secrecy still inhibits a full accounting of the naval accident record,'' the report said. ``Information is still too sketchy to determine the dangers accidents posed to nuclear weapons or reactors, particularly since direct data about accident trends for U.S. naval nuclear weapons and reactors continues to be kept secret.'' Still, ``the U.S. Navy provides more information that any other country on its accident record,'' Greenpeace said. Despite unusual Soviet candor over the fire which resulted in the loss of 42 sailors and their Mike-class sub in the Norweigian sea, the report said, ``the Soviet record on disclosure is still horrendous.'' Greenpeace estimated that the world's five nuclear navies _ including Great Britain, France and China _ together suffered 3,200 accidents in the 1980s, or almost one a day. The guess was based on the number of U.S. accidents, 1,596, compared to the fleet sizes of the other nations. It said about half the 99 ships and submarines involved in documented accidents last year were nuclear powered, and, similarly, about half were capable of carrying nuclear weapons. American vessels accounted for 78 percent of the documented episodes. Soviet ships and submarines were involved in 8 percent of those cases, while those from Great Britain accounted for 7 percent. The report, while mentioning fatalities caused by accidents previously reported, did not mention overall death tolls. But it did say: _The sinking of the Soviet Mike-class sub raised the total number of nuclear warheads on the ocean floor from 48 to 50, with 43 of those from the Soviet Union and 7 from the United States. It also raised the number of sunken naval nuclear reactors from 7 to 8, with 5 of those from the Soviet Union and three from the United States. _Collisions, fires and explosions accounted for almost half of the 439 accidents involving U.S. surface ships in the 1980s, with the largest portion occurring in the Atlantic Ocean. _Forty percent of the U.S. naval accidents during the decade involved submarines.

DOC.HEAD: 2nd Convoy Carrying Emergency Food Leaves for Ethiopia War Zone
DOC.TEXT: Another convoy left for the war zone in northern Ethiopia with emergency supplies for thousands of people threatened with famine, a relief worker said Wednesday. It was the second such convoy heading to Tigre province in two days. Eighteen trucks carrying eight tons each left Dessie, the capital of Wollo province, in the morning for Mekelle, capital of neighboring Tigre province, said Ahmed Baghet, the deputy director of the Catholic Relief Services in Ethiopia. Another convoy of 55 trucks, which left Dessie on Monday, was reportedly unloading in Mekelle and was expected back in Dessie on Thursday, Baghet said in a telephone interview from Nairobi. Those in Mekelle are among up to an estimated 6 million people threatened with famine, mostly in Tigre and the northern province of Eritrea. The rebel Tigre People's Liberation Front has controlled Mekelle and the entire Tigre province since forcing government troops to withdraw in February 1989. Mekelle is 170 miles north of Dessie and 320 miles north of Ethiopia's capital, Addis Ababa. A consortium of three Ethiopian churches recently began delivering emergency food to northern Wollo and Tigre after the government and the rebels agreed on safe passage for relief convoys behind the battle lines. Most of the trucks used in the operation, however, belong to the U.S.-based Catholic Relief Services and the Lutheran World Federation. The emergency food is donated by the United States and other Western aid agencies. Monday's convoy, which Baghet said passed through the war zone without incident, delivered the first emergency supplies to Mekelle since the rebel takeover. Bhaget said the convoy was not in touch with Addis Ababa or Dessie. ``But we heard from another truck that ours were unloading and we consider the information reliable. Yes, report it,'' he said. Recently the Tigreans accused relief officials of citing bad road conditions to delay the distribution of food in northern Wollo, contested by the government and the rebels, and in Tigre. Bhaghet said the road conditions prevented trucks from using trailers and forced them to carry half their maximum load. The Tigreans took up arms in 1975, seeking President Mengistu Haile Mariam's overthrow and the establishment of a government patterned after that of Albania, the last of the hard-line Marxist states in Eastern Europe. The government is battling a larger rebel group, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, in northern province of Eritrea. The Eritreans captured the Red Sea port of Massawa in an offensive in February, forcing donors to divert all emergency supplies to Assab port, also on the Red Sea but much farther south. The Eritreans said in a clandestine radio broadcast Monday they had repaired damage caused to the port in the fighting and appealed to international donors to resume emergency shipments through the port for distribution in Eritrea and northern Tigre. Massawa is Ethiopia's only deep sea port and the United Nations had hoped to ship through the harbor 1.1 million tons of emergency food to those threatened with famine. The rebels from Eritrea, a former Italian colony on the Red Sea, have fought the government since Ethiopia incorporated it as a province in 1962.

DOC.HEAD: Administration's Global Warming Path Proves Rocky
With AM-Greenhouse Conference Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Although American officials are calling the two-day White House conference on global warming a success, it did not occur without some embarrassing glitches. A copy of a White House ``talking points'' document on the conference made its way to some of the environmental activists monitoring the sessions. They quickly provided copies to reporters and charged the White House was trying to put a false ``spin'' on the global warming issue. The guidelines, presumably for administration officials attending the conference, included a section on ``debates to avoid.'' It was not the first embarrassment for conference organizers. On the opening day, the Soviet Union was omitted from the list of participants to the 18-nation conference, which was held at a downtown hotel a few blocks from the White House. A Soviet official sought out EPA Administrator William Reilly and wanted to know if it was an intentional slight. He was told, according to one conference organizer, it certainly was not. The Soviet Union in addition to being a superpower also is one of the biggest producers of global warming pollutants. The ``talking points'' document, however caused the biggest stir when it surfaced Wednesday. It suggested U.S. officials not talk about whether there is too much warming of the Earth because ``in the eyes of the public we will lose this debate.'' Instead, officials were advised to ``raise the many uncertainties'' of the issue. Other things not to do, according to the White House guidelines: _``Don't get into an advocacy position of the merits of the various policy proposals.'' _``Don't use specific numbers (degrees, dollars, rates, etc.)'' when discussing how the conference is ``accelerating the international discussion and understanding of these issues.'' _Finally, ``don't let reporters position this conference as an attempt to delay serious decisions on this issue.'' Yet, much of the two-day conference focused on just such criticism as European delegates chastized the Bush administration for emphasizing research and not enough at the expense of strategies to curb global warming. It wasn't clear who drew up the ``talking points,'' although adminstration officials said they were authentic. ``I personally did not review (the document) and I certainly didn't authorize it,'' said Michael Deland, the president's chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality and a conference co-chairman. Reilly said he frequently talks about many of the forbidden subjects outlined in the ``don't'' section. And on Wednesday morning, an unnamed staffer mistakenly, according to conference organizers, distributed a detailed U.S. proposal for a broad-ranging research initiative to conference delegates. ``It was circulated inadvertently,'' said Deland. He said the staffer actually should have distributed copies of summary reports from the various working sessions that had been underway. But enough of the European delegates saw the document before it was withdrawn to cause another stir. The Europeans, already upset because they believed they did not have opportunities to present their views in public sessions, saw it as another effort to impose an American outlook on the conference. ``I challenged the status and nature of the document,'' said Padraig Flynn, environnment minister from Ireland and an official of the European Community, ``and it was quickly and effectively rubbished by William Reilly.'' ``It was a complete misunderstanding,'' said Allan Bromley, the president's science adviser and a conference co-chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Bulldozers Prepare Gaza Site for New Jewish Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th graf `In Dugit' to ADD that orange trees on state-owned land. Pickup 6th pvs, `The prefabricated...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TLV3
DOC.TEXT: Bulldozers guarded by Israeli soldiers leveled an orange grove Wednesday to ready a new Jewish settlement for construction only a short distance from a crowded Palestinian refugee camp. In Jerusalem, a group of Jewish settlers who moved into the old walled city's Christian quarter ignored a court order to leave. The new settlement activity in Gaza drew a protest from Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfilyev. He told reporters in Moscow it showed ``some circles in Israel continue to deliberately raise obstacles to a peaceful settlement in the Middle East.'' U.S. officials have also called the construction of Israeli settlements a threat to peace efforts. They have conditioned a $400 million housing loan for immigrants on assurances Soviet Jews will not be settled in occupied areas. In Dugit, armed Jewish settlers from a nearby settlement watched as the bulldozers smoothed out sand dunes and uprooted orange trees for the trailer-type homes of 40 Israeli families who plan to move in by the summer. Settlers said the orange trees were on state-owned land allocated to Dugit, but the trees were apparently cultivated by Gazan Arabs. The prefabricated housing is expected to arrive soon, according to Arab workers who operated the earthmoving equipment. Dugit's future residents plan a tourist beach and yacht club on the beachfront about a mile from their homes. The site replaces another nearby that military officials rejected. ``These people want to bring their yachts, build a marina, attract tourists,'' said Datia Hershkowitz, a settlement activist in Gaza. ``The move was delayed when military officials designated the original site, the prettiest beach in Gaza, too close to a Palestinian refugee camp for proper security,'' she added. The Shati refugee camp, a beachside shantytown of 41,000 Palestinians, is only two miles from the Dugit site. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's spokesman Yossi Ahimeir said Sunday, when Israel TV reported the final permits had been granted for Dugit, that it was one of eight settlements agreed to by Shamir's Likud and the center-left Labor Party when they formed a government in 1988. Ahimeir said it was therefore wrong to consider Dugit's establishment part of a new policy. Three settlements were built after the coalition government came to power, but former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Labor postponed the ground-breaking of the other five. Leftist Parliament member Dedi Zucker said this week that in addition to agreed-upon settlement plans, the government recently authorized construction of Jewish housing in the West Bank town of Nablus and expansion of a settlement near Hebron. The daily Maariv newspaper said Wednesday that Shamir aide Michael Dekel had approved a request by settlers to expand Kfar Adumim ``and in effect to open a new settlement'' in the West Bank. The fresh settlement activity prompted speculation that Shamir's caretaker government was trying to accelerate the building effort since Labor left the government March 13. Shamir aide Avi Pazner on Wednesday denied that Shamir knew in advance about the plans of more than 150 Jewish settlers to establish themselves in Jerusalem's Arab Christian quarter. Pazner also rejected a charge by left-wing lawmaker Yossi Sarid that Shamir had ordered the police not to evacuate the settlers when a judge upheld an eviction order Tuesday. The settlers in Jerusalem ignored a court-ordered deadline for them to leave, contending the law gives them 21 days to appeal. As the 9 a.m. deadline expired, a dozen paramilitary police relaxed outside the four stone buildings that are owned by the Greek Orthodox Patriarchate. The church maintains that a tenant illegally sold the rights to the building to the Jews. David Bason, a lawyer for the Greek Orthodox Church, said the order required the settlers to leave immediately and threatened to take legal action against the police unless they acted to enforce the court order. ``The problem is the police are very lazy. They want us to make the eviction,'' said Bason, an Israeli lawyer. Police spokesman Uzi Sandori could not be reached for immediate comment on whether police would evict the settlers. The Jews' move into the 72-room complex a week ago set off angry protests by Palestinians and church officials. The move upset a delicate balance in which Christians, Moslems and Jews live in jealously guarded separate quarters. The dispute has political overtones since the old city is part of the land captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel has annexed the area into its capital, but most other countries, including the United States, do not recognize the action.

DOC.HEAD: Record Low Temperatures in the East
DOC.TEXT: Spring seemed more like winter Wednesday in the East and the Midwest, as the mercury dipped below freezing, breaking low-temperature records in five cities and tying them in four. Scattered snow showers fell over central New England. Showers and occasional thunderstorms were scattered from central Arkansas to Oklahoma, the Texas Panhandle, the northwest third of Texas, southern and western New Mexico, southern Colorado, Arizona and southern Nevada. Small hail fell near Monte Vista, Colo., and at Truth or Consequences, N.M. A cold front accompanied by northerly winds made temperatures plunge in much of the eastern half of the nation overnight before moving into the Gulf of Mexico. It was 22 degrees in Flint, Mich., where the old mark of 23 had stood since 1953, and 31 degrees in Atlantic City, N.J. (32 degrees, 1983). Other records were Fort Wayne, Ind. (23 degrees, 27 in 1926 and 1953), Mansfield, Ohio (23, 26 in 1983) and South Bend, Ind. (24, 25 in 1983). Records were tied in Binghamton, N.Y. (28 degrees, 1962), Evansville, Ind. (31, 1983), Moline, Ill. (23, 1983) and Rockford, Ill. (22, 1983). Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 32 degrees at Limestone, Maine, to 91 degrees at Fort Meyers, Fla. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 16 degrees in Pellston, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Former Aquino Aide Says He Gave Her `Package of Diamonds'
DOC.TEXT: A former official in Philippine President Corazon Aquino's government testified Wednesday that he gave her a package of diamonds found in the official residence of her deposed predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos. The disclosure came as Imelda Marcos' attorney questioned Potenciano Roque, a U.S. government witness called to describe the discovery of financial records at the Marcos residence in Manila after she and her husband fled the country in February 1986. Mrs. Marcos is on trial in U.S. District Court on charges of using embezzled money to buy New York properties and finance a lavish lifestyle. Roque was an aide to Joker Arroyo, a Manila civil rights lawyer and Mrs. Aquino's former personal secretary, from 1986 until last year. The diamonds suddenly came up after a morning of testimony about documents prosecutors say will help show that the Marcoses diverted money to Swiss bank accounts and other personal uses. ``Did you ever give Mrs. Aquino a package of diamonds?'' Mrs. Marcos' attorney, Gerald Spence, asked Roque. After a pause, Roque replied, ``Yes.'' ``How many diamonds?'' asked Spence. ``Six to ten.'' ``Did you take a receipt for them?'' the attorney said. ``No,'' Roque said. Roque didn't tell the jury where he found the diamonds, but Spence said in a conference away from the jury that the witness discovered the packet among documents at Malacanang Palace. Spence was concerned that if he raised that matter in front of jurors, it could open the door for prosecutors to introduce evidence about other jewels. Under questioning by Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella, Roque testified that he had given ``eight to ten'' diamonds in a small plastic packet to Mrs. Aquino in her office and that she had instructed her daughter, Corazon Cruz, who is also her personal secretary, to call the Central Bank. Roque gave no other details about the incident. However, documents newly admitted into evidence refer to jewelry purchased by Mrs. Marcos in New York. Spence said Tuesday that he believed a government witness then on the stand would have testified, had she been asked by prosecutors, that jewelry had been taken from the palace after the Marcoses left. ``And I think we can show that jewelry has since been identified and seen ... on both Mrs. Aquino and relatives,'' he said. The witness, Angelita Reyes, had told how she helped gather documents at the palace and later turned them over to the President's Commission on Good Government, which Aquino created to try to recover money allegedly stolen by the Marcoses. Judge John F. Keenan said that since U.S. prosecutors had indicated they didn't plan to introduce other evidence concerning jewelry, he saw no reason to hold Reyes for further testimony. Mrs. Aquino's government is trying to recover millions of dollars the Marcoses allegedly stole from their country's treasury during 20 years in power.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Dissident Leader Predicts China's Communists Will Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT dissident's name to Wang Dan.
DOC.TEXT: Chinese dissident leader Chai Ling said Wednesday that resistance to China's Communist rulers is growing in her homeland, and she predicted it will lead to the fall of the hard-line leadership. Appearing at her first news conference since surfacing in Paris two weeks ago, Chai held a placard with messages written to China's leaders by opponents. ``Not even his own relatives will help him,'' said the message to Prime Minister Li Peng. Chai was a leader of last spring's pro-democracy movement in China, which was crushed by a military crackdown launched the night of June 3. After the crackdown, she spent 10 months on the run in China. Chai and her husband, Feng Congde, reached France this month. An underground movement against the Beijing government is gaining strength in China, Chai told reporters. ``Even before we left Tiananmen Square, we thought there might be a period of terror,'' she said. ``Some groups had already formed before the massacre. We have been helped not by one group but by several groups that are everywhere and growing stronger.'' She gave no details of how she escaped China but said those who helped her included soldiers and Communist Party members. Animated and engaging, the diminutive Chai waved to the crowded press gallery and smiled as the news conference began. A badge of the Goddess of Democracy, the statue raised by the demonstrators in Beijing last year, was pinned to her red sweater. During 10 months on the run, ``I noticed that the feelings we felt in Beijing have spread throughout the country,'' Chai said. ``Resistance has taken many forms _ passive forms like silence, but more active forms, also. People were very active in helping us escape.'' Chai helped organize the protest campaign, which was suppressed when soldiers shot their way into central Beijing and drove student protesters from the city's Tiananmen Square. Hundreds of people were killed. She and Feng, who have applied for political asylum in France, were on a wanted list of 21 student leaders sought by the Chinese Communist authorities. Chai recalled that in 1982, she was chosen by the Young Communists League as one of 200 model students. ``How did it come about that I have been listed as No. 4 of the 21 most wanted criminals?'' she said. ``I haven't stolen, I haven't killed, I obviously haven't raped anybody. How did I become a criminal?'' ``The old men running the government did not take into account the changes of the last 10 years,'' she said. ``Our generation represents conscience and courage. When they (the government) sent the tanks after us, they never would have thought that in front of them there were people so fearless.'' Her eyes grew moist as she described her taste of freedom in Paris. ``I have felt freedom before, during those few days in the square. During my escape I lost it, but we found it again,'' she said. ``I think about my friends... We would want them to be here.'' The emergence of Chai and Feng has given a boost to the Federation for Democracy in China, a Paris-based dissident group. On Tuesday, the federation and the news magazine Actuel announced plans for rock concerts in Paris, New York, Hong Kong, Taipei, Prague and Sao Paulo on June 3 to commemorate the Chinese military crackdown. The front and the magazine are also among the sponsors of ``A Boat for China,'' which is sending a radio ship to the Far East to transmit pro-democracy broadcasts to China. Chai was among the three most prominent student leaders of last year's demonstrations. One leader, Wu'er Kaixi, fled to France shortly after the crackdown. The other, Wang Dan, was captured in Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Allowed Into Libya to Help Wipe Out Pest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th pvs `Recently, the' with two grafs to ADD background; SUBS 8th pvs `The United...' with one graf with more background. Pick up 9th pvs, `Under the...'
DOC.TEXT: The United States will let Americans travel to Libya to help wipe out a deadly parasite that threatens Africa's livestock and wildlife, U.N. officials said Wednesday. In January, President Bush renewed sanctions against Libya, including a ban on American travel. The measures date back to former President Ronald Reagan, who accused Libya's leader, Col. Moammar Gadhafi, of sponsoring terrorism. Earlier this year, U.S. officials denied requests by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization for permission to send American experts to Libya and help rid the North African country of the screwworm fly. However, in March, Bush allowed U.S. officials to sell Libya sterile screwworms in an attempt to wipe out the parasite. Henryk Jasiorowski, FAO assistant director general, said the United States also has agreed to allow U.S. technicians employed by international organizations to travel to Libya but only on international passports. The fly settles in wounds or tick bites and in a few days can kill its animal hosts by eating away at tissues. Humans with flesh wounds can also invite infestation. It was first sighted in northern Africa in July 1988. Another FAO official, Bjorn Sigurbjornsson, said an American entomologist employed by the FAO and the International Atomic Energy Agency is working in Libya this month. ``This is very important because the know-how is American,'' Jasiorowski said at a news briefing about the pest. The United States became an expert on the pest after a devastating infestation of livestock in the American Southwest. Entomologists developed a patented way of irradiating the flies to make them sterile, and the parasite was wiped out in the United States by 1982. Under the strategy, tens of millions of flies are sterilized at a facility in Mexico, then released from airplanes above an infested area. Matings yield no offspring and the insect dies out. International experts have devised an $85 million, two-year plan that calls for the release of treated flies in Libya, starting in 1991. A trial program is to begin this summer. Confirmed sightings of the pest have been limited to a swath across northern Libya, but experts say the infestation could spread. Particularly vulnerable, they say, are Libya's neighbors, Tunisia and Egypt. In Egypt the fly could move quickly down the Nile River Valley into Central Africa, threatening livestock as well as exotic wildlife in central Africa, the experts said. Southern Europe is also considered at risk. Sigurbjornsson said he thought Egypt and Tunisia helped persuade the United States to allow Americans into Libya. U.S. officials have traveled to both Tunisia and Egypt to aid inspection there, he said. After talks earlier this year, Washington was persuaded also to allow the American technology to be used in Libya against the screwworm fly. U.S. officials only agreed after receiving assurances no resources would be given directly to the Libyan government. Experts say Libyan inspection has so far helped prevent the pest from spreading beyond its present area. Two relatively miled winters have also helped contain the fly. Although FAO officials praised U.S. collaboration in the effort, sources have said the timetable for full-scale eradication could have been much sooner if it weren't for obstacles posed by the U.S. sanctions. The fly's appearance in Libya was its debut outside the Western hemisphere. It was believed to have entered Libya on an infected animal, probably from Latin America.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Says Tubes Seizure Set Back Iraqi Big Gun Project
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with statement from British owners of Belgian firm, no comments from Iraqi Embassy and Forgemasters. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Britain said Wednesday it is convinced that Iraq was trying to build a giant gun but that customs officers frustrated the project by seizing eight steel tubes last week. ``Let me make it absolutely clear that the gun itself cannot be in operation without all its parts, and it is a great success on the behalf of this country to have been able to prevent that happening,'' Trade and Industry Secretary Nicholas Ridley told the House of Commons. Weapons experts have said a gun on the scale of the seized parts _ 131 feet long with a bore of 39 inches _ would have the potential to lob nuclear or chemical warheads hundreds of miles, or even boost rockets into orbit. The Iraqi government and the manufacturer, Sheffield Forgemasters, have insisted the tubes were designed for a petrochemical plant. The Iraqi Embassy in London and Forgemasters said they had no comment on the government's statement Wednesday. Ridley said the government believed that Iraq's gun project followed the designs of Gerald Bull, a Canadian-born U.S. ballistics expert who was murdered in Brussels on March 22. The Financial Times reported Wednesday that the British and Belgian governments have evidence that a Belgian defense company, PRB, was contracted by Iraq to help produce a booster-assisted shell for the same type of gun. PRB is owned by the British munitions company Astra Holdings. Astra Holdings issued a statement Wednesday night saying that after it acquired PRB last Sept. 11 it discovered a contract ``for unusual types of gun propellant for very large guns.'' ``Although all normal export documentation was in place and appeared correct, Astra immediately reported the matter to Her Majesty's government. The contract is no longer in force,'' the statement said. Astra Holdings did not say whether the propellant had been shipped to Iraq. Ridley confirmed that his own department had cleared the production of the tubes two years ago, but said his agency had no knowledge the goods were designed to form part of a gun ``until a few days ago.'' ``The government is entirely satisfied that these tubes form part of a gun, and that the Customs action was correct,'' he said. Ridley's statement was the first Cabinet-level statement that the tubing had military potential. During her visit to Bermuda to meet with President Bush last weekend, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said more information was needed to determine the purpose of the tubes. Gordon Brown, of the opposition Labor Party, contended the government had been ``deceived and duped on a grand scale.'' ``This government allowed through an order which could have made it possible for Iraq to operate a weapon whose use could affect regional and even world stability,'' Brown said. The Customs and Excise Office seized the tubes on the docks at Middlesbrough last Thursday after a Ministry of Defense expert concluded they could be used as a gun barrel. Sheffield Forgemasters said it had already shipped 44 sections of tubing to Iraq. But Ridley said Wednesday, ``I understand that it will not be possible to build a complete full-size gun from parts that have been supplied'' from Britain. Ridley said his department was contacted in 1988 by Sheffield Forgemasters, asking whether licenses were required ``for export of tubes to Iraq for use in the polymerization of polyethylene.'' The Department was also contacted by Walter Somers Ltd. of Birmingham about a separate order of metal tubes from Bull's Belgian company, Space Research Corp. Ridley said the export licenses wouldn't have been granted if his department had known at the time that the tubes were designed for use in a giant gun. Britain banned arms shipments to Iran and Iraq when the two countries were at war, and the ban remains in effect. Western fears abut Iraqi arms programs have intensified in recent weeks. On March 28, British customs officials seized U.S.-made parts for atomic bomb triggers that were bound for Iraq. Iraq has denied seeking a nuclear capability, but has confirmed its arsenal includes chemical weapons. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein recently threatened to use missiles armed with chemical weapons against Israel if Israeli forces attacked his country.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan to Sell Non-Profitable Public Enterprises
DOC.TEXT: Sudan's military government will put non-profitable public sector enterprises on sale to private buyers, a decree issued Wednesday said. It did not identify the enterprises but said they include ``all losing, marginal and non-vital economic units in the country.'' It said Arab and foreign investors would be allowed to buy such enterprises that ``failed to boost the public treasury resources.'' The decree by Col. Salah Mohamed Karrar, head of the economics committee of the ruling military junta, said the step was taken to ``stop the deterioration of the economy.'' On May 5, Sudan has a round of talks scheduled with the International Monetary Fund. But the decree said the decision to sell public sector units comes within the government economic reform program and denied it was taken under pressure from the IMF. Sudan has a foreign debt of $13 billion. The decree said the units proposed for sale have assets of nearly $416.7 million and owe Sudan's Central Bank $83.3 million. Karrar has said the IMF proposed raising the official exchange rate for Sudan's currency from 4.5 pounds to the dollar to 15 pounds and the free market exchange from 12 pounds to the dollar to 30 pounds. The IMF talks will be the fourth round since the government of Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir came to power in a military coup last June 30.

DOC.HEAD: Two German Governments Say They Won't Spy on Each Other
DOC.TEXT: The two German governments on Wednesday pledged not to spy on each other, and said they hope to have a completely open common border by summer. Interior ministers Peter-Michael Diestel of East Germany and Wolfgang Schaeuble of West Germany conferred in Bonn on ways to improve security cooperation and help pave the way for German unity. Schaeuble said he and Diestel agreed that East German ``espionage activities would not be continued under the new (East German) government'' against West Germany. Schaeuble added the new East German government is ``not the target of intelligence observation'' by West Germany. But he noted that both German states still belong to opposing military alliances. The West German minister said the matter of future German intelligence-gathering can be ``settled only in a comprehensive way.'' He suggested the issue will come up in German unification talks among the two Germanys and the four World War II allies _ the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union. Under the ``two-plus-four'' talks formula, foreign ministers of the six nations will meet to discuss international complexities involved in unification. Schaeuble told a news conference the two Germanys hope to have a completely free common border by summer. East Germany opened its borders last Nov.9. Officially, residents of both German states still must show passports when they cross the border now, but sometimes even that practice is waived. Diestel said East Germany plans to do away with that formality.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors of Jamaican Prime Minister Find Cancerous Lump
DOC.TEXT: Doctors who examined Prime Minister Michael Manley in New York have determined he has a cancerous lump on the prostate gland, his spokesman said Wednesday. The physicians however are optimistic about a full recovery and the 65-year-old prime minister plans to ``resume work fully,'' spokesman Hartley Neita said. The condition was diagnosed from tests Manley underwent Monday during a checkup at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Neita said. Doctors found that a lump found on Manley's prostate gland during his annual medical examination was cancerous, but ``tests have not shown any spread beyond the lesion,'' the spokesman said. He said Manley would take oral medication for one month and then have the lump surgically removed. Cancer of the prostate gland, which is at the base of the urethra, commonly afflicts older men. His Jamaican doctors ``have indicated that the prognosis for a full recovery is excellent,'' a government statement said. The medical team ``is also satisfied that the condition diagnosed and the treatment prescribed will not affect Mr. Manley's ability to carry out his responsibilities and duties as prime minister of the country,'' the statement added. Manley was flying back to Jamaica Wednesday night in time for Thursday's re-opening of Parliament, Neita said. Manley, who served as prime minister from 1972 to 1980 and was elected to a third term in February 1989, has previously been troubled by diverticulitis, an inflammation of the intestines. He has undergone surgery for the condition in 1985 and 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Scandinavian Star Towed to Denmark for Examination
DOC.TEXT: Tugboats on Wednesday began towing the burned-out hulk of the Scandinavian Star ferry to Denmark, where it will be examined to see if a fire that killed an estimated 161 people was deliberately set. Two tugboats towed the disabled 20-year-old ferry from the west coast port of Lysekil to Copenhagen. Earlier Wednesday, a commission of government officials from Norway, Sweden and Denmark boarded the ferry for the first time to evaluate the ship's safety standards. The Nordic commission is expected to recommend new safety standards for ferries traveling in Scandinavian waters. A separate marine inquiry in Copenhagen, which this week heard testimony from 24 witnesses to the disaster, exposed a series of safety omissions and blunders that may have contributed to the high death toll. Police in Oslo, Norway, estimated 161 people died in the April 7 fire, but said the figure was not final because it was still uncertain how many passengers boarded the ferry. The Danish-owned vessel was on an overnight run from Oslo to Frederikshavn, Denmark. Police have said they suspect arson in the disaster.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Parliament Refuses to Lift Prosecutors' Immmunity
DOC.TEXT: Parliament refused Wednesday to allow prosecution of two embattled anti-corruption investigators accused of attacking Communist Party privilege in a witch-hunt. The Supreme Soviet's decision not to lift legislative immunity from prosecutors Telman Gdlyan and Nikolai Ivanov quieted, at least temporarily, a dispute that had aroused the political ire of many Soviets. Tens of thousands of people rallied in Moscow and Leningrad on Tuesday in support of the two. Demonstrators in Leningrad had urged a strike if they lost their immunity. Even in the era of glasnost, when virtually any political topic is open for debate, few political issues have aroused such intense interest. The campaign to protect Gdlyan and Ivanov has encompassed Soviet frustration with Communist Party privilege. The prosecutors and their supporters say officials have tried to silence them to keep the investigation from stretching to Politburo officials. Opponents say the two have succumbed to the illegal means that were a trademark of the authorities they are pursuing. Gdlyan and Ivanov, who did not attend the legislative session, were warned ``if they continue activity leading to the destabilization of the situation in the country, the Supreme Soviet will move to lift parliamentary immunity from them,'' the Tass news agency said. Tass did not report the vote total, but the evening TV news program ``Vremya'' showed a picture of the Supreme Soviet's vote tally board, indicating the measure passed 275-84. The Parliament sanctioned an earlier decision to fire them from the Soviet Prosecutor's Office, but also called for the dismissal of unidentified officials who failed to supervise their work. It said the prosecutor's office, the Interior Ministry, the KGB and the Supreme Court should hold accountable ``those senior officials whose activities caused especially sharp public anxiety.'' The officials were not identified, but among those subject to criticism during the sharp two-day debate on the prosecutors' activities was Soviet Prosecutor General Alexander Sukharev. Demonstrators who rallied near the Kremlin on Tuesday carried signs reading ``Gdlyan and Ivanov are our conscience!'' and ``The fate of Gdlyan and Ivanov is the fate of democracy. Protect them!'' A legislative committee found no grounds to charges by the pair that conservative Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev was linked to the corruption they were probing, or that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was ``turning a blind eye to the mafia.'' The Supreme Soviet condemned what it called ``unfounded statements ... which discredit the Supreme Soviet, individual people's deputies and officials.'' Sukharev accused the two of holding 50 people illegally for periods of up to several years. They also have been accused of threatening detainees and their families in order to extract statements. Gdlyan and Ivanov were discharged from the Communist Party on Feb. 21. They rode their populist anti-corruption campaign to election to the national Congress of People's Deputies last March. The two gained fame uncovering a trail of bribery and corruption among top Communist Party officials in the Central Asian republic Uzbekistan that led to the conviction of former President Leonid I. Brezhnev's son-in-law. In 1988 Yuri D. Churbanov was sentenced to 12 years in a labor camp.

DOC.HEAD: More Cuts in Ozone-Destroying Chemicals Needed, Projection Suggests
DOC.TEXT: Nations will have to impose stronger controls on ozone-destroying chemicals if the atmosphere is to be made safe for ozone again within the next century, a new study suggests. Even if all emissions were stopped in the year 2000, levels of ozone-depleting chlorine in the atmosphere would not drop to relatively benign levels until about the year 2070, the study says. The work is presented in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature by Michael Prather and Robert Watson of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Scientists are concerned about destruction of ozone at high altitudes because that ozone layer shields Earth from solar rays that can cause skin cancer. The United States and other nations have signed a 1987 agreement, called the Montreal Protocol, in which they pledged to cut production of some ozone-destroying chemicals in half by the end of this decade. Since then, representatives of 81 countries have called for an end to production and use of ozone-destroying chlorofluorocarbons by the year 2000. The new study considered not only the compounds covered by the Montreal Protocol but also other ozone-depleting compounds, including carbon tetrachloride and methyl chloroform. It estimated how long it would take, under various degrees of regulation of the compounds, to lower the atmospheric concentration of chlorine from more than 3 parts per billion today to 2 parts per billion. The lower figure was the concentration in the late 1970s when scientists first noticed the ``ozone hole,'' an area over Antarctica in which a substantial amount of ozone disappears every year. The study found that if emissions were cut to half of their 1985 levels at the end of the year 2000, atmospheric chlorine concentrations would dip only slightly from a starting level of just under 5 parts per billion, and then rise above 5.3 parts per billion by the year 2100. If emissions were eliminated in the year 2000, chlorine concentrations would reach the 2 parts per billion target in the year 2073, researchers said. But the target might be difficult or impossible to reach by the year 2100 if chlorine-bearing substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons were used indefinitely, researchers said. Similarly, a 90 percent reduction in emissions in the year 2000 would delay reaching the target until 2175, researchers said. Guy Brasseur, director of the atmospheric chemistry division at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., called the study important. It shows, he says, that ``at the present time we haven't solved the problem.''

DOC.NOTE: For Release 8:30 p.m. EDT. Time set by source.
DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Calls for Civil Rights Bill Approval _ Over Veto If Need Be
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Edward M. Kennedy on Wednesday called for approval of a major civil rights bill even if it means overriding a presidential veto and blamed the administration for being more willing to compromise than to lead. ``Often, as in the current civil rights debate, the administration waits on the sidelines until its position becomes untenable in Congress,'' the Massachusetts Democrat said. ``Then it rushes onto the playing field with a half-hearted alternative.'' He was scornful of a Bush administration version of the civil rights bill. ``On a surprisingly large number of significant issues, this administration has shown a willingness to compromise but a reluctance to lead,'' Kennedy said. ``What we expect and need instead is a whole-hearted commitment to civil rights,'' Kennedy said in remarks prepared for delivery to a dinner in honor of the 50th anniversary of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. Kennedy is chief among 40 Senate co-sponsors of a bill that would reverse six Supreme Court rulings last year that civil rights forces call a severe setback. Provisions range from banning racial harrassment in the workplace to requiring employers to provide proof if they claim lopsided hiring practices are a business necessity. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said recently the measure would usher in hiring quotas and added that he and other top administration officials would urge a veto if the bill reached President Bush's desk. Kennedy said that ``Martin Luther King eloquently taught us acceptance of injustice is unacceptable ... now is always that time for civil rights.'' ``And if that means overriding President Bush's veto of the Civil Rights ACt of 1990, I say, `so be it.' America is not America if we pay lip service to liberty and close our eyes to clear injustice.'' The administration is pushing for an alternative bill that would overturn two of the six Supreme Court decisions. Kennedy scoffed at that approach.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Says Soviet Oil Supply Cut Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Landsbergis statement, premier in Norway seeking oils, all oil shut off within one hour, gas supply normal. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOS17, OSL2
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union shut off oil supplies to Lithuania's only refinery Wednesday as Moscow began to impose Mikhail S. Gorbachev's threatened economic embargo on the breakaway Baltic republic, Lithuanian officials said. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said the move represented ``economic coercion and economic warfare against a neighboring country.'' ``Truly, this is recognition of the independence of Lithuania,'' he said. ``It is hard to imagine why the people of Lithuania ... are being punished. What was their crime?'' Lithuanian Premier Kazimiera Prunskiene went to Olso, Norway, on a three-day mission seeking alternative oil supplies. The action was one of the toughest in Soviet President Gorbachev's effort to make Lithuania rethink its March 11 declaration of independence. Lithuania _ forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 _ is entirely dependent on Moscow for its oil and gas, which it receives at subsidized prices. Lithuanian officials estimated this week that the republic of 3.8 million people has enough oil to last six weeks to three months. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said action by Moscow against Lithuania could doom commercial relations between the Soviet Union and the United States. He said, ``It's very difficult to see some of the commercial aspects of our relationship surviving the use of force or coercion'' against Lithuania. President Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said ``we are looking into'' reports of the oil cutoff. He also said Bush received a private letter from Landsbergis _ ``The president has not seen it yet but he will. We won't comment on the content.'' The oil turnoff came hours after Soviet Deputy Oil and Gas Minister Aklim Mukhamedzyanov told the Tass news agency reports of an energy cutoff ``are completely groundless,'' and that the Council of Ministers issued no instructions to stop the flow. ``The flow of crude oil to Mazhiekiai was cut off at approximately 9:30 p.m. (2:30 p.m. EDT),'' said Aidas Palubinskas, a spokesman for Lithuania's Supreme Council legislature. Lithuanian gas officials said there was no disruption in natural gas, and the supply of Soviet gas would continue uninterrupted at least until morning. Reading an official government statement, Palubinskas said Mazhiekiai refinery director Bronius Vainoras confirmed the single pipeline feeding the plant from the Russian city of Polotsk had been shut down. The statement said a message read earlier by telephone to Vainoras stated: ``In accordance with the resolution of the Council of Ministers, we are halting pumping of crude oil to your refinery.'' All oil stopped moving through the pipeline about an hour after the shutdown, said Lithuanian Supreme Council spokeswoman Loretta Stanulis. She quoted Vainoras as saying the plant would continue operating on reserves for now. Landsbergis told a news conference earlier Wednesday that an economic embargo ``would resemble an angry man beating himself.'' He said it would have an impact on Latvia, Estonia and the Kaliningrad region of Russia, Eduardas Potasinskas of Lithuanian TV reported. Gorbachev said last Friday that unless Lithuania rescinded several laws supporting the declaration of independence, he would impose an embargo on key supplies. He called unconstitutional Lithuania's moves to curtail the spring draft into the Soviet Army, give residents Lithuanian identity cards and seize the property of the Communist Party on Lithuanian territory. The Kremlin says Lithuanian independence can be discussed only within the framework of the Soviet Constitution. A law passed April 4 would let republics secede if two-thirds of their residents approve secession in a referendum, and sets a maximum waiting period of five years. Gorbachev did not spell out what materials would be cut off, saying only they would be those goods the Soviet Union sells abroad for hard currency _ meaning oil and natural gas. Petroleum products are the Soviet Union's most profitable export. The Mazhiekiai refinery in northwestern Lithuania refines about 12 million tons of petroleum products a year, but Lithuania uses about a quarter of the output, journalists quoted government officials as saying. Sales of gasoline in Lithuania tripled this week as motorists reacted to Gorbachev's threat with panic-buying, said Lithuanian Energy Minister Leonas Asmantas. He reported Tuesday receiving unofficial information that crude oil supplies and natural gas would be reduced Wednesday. Lithuanian gas officials received a telegram from a regional Soviet energy official saying supplies of natural gas would be curtailed sharply by order of the government. But by late Wednesday, no change in the supply had been noted. Lithuania's Supreme Council has refused to rescind the laws Gorbachev wants off the books, but offered to pass no more such measures if the Kremlin starts negotiations by May 1. That effort at compromise appeared unlikely to be accepted by the Soviet leadership. The Supreme Council, in anticipation of a possible embargo, urged Lithuanian factories and consumers to ``prepare themselves for spiritual endurance and strict economy on all consumption.'' It announced no specific conservation measures. In a resolution titled ``On the Expansion of Relations between the Republic of Lithuania and the U.S.S.R., members of the Supreme Council reaffirmed their declaration of independence and appealed to Gorbachev not to use violence against Lithuanians or impose the economic sanctions he threatened. In a separate letter to Gorbachev, the Lithuanian legislature expressed ``regrets on the position and methods chosen by the U.S.S.R.'' Legislators said they were forming a delegation led by Bronius Kuzmickas, vice president of the Supreme Council, to travel to Moscow for possible talks. Gorbachev has issued a series of ultimatums since Lithuania declared independence. In most cases, such as a demand that Lithuanians surrender private firearms, he has not reacted when they refused to give in. The Kremlin also sent tanks and military vehicles through Lithuania's capital, Vilnius, rounded up Lithuanians who deserted from the Red Army, seized buildings and barred Western journalists from Lithuania. Lithuania picked up support Wednesday from neighboring Poland, with the Solidarity delegation to the Polish parliament adopting a resolution expressing concern over Moscow's exerting ``growing pressure.'' The delegation also suggested Warsaw assist in negotiations between the republic and the Kremlin. Japan's cabinet secretary, Misoji Sakamoto, urged Soviets to exercise ``prudence'' and expressed concern over Kremlin threats of punitive actions.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Firm Ready To Ship Detector To Britain
DOC.TEXT: The first detector of plastic explosives to be installed by U.S. officials in a foreign airport is to be set up at London's Gatwick Airport in a few weeks, a spokesman for the company that built it said Wednesday. The Federal Aviation Administration announced that it signed an agreement with the British Airports Authority for the thermal neutron analysis, or TNA, unit in the public area of the airport for use by U.S. and other airlines. The FAA's decision to use the machines was prompted by the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in December 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland that killed 270 people. Other neutron analysis units have been installed at John F. Kennedy airport in New York and at Miami's international airport, but both have been put in baggage areas and handle luggage of only one carrier. The FAA said baggage destined for the United States aboard U.S. carriers will be given first priority for the London machine. The next prioirty will be other planes bound for the United States. ``The machine has been ready and boxed for several weeks,'' said Hadi Bozorgmanesh, vice president of Science Applications International Corp. of California, the only manufacturer. Bozorgmanish said in a telephone interview that space for the machine is ready at Gatwick. The FAA has ordered U.S. airlines to pay for and install nuetron analysis units or similar machines at high-risk airports they use around the world. The London machine, however, will be operated by the airport, rather than an airline. FAA Administrator James B. Busey has said he has been frustrated by difficulties with negotiations to install the devices in airports. The agency is negotiating to put the machines in airports in Frankfurt, West Germany, where Flight 103 originated, and Manila, the Philippines. One is also planned for Washington's Dulles International Airport. ``TNA cannot guarantee security,'' Busey said on Tuesday. ``But it is the latest and best technology that we have and it is a needed weapon in what is a growing arsenal in the sturggle against terrorism.'' The FAA said the Gatwick machine should be in operation in time for the summer travel season.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Prime Minister in Norway to Seek Oil
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
LaserPhoto OSL2
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's prime minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, came to Oslo on Wednesday seeking Norwegian oil to help offset a Soviet oil cutoff to the independence-minded Baltic republic. ``This trip is important because of the brutal economic blockade,'' she said. She spoke before reports from Lithuania said Moscow cut off crude oil supplies to Lithuania late Wednesday in an effort to thwart its drive toward independence. Mrs. Prunskiene called her first visit to the West ``unofficial and informal.'' She told an airport news conference that talks with senior Norwegian officials ``will have a lot to do with practical problems.'' The three-day visit will help determine if Norway, a major oil exporter, would help break the blockade, she said. Prime Minister Jan P. Syse of Norway soft-pedaled the meeting. He said in a television interview that a non-governmental body made the invitation prior to increased tensions between Lithuania and Moscow. He did not expect Moscow to see the meeting as ``meddling in the internal affairs of the Soviet Union.'' He said NATO-member Norway has not promised Lithuania oil supplies. ``The state does not sell oil, that is up to the oil companies,'' he said. ``It is very curious that yesterday we heard promises of supplies,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said at the airport, without elaborating. Norway's state oil company Statoil has said it was willing to sell Lithuania crude oil supplies at market prices paid in dollars. A spokesman said Statoil had not been approached. Asked if Lithuania had enough Western currency to pay for oil, Mrs. Prunskiene replied, ``We don't expect oil companies to give us anything for free. Naturally we are prepared to pay. Very much depends on what kinds of contacts and contracts are possible.'' Mrs. Prunskiene and Foreign Minister Algirdas Saudargas were invited by Norway's three governing coalition parties, through a joint organization called ``Give Democracy in the East a Chance.'' The organization is non-governmental, but was created by Norway's Conservative-led coalition to nurture non-socialist political parties in the East bloc. The Lithuanians will meet Syse, Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik and members of parliament. They will also visit the west coast city of Stavanger, center of Norway's 1.5 million-barrel-a-day offshore oil production, according to a news release.

DOC.HEAD: Divided Over Fate Of One Of Its Roughest Housing Projects
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-9, `To complicate ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with comment by mayor, attorney; picks up 10th graf, `Scattered low-income ...'
DOC.TEXT: Tonya Brooks is often afraid to look out her window. ``Bullets don't have no names on them,'' said the 21-year-old mother of three who lives in the 50-year-old Logan Fontenelle public housing project, which has been dubbed ``Vietnam'' because of the drugs, gangs and violence. Ms. Brooks would like to live in a quiet, safe neighborhood. But a plan to demolish the 388-unit housing project and relocate its residents has stirred controversy in this largely middle-class city of 350,000 along the Missouri River. The Omaha Housing Authority wants to use a $9 million U.S. Housing and Urban Development grant to scatter 194 of the families at Logan Fontenelle around the city, a plan rejected 4-3 by the City Council in December. Some opponents said it was too costly; others wanted more say in where the new housing units would be located. The housing authority then revised the plan so that it didn't need city council approval for the scattered site housing. But the council still must approve the razing of the Logan Fontenelle, a grim, red-brick project on Omaha's predominantly black north side. Mayor P.J. Morgan and Omaha Housing Authority Executive Director Robert Armstrong are determined to demolish Logan Fontenelle, which is overrun by Los Angeles-based gangs, the Bloods and the Crips, who sell cocaine and crack. Drive-by shootings are commonplace. No further city council debates are scheduled on the issue, however, as Morgan and Armstrong try to draft a compromise measure that would gain majority council support. But the mayor said Wednesday he would withdraw his support for the plan if the Logan Fontenelle units are only boarded up and left standing. ``That brings a greater blight to that part of the community,'' Morgan said. To complicate matters, four black residents of Logan Fontenelle have filed a lawsuit in U.S. District Court accusing the housing authority, HUD and city officials of racial segregation in housing policies. Armstrong said he hopes the lawsuit might be dropped if the scattered site plan gets the expected approval from HUD. Mary Clarkson, an attorney for the four residents, said Wednesday that in addition to Logan Fontenelle the lawsuit involves claims about Section 8 low-income housing and other housing projects. She said any attempt or plan that would desegegrate Logan Fontenelle is relevant to the case. ``It's premature at this time to know whether this plan ... would have that effect because there's little or no information about where these scattered sites would be,'' she said. Scattered low-income housing isn't new to Omaha, which has put 195 units around the city since 1980. But it became an issue with Logan Fontenelle because of the project's tough reputation and the large number of families who would need relocating at once. HUD doesn't push for scattered-site housing, but it's an option for local housing authorities, said HUD's director of public housing, Thomas Sherman. Sherman said the program often faces community opposition. ``It's just a feeling, not based upon fact, if you put low-income people in their neighborhoods, property values will deteriorate. The other reason is purely racial. There are still communities around this country that don't want to desegrate or integrate,'' he said from Washington. He said HUD encourages low-income people to find their own housing and use a federal voucher system, called Section 8 certificates, to help pay the rent. Under the housing authority plan, the authority would buy 134 homes and duplexes over a four-year period, giving the tenants an option to buy. Sixty additional units would be leased through Section 8 certificates. As the plan stands now, the 194 units emptied by those actions would be boarded up until the council approves their demolition. The authority's plan has a long-term goal of demolishing the remaining 194 units in Logan Fontenelle by the year 2000, but how the tenants would be relocated has not been determined. Some opponents of scattered-site housing in Omaha have said it gives low-income people housing they don't deserve and costs too much. ``How far do we go in providing homes for people who are unemployed?'' City Councilman Steve Tomasek asked. ``Are we supposed to provide a $70,000 home in a neighborhood that is otherwise gainfully employed?'' Armstrong said people in the scattered-site program would have to hold jobs and pay 30 percent of their income for rent. An average of $67,000 in federal money would be available to purchase each home. ``I guess I hate to see taxpayers providing money for housing that is of greater value than the taxpayers','' said one northwest Omaha resident, Walt Nabity. Others support the housing authority's plan. ``I think it'd give people a better chance ... to get them out of that ghetto,'' homeowner Mary Barnhart said. ``They deserve that chance.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Iran-Contra Figure in Baltimore Case Tried to Hide Money
DOC.TEXT: Former CIA agent Thomas Clines attempted to hide from the government hundreds of thousands of dollars in profits he made from supplying arms to the Contras, according to court papers filed by Iran-Contra prosecutors. Clines was indicted Feb. 22 and he is seeking to have the tax charges against him thrown out on grounds that the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh lacks jurisdiction in the case. The government's reply was made available Wednesday. Facing a May 14 trial in U.S. District Court in Baltimore, Clines is accused of underreporting his income to the Internal Revenue Service and failing to report foreign financial accounts to the Treasury Department. Clines' lawyer says the tax case falls outside the scope of the Iran-Contra prosecutors' jurisdiction. ``Mr. Clines has not been charged with committing any crime by virtue of his particiption in the purchase, sale or transfer of arms ... nor has he been charged with any crime relating to ... support to the Contras,'' said his lawyer, Paula Junghans. Prosecutors opposed Clines' motion to dismiss the indictment, saying that ``crimes involving the attempt to hide arms sale profits'' are within Walsh's authority to investigate, according to their counter-motion. The government expects evidence at Clines' trial to show that in 1985, $423,000 in profits were distributed to him as a result of his Iran-Contra activities, according to papers filed Tuesday by Iran-Contra prosecutors in Baltimore and released Wednesday in Washington. In 1986, said the prosecutors, Clines' profits from Iran-Contra activities amounted to some $459,000. Clines reported gross receipts of $265,000 and $402,513 for 1985 and 1986 respectively, according to his tax returns which were filed in the case. Clines assisted the Contra resupply network overseen by Oliver North. He helped locate a European arms dealer as a source of weapons, helped arrange for shipping and lined up crews to transport the supplies to the rebels. He worked with businessman Richard Secord, a retired Air Force major general whom North enlisted to run arms to the Contras. Clines also moved that the court suppress evidence, arguing that documents on foreign accounts which prosecutors obtained under a U.S.-Swiss treaty cannot be used in the case. Prosecutors say that ``the only Swiss records to be used as evidence in this case'' will be those produced by Secord's business partner Albert Hakim, who pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor in the scandal and is cooperating with the government.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Begin Sit-in to Protest New Censorship Measures
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen opposition legislators began a 48-hour sit-in Wednesday to protest the government's implementation of censorship rules without consulting Parliament. The legislators, all independents except for one member of the main opposition Social Democrat Populist Party, said they would not leave Parliament's assembly hall for two days. The government last Saturday adopted a decree sharply restricting news coverage in the southeastern Kurdish areas, and increasing the powers of the regional governor in charge of areas where Kurdish guerrillas have been fighting for an independent homeland. Almost 2,500 civilians, guerrillas and security forces have been killed in clashes in the southeast since 1984. Ethnic Kurds make up about one-fifth of Turkey's population of 55 million. The decree banned the Turkish press from carrying stories or analyses that might harm security operations. It ruled that publications carrying reports threatening law and order would be banned throughout the country or their printing plants closed. Two leftist weeklies, 2000'e Dogru and Sokak, which gave wide coverage to the Kurdish insurgency in the past, failed to appear at newstands this week as printers canceled their contracts to protest the new rules. The decree also empowered the regional governor to ban strikes that threaten law and order and expel from the area residents threating public order. Fehmi Isiklar, a spokesman for the protesting deputies, demanded the decree be brought before Parliament as soon as possible. The constitution requires the government to submit such decrees to Parliament for approval, but does not specify the timing. Opposition parties have been demanding decrees go into force after and not before Parliament approves them.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Lifts State of Emergency in Kosovo
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslav authorities lifted a yearlong state of emergency Wednesday in the ethnically troubled southern province of Kosovo, Belgrade television reported. It said the federal collective presidency acted at the request of Serbia following a Serbian police takeover in the region. Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, administers Kosovo. Serbia's Communist authorities announced last month they were abolishing existing police autonomy in Kosovo because local security forces failed to act during unrest there by ethnic Albanians demanding self-government. Ethnic Albanians make up 90 percent of Kosovo's population. They have staged numerous protests and demonstrations to back up their demands since the Yugoslav government introduced, at Serbian request, a state of emergency in the province in March 1989. The presidency said in a statement that security ``has been stabilized to a certain degree in Kosovo, making it possible to lift the state of emergency in the province.'' It said it was convinced that easing security measures ``will improve the overall situation in Kosovo and the country as a whole.'' About 60 ethnic Albanian protesters were killed in Kosovo and hundreds more imprisoned after federal authorities deployed Serbian police units and army contingents to curb the unrest. Serbian officials claim the measures were needed to prevent what they describe as harassment of Kosovo's 200,000 Slavs by ``terrorists and separatists'' of Albanian origin. They say ethnic Albanians are trying to secede from Yugoslavia to join neighboring Albania. Human rights groups from Yugoslavia's liberal northern republics of Slovenia and Croatia, international rights monitors and several Western governmental organizations denounced the crackdown in Kosovo.

DOC.HEAD: New Technique Reveals Sex of Embryo Before Pregnancy Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The new...,' to CORRECT hospital name to Hammersmith, sted Hammsmith.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists say they have identified the sex of 3-day-old embryos in the test tube, and that two women implanted with tested embryos are expected to delthis summer. Further research might provide a way to screen out embryos that would develop serious genetic diseases, removing the prospect of abortions in those cases, researchers said. The study was aimed at producing female babies in cases whiver twin girls ere a male could inherit a serious genetic disease, said researcher Alan Handyside. While the technique also would allow choosing the sex of a child without any medical reason, Handyside said he would consider that unethical. The new work is reported in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature by Handyside and colleagues at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School at Hammersmith Hospital in London. Laboratory techniques have been used before to determine a baby's sex. In 1986, a New Orleans fertility institute announced the birth of a boy whose sex had been selected during ``in vitro'' fertilization, which is done in the laboratory. That case involved selecting sperm to produce a boy. But sperm ich only a risk rather than a certainty can be predicted, diseases that appear only after decades of normal life, and childhood diseases with which people can live into early adulthood, she said. ``Some might consider it to be socially very undesirable for a woman to take a 50 percent chance of having a child who is going to be obese ... since those children are likely to get into more medical problems and cost the society,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Damages Winston Churchill's Birthplace
DOC.TEXT: Blenheim Palace, the Duke of Marlborough's stately home and birthplace of Winston Churchill, was damaged Wednesday by fire, but there were no reported injuries. There was no serious structural damage to the house, 60 miles northwest of London, palace administrator Paul Duffie said. Duffie said he was the first to spot the flames on the roof of the southwest tower, where roofers had been working earlier in the day. Before firefighters arrived, palace staff used fire extinguishers and covered the house's bookcases with protective sheeting, he said. ``The fire brigade did not use one more drop of water than was necessary so damage was kept to a minimum,'' Duffie said. ``If thousands of gallons had been poured onto the flames, the results could have been disastrous.'' But the wooden roof, flooring and some metallic work of the house would have to be replaced, fire brigade officials said. Duffie said a conservation expert was examining the collection of 10,000 books at Blenheim Palace, which is open to the public.
