An investigation was launched into the cause of the fire, which was controlled within an hour. The Duke of Marlborough is from one of most famous British aristocratic families. The current duke is the 11th duke. Lord Randolph Spencer-Churchill, father of wartime Prime Minister Winston Churchill, was the third son of the 7th Duke of Marlborough. Blenheim Palace was designed by Sir John Vanbrugh and finished in 1722. Winston Churchill was born at Blenheim Palace in 1874 and is buried in the churchyard at the edge of the house's vast park. The Duke of Marlborough was not home at the time of the fire.

DOC.HEAD: February Shows Smallest Trade Deficit in Six Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 2-3 to include administration predictions on trade; INSERTS grafs 16-17: ``The administration's,'' with more on trade outlook
DOC.TEXT: The United States in February recorded its smallest trade deficit in more than six years, a $6.49 billion imbalance that reflected a sharp drop in oil imports, the government reported Wednesday. The Bush administration hailed the dramatic narrowing of the deficit but later in the day released a new forecast which pessimistically predicted that further trade improvements this year were likely to be ``at best very modest.'' The administration's trade forecast, required by Congress, said that any further narrowing of the trade deficit this year is likely to be much smaller than in the past two years and that a ``modest widening'' of the deficit could not be ruled out. The Commerce Department said February's trade gap was down 30 percent from a $9.32 billion January deficit. It was the best trade showing since December 1983, when the deficit was $5.68 billion. Imports fell by 7.6 percent, to $38.12 billion, while U.S. exports totaled $31.63 billion, a modest 1 percent decline from an all-time high for exports set in January. Michael Boskin, President Bush's chief economic adviser, called the trade figure ``very good news indeed'' while cautioning that ``we can't tell yet the extent to which it is a temporary or permanent phenomenon.'' Some private economists remained pessimistic, contending that February's good showing came primarily from a huge 20 percent drop in oil imports that's not likely to be sustained. With U.S. domestic oil production at 25-year lows, many economists look for America's dependence on foreign oil to continue rising, thus holding back improvements in the trade deficit. Last year's trade deficit totaled $109 billion and many analysts are looking for the figure to deteriorate this year, reflecting a higher oil bill and weaker export growth because of the strength of the U.S. dollar. A stronger dollar makes U.S. goods less competitive in overseas markets. ``It's nice to have a low number for February, but it would certainly be a mistake to conclude that our competitiveness problems have disappeared and everything is now terrific for us on international markets,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser at the WEFA Group, an economic consulting company in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. But Bruce Steinberg, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said he believed the trade deficit would shrink further this year, falling below $100 billion for the first time since 1983. He said America's trade fortunes were being helped by strong demand in Western Europe, the primary market for U.S. exports. While the trade balance with Japan worsened in February, rising to $3.12 billion, the United States ran a $1 billion trade surplus with Western Europe. ``We have gone from running big trade deficits with Western Europe to being in rough balance and everything is in place to start running big surpluses,'' Steinberg said. The administration's trade outlook held out some hope that the dramatic changes occurring in Eastern Europe would narrow trade differences, at least in Europe. The report said that the unification of West and East Germany should act to lower West Germany's huge trade surplus because the united country will need to import more from abroad to meet increased demand. The deficit with Japan, which accounted for half of February's total imbalance, is coming as the Bush administration applies heavy pressure on the government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to open Japanese markets to more American products. Regardless of their view about future trade prospects, economists agreed that February's improvement would significantly boost overall economic growth for the first three months of the year. Steinberg predicted that the overall economy, as measured by the gross national product, expanded at an annual rate of between 2.5 percent to 3 percent, with more than 1 percentage point of that gain coming from a smaller trade deficit. In the final three months of 1989, the GNP grew at a sluggish 1.1 percent rate. Oil imports, which surged by 44 percent in January, fell in February by 20 percent, to $4.71 billion, reflecting a drop in the price per barrel and the number of barrels imported. The big swing in both months was weather related, with cold December temperatures pushing up demand and an unusually warm January cutting back on oil imports in February. In addition to the drop in oil shipments, imports of consumer appliances and other durable goods fell by 7.5 percent while imports of clothing and other consumer non-durable goods dropped by 10 percent, primarily reflecting sluggish U.S. demand, analysts said. However, imports of foreign cars were up by 25 percent, to $2.56 billion in February. On the export side, there were small declines in a variety of areas but these were offset by a doubling in sales of aircraft, which climbed to $2.27 billion, reflecting a spurt in shipments by the Seattle-based Boeing Co., which was idled by a strike late last year.

DOC.HEAD: Frederic Rossif, European Documentary Filmmaker, Dead at 68
DOC.TEXT: Frederic Rossif, a Yugoslav-born documentary filmmaker whose subjects included Pablo Picasso, African wildlife and Nazi Germany, died of a heart attack Wednesday, his production company said. He was 68. He won France's coveted Jean Vigo award in 1963 for ``To Die in Madrid,'' about the Spanish Civil War, and was considered one of Europe's foremost documentary filmmakers. Rossif was born Feb. 16, 1922, in Montenegro, Yugoslavia, and went to college in Rome. He fought with the French Foreign Legion during World War II, then settled in France and gained citizenship in 1947. One of his most recent major works was a three-hour television documentary about Nazi Germany, ``From Nuremberg to Nuremberg.'' It was completed three years ago but not broadcast until last year. At the time of his death, Rossif was planning to make a film about Soviet dictator Josef Stalin.

DOC.HEAD: Abernathy's Epitaph Reads: `I Tried'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Members of...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with scheduling of funeral, memorial service.
DOC.TEXT: The tombstone of the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, the civil rights leader, will carry the two-word epitaph he chose before his death: ``I tried.'' ``That was more or less his motto. But in my eyes, he did more than try. He made a difference,'' said Abernathy's son, state Rep. Ralph David Abernathy III. The elder Abernathy, who was a friend and confidante to the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. but was spurned by civil rights colleagues last year for discussing King's alleged infidelity in his memoirs, died Tuesday at Crawford Long Hospital. He was 64. Abernathy, who suffered strokes in 1983 and 1986, died of coronary arrest brought on by a blood clot in the lung, hospital spokesman Mendal Bouknight said Wednesday. Abernathy had been in the hospital since March 23 for treatment of a sodium deficiency. The younger Abernathy, in an interview Tuesday night with The Atlanta Journal, said his father would want to be remembered ``as a man of God, or better yet a soldier of God first, a man of peace and a man of love.'' ``I serve in the Georgia House of Representatives because of the work my father did, but he always told me I wouldn't be free until everyone was free,'' the son said. Former President Jimmy Carter, following a speech at a private college in Williamsburg, Ky., said: ``I thought Ralph Abernathy was a great man. ... I think that as the years go by, Abernathy is going to get more and more credit from people who look at his actual accomplishments.'' Friends and family came and went quietly Wednesday from the single-story, white brick Abernathy home in southwest Atlanta. A Fulton County policewoman stationed inside the house for security said Abernathy's wife, Juanita, would make no comment. The funeral was scheduled for noon Monday at West Hunter Street Baptist Church, where Abernathy had been pastor since 1961. A memorial service was to be held at 7:30 p.m. Sunday at West Hunter Street Baptist Church. Following the service, the public may view the body. Abernathy shared 17 jail cells with King, marched with him in Selma and cradled his bloody head when King was killed in Memphis. But civil rights leaders who had worked with Abernathy during those years criticized him in 1989 following publication of his autobiography, ``And The Walls Came Tumbling Down.'' In the book, Abernathy wrote that King had spent time with two women and had argued with a third in the 24 hours before his assassination. Among those criticizing Abernathy for the book was Jesse Jackson. But on Wednesday, Jackson was among those who praised Abernathy for his role in the civil rights movement. ``The benefits of his service to the common people of America and the world will never be lost,'' Jackson said in a statement issued from Washington, D.C. ``I have marched with him. I have debated with him. I have argued with him. I have disagreed with him. I have learned from him...,'' Jackson said. From his office in Los Angeles, former President Ronald Reagan issued a statement calling Abernathy ``a man of great courage and totally unselfish dedication to the most just cause known to mankind _ ending discrimination.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Boston Hotel Workers' Housing Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed legislation Wednesday amending the Taft-Hartley Act and clearing the way for a Boston hotel workers union and other employees across the country to negotiate for housing benefits. Wednesday's signing affects not only the Boston local but every union and employee association in the country. ``It's much more than just a housing trust for a handful of workers,'' said Dominic Bozzotto, president of the Hotel Workers Local 26 in Boston. ``It says that there are employers out there who understand that they have to stabilize neighborhoods and communities in order to have a workforce.'' Without ceremony or fanfare, Bush signed the bill at the White House, according to Bruce Marks, Local 26 housing director. It was Local 26 that in 1988 negotiated an unprecedented agreement with nine Boston hotels requiring the employers to put money into a housing trust fund that could be used to finance housing purchases and rentals. The 5,000-member local needed a technical amendment to the Taft-Hartley Act before the agreement could be legal. ``We're going to be able to provide housing assistance within the next month,'' Marks said. Taft-Hartley, the nation's overriding labor relations law for 43 years, includes anti-corruption provisions that prohibit management from making direct payments to unions except for certain purposes such as employee education, health care and retirement. The amendment adds housing to that list. An unusual political coalition developed around the legislation. It included the Boston area employers who support the measure because it will enable them to retain a stable workforce in a costly housing market; Reagan and Bush administration officials who backed the bill because it accomplished a social goal without involving tax dollars; and Massachusetts Democrats including Sen. Edward M. Kennedy and House Rules Committee Chairman Joe Moakley, longtime backers of the labor movement. ``What the whole exercise proves is that you can get a broad coalition to come together around social responsibility,'' Bozzotto said. ``It shows that the idea of the large community where the strong take care of the week is alive and well in our society.''

DOC.HEAD: `Spunk,' Three Stories by Zora Neale Hurston, Adapted for the Stage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: ``Spunk'' is an apt title for George C. Wolfe's stage adaptation of three short stories by Zora Neale Hurston. The playlets, which opened Wednesday at off-Broadway's New York Shakespeare Festival, are gutsy, gritty and often very funny examinations of black life, both in the South and up North, during the 1920s. Wolfe, author of that satiric look at black history called ``The Colored Museum,'' uses song, mime, dance and story theater techniques to make Hurston's stories come alive. Under his direction, they have made the leap from page to stage with an irresistible theatricality. The first play, ``Sweat,'' is a familiar tale of a woman done wrong by her man. Delia, a religious, hard-working laundress, is increasingly battered by her philandering husband. Her revenge is positively serpentine. Danitra Vance personifies the woman's sweetness, while Reggie Montgomery portrays her doomed helpmate with a stylish sense of evil. Style also carries ``Story in Harlem Slang,'' an uproarious confrontation between two Harlem dandies who work hard at doing nothing at all. If their dialogue is often incomprehensible, the meaning is very clear as they attempt to cadge free meals from passing women. Montgomery and K. Todd Freeman play the preening roosters who don't miss a word or a beat as they strut their stuff. And the theater program contains a glossary of the more arcane terms for audiences who have to know every word. The longest play, ``The Gilded Six-Bits,'' forms the second half of the evening. It meanders a bit, and the story it tells is also one of love betrayed. But this time the victim is a husband whose wife falls for a wealthier man. And unlike the curtain-raiser, ``The Gilded Six-Bits'' is a plea for forgiveness that succeeds. The three sories are punctuated by some wonderful music, mostly blues, written and performed by the oddly named Chic Street Man. He is assisted by Ann Duquesnay, a woman who can sing and sashay with the best of them. Hurston's stories are testaments to the human spirit. Her people are more than just survivors. They thrive in adversity. In ``Spunk,'' Wolfe has managed to document the way they flourish with grace, good humor and affection.

DOC.HEAD: CDC to Require Special Permit for Importation of Lab Monkeys
DOC.TEXT: The national Centers for Disease Control on Wednesday effectively shut down the importation of research monkeys into the United States until importers present plans to combat a potentially deadly virus. The CDC announced that no rhesus, cynomolgus or African green monkeys may imported into this country _ or distributed out of quarantine _ unless accompanied by a special permit issued by the CDC director. The decision came amid concerns over an Ebola virus strain detected in shipments of laboratory monkeys from three Philippines importers. The permits must be issued at least 30 days prior to importation, which effectively suspends all imports for one month, even by those animal dealers not affected by the suspension of three major importers in March. At least one of the three suspended facilities, Charles River Primates Corp. of Port Washington, N.Y., was reinstated earlier this month. ``These three species of monkeys are capable of being an animal host ... of human disease,'' The CDC said in announcing the new restrictions on importing the three species. The CDC reported earlier this month that four animal handlers have become infected with a presumed Ebola virus carried by Philippine lab monkeys, although none have become ill. That's in contrast to patterns of infection with African Ebola virus, which typically attacks suddenly and produces serious, and often fatal, illness. Importers wishing to deal in laboratory monkeys must now submit to the CDC director a written plan outlining measures ``to prevent exposure of persons and animals during the entire importation and quarantine process,'' the CDC said. Researchers believe that as many as 10 percent of the lab monkeys coming into the United States have been infected with a filovirus _ the family of viruses including Ebola virus.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed in Bomb Blast at Bus Stand
DOC.TEXT: A bomb ripped through a packed bus stand in a village near the Afghan border Wednesday, killing three people and wounding 30, the government news agency said. No one claimed responsiblity for the explosion in Parachinar, along Pakistan's rugged border with Afghanistan. Scores of people have died and hundreds more have been wounded in bomb explosions that regularly rock cities and villages in Pakistan's Northwest Frontier province. Police refused to speculate on who may have planted Wednesday's bomb, though in the past they have often blamed agents of Afghanistan's Communist government. U.S.-backed rebels, waging a 12-year war with Kabul's ruling Communist government, are headquartered in Pakistan. More than 3 million Afghan war refugees have fled to Pakistan since 1979, when Soviet soldiers marched into the Central Asian nation to prop up an allied Communist government and put down a burgeoning Moslem insurgency. Last year Moscow withdrew its soldiers in line with a United Nations-brokered accord. The Moslem insurgents have said they would continue their fight until Kabul's Marxist government has been toppled.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Says Cuba-Soviet Relations Still Close
DOC.TEXT: President Fidel Castro said the Soviet Union is strengthening economic ties with Cuba despite domestic problems, the Cuban news agency said Wednesday. On Tuesday, the two countries signed an agreement calling for an 8.7 percent increase in trade and no cuts in Soviet sugar imports. In 1989 the Soviets purchased more than half of Cuba's sugar production. Also Tuesday, the head of the Soviet trade delegation, Leonid Abalkin, met with Castro and toured sports and oil installations, the Prensa Latina dispatch monitored in Mexico said. ``I can tell you that the contacts and the conversations were held in a very friendly atmosphere, one of great mutual understanding and of the best will on both sides to help satisfy the needs of the other,'' Castro was quoted as saying. Castro said the Soviet Union is ``making a great effort, in the midst of its own difficulties, to continue development of economic relations with this country.'' But he said democratic changes in Eastern Europe had left Cuba with a smaller circle of friends. Castro has vowed to uphold his country's socialist system rather than implement democratic and economic reforms. When asked if he ever planned to leave office, Castro said that politicians, doctors, painters and writers never retire, the press agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lanka Gov't Lifts Ban on Public Meeting
DOC.TEXT: The government on Wednesday lifted a ban on public meetings and relinquished the right to commandeer property and vehicles for safety reasons. The measures were among tough emergency regulations imposed in June to counter a violent anti-government campaign by Sinhalese radicals, who opposed government concessions to the minority Tamil population. A government statement said the regulations banning the meetings and permitting the seizure of property and vehicles were repealed. ``It is the desire of the government to lift the emergency altogether as soon as possible,' the statement said. At least 7,000 people have died in the insurgency, which came in a backlash to government concessions to the mostly Hindu Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the population. The mainly Buddhist Sinhalese make up 74 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. More than 11,000 people were killed since 1983 in a separatist Tamil insurgency. The government and the leading Tamil rebel group, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, reached an accord last summer under which they jointly police the Tamil-dominated north and east. The Tamil Tigers, however, still want independence, and the government not announced future plans for the region.

DOC.HEAD: Entertainer Ben Vereen Ordered to Pay $7,500 to Woman Claiming Assault
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Ben Vereen was ordered Wednesday to pay $7,500 to an aquaintance who claimed he broke into her home and assaulted her. In exchange for the money, the woman agreed to return Vereen's Les Brown recordings. Superior Court Judge Pro Tem Robert Zakon signed a three-page handwritten agreement worked out by attorneys that also stipulates Vereen and Christine Rich must stay at least 100 yards apart. In a complaint filed the day after the alleged March 1 attack, Ms. Rich claimed Vereen kicked in her apartment door and assaulted her. The actor ``grabbed my arm causing injuries, grabbed my neck, clothing and threw me to the ground,'' she said. ``I was able to dial 911 and the police arrived and placed defendant under arrest,'' she continued. ``I was placed in fear for my life and suffered great emotional distress requiring immediate therapy treatment.'' Under terms of the agreement, Vereen will pay Ms. Rich $7,500 and she will return ``two Les Brown tapes, any and all answering machine tapes and photographs of (Vereen) and letters from (Vereen) in her possession at any time.'' The agreement also prohibits Vereen and Ms. Rich from discussing the case. The exact relationship between Vereen and Ms. Rich was not known. Vereen, who appeared in the movie ``All That Jazz'' and such television miniseries as ``Roots,'' and ``Ellis Island,'' didn't attend the court proceeding.

DOC.HEAD: Quakes Jolt Northern California on '06 Great Quake Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th graf, `Nine quakes ...' with 3 grafs to ADD background with total number of quakes since October. Picks up 10th graf pvs: `The Richter ...' Subs 16th graf pvs.: `Ron Rutkowski . ..' to UPDATE with all power restored. Picks up 17th graf pvs: `Wednesday marked ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SLN1 and SC1; LaserGraphics
DOC.TEXT: About 75 earthquakes jolted Northern California on Wednesday, the anniversary of the catastrophic Great Quake of 1906. The temblors were aftershocks of the October quake that killed 67, geologists said. There were no reports of injuries or major damage from Wednesday morning's quakes, the largest measuring up to 5.4 on the Richter scale. Eight others registered at least 3.3. The temblors on the San Andreas Fault were felt from San Francisco to King City, 150 miles south. The San Andreas also caused the 1906 and Oct. 17 quakes. ``All the memories came back to the kids _ this one especially,'' Darrell Daniels said with his 4-year-old daughter, Eleth, on his lap. ``She won't let me go.'' The family is living in a mobile home because their home in downtown Watsonville was condemned after the October quake. Wednesday's aftershocks were centered about four miles east of Watsonville, 60 miles south of San Francisco. October's 7.1-magnitude quake caused major damage to the farming community. The temblors began at 6:38 a.m., shortly after a group of Great Quake surivors gathered in San Francisco to commemorate the 1906 disaster. The strongest quake Wednesday struck at 6:54 a.m. In all, about 75 were recorded, according to Pat Jorgenson, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Geological Survey in Menlo Park. Nine quakes of 3.3 or larger were recorded, the USGS said. Including the latest temblors, the number of aftershocks from the October quake registering 3.0 or more grew to 115. Of those, 38 had magnitudes of 4.0 or larger. The University of California-Berkeley Seismographic Station said the strongest quake Wednesday had a preliminary reading of 5.4 on the Richter scale. Allen Lindh of the USGS also issued a preliminary report of 5.4. The Richter scale is a gauge of energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number, for example from magnitude 5.5 to magnitude 6.5, means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. ``We are considering them aftershocks. They occurred in the same location of other aftershocks of Loma Prieta,'' said David Oppenheimer, a Geological Survey seismologist. Loma Prieta was the name given to October's quake. He said aftershocks from a magnitude-7.1 quake can continue for two years. ``We figured it was all over,'' said Robert Holleson, a former Watsonville resident who was visiting Wednesday. ``But the power's off, the phone's dead, helicopters are flying all over. It's like it's starting all over again.'' Early damage reports from the Watsonville area were light, with some dishes broken and small rockslides on Highway 152 into Watsonville. San Francisco police said many worried residents called, but no damage was reported. Ron Rutkowski, spokesman for Pacific Gas & Electric Co., said about 11,000 customers in the Watsonville and Santa Cruz area lost power. All service was restored by noon. Wednesday marked the 84th anniversary of the 1906 quake, which struck at 5:13 a.m. on April 18. Although the Richter scale didn't exist then, it was later determined that the quake's magnitude was 8.3. For decades it was believed that about 700 people died in the 1906 earthquake. But in recent years, research by San Francisco City Archivist Gladys Hansen documented at least 2,500 deaths, and she has said the real toll may be much higher. About 150 people gathered Wednesday at Lotta's Fountain in downtown San Francisco by 5:13 a.m. Some were heading to another commemoration when the first tremor occurred. ``One or two of the survivors commented that it didn't faze them at all as they had experienced THE big one,'' said organizer Taren Sapienza. The October quake caused more than $7 billion in damage and rattled residents who used to shrug off small temblors. That quake caused a double-deck section of Interstate 880 in Oakland to collapse, killing 42 people. Parts of three freeways that were damaged remain closed. On Tuesday, exactly six months after the quake, more than 100 people mingled at an earthquake-preparedness rally at San Francisco's Justin Herman Plaza, a few yards from the ruined Embarcadero Freeway. Around the plaza, people manned display tables, where pamphlets and disaster checklists were handed out. Pictures of the October earthquake destruction also were on review. At Watsonville's mobile home park, Jimmie Henson said even though Wednesday's quakes were smaller than October's, they were more destructive for her. The tremors caused cracks in the walls of her home and broke dishes and other small objects. ``I'm more upset today than I was from the big one _ much more,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Ivory Prices Fall Following International Ban on Trade
DOC.TEXT: An international ban on trade in ivory has sent prices plummeting on most traditional markets, the World Conservation Union said Wednesday. In several countries, shrinking demand also has led to reduced poaching, a study by the group said. Poaching was blamed as a major factor in reducing Africa's elephant population from 1.3 million to about 610,000 in the past 15 years. The treaty to protect the dwindling herds took effect Jan. 18, following a 103-nation meeting in October of members of the Convention on Trade in Endangered Species. It bans trade in ivory and all other elephant products. Five southern African nations which regularly cull their elephant populations _ Botswana, Malawi, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe _ filed for exemptions. China has declared it will continue to import the tusks. The World Conservation Union study says ivory prices in Africa, Europe and Africa fell significantly although they rose somewhat in Japan where ``high internal demand remains.'' The study cautioned, however, that with stockpiles rising because of natural mortality and confiscations, there is growing danger that much of this ivory will enter trade through nations that did not sign the treaty. It said the large quantities of stockpiled ivory, at least 250 tons in Africa and another 580 tons in consumer countries, thus ``may foster new markets, which will be difficult if not impossible to control.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Links Kremlin Action in Lithuania to Commerical Relations with U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 5-7: ``President Bush,'' with Bush non-comments in interview
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Luthuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III warned Wednesday that action by Moscow against Lithuania could doom commercial U.S.-Soviet relations as the administration sought details on reports of an oil cutoff. ``It's very difficult to see some of the commercial aspects of our relationship surviving the use of force or coercion'' against the independence-minded Baltic republic, Baker told the House Ways and Means Committee at a hearing on East Bloc economic reform. Baker spoke just hours before Lithuanian spokesmen said the Soviet Union shut off the supply of oil to Lithuania's only refinery, imposing part of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's threatened economic embargo. ``We've seen the reports,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``We don't have any independent verification. We are looking into it. We want to analyze the situation and I don't expect any response tonight.'' President Bush, in an interview with the ``World Monitor'' television show sponsored by the Christian Science Monitor broadcast Wednesday night on the Discovery Channel of cable systems, declined to answer a question about whether the United States would supply oil to Lithuania. He said the question was ``too hypothetical.'' Prodded that an aswer would ``be a message,'' Bush said, ``I understand that; I have a chance ... to send messages every single minute, and I don't elect to do that.'' Bush said he had not spoken with Lithuania's president, and had not spoken with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev since the Soviet oil threat last Friday. Fitzwater also said that the White House had received a private letter from Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. ``The letter was delivered to the State Department and forwarded to the White House. The president has not seen it yet but he will. We won't comment on the content,'' Fitzwater said. Lithuania's U.S. representative, Stasyas Lozoraitis Jr., said the letter was written March 19, about a week after the Lithuanian parliament declared independence, and brought out of the country by a traveler because the Lithuanian government did not trust Soviet handling of its mail. The letter ``simply explains the situation'' to Bush and said, ``We ask your political support,'' without making specific requests for help, Lozoraitis said. It was followed by letters to Pope John Paul II and French President Francois Mitterrand and others, the envoy said. He said he expects Landsbergis to write again. Baker, reading a carefully drafted statement at the congressional hearing, made it clear that U.S. action in response to any crackdown on by Gorbachev would be dictated by U.S. interests. He then listed areas of U.S.-Soviet cooperation that are in the interest of the United States, including ridding former stellite countries of Soviet military presence, conventional and nuclear arms control and economic reform in the Soviet Union. ``But some of our bilateral commercial contacts with the Soviet Union may be more directly in their interest than in ours,'' Baker added, inserting the word ``commercial,'' which did not appear in his written text. ``And those contacts are being put to risk by Soviet actions in Lithuania,'' he said. ``Our willingness and ability to take steps that benefit perestroika (economic and political restructuring) in the near term is, to be sure, affected by Soviet behavior. ``Perestroika, glasnost and democratization cannot be divisible. The reform process won't go forward and succeed if it is applied in some republics but not in others.'' Asked by reporters to clarify what commercial relationships would be endangered, Baker declined. Elsewhere in his testimony, Baker described ongoing talks on a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement, which coupled with codification of emigration reform could lead to most-favored-nation trading status for the Soviet Union. He also referred to future possibilities of lifting restrictions on U.S. lending to the Soviet Union, and to a bilateral investment treaty and a revised tax treaty. Gorbachev threatened last week to impose an embargo of critical supplies unless Lithuania rescinded within 48 hours several laws meant to bolster its March 11 declaration of independence. Lithuanian leaders have made no move to meet Gorbachev's demands, but say they are willing to negotiate. Gorbachev refuses to meet with them until they rescind their declaration of independence. In his testimony, Baker said it was time for the Soviets to begin a dialogue with the Lithuanians about how to resolve the question of independence. ``The Lithuanians want such a dialogue,'' he said. ``It seems to us that is the answer to the problem: dialogue, not economic boycotts, and not threats to invoke presidential rule.'' Members of the tax and trade panel generally welcomed the administration's cautious approach to the Lithuania problem. A typical comment came from liberal Rep. Tom Downey, D-N.Y. Some ``would love an excuse to jump-start the cold war,'' Downey said, adding that ``the measured response you have given to date is going to prove to be the correct one in the long sweep of history.''

DOC.HEAD: Men Vow To Continue Peyote Fight as Navajo, Hopi Express Support
DOC.TEXT: Two former drug counselors who were fired for eating psychedelic peyote as part of their religious practices expressed dismay that the U.S. Supreme Court ruled against them, but one said he won't give up. ``Maybe a battle's lost, but the war's not over,'' said Al Smith, 70, of Glenwood. ``I've lost battles before.'' In Arizona, leaders of the Hopi and Navajo tribes on Wednesday criticized the decision Tuesday by the nation's highest court. The ruling upheld Oregon officials' decision to deny unemployment benefits to Smith and Galen Black of Cottage Park. Justice Antonin Scalia, writing for the 6-3 majority, said it ``would be courting anarchy'' to let a few do what is illegal for everyone else. Dissenting justices said the ruling permits religious oppression of Indians, a view supported by Indian spiritual leaders. Black said the ruling went beyond a cultural slap and dehumanized everyone involved in the case. ``I'm astounded they've taken the people out and the law-book mentality is the only thing they know,'' he said Tuesday. ``They can't see that these people (who eat peyote) are searching out for something. Those people are searching for a little peace and tranquility within themselves.'' Smith, a Klamath Indian and recovering alcoholic, said he frequently attends Native American Church meetings and uses peyote, a small, button-shaped cactus containing the hallucinogen mescaline. Smith said the substance's effect in a church setting is spiritual rather than recreational. Black, who is not an Indian, also has attended church meetings. Black and Smith were fired after breaking a policy of ADAPT, the non-profit rehabilitation organization they worked for in Douglas County, Ore., by eating small amounts of peyote as part of a Native American Church sacrament. Smith said the effect of state Attorney General Dave Frohnmayer's case against him is ``cultural genocide'' in Oregon, and conflicts with the ideals of the framers of the U.S. Constitution. ``It's very important,'' Smith said. ``If the First Amendment doesn't protect me, how the hell's it going to protect you?'' The Native American Church is an umbrella group that claims at least 250,000 members belonging to 70 church chapters that practice the peyote ritual in 23 Western states. In Window Rock, Ariz., on Wednesday, interim Navajo Chairman Leonard Haskie said the ruling would affect many in the 200,000-member tribe who belong to the church. ``The ruling indicates the need to educate the U.S. government, state governments and society in general of the beliefs and practices of the Native American Church,'' Haskie said in a statement issued in the Navajo reservation's capital. Haskie said church members believe peyote use as a sacrament is as old as the origin of the Navajos. He said the Navajo government would do whatever was necessary to ensure that legal exemptions allowing religious use of peyote will continue in states surrounding the reservation. The reservation, which covers an area the size of West Virginia, sprawls across much of northeastern Arizona and into New Mexico and Utah. Haskie also called on members of Congress to strengthen safeguards against governmental encroachment on individual rights. In the Hopi capital of Kykotsmovi, Ariz., tribal Chairman Vernon Masyesva called the Supreme Court's decision ``unfortunate.'' Masayesva said religious rights should be inviolable by any considerations but national interests.

DOC.HEAD: Colombia Says Israeli Arms Turned up with Medellin Cartel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Three grafs SUB for grafs 14-15, The Colombian ... CORRECTING spelling of Afek and specifying he was killed in January, CORRECTING that Klein was a lt. col. Picks up 16th graf, Colombia's secret ...
DOC.TEXT: The Colombian Defense Ministry said weapons sold by Israel to a Caribbean island-nation mysteriously ended up in the hands of the powerful Medellin drug cartel, newspapers reported Wednesday. The weapons were originally sold by Israel in early 1989 to the tiny country of Antigua and Barbuda, according to a communique released Tuesday by the Defense Ministry. The communique, signed by Defense Minister Oscar Botero, was published Wednesday in daily newspapers. Soldiers found 232 Israeli-made weapons in February during a search of ranches seized from Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, a major drug trafficker who was killed in a December gun battle with police, Botero said. A Feb. 2 search of one ranch owned by Rodriguez Gacha turned up more than 100 of the Israeli weapons and $3.2 million in cash, Botero said. The weapons found at the drug trafficker's ranches included assault rifles, machine guns, submachine guns, pistols, shoulder-fired rockets and infrared night scopes, the communique said. The defense minister said the seized Israeli weapons originally were sold to Antigua and Barbuda, but authorities have not been determined how the weapons wound up with Medellin drug traffickers. He said authorities in Israel and the Caribbean nation were investigating the matter. A spokeswoman for the Israeli Embassy in Bogota, Anna Cecilia de Nieto, said the embassy would have no comment on the communique. On Feb. 5, Colombia privately complained about the weapons to the Israeli government. The Israeli government told Colombia last month that the weapons discovered at Rodriguez Gacha's property had been sold by Israel to Antigua and Barbuda last year, Botero said. The minister said Colombia issued a formal protest to Antigua and Barbuda on April 3. Since the two countries do not have diplomatic relations, the protest was issued through the Organization of American States. The complaint against the island nation was not made public at the time. The mystery over the Israeli weapons follows a scandal that broke last year concerning the alleged involvement of Israeli mercenaries in training the Medellin cartel's private armies. The Colombian government has formally charged two Israelis, Yair Klein and Arik Afek, with complicity with the Medellin cartel. Colombian authorities have requested the extradition of Klein, a former Israeli army lieutenant colonel, who is in Israel. Afek was discovered dead on Jan. 24 in the trunk of his parked car at Miami International Airport in what police describe as a gangland slaying. Colombia's secret police have identified at least five other alleged Israeli mercenaries who were in the country in 1987. Klein has said he was told he was training Colombian ranchers and peasants to defend themselves against leftist guerrillas. But Colombian authorities said the Israelis were actually training the Medellin cartel's gunmen. Investigators determined the cartel had also hired British and Australian mercenaries to train and equip its army, which is believed to have as many as 4,000 gunmen.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Pardon Board Recommends Freedom for Killer-Turned-Journalist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix writethru designation. INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf, `Rideau said ...,' to UPDATE with further Rideau comment; SUBS 7th graf, `Rideau said ...,' to DELETE now-redundant reference to telephone interview.
DOC.TEXT: The Louisiana Pardon Board on Wednesday recommended that Wilbert Rideau, a convicted murderer who became an award-winning journalist behind bars, be set free after 29 years in prison. The final decision will be made by Gov. Buddy Roemer, who has cited the viciousness of Rideau's crimes in refusing to commute his life sentence in the past. After Wednesday's decision, Roemer said he had no plans to do so now. ``It's difficult. I wish I had an easy answer. But my inclination is not to accept their recommendation,'' the governor said. Rideau said Wednesday in a telephone interview from Louisiana State Penitentiary in Angola that he'd be a free man now if he'd spent his time in prison making license plates instead of writing. ``I've become distinguished because I did some good over the years I've been in here,'' he said. ``The problem with doing good and being productive is that you acquire notoriety and that goes against getting out.'' The five-member board voted unanimously to reduce the 48-year-old prison magazine editor's sentence to 55 years, which defense attorney Julian Murray said would qualify him for immediate release. ``This is the same recommendation this board made in 1988,'' said board Chairwoman Yvonne Campbell. ``It was based on his prison record, his accomplishments, and he has only had one writeup in his 29 years in prison.'' Two board members also recommended that Rideau be required to leave the state permanently, contribute part of the earnings from his writing to the victims' reparation fund and be ordered to perform some community service. Rideau said, ``I appreciate the board of pardons having once against expressed their belief in my worth and potential as a human being. ``They have also expressed their continued belief in the American principle of equal justice, judging me the same way they judge every other person in this state who has been convicted of murder and then released.'' Rideau didn't attend the hearing, but about 30 friends and supporters did. It was the seventh time he has applied for clemency after being sentenced to death for the 1961 murder of a bank teller in an armed robbery. His sentence was commuted to life in 1973 when the U.S. Supreme Court overturned the death penalty. Murray Henderson, former warden of the state prison at Angola, told the board he'd known Rideau for 20 years. ``I have seen a man who has changed, who has grown, who has developed into a mature, hard-working person,'' Henderson said. ``He should have been released 15 years ago, or at least 10. I don't know what more he can do. ... ``Certainly no useful purpose could be served by his continued incarceration,'' Henderson said. ``You could send him to Harvard cheaper than you could keep him there.'' Former state Secretary of Corrections Paul Phelps also urged that Rideau be released. Others, however, argued against clemency. Frank Salter, one of the prosecutors at Rideau's trial, noted that, because of appeals Rideau won, he was tried three times and sentenced to death each time. ``The vote was 36-0 for the death penalty,'' Salter said. ``Wilbert Rideau has had his clemency.'' Rick Bryant, an assistant prosecutor in Calcasieu Parish, called the premeditated robbery and murder one of the most heinous ever in the parish. ``I've spoken with people who are still terrified of Wilbert Rideau,'' Bryant said. ``We do believe Mr. Rideau has received his clemency. He's not dead.'' The Parole Board has recommended clemency for Rideau three times since 1984, and governors have refused to grant clemency each time. The last time was in 1988, under Roemer. Rideau said Wednesday he was dismayed that the governor appeared to make a decision after only listening to a survivor of his crime. ``Everything else _ the hearing, the pardon board decision, everything else _ is a hollow finality,'' he said. Rideau was sentenced to die in the electric chair for the murder of Gulf National Bank teller Julia Ferguson after the 1961 holdup in the southwest Louisiana town of Lake Charles. Rideau, then 19, forced two tellers and the branch manager, all of whom he knew, into a car at gunpoint, drove them to a deserted road and shot all three. When Mrs. Ferguson begged for her life, Rideau cut her throat and stabbed her in the heart. She was the only one who died. Rideau's prison prose earned him and his magazine, the Angolite, national honors, including the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award, the American Bar Association's Silver Gavel Award and the George Polk Award for special interest reporting. It also has allowed him to travel, with guards. Two weeks ago, Rideau went to the American Society of Newspaper Editors' meeting in Washington to speak about prison journalism. Rideau says he has offers of journalism jobs if he can get out of prison. But he worries that his case attracts so much attention it puts extra pressure on the governor.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Cleanup of Prince William Sound To Begin
DOC.TEXT: The cleanup of environmentally sensitive areas of Prince William Sound fouled by the Exxon Valdez oil spill may resume as early as Friday, Exxon Corp. and government officials said Wednesday. A boat carrying Exxon's first 1990 cleanup crew will be ready to begin work then, said Andy Teal, coordinator of Exxon's shoreline cleanup assessment team. The crew may initially begin cleaning sea bird rookeries and areas where seals and sea lions congregate, Teal said, in order to minimize disrupting nesting activities in May. The need to clean those sites is not yet certain, however. He said the first sites to be cleaned will not be determined until the federal coordinator on the scene gives the go-ahead. The coordinator, Rear Adm. David Ciancaglini, is expected to begin approving site cleanup recommendations soon, said Coast Guard spokesman Ernest Del Bueno. The general cleanup of remaining oiled shorelines in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska begins May 1, Exxon officials said. The 1989 cleanup was halted Sept. 15 in anticipation of winter. Hundreds of miles of shoreline in Prince William Sound were covered with an oily goo when the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground on a charted reef on March 24, 1989, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil. Countless fish, otters, other mammals and sea birds were killed. Exxon says it spent more than $2 billion in last year's cleanup, hiring more than 10,000 workers and leasing more than 1,000 boats for the operation. The company says it plans a greatly reduced cleanup this year. A technical advisory group composed of representatives of the Coast Guard, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation and Exxon has been meeting for a week to determine cleanup methods for about 600 shoreline sites. Recommendations include simply picking up tar-laden mats coating rocky shorelines, and raking, shoveling and using backhoes or other equipment to remove deep-seated oil from rocks and soil. Proposals also include spraying fertilizer or chemicals on beaches to break down the remaining oil. Certain cleanup methods have created some controversy, and state regulators have not yet said whether they will approve the use of fertilizers on shorelines or the introduction of large machinery. Exxon and a subsidiary, Exxon Shipping Co., are scheduled to go on trial in U.S. District Court in Anchorage on June 18 on two felony charges and three misdemeanors in the spill. The skipper of the Exxon Valdez, Capt. Joseph Hazelwood, was convicted last month of a misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil into state waters, but was acquitted of more serious charges.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Asks Appeals Court to Continue Reuters Picture Exchange
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs to UPDATE with UPI comment.
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for United Press International told a federal appeals court Wednesday it could go out of business if Reuters is allowed to terminate a photo exchange agreement. Three judges of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision on UPI's request for an injunction barring Reuters from terminating the contract. The judges, however, extended an earlier stay that keeps the agreement in effect until they issue a written decision. The contract between the news services was made in 1984 and called for UPI to supply Reuters with pictures from the United States and for Reuters to provide UPI with pictures from other countries. It was to run for 10 years beginning in 1985. ``We will immediately lose customers the minute Reuters cuts us off,'' UPI lawyer Mitchell Karlan told the court. ``If we are unable to get pictures from Reuters, UPI is going out of business.'' UPI is appealing a decision by U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure that the agency had not shown it would be irreparably harmed if the arrangement was discontinued. The injunction request stemmed from a counterclaim by UPI to a Reuters lawsuit that seeks to void the picture exchange agreement. Reuters said the agreement was not living up to expectations. Robert Sugarman, an attorney for Reuters, argued against the injunction on the grounds that UPI had not shown how many customers it would lose without foreign photos from Reuters. Sugarman pointed to testimony from UPI Chairman Earl Brian that UPI had negotiated to receive foreign photos from the French news service, Agence France-Presse, for a three-month period in the event the Reuters contract is discontinued. In a statement, Brian said, ``We will continue to pursue UPI's rights by confronting Reuters' erratic and unwarranted behavior. We take further encouragement from today's hearing and continuation of the order against Reuters. ``We at UPI consider photos and graphics a strategically vital component of our business today and in the 1990s,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Holds Federal Government to Agreement on Quake Aid
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ordered the government Wednesday to carry out an agreement to repair or replace more than 2,200 units of rental housing for people who were displaced by last October's earthquake. U.S. District Judge Eugene Lynch rejected arguments by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that the agreement was signed under a misunderstanding and should be cancelled or changed to limit FEMA's obligations. Legal Aid lawyers said FEMA was trying to eliminate more than two-thirds of the aid it had promised to provide. ``Now we can get on with implementation of the agreement,'' attorney Stephen Ronfeldt of the Legal Aid Society of Alameda County told reporters. ``FEMA's job is to address an emergency, not to back out of an agreement.'' He said FEMA is required to make money available to local government to repair the housing units, build new housing or provide the former residents with housing vouchers by mid-July. The agreement covers Alameda, San Francisco and Santa Cruz counties. Assistant U.S. Attorney George Stoll said local FEMA officials were awaiting instructions from Washington. The units were in residential hotels and other single-room rentals that were made uninhabitable by the Oct. 17 quake. FEMA was sued by poor people who were denied housing aid because they had not lived in their last residence at least 30 days, or because they lived in housing shared with others who received aid. In the settlement, signed Feb. 23, FEMA agreed to make funding available to replace all lost low-income housing units in the three counties. But a month later, the agency said it did not consider itself required to replace housing for displaced people who had found new homes and were receiving temporary cash help from the government. Lynch ruled, however, that FEMA was bound by the agreement, which required replacement of all the housing units.

DOC.HEAD: Romania Writers Declare Artistic, Political Independence
DOC.TEXT: The Writers' Union on Wednesday opened its first congress since the ouster of Nicolae Ceausescu with a declaration of political and artistic independence after decades of following the Communist leader's dictates. At its four-day session, the congress plans to pass statutes for the 1,700-member union calling for political and financial autonomy of writers from the state. Poet Mircea Dinescu, interim chairman of the organization and a former leading dissident, urged Romanian writers in a keynote speech to discard fears that prevented them from freely expressing their thoughts. ``Our congress will help us to abandon our fear to speak our minds,'' Dinescu told a reporter after the meeting. He was held under house arrest for more than six months under Ceausescu, who was executed in December. The Writers' Union was run by the Council of Socialist Education and Culture, a state body which dictated cultural life in Romania in accordance with Ceausescu's wishes, for more than four decades of Communist rule. The council was dismantled after the December revolution and its leaders are now in government custody. Dinescu said the union now will be free of state censorship and of the former secret police who used to keep close tabs on free expression and writers who strayed from established cultural policy. ``We now say goodbye to government officials,'' Dinescu told about 1,000 writers gathered in the Palace Hall, traditional site of Ceausescu's Communist Party congresses. ``We were in the Middle Ages then, but now we will not bow our pens anymore in front of the government,'' said Stefan Augustin Doinas, a member of the 30-writer panel presiding over the congress. Doinas, a poet jailed by Communists in the early 195Os for deviating from Moscow-imposed strictures on culture, is expected to become the union's new chairman at the conclusion of the congress, delegates said.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes off Contadora, 4 Americans Among 20 Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with search suspended, Americans identified. Pick up 10th pvs, `The plane...'
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine plane carrying 22 people crashed Wednesday minutes after takeoff from Contadora island when birds were sucked into its right engine, Aeroperlas airline said. It said 20 people were missing and two were rescued. Passenger lists showed four Americans aboard the aircraft, the airline and control tower said. U.S. planes, boats and divers joined Panamanian rescue workers in the search for survivors of the Twin Otter plane in 120-foot-deep Pacific waters three miles south of the resort, the U.S. Southern Command said. The search was suspended Wednesday night and will resume Thursday morning, said Panama's director of civil aviation, Jaime Fabrega. The Americans were listed as Anita Heck, Karl Heck, Lisa Larglow and Richard Poux, according to Panamanian civil aviation sources. No hometowns and ages were available, and late Wednesday the State Department in Washington said it had no details on the plane crash or the Americans on board. Asked if other survivors had been located, Fabrega said, ``For now, no.'' He told reporters, ``Since we haven't reached the plane, it would be foolish to say anything more.'' A statement by the airline blamed the crash on the failure of the right engine after a group of birds flew into it at takeoff. Aviation experts say that in such incidents, the impact of the birds causes the engine's turbines to stop, forcing the plane to stall. The statement added that those rescued and taken to Panama City were ``Frederick Pirot Jr., 14, and Mrs. Ana Jury.'' The passenger list shows two others with the name of Pirot _ presumably related to him. Mrs. Jury, of Switzerland, suffered a broken vertebra, and Pirot, of France, suffered a broken arm, the airline said. The rest of the passengers and two crew members were Panamanians, the Civil Aviation office said. The plane was en route from Contadora, about 50 miles southeast of Panama City, to the capital. The Pacific resort island is where former Panamanian leader Omar Torrijos gave refuge for several months to the Shah of Iran, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, after the shah's 1979 exile. It also was the site of a 1981 meeting by four Latin foreign ministers, Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Panama, to negotiate the first attempts at peace in Central America.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Representative Meets U.S. Official
DOC.TEXT: PLO official Hakam Balawi told U.S. diplomat Edmund Hull on Tuesday that only an international conference can bring lasting peace in the Middle East, the official Palestinian news agency WAFA reported. Balawi's comments to Hull, counselor to U.S. Ambassador Robert Pelletreau, reflect the Palestine Liberation Organization's long-standing goal of an international conference on the Mideast. ``The two men discussed the peace process and international efforts to give it a new impetus,'' the WAFA communique said. The communique criticized Israel for ``obstructing'' peace efforts. Balawi, an adviser to PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat, said an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue could only be a preparatory step toward an international settlement, the WAFA statement said. The meeting follows one Thursday between Balawi and Pelletreau. The U.S. Embassy in Tunisia became the sole U.S. government body authorized to hold talks with the PLO after the organization renounced violence in December 1988. The embassy does not comment on its meetings with the PLO.

DOC.HEAD: Greece Warns It May Expel Syrian Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: Greece on Tuesday warned it would expel a Syrian diplomat unless he gave a satisfactory explanation to a statement that appeared to support terrorism. Foreign Minister Antonis Samaras summoned Syrian Ambassador Shahine Farrah and asked him to explain a statement made by the embassy's economic counselor Mohamed El Sayed in a press release last week. The newspaper Apogevmatini said last week that Sayed had said in a release that, ``I am an educated and religious man, and naturally I do not rule out absolutely any form of violence in political activity.'' Sayed said the statement was incorrect and that his typist had added a single letter to its Greek text, changing the meaning of what he said was intended to be a rejection of violence. Government spokesman Vyron Polydoras said: ``The foreign minister warned that the diplomat in question will be classified persona non grata, with all that that implies, in the event that the explanations are not deemed satisfactory.'' In a telephone interview Sayed said, ``We have sent our explanation of the mistake to the newspaper. Tomorrow the embassy will forward it to the Foreign Ministry.'' In his press release Sayed also denied an April 8 report in Apogevmatini claiming that he was involved in the assassination of conservative lawmaker Pavlos Bakoyannis on Sept. 26. Bakoyannis, spokesman of the conservative New Democracy party and son-in-law of newly-elected Premier Constantine Mitsotakis, was killed by unidentified gunmen. The shadowy November 17 leftist terrorist group claimed responsibility for the murder. The group has killed 14 people since it first emerged in 1975. None of its members have been arrested.

The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy, who shared 17 jail cells with Martin Luther King Jr., marched with him in Selma, cradled his bloody head in Memphis and broke with his followers over a tell-all memoir, is dead at 64. Abernathy died Tuesday at Crawford Long Hospital while being prepared for a lung scan to locate a suspected blood clot, hospital spokeswoman Tisha Burland said. The cause of death was not immediately known. As King's chief lieutenant, Abernathy was at his side at almost every key battle of the civil rights movement of the 1950s and '60s and took his place as leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference after King's 1968 assassination. But the fame and adulation enjoyed by King never quite extended to Abernathy. In a 1986 interview, he lamented that during a visit to a school in Connecticut, ``not a single student knew who I was.''

Diets with about twice the amount of fiber and vegetables now consumed by most Americans can reduce the risk of colon cancer by about 40 percent, a government study shows. A research report published today in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute reviewed 37 studies conducted since 1973 and found what it called ``a great deal of evidence'' that diets rich in fiber and vegetables protect people against colon cancer. ``The data ... suggest a reduction in risk of approximately 40 percent for persons consuming diets high in fiber and vegetables,'' the report said. ``Furthermore, there are undeniable cardiovascular benefits and little likelihood of adverse consequences associated with this data.'' Bruce Trock, a researcher at Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia, said the evidence ``is powerful'' and very clear.

Federal investigators following the money trail left by Colombian drug dealers say the Medellin cocaine cartel stashed $400 million in 754 U.S. bank accounts _ most of them now frozen under court order. The Justice Department said it won a court order freezing 684 U.S. bank accounts as a result of a painstaking investigation of financial transactions used by Colombian drug lords to hide at least $1.2 billion. The order, signed by a federal judge in Atlanta, also directed 173 banks in 22 states and the nation's capital to provide records to prosecutors. The Justice Department said Tuesday its long-running investigation of Colombian drug dealers, dubbed ``Operation Polar Cap,'' determined that the accounts once contained $400 million the Medellin cartel amassed from selling cocaine in America.

A Ku Klux Klansman arrested for wearing a hood in violation of state law has his day in court Thursday in a confrontation over whether the Constitution guarantees the right of anonymous free speech. ``Any law that infringes on any person's First Amendment rights infringes on all our rights,'' said Michael Hauptman, Klansman Shade Miller's lawyer. Miller was charged with violating the 1951 law in February after wearing a KKK hood at the county courthouse in Lawrenceville. The case is being watched closely by civil rights leaders, who credit the law with helping reduce Klan violence in the last four decades.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv19
For Release Wed PMs, April 19, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: PBS Havel Documentary Really is History
DOC.TEXT: Imagine a life in which you're banned from practicing your profession. Teacher? You can't teach. Painter? Put away those brushes. Playwright? You will never see your work performed in your own country. Worse, the government will incarcerate you for defying those rules. And when you're not in prison, it will find you work _ as a cab driver and a brewery worker. This was the life of Vaclav Havel, the dissident Czechoslovakian playwright who now leads a country still hungover from the intoxicating revolution that has rewritten its history. To get a gut feeling for what Havel's life has been like lately, watch ``Havel's Audience with History'' on PBS Friday. Hosted by Paul Newman, the documentary chronicles the first public performance of a Havel play in Czechoslovakia. It is January, and Havel has been president for two weeks. The play, titled ``Audience,'' is 15 years old and the new Czechoslovakian leader is in the emotional audience. His disheveled manner makes him one of the world's most unlikely presidential candidates. The play premiered Jan. 8 at the Cinoherni Club, just off Wenceslas Square, the site of Czechoslovakia's mass demonstrations. The fact it debuted at all was due to two New York-based documentary producers who thought ``God, we've got to do this.'' Robert Kanter and Michael Wolkowitz first saw ``Audience'' performed in New York by Newman's Actors Studio. That was December, and Czechoslovakia's ``Velvet Revolution'' was in full tilt. What if, Kanter and Wolkowitz thought, we took this production to Prague? In 47 days, they arranged the financing, secured Havel's blessings, lugged a crew onto a trans-Atlantic flight and completed filming. ``We never stopped to question it,'' said Kanter, 37, in a phone interview from New York. ``From the beginning, we thought this was something we had to do.'' But seeing it become a reality was overwhelming. ``I cried, Michael cried. It was probably the most incredible theatrical experience of my life,'' he said. Foreign correspondent Dan Fisher, who covered the ``Velvet Revolution'' for the Los Angeles Times, also was in the ``Audience'' audience. ``To actually see it done in public is something else,'' Fisher said in a phone interview from London. ``Audience,'' laden with obscenities and chock-full of absurdity, showcases a sodden conversation between a sleazy, communist brewmaster and the blacklisted playwright forced to work for him. Havel molded the playwright after himself. The brewmaster is a composite of brewery workers he was ordered to work with. The country prohibited its publication, but Czechoslovakians typed the play and passed it through the underground. It was so well-read that hitchhikers could recite it verbatim. Kanter and Wolkowitz's production ran four performances. Two were in English _ featuring the Actors Studio cast _ and two in Czech, starring Czech actors. In the Czech version of the two-character, one-act play, exiled actor Pavel Landovsky, a longtime friend of Havel's, walked onto a Czechoslovakian stage for the first time in 12 years. In the documentary, alongside outtakes of the ``Audience'' performances, interviews and film clips chronicle Havel's long and torturous battle as playwright and dissident. The new president is left-handed, writes at night and can't chop wood worth a darn, we learn from his wife, Olga. Childhood pal and lifetime friend, film director Milos Forman, says that in school, Havel ``was the most shy, inconspicuous kid.'' That is obvious while watching Havel address the Cinoherni Club audience, which was double the theater's capacity and spilled out onto the street, where television monitors had been mounted. The president alternately stared at his fingernails and picked at his moustache while talking to theater-goers that included new heads of state, U.S. congressmen and American Ambassador Shirley Temple Black. To get to the Cinoherni Club, Havel drove himself. The irony of Havel's work is perhaps best summed up by Forman, who notes during the PBS documentary: ``The good news is that Vaclav Havel is the president of Czechoslovakia. The bad news is that he can't ever write plays again.''

Elsewhere in Television ... WHOLE LOT OF HAVEL: If you're interested in seeing more of Havel's work, tune in early Friday. PBS will broadcast Havel's ``Largo Desolato,'' starring Oscar-winner F. Murray Abraham, Phoebe Cates and Sally Kirkland. This play also draws on Havel's life, focusing on two days in the life of a dissident writer who is waiting for the knock at the door that may send him to prison.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Stands Out As Activist in Largely Passive Cabinet
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Jack Kemp, according to Jack Kemp, is a bleeding heart conservative supply side progressive suburban Republican, and never mind the commas. That compound description comes in one burst. Kemp is an activist in a relatively passive administration. And glad to be there, he says, on the team, not the pitcher or the catcher but nevertheless fielding an important position in the George Bush lineup. It is a politically delicate position because he inherited a Republican scandal. ``I'm not the Republican National Committee chairman, as I tell anybody who wants me to come in to speak in their district,'' Kemp says. ``I'm the secretary of housing and urban development.'' As the boss of the Cabinet agency that bequeathed this administration a Reagan-era scandal over political influence-peddling and federal grants, Kemp says he has rationed his role in the 1992 congressional campaign. ``Do I go? Yes,'' he said over his rapidly cooling salmon lunch. ``Am I careful? Yes ... I don't want this to be confused with the Republican committee, as it was in the past.'' Nor, Kemp said, should he be confused with the candidate he was in the past. Not now, anyhow. He is purposefully vague about the political future, saying that he likes what he's doing, sees it as an opportunity for Republicans to demonstrate that they care about the cities and the poor and can improve the lot of both. Kemp waves off the observation that the Republican administration wants to spend less, not more, on the construction of housing for the poor. He says that's not the way to do it, that tax and other incentives will spur private investment while the prospect of owning their homes will help the poor break out of the welfare and project housing cycle. It's the same supply-side theory Kemp advanced as the House sponsor of the tax cut that eventually became the centerpiece of Reaganomics. Now he argues for President Bush's proposal to cut the capital gains tax rate, saying it will benefit low income Americans by creating jobs and opportunities, and for the enterprise zone plan he pushed as a member of Congress. That program would waive the capital gains tax altogether, and provide other tax breaks to attract investment into economically blighted districts. Critics call it trickle-down Republican economics. Kemp told Congress it would open a Niagara Falls of economic growth in depressed neighborhoods. And he tells Republicans that if they show a real and lasting commitment to dealing with the problems of low-income Americans, theirs will become the majority party. Kemp is pushing that mission, and not quietly. He says he wants this administration to wage war on poverty, with different methods but about the same goals as the one attempted by Lyndon B. Johnson. That slogan isn't popular with everyone around the Cabinet table, but Kemp isn't deterred. ``I try to be pithy in my advice,'' he says, smiling. Kemp is not in a job he sought, but now that he has it, he tells audiences he was born for it. His first choice, of course, would have been the presidency. He sought the 1988 Republican nomination with conservative backing, but limped in the primaries and quit the race early. He was on the list of vice presidential prospects, and would have relished the nomination Dan Quayle got. In the Cabinet he would have preferred Treasury. But HUD is working out. For all the headaches that go with the earlier ethics and influence scandals, those problems made it an agency in need of change, reform and repair, and that makes Kemp's role more visible. While he won't speculate on a possible next step, Kemp said ``it is no secret'' that he would not want to stay at the department through eight years of a Bush administration. Then he quickly adds that ``I want to stay on the team,'' for as long as the president wants him. Kemp says he's a team player, part of what he describes as the outer circle of the Bush administration. ``I don't expect to be on the inner circle,'' he said. The real insiders were with Bush before his nomination; in those days Kemp was an opponent. He said he harbors no thoughts about running for president again _ an obligatory disclaimer for a political figure in his situation. ``I've had three great careers,'' said Kemp, 54, a professional football quarterback, then a nine-term New York congressman before he joined the Bush Cabinet. ``I have absolutely no thoughts of '96. ``I'll be 61 or 62,'' he said. ``I'll be too old.'' Bush was 64 when he was inaugurated.

DOC.HEAD: Funds Still Face Safety Questions
DOC.TEXT: It may be true that it never rains on investors in money market mutual funds. But every now and then in money-fund land the rumble of distant thunder can be heard. That message was driven home afresh a few days ago with the news that a prominent firm that manages a group of funds had dipped into its own pocket to protect its money fund against the threat of a loss. T. Rowe Price Associates of Baltimore, which runs a $28 billion-plus stable of investments that includes 30 mutual funds, said it had bought $64.6 million in securities of Mortgage & Realty Trust from portfolios it manages. The market price of M&RT's commercial paper, or short-term IOUs, appeared ready to suffer a drop after the real estate investment trust filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. Though T. Rowe Price said it hopes and expects M&RT eventually to pay everything it owes on the paper, the firm acted to stave off even the possibility of a small and temporary dip in the net asset value of its Prime Reserve Fund and unspecified other pools of money. Price wasn't the only fund manager caught in that bind. Erick Kanter, a spokesman for the Investment Company Institute, a trade group, said there were ``about half a dozen'' in all, but declined to identify any of the others. In no case, apparently, did money fund shareholders lose any money, since the fund sponsors followed a precedent that is fast becoming the customary practice in cases like this. When a fund is sitting on an investment that is losing market value because of a drop in the issuer's credit standing, it can be made whole through the sale of that security to the separate entity, with different owners, that sponsors the fund. Still, the fact remains that fund managers typically are under no legal obligation to do this, and conceivably could find themselves unable to take such action in some future instance involving large, multiple defaults. Money funds, however safe their records may be, remain securities subject to at least theoretical risks, without any backing from federal deposit insurance or any other government guarantee. But that basic disclaimer doesn't answer the question of what further responsibilities, if any, should fall on the industry as in continues the growth that has brought it nearly $400 billion in assets in just two decades of existence. Right now, the chief response of many fund advisers seems to have been to upgrade the safety of their holdings _ especially in commercial paper, where they are already forbidden to venture beyond issuers with high credit ratings. From the point of view of money-fund investors, and of a financial system in which the funds play an increasingly important role, is that enough? Even the highest rating is no absolute assurance of safety in an investment like commercial paper, which normally is not secured by any particular asset of the corporation that issues it. Says James Grant, financial newsletter publisher and frequent critic of many credit practices of recent years: ``Now that the corporate credit risk has been positively identified in the junk-bond market, perhaps it is time to look somewhere else for it.'' At the same time, officials in the industry dismiss recurrent conjecture that they might have set up or be planning to create some unpublicized rainy-day reserve to help cope with any future crisis. Perhaps some day money funds will have a backup system analagous to deposit insurance in banking. But it could prove a painful error for investors to suppose that any such thing exists today.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thurs April 19
