For Release PMs Thursday, April 19
DOC.HEAD: Goodbye '60s. Hello '90s
DOC.TEXT: Corporate management is maturing, and it probably means a more competitive industrial America in the 1990s. ``It is very good news,'' says Professor Eugene Jennings. Jennings' assessment is based on research of corporate and managerial data, an endeavor now into its fifth decade, making it the longest existing and continuing study of business by the same researcher. It began in the 1950s with the curiosity of a young man seeking to make his mark in university circles. It continues with the same intensity, but the man is now a professor emeritus, adviser to corporate chairmen and a prolific author. In writing the manuscript for a new book, to be called ``Chiefs,'' Jennings, professor emeritus of management at Michigan State University's graduate school of business, found that American corporate management now blends some of the best of the new ideas with those proven in the past. It leads him to conclude: ``Industrial America is probably better positioned for competition now than ever before, judging from the qualities of chiefs selected in the past decade.'' The comparisons of various measurements of corporate chiefs are consistent, each tending to support the other. First, Jennings compared the ratios of what he calls natives and immigrants. In his lexicon, a native is a chief who grew up within the company, and an immigrant is one appointed from outside the business. In pre-1960s days corporations were inflexible. Chiefs almost always were named from within the company. In the 1960s the ratio became 50-50, meaning just as many were brought into the company as were nurtured within. In the 1980s, however, the ratios shifted back to a middle position. Now, three times as many chief executives are appointed from within as from without. It indicates, says Jennings, that boards are being more selective in their search for the best. No longer are they blind to the possibilities of outsiders, but they also recognize the importance of promoting from within. He made another comparison. In pre-1960s, there was no such thing as an early arrival, or a person appointed chief executive at age 49 or younger. In the 1960s, 40 percent were early arrivals. Now, it is down to 25 percent. The blend of old and new continues in another test. In the pre-watershed days of the 1960s, so-called late arrivals, age 58 or older, made up 30 percent of appointments. In the 1960s, late arrivals dropped out of sight. Companies wanted young blood. But in the 1980s the percentage rose to 21 percent. At this point, says Jennings, some people might think of the 1960s as irresponsible. At any rate, he said, they had very poor screening of the top executives. The anti-establishment attitude, it seems, rose to the very top. A fourth test underscored the consistency of old to new to middle ground. In pre-watershed days almost nobody was named chief executive who didn't have his hands on the product, such as in sales and manufacturing. These people are often said to have on-line experience. In the 1960s, that old way changed. More than 50 percent were named who had no hands on experience. But in the 1980s, screening committees rediscovered the old ways. The percentage without hands on experience dropped to 27 percent. Still another test showed similar results. Migrant chiefs, or chairmen appointed from outside, were uncommon before the 1960s. But all, at least, had experience within the industry. In the 1960s, however, only a slim majority of those named chief had experience within the same industry. But that too changed; in the 1980s, the vast majority of migrants had experience within the particular industry. Same trend with another test, this one age. Before the 1960s, it took 33 years to produce a chief. In the decade of the 1960s it took only 21.5 years. Then in the 1980s, it rose to 26 years, as industry opted for more experience. To Jennings it means that today American industry wants, and is getting, seasoned and sure-footed executives, preferring them to ``the younger, vital, exhuberant types.'' In a sense, he says, screening committees are seeking better corporate health, just as all America does when it seeks better nutrition and care in handling drugs and artery-clogging foods. Business is choosing good blood over fresh blood, he says. Industry, he says, is getting a ``better balance of proteins and carbohydrates rather than fresh blood hyped with vitamins.''

DOC.HEAD: Namibians Applaud United Nations for Mission Accomplished
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations had a major success in guiding this vast, arid land to independence from South Africa and learned important lessons for future operations in troubled aear-long effort was one of the world organizatioreas. The yn's largest and most expensive. The U.N. mission overcame several crises that threatened to derail independence for Namibia after 75 years of South African rule. As the United Nations withdraws, it is being praised by Namibia and other countries. Local residents gave farewell parties for the personnel of U.N. offices around the new country, sometimes slaughtering sheep and oxen for the occasion. ``UNTAG will forever be remembered by our people,'' Foreign Minisy matters dealt with by field workers had nothing to do with independence. ``The local UNTAG stations became a place to bring one's problems,'' Eckhard said. ``People even sought help for marital disputes.'' South Africa threatened to cancel the elections days before the scheduled date in November, claiming U.N. radio traffic was reporting an infiltration by SWAPO guerrillas. South Africa withdrew the allegations, but suspicions remained. Seven political parties, led by SWAPO, won constituent assembly seats in an election that attracted 97 percent of the eligible voters. ``We effectively trained hundreds (of U.N. personnel) for politically delicate field missions and learned quite a lot about how to respond in tense situations,'' Eckhard said. The U.N. took over social services that had been provided by Namibia's territorial army, he said, such as health care, teaching school and delivering food to remote villages. He said the Namibia operation was being reviewed and future election-monitoring operations probably would be run largely by policemen and civilians, with fewer soldiers. Five hundred policemen and 4,650 soldiers were in the original U.N. contingent for Namibia, but 1,000 more police were sent when it became evident they were best equipped to monitor elections, Eckhard said. By the time Independence Day arrived March 21, political parties had unanimously agreed to a democratic constitution and joined a call for national reconciliation after 23 years of war. ``I would like to make this country a kind of a model of what all African countries, all developing countries, should be,'' U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said at the independence celebrations. The Namibian operation cost $373 million, $40 million below the budget estimate.

DOC.HEAD: Two African Leaders Pledge to Keep One-Party Systems
DOC.TEXT: The tide of democracy sweeping Eastern Europe is being felt in black Africa, but one-party rule still predominates and three of the major states have publicly committed themselves to it. Tanzania has had only one party for 26 years and said this month the policy will not change. Kenya did the same and Zimbabwe's leader, Robert Mugabe, declared his intention to install one-party rule. ``If we have many political parties, we will have chaos as different tribes rush to form theirs,'' President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya told trainee teachers at Laikipia in central Kenya. ``Tribal inclinations and consciousness is still paramount in the minds of many Kenyans.'' ``For now, I say no to the multiparty system, at least until we are cohesive enough as a nation,'' he said. Kenya has 40 tribes in a population of 22 million. Ethnic feuding is common in Parliament, at public rallies and in the press. Moi, a 66-year-old a former teacher from the minority Kalenjin tribe, inherited the one-party system in 1978 from the late President Jomo Kenyatta, the nation's founder. Kenyatta had banned opposition parties nine years earlier. Kenyatta created a de facto one-party state by locking up his political opponents. Moi made it constitutional in 1982. The president's statement was his first on the subject since some other African states began considering more liberalized political systems this year. He spoke after weeks of debate in Nairobi newspapers about whether Kenya should restore the style of democracy bequeathed to Kenyatta when he led the former British colony to independence in 1963. Writers supporting the status quo argued that Kenya had prospered under the current system, without tribal strife. They said a return to the old order might cause ethnic violence and drive away tourists and investors. Those who wanted change said Kenyans were politically mature enough for competition, that recent reforms in eastern Europe should be used as an example and that a parliamentary opposition would help check official corruption, mismanagement and nepotism. Neighboring Tanzania, a nation of 100 tribes, also was a British colony until independence in 1961 under Julius Nyerere. Unlike its wealthy capitalist cousin, Tanzania followed socialism based on Eastern European models. Both Nyerere and Ali Hassan Mwinyi, who succeeded him as president in 1985, have admitted the policies were flawed. Mwinyi, 65, has adopted radical economic reforms prescribed by Western lenders, but has rejected suggestions that they be accompanied by political change. ``While a multiparty system would be suitable for Europeans, it might not be the same with Tanzania,'' Mwinyi told reporters in Dar es Salaam. ``What Africans want is a fair return for their sweat through a new international economic order. ... This cannot be solved by the creation of 100 parties, which can bring chaos instead of progress.'' He said Tanzanians had voted consistently for a single party as a way to guarantee national unity. He did not mention a statement Nyerere made in February that multiparty democracy now may be possible. Nyerere, still chairman of the ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi Party, remains a powerful political figure five years after he resigned as president. Only a few of the 50 member nations of the Organization of African Unity have Western-style democracies. Zimbabwe is one, but President Robert Mugabe declared after an overwhelming victory in recent national elections that he will transform the former British colony of Rhodesia into a one-party state. Mugabe, who led Zimbabwe to independence 10 years ago, said the elections were a mandate from the 4.8 million registered voters to get rid of the opposition. His opponents accused Mugabe, 66, of seeking a dictatorship. They noted that only 54 percent of the electorate voted and opposition parties got 20 percent of the votes, although they won only three of the 150 Parliament seats. Benin, a former French colony, is pledged to eliminate one-party rule, Gabon is debating the question and there is pressure in the Ivory Coast for a freer political order. Cameroon and Niger, scenes of recent political upheavals, have rejected multiparty politics. Significant signals of change are coming from unlikely quarters. Ethiopia and Mozambique have abandoned their hardline Marxist ideologies, and the Marxist leaders of Angola have committed themselves to peace talks with U.S.-backed guerrillas that, if fruitful, could lead to open elections.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Delayed No More: Once-Criticized Court Praised
DOC.TEXT: When the lawsuit began, Sophie and Milos Malesev's daughter was in high school. When it ended, their daughter's youngest son was in high school, and Milos had been dead for 17 years. ``I thought they were waiting for me to die,'' said Mrs. Malesev, who waited nearly 25 years to settle claims over damage her house sustained when a water tunnel was built through her neighborhood. Large urban courts typically are backlogged, but Wayne County Circuit Court's civil system was branded as among the nation's most-stalled in 1978 and 1984 studies by the National Center for State Courts. Now, four years into a makeover that included a new computer system and method of assigning cases to judges, the court is being hailed as a model. ``We had a lousy case-flow management system. It placed total responsibility everywhere and individual responsibility nowhere. And as you see in the collapse of the communist world, that doesn't work well,'' said Richard Kaufman, chief judge since 1986. Judges' impatience with delays and embarrassment over the low ranking in the two studies spurred the changes. Per-judge caseloads have been whittled from 1,900 to 1,400. Nineteen of the court's 35 judges are handling fewer than 700 cases each, and 15 of those carry fewer than 600 each. On Jan. 1, 1986, the court had about 60,000 pending cases, of which 17,000 were ``old dogs'' _ more than 2 years old. Now just are 29,000 pending, including 2,700 old dogs. ``It's certainly a major triumph,'' said Ken Pankey of the National Center for State Courts. ``Wayne County is the major success story,'' said Barry Mahoney of the Denver-based Institute for Court Management, a branch of the National Center for State Courts in Williamsburg, Va. Mahoney is planning a workshop for managers from other courts in Detroit next year to show off what Wayne County has done. One problem with the old system was paperwork. With more than 100 cases filed daily, it was hard for keypunch operators to keep up, said Terry Kuykendall, a deputy administrator. The first change was a new computer system and a review of existing cases. Another help was the Michigan Supreme Court's coincidental adoption of a rule that required discovery _ the pretrial gathering of information about a case _ to be completed in 12 months instead of 26. The most important change, how cases were handled, evolved after long planning sessions with judges, staff, consultants and experts from the American Bar Association and National Center. Until 1986, incoming cases were assigned to one judge for pretrial matters and transferred to another for trial. Under the individual docket, cases are assigned to one judge from the moment they're filed. Hearings and other deadlines are scheduled automatically, and the judge retains responsibility for every phase of the case. Kaufman picked seven judges to go on the new calendar in October 1986. It worked. Every October since, seven more judges have gone to the new system. Judge Marianne Battani was in the first group. She hears her own pretrial motions and sets her own trial dates. Cases that waited three years under the old system now are finished in 12 to 18 months, she said. ``I love it,'' Battani said. However, she wonders if it will become tempting to push cases to settle out of court r transfer to another jurisdiction to get them off the books. ``I think sometimes we get bogged down with statistics,'' she said. ``I think there's an urge to handle cases quickly, because of numbers.'' Gerald Thurswell, a Detroit lawyer for 22 years, remembers how under the old system, he sometimes pleaded for an accelerated trial date for fear his client would die before the case came up. Judges rarely granted such requests. ``There were so many excuses to get a fast trial. Clients used to wait years,'' he said. Under the new system, lawyers in his firm are handling fewer cases at one time because of the quickened pace. ``We've had to hire more attorneys,'' Thurswell said. ``They move so fast; judges are in competition with each other. It's better for the whole system.'' ``It's good,'' said Chris Andreoff, another attorney. ``The advantage is you know where you'll be. The judges have more grasp because of the continuity.'' Detroit court officials now are hoping to meet, within a few years, ABA processing-time standards that call for 90 percent of all civil cases to be completed in a year, 98 percent to be cleared up within 18 months and 100 percent within two years. Currently, no urban court meets that standard, although a few come close, said Doug Somerlot of the ABA's Lawyers Conference Task Force on the Reduction of Litigation Cost and Delay. Nationwide figures on civil delays don't exist because states use different data, making comparisons impossible, he said. The National Center is studying whether the Wayne County project can be applied to other courts, Pankey said. Somerlot said persistence might be the key to Wayne County's reform. The most important thing, he said, is ``that they agreed it was a problem and worked on it.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed AMs, April 25

DOC.HEAD: AFTER THE COLD WAR: Backers Push for Smaller Scale Star Wars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is one in an occasional series looking at how the U.S. military is responding to the changes in the Soviet bloc.
DOC.TEXT: In the dim light of a super-secure command bunker, Army Lt. Col. John W. Wilson paced, chin on chest, listening to an intelligence report on a Soviet submarine off the California coast. An instant later, as he glanced up at an illuminated global ``chessboard'' of U.S. and Sviet military forces, Wilson stopped short. A voice near him cried, ``BSTS alert.'' An early-warning satellite was signaling the launch of a nuclear missile. Wilson had the comfort of knowing this was only a ``war game'' simulation, but voices in the control center carried a serious tone from the moment a U.S. surveillance plane over the Pacific reported spotting a missile booster surging toward the surface. For Wilson, it was time to start thinking about doomsday and how to escape. He sent word to the White House: ``We have a detected launch off the West Coast.'' Then, nearly as abruptly as the ``attack'' had begun, it was over. Minutes after the count of incoming Soviet missiles reached 15, and before the warheads could hit their targets in the southwestern United States, all were destroyed in a space- and land-based rocket barrage orchestrated from Wilson's bunker. The ``crisis'' was a computer-simulated nuclear attack. It was not the all-out assault that America has spent trillions of dollars trying to deter throughout the Cold War, but a small-scale launch by a rogue Soviet submarine commander. The scenario, played out for reporters recently at the Army's Strategic Defense Command, dramatizes the new rationale being promoted by the Bush administration for investing billions in a Star Wars missile defense at a time when even the Pentagon acknowledges that the threat of World War III is the lowest in 40 years. Instead of the impregnable, worldwide shield against a massive wave of Soviet missiles _ as originally envisioned by Ronald Reagan seven years ago _ promoters of the Strategic Defense Initiative say a more modest defense is needed, one that still would put weapons in space at a cost of about $55 billion but would be capable of knocking out only half of the Soviets' main intercontinental ballistic missile force. The new rationale also stresses a need to protect against an accidental or unauthorized Soviet launch or a limited missile attack by a Third World country. Gone is Reagan's talk of making nuclear weapons ``impotent and obsolete.'' The aim now is to improve the traditional role of offensive nuclear forces as a deterrent to war by making the odds of a successful first strike even more uncertain. Gone, at least for the remainder of this century, are ideas of using exotic and futuristic weaponry, such as the X-ray laser and particle beam weapon, that originally gave SDI the Star Wars nickname. The new emphasis is on more down-to-earth, rapidly maturing technology such as kinetic-energy warheads that ``kill'' their targets in space by ramming them at high speed. Gone, too, is much of the interest in Congress for financing the project. Last year, for the first time, the SDI budget was lower than in the year before. Today it's an easy target of politicians looking to harvest a post-Cold War ``peace dividend.'' ``SDI is public enemy No. 1 on Capitol Hill,'' Sen. John Warner, R-Va., said recently. Says Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., who supports a scaled-down SDI research budget but not deployment: ``Congress hasn't voted to produce it and probably never will.'' Bush has told the Pentagon he wants to be able to decide by 1992 whether to deploy a Star Wars defense, but he probably won't get the chance by then. Officials and scientists working on the project say they'll need a healthy increase in funds _ well above what Congress seems likely to grant _ next year and in 1992 to lay a sound technical foundation on which Bush could base his decision. Lt. Gen. Robert D. Hammond, commander of the Strategic Defense Command that handles about one-third of the Star Wars research, told reporters recently that he believed Bush could meet his target date for a deployment decision ``only if you have good growth'' in financing beyond the $3.8 billion authorized for this year. Bush has requested a $1 billion increase for next year, but it appears unlikely he'll get anything close to that. He and the Pentagon may have to live with less. From the start, more than seven years and $19 billion ago, the project was designed as a long-term effort, with little prospect for payoff before the turn of the century. But political pressure to show results grew as policymakers wondered: Can it work? Is it affordable? Will the Soviets find a way around it? All three are still open questions. The main pieces of a Star Wars system, as currently envisioned, are sensors to detect and track enemy missiles from their launch silos; land- and space-based rockets to attack the missiles in flight, and computers to manage the battle. Of those three elements, the computer technology is perhaps the most problematic. At the Strategic Defense Command in Hunstville, where Wilson and his team of specialists test their responses to simulated nuclear attacks, engineers are still experimenting with computer programs that would be used to orchestrate a Star Wars response to a real attack. Lawrence Tubbs, acting chief of battle management at the Strategic Defense Command, said the key questions about the computer software are: Can it be adequately tested, and would it work? Some scientists say the answer to both is no. ``The problem of developing trustworthy software for the SDI is not a problem that will be solved in our lifetimes or those of our children,'' the Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility wrote in an open letter to Congress on Feb. 16. The scientists group urged the abandonment of SDI, arguing that a single error in the system's software could cause a complete system failure under unpredictable circumstances. It appears unlikely Star Wars will be killed any time soon, if only because of its economic lure. About 28,000 people are working on the project at defense contractors, national laboratories, universities and military installations in every state in the nation and in five foreign countries. Two aerospace companies, Boeing Co. and Lockheed Corp., together have taken in $2.2 billion in Star Wars contracts over the life of the program, according to Pentagon figures. That is more than 10 percent of all Star Wars spending. Altogether, more than 1,000 military contractors have a piece of Star Wars action. The project's supporters say the American public will support more research if they get the message that the goal of ballistic missile defense is attainable. Lt. Gen. George Monahan, director of the SDI project, acknowledged in testimony to a House panel April 4 that much more work was needed to put the Star War pieces together, but he said many scientific question marks have been erased. ``There is no doubt in my mind that the technology is here, sufficient to develop and deploy such a system,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, April 23

For Release Sunday, April 22, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Murder and Mystery in the Texas Hill Country
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Months later, sheriff's deputy Bill Beard could recall nothing unusual about his chance meeting with Bruce Parker that gray Sunday morning. The two friends shared coffee and conversation at Dauna's Store, a favorite gathering spot in this tiny Hill Country community, and Parker seemed in high spirits. Beard knew of Parker's problems with members of his family and that his friend had returned only recently to rejoin the ranching clan. Like everyone else in town, Beard also knew the rumors of ``bad blood'' among the Parkers, an imposing family tracing its ancestry back to the Alamo. And finally, he knew only too well the family's history of violence. Before nightfall that Sunday last autumn, Parker, 42, lay mortally wounded on a bluff overlooking Big Rock, a scenic and secluded area along the Little Devil's River in the heart of Parker ranchland. In just six incredible months, three Parkers were dead _ and a fourth was charged with murder.

To some, the Parker family seemed larger than life, proud and private, linked by blood to Comanche Chief Quanah Parker and by legend to bandit queen Bonnie Parker. And certainly they were, as one claimed, ``Old West, Big Ranch.'' James Henry Parker arrived in the rolling, brittle woodlands of the Texas Hill Country in the early 1870s, accompanied by his young bride Matilda, a grandniece of Davy Crockett, a name as famous as the Alamo itself. Soon, the couple's original 160-acre tract grew to 12,000 acres, and Jim and Tildy produced 11 children, including a son named Jess, who in 1913 married Lorena Milam, a relative of Ben Milam, another history book hero. In the late 1930s, Jess, called ``Big Daddy,'' and Lorena, ``Big Mama,'' moved into the remote family homesite, now known as ``Old Ranch,'' and raised five children. The four boys _ Doyle, Cecil, Raymond and Aubrey _ chose to ranch with their father, who set aside land for each. But even then, life was not as harmonious as ``Big Daddy'' would have liked. Friends said the relationship between Doyle and Cecil was severely strained, and everyone suspected the feud involved land. After Cecil Parker died in 1968, his widow and family, which included Bruce and his two sisters, were all but banished from the ranch. It was ``Big Daddy'' himself who reluctantly urged them to leave ``before something bad happens,'' according to Bruce Parker's elder son Bart, now 24. But at ``Big Daddy's'' death, the old man's will restored a parcel of Parker land to his grandchildren, and Bruce returned with a new wife and a new outlook on life. A carpenter by profession but a cowboy by preference, Bruce Parker looked and lived the part of a man born and raised on a sprawling Texas ranch. Handsome, hard-working and easygoing, Parker rarely dressed in anything other than boots, jeans, western shirts and cowboy hats. Only 19 when his father died and his family was ousted, Bruce bounced around the Hill Country working at an assortment of jobs. But always he was drawn back to Kimble County. ``It wasn't that the land was so important, but this is where his home was,'' said Linda, whose 1983 marriage to Bruce was the second for them both. ``Being away was like a great big empty hole in him.'' In the fall of 1986, shortly after inheriting his ranchland, Bruce guided Linda to a hilltop commanding a regal view of the countryside below. Producing blueprints of a two-story house, he embraced her and asked: ``How would you like a house like this built right here?'' ``I remember telling him I would never love him as much as I did at that moment,'' she said. Bruce himself built the house, a spacious country home constructed in part with native rock, not unlike what his great-grandfather used more than a century ago. Early one morning, as they sipped coffee and watched their horses grazing below, Bruce told Linda he was never happier, but still was troubled by something. ``I'm afraid somebody's going to come and take this away,'' she recalled him saying. ``Nobody can take this away from you,'' she replied. ``It's yours.'' In both good times and bad, Linda said, Bruce was always very proud to be a Parker. ``They are wonderful, honest, hard-working people ...,'' she said. ``There is nothing superficial about them. They're either for you or against you. There is no in-between.'' And, she said, most were supportive after Bruce's death. On that fateful weekend last October, the couple attended a Friday night football game at Harper High School, where Bruce once played quarterback. Bruce spent much of the weekend working on his Uncle Raymond's ranch, where he had leased the hunting and fishing rights. He drove along Little Devil's River, where years ago the Parker clan gathered under shade trees across from Big Rock. They would barbecue steers and goats at the river's edge and sing and dance to live music, often until dawn. ``This was Bruce's favorite spot in the whole world,'' Linda said.

The Parkers worked and played hard, and though they kept a low profile, they seemed eerily doomed to uncommon and often violent tragedy _ ``some real bad luck,'' according to Kimble County Sheriff Pat Davis. One of ``Big Daddy's'' brothers and his wife died in a double shooting in 1935. No motive ever was uncovered, but a note indicated the couple formed a suicide pact. Five years later, Jim Parker's granddaughter was slain by her husband, who cut her throat. And in 1962, one of Parker's great-grandsons was shot and killed in a dispute over a girl he was dating. But it was an episode last summer that set the tone for the most recent violence. Jesse ``Jett'' Parker, another of ``Big Daddy's'' ill-fated nephews, was gunned down on Parker ranchland June 10, an apparent robbery victim. Investigators said a warrant was issued for a fugitive from Mexico, but no arrest has been made. No one professes to know who or what lured Bruce Parker to the bluff above Big Rock that Sunday last October. There was not a hint of trouble, Linda said, and if there had been renewed friction between Bruce and any of his relatives, ``I think we would have known it.''

DOC.HEAD: HARPER, Texas: known it.''
DOC.TEXT: She last saw her husband alive down at the camphouse where he was working that afternoon. When she returned from an errand, he was gone. The phone call from ``Big Mama,'' the aging matriarch of the Parker clan, came at dinnertime. Lorena Parker told her something had happened to Bruce. A sizable crowd already had gathered atop the bluff when Linda arrived. Her husband's lifeless body, face down in a pool of blood, was sprawled along the dirt road on the driver's side of the pickup. Deputy Bill Beard, the first officer at the scene, spotted a powder burn about the size of a half-dollar on his friend's chest. He privately concluded that Bruce's death was a homicide. ``There were too many things that didn't add up to a self-inflicted wound,'' Beard said. Bruce's western hat was on the hood of the truck, which Kimble County Sheriff Pat Davis considered significant. ``They said when he was mad and about ready to fight, the first thing he did was take his hat off and set it down,'' Davis said. ``It looks like there might be some sort of altercation.'' Linda would not totally accept that premise, but never did she embrace the theory her husband killed himself. The motive behind the slaying? ``Jealousy and greed,'' she snapped. Would she explain? ``No,'' she replied. ``All of this will come out in court.'' An investigator, speaking despite a judicial gag order, may have struck close to the truth. ``The family got larger and larger,'' he drawled, ``and the land smaller and smaller.''

In mid-November, a steady stream of Parkers clattered across the bridge spanning the Llano River and rolled up to the old brick-and-stone courthouse in Junction. For two days, they and others appeared before grand jurors to answer questions about the events of Oct. 29. Among the witnesses subpoenaed were Doyle Parker, 75, and his brother Raymond, 66, the uncle who owned the land where the shooting occurred. Friends knew Doyle as a man with a fondness for cigars and a dedication to ranching and family. He spent his entire life on Parker land and had acquired holdings beyond what he inherited from ``Big Daddy.'' Unlike Doyle, Raymond left the Parker conclave for San Antonio and spent 17 years in business before returning to the ranch in his later years. After hearing two days of testimony, grand jurors returned a murder indictment accusing Doyle Parker of ``intentionally and knowingly'' killing his nephew. He was arrested, but quickly freed on $25,000 bail. A trial date is pending. Ron Sutton, the district attorney, calls his case ``circumstantial and complicated,'' but says he is eager to prosecute despite Doyle Parker's advanced age. ``His mother's in good shape at 92 and his father lived to be 97,'' Sutton said. ``These people live forever down there unless they get shot.'' The frost-laden northers that usher in a Hill Country winter were no match for the chill that penetrated the Parker compound in the days following the indictment. According to investigators and others, ``Big Mama'' indirectly blamed her son Raymond for Bruce's death. Even though Doyle stood legally accused, authorities said she felt the tragedy occurred because Raymond had granted his nephew hunting and fishing rights to sacred Parker ground. Raymond said nothing, at least publicly. On a Sunday night in early December, he picked up his .22-caliber automatic pistol and disappeared into the bathroom of his ranch home. Without a word, or a note, he blew his brains out. He left behind only his grand jury testimony, secret by law.

DOC.HEAD: Sandra Bullock Gets `Working Girl' Role She Heard About On TV
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Sandra Bullock was visiting Los Angeles when she heard on television that the NBC sitcom ``Working Girl'' was seeking a new leading lady. She'd had only a few jobs as a New York-based actress, and was hoping to find regular work in the larger market for performers here. ``Nancy McKeon had just left the show and I heard on a news show they were looking for someone,'' Bullock said. ``I knew a lot of people who auditioned for it. They were seeing a bunch of people, and my agent sent me. Finally, it got down to about five people, and we went to the network. I think it was my begging that got me the job.'' ``Working Girl,'' a spring tryout series, is based on the hit comedy movie starring Melanie Griffith, Harrison Ford and Sigourney Weaver. Griffith was nominated for an Academy Award for her role as Tess McGill, the character Bullock plays. Tess is a young secretary from Staten Island who becomes a junior executive in Manhattan, and the series draws on contrasts between her home life and life in the corporate world. It also stars George Newbern as a preppie co-worker, Nana Visitor as her hard-driving boss, Tom O'Rourke as a self-made corporate powerhouse, Edye Byrde as the seen-it-all ``temp,'' Anthony Tyler Quinn as a neighborhood Romeo, and Judy Prescott as Tess' best friend from childhood. ``Tess is a very stubborn woman, but in a good way,'' Bullock said. ``She's a little more daring in her choices than I am. She's headstrong, but she would not sacrifice her beliefs or her family to get ahead. ``In the first show, she's a secretary again. Then she has to adjust to becoming a junior executive. She doesn't quite fit in and her accent doesn't quite fit in.'' The concept has undergone changes to adapt it from a movie to a sitcom, and Tess' character has been altered somewhat since Melanie Griffith is softer while Bullock has more of an edge. Nancy McKeon, formerly of ``The Facts of Life,'' had been set to portray Tess, but left the show because of ``creative differences.'' Before ``Working Girl,'' Bullock had worked mostly in small films. ``I had a few lines in the ABC movie `The Preppie Murder,''' she said. ``I was in `The Bionic Showdown' with Lee Majors and Lindsay Wagner. In New York, I did a lot of small, independent films, the kind you find through the trade papers.'' Two of those movies that will be coming out are ``Who Shot Patakango,'' about racial gang violence, and ``Religion Inc.,'' a satire in which she plays a by-the-book lawyer. Bullock was born in Germany. Her mother was a German opera singer, and her father was an American voice teacher who had been in the U.S. Army there. ``Once in a while, I'd come down with one of my father's voice students and hit high C,'' she said. ``I've never had a desire to sing, I guess because my parents did it so well. I wanted to do something else. ``I loved acting. I was a ham. I was good at goofing off. I didn't know if I wanted to do acting permanently when I started in college. But I did love goofing off because I was no good at math.'' Bullock attended East Carolina University in Greenville, N.C. ``One of the first things I did out of college was `No Time Flat,''' she said. ``They were looking for a Southern belle, although I'm certainly not Southern. It's a comedy about a Vietnam vet who looks up his old girlfriend and I answer the door. I'm her daughter and I go along with him.'' Bullock said she had a difficult time auditioning for roles in New York because nobody could put a label on her. ``Nobody knew what to make of me,'' she said. ``I was too offbeat. I auditioned for two soaps, but they said, `Where'd you come from?' They were looking for the girl next door. I'd try to put a little humor in it. `Ashley, I didn't know I had any children!' I couldn't get a line like that out of my mouth without laughing.'' To pay bills, she worked as a bartender and cocktail waitress. ``I learned a lot of accents as a bartender,'' she said. ``A lot of girls came in looking for rich husbands. I learned to imitate them.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, May 4-6

DOC.TEXT: Sharp increases in clothing, housing and medical costs contributed to a 0.5 percent leap in consumer prices in March that pushed inflation to the highest level since 1982. Private economists said Tuesday the unexpectedly brisk advance in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index was a discouraging sign that inflation was not retreating as they had hoped. Through the first three months of the year, inflation has risen at an annual rate of 8.5 percent, the fastest quarterly increase since a 10.1 percent increase in the spring of 1982.

The nation's industrial production gained 0.7 percent in March, the government said. March's advance followed an even stronger 0.8 percent increase a month earlier. Both gains reflected increases in the output of automobiles, the Federal Reserve reported Tuesday. Production had plummeted 1.3 percent in January because of the effect of the weather on utility output and of layoffs in the automobile industry as automakers trimmed bloated inventories.

Sales of North American-made cars and light trucks skidded 11.2 percent in early April from the incentive-boosted sales levels during the same period last year, automakers said. Chrysler Corp. on Tuesday reported a 29.2 percent decline in car sales during the April 1-10 period. A year earlier, the No. 3 automaker had just announced interest-free financing on some vehicles. Ford Motor Co. car sales fell 20.7 percent and General Motors Corp. sales declined 13.6 percent from a year earlier, the companies said.

Housing starts dropped 9.3 percent in March in their sharpest decline since a 12.4 percent plunge in January 1989, the government reported. The Commerce Department reported Tuesday that starts of new homes and apartments fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.32 million units _ a pace many analysts said probably would continue.

Bank of New England Corp., which has shrunk under the weight of bad real estate loans and a troubled regional economy, announced a plan to make the company smaller but stronger. The plan disclosed Tuesday calls for the bank eventually to cut its assets to about $20 billion, compared with a current level of $25 billion, and $32 billion last fall. The corporation also said it would create a ``collecting bank'' to deal with a mountain of troubled loans.

Sony Corp. plans to invest $300 million to renovate a mothballed Volkswagen assembly plant to produce television picture tubes and, eventually, high definition TVs. The move, a major expansion announced Tuesday and aimed at bringing Sony's U.S. manufacturing capability closer to its suppliers, comes amid increasing competition and friction between the United States and foreign business.

A federal judge ordered former Wall Street arbitrager Robert Freeman to serve four months in prison and pay a $1 million fine for insider trading in a 1986 takeover deal. The sentence on Tuesday capped one of the longest and most contentious episodes in the government's crackdown on white-collar crime, in a case stemming from the confessions of former stock speculator Ivan F. Boseky.

American Telephone & Telegraph Co. has reached a tentative agreement on an early retirement plan with two unions, part of the company's effort to cut costs. The plan, which would add three years of age and service to each worker's record on May 1, would nearly double the number of workers eligible for a pension to 34,000, AT&T spokesman Burke Stinson said Tuesday.

Legislators have approved a bill to help protect Norton Co. in its takeover battle with a British firm. The measure sped through the Senate and House on voice votes Tuesday, hours after a legislative committee endorsed the bill. The measure was sent to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, and it would take effect immediately once signed. Norton, a Worcester-based maker of abrasives, faces a proxy fight at its annual shareholders meeting, currently scheduled for April 26.

Prices finished mixed Tuesday on Wall Street where the Dow Jones industrial average posted a 2.71-point gain to close at 2,765.77. Bond prices fell broadly on signs of high inflation and a strong economy. The dollar ended lower in New York against major foreign currencies after rising modestly overseas. Cocoa futures fell sharply; precious metals were mixed; grains and soybeans were mostly higher; energy futures fell and livestock and pork futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Arbitrager Gets Four Months, $1 Million Fine
DOC.TEXT: It was one of the most widely quoted one-liners in Wall Street's insider trading scandal _ ``Your bunny has a good nose'' _ but there was nothing funny about it for Robert Freeman. The former head of arbitrage for Goldman, Sachs & Co. was ordered Tuesday to serve four months in prison and pay a $1 million fine for trading securities after hearing the comment, which helped him conclude that a takeover deal was in trouble. U.S. District Judge Pierre Leval said he imposed a prison term to send a message to Wall Street that insider trading and other white-collar crime cannot be treated lightly. ``These practices seriously undermine the integrity of the marketplace,'' he said, later adding: ``It is perhaps one of the consequences of enormous power and wealth that there are downsides.'' Leva sentenced Freeman to one year in prison but suspended the last eight months of the term. The judge said he rejected a lengthy term because Freeman was shown to be a good man who was chastened by his crime. Freeman faced a maximum of five years. The sentence capped one of the longest and most contentious episodes in the government's crackdown on insider trading stemming from the confessions of former stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky. Freeman, 47, pleaded guilty last August to one count of mail fraud for using illegally obtained inside information to trade securities in connection with the proposed takeover of Beatrice Cos. by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. He admitted getting information from former Kidder, Peabody & Co. investment banker Martin Siegel, who has pleaded guilty to two counts and is awaiting sentencing. Kidder represented KKR in the proposed takeover. The case turned on a comment made by Siegel after Freeman called him on Jan. 8, 1986, to try to confirm rumors that the Beatrice takeover was in jeopardy. Freeman told Siegel he had heard about problems in the deal from a prominent New York Stock Exchange trader, Bernard ``Bunny'' Lasker. Siegel responded: ``Your bunny has a good nose,'' Freeman said in an account of the episode. After taking the call, Freeman reduced Goldman's stake in Beatrice. He admitted to a felony crime for the action but defense lawyers said it did not merit prison. The government had requested prison time. ``Mr. Freeman is a good man who made a mistake that he has admitted, for which he has been punished extraordinarily,'' defense attorney Paul Curran said, citing the ``agony that Mr. Freeman and his family had to endure beginning with his arrest on false charges three years ago.'' Freeman was arrested in February 1987 along with two other Wall Street executives on charges the U.S. Attorney's Office in Manhattan called ``the tip of the iceberg.'' But the government dropped the original indictments and last year called off its investigation of the two others, Timothy Tabor and Richard Wigton. Wigton was arrested on his trading floor and hauled away in handcuffs. The nature of the arrests and their disposition provoked outrage on Wall Street. Leval said the conversation with Siegel, who implicated Freeman after he was linked to insider trading by Boesky, was illegal and deserved prison. ``Although the answer was couched in veiled language, it constituted the illegal transaction of inside information,'' Leval said. ``...There is no question he knew full well he was breaking the law.'' The $1 million fine was about twice the trading loss avoided by Goldman, Freeman and his clients by selling the Beatrice holdings, the maximum penalty under the law, Leval said. Freeman has 30 days to pay. Freeman, who lives in the New York suburb of Rye, also was placed on two years' probation and ordered to serve 300 hours of community service. Freeman asked to serve his sentence in a minimum-security prison camp in Pensacola, Fla. He must surrender to the government June 19.

DOC.HEAD: Merc Members Approve Dual Trading Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange hopes its newly proposed curbs on dual-trading will convince federal regulators to stop considering more drastic bans. Members of the exchange voted Tuesday to approve a management-backed plan to ban the controversial practice for two-thirds of the Merc's trading volume. The Merc said 76 percent of the 1,561 ballots cast favored the restrictions, which were drawn up by an exchange committee and approved recently by board of governors. The exchange has 2,500 active members. Dual-trading is the long-standing practice of floor brokers trading for their own accounts and for customers. A government probe of the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade zeroed in on dual-trading and other practices as key factors in trader abuse. Despite the potential for abuse, the Merc and the Board of Trade argue that dual-trading brings an added level of liquidity to the market, helping guarantee that at any moment someone wanting to sell or buy a contract will find someone with whom to do business. The proposal approved by Merc members would ban dual-trading in contracts that have a proven record of liquidity. Contracts in which there isn't much business, usually those for delivery in distant months, still would permit dual-trading. The lightly traded contracts also are more easily monitored for abuses, said Merc spokesman Andrew Yemma. The Commoditiy Futures Trading Commission has proposed a trial reform in which dual-trading would be banned for all delivery months for one financial future and one agricultural commodity. The Merc said it will ask the CFTC to approve the exchange's proposal in lieu of the agency's pilot program. The CFTC is expected to make a final determination late in the summer. Congress also is considering dual-trading restrictions that would be potentially more severe than those proposed by the Merc. The Merc's proposed restrictions were recommended by a committee that reviewed trading practices in light of the government investigation, in which 48 people, mostly traders, have been indicted. Even before the investigation was revealed last year, the Merc banned dual-trading in 1987 for 90 percent of the trades in its Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures pit. ``There was a feeling among members in the pit that there were abuses of dual-trading that needed to be addressed,'' said Yemma. The Board of Trade also believes the CFTC proposal goes too far, said CBOT spokesman Michael O'Connell. There currently are no restrictions on dual-trading at the Board of Trade, and officials there want to keep it that way, O'Connell said. ``Dual-trading accounts for a great source of market liquidity,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Unveils Reorganization Plan
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. says it plans to make the company smaller but stronger by stripping its troubled real estate loans from its main banking business. The strategy, unveiled Tuesday, will create a separate ``collecting'' bank to deal with a mountain of troubled loans and use advertising to allay depositor fears. The plan also calls for the bank to sell its Rhode Island and Maine subsidiaries and eventually cut its assets to about $20 billion. Assets currently stand at $25 billion and were $32 billion just last fall. Solving the bank's problems ``will require major financial and business restructuring which, while challenging, will allow us to rebuild a strong regional bank,'' Chairman Lawrence Fish said. Fish, who succeeded ousted chairman Walter J. Connolly last month, said the company will focus on businesses including retail and commercial banking, and real estate lending. ``We're going to keep it simple,'' Fish said in a statement. ``We're going to take deposits and we're going to make sound loans.'' The bank, which has been operating under government orders for more than a month, lost more than $1 billion last year. It recently announced plans to cut 5,600 workers, or one-third of the payroll, through a combination of layoffs, attrition and the sale of assets. Much of the bank's trouble has been blamed on shaky construction loans that were exposed during a downturn in the Northeast real estate market. But analysts warn that the bank could face more trouble as the New England economy continues to worsen, deteriorating the bank's assets further. Some analysts had suggested that the bank separate the bad loans from the rest of the assets in order to alleviate the burden from the solid operations. The bank said Steven E. Wheeler, a former Morgan Stanley executive, would serve as executive vice president and oversee the new ``collecting'' bank. This operation will restructure the troubled real estate assets and possibly offer them for sale, the bank said. Wheeler has experience in the New England real estate market, having served as president of First Winthrop Corp., a Boston-based real estate syndication and investment firm. The bank also is trying to improve its capital levels and reduce borrowings from the Federal Reserve Bank. Part of the plan is to use advertising campaigns to stem the fears of depositors, who have pulled billions of dollars from the company. Bank of New England said it would adopt a ``new organizational structure'' that would change management processes and emphasize accountability. As part of its sale of assets, the bank also announced Tuesday it had reached an agreement to sell all the securities activities handled by its discount brokerage unit, New England Discount Brokerage Inc., to Charles Schwab & Co. Inc. for an undisclosed cash price.

DOC.HEAD: Nike Plans to Spend $5 Million to Place Public Service-Type Ads
DOC.TEXT: Nike Inc. plans to spend 17 percent of its $30 million basketball shoe advertising budget this year on public service-type messages encouraging youngsters to stay in school. The campaign comes at a time when some critics have blamed high-priced athletic shoes for triggering crime in poor urban areas. Some children wearing the shoes have been attacked by other youngsters who covet them as status symbols. ``We know people that are in our ads are role models and kids pay a lot of attention to our ads,'' said Liz Dolan, a spokeswoman for Nike. ``We felt this could be a real contribution that we could make.'' The Beaverton, Ore.-based athletic shoemaker said Tuesday it plans to spend $5 million to buy time for these messages and will run them along with its regular product ads so they won't be consigned to the least-watched times. Nike's public service messages would feature pro basketball stars Michael Jordan, who has appeared for his own line of Nike shoes, and David Robinson, who is about to turn up in a new ad campaign for Nike's Force line. Robinson, who plays center for the San Antonio Spurs, told a news conference he thought it was unfair to single out the makers of athletic shoes for causing crime. ``Kids are attacking kids over a lot of things, not just shoes,'' he said. He said the new ads give him a chance to become a positive role model for children who may not have one. Prices for the Force line of shoes run from $58 to $135 a pair with the major share of sales coming in the least expensive shoes, Ms. Dolan said. Nike brand marketing manager Ron Hill said the Force line accounts for about 60 percent of Nike's $250 million a year in basketball shoe sales. In the $15 million ad campaign for the line, which debuts in late April on the NBA playoff telecasts, Robinson is the amiable focal point in his own ``Mr. Robinson's Neighborhood,'' an apparent takeoff on the children's public TV show ``Mister Rogers' Neighborhood.'' In one ad, Spurs Coach Larry Brown talks about the words for that day, ``Transition Game.'' Brown repeatedly admonishes Robinson to run back down the court after the opponent misses a shot as clips of Robinson playing basketball flash on the screen. ``I don't think we'll have Coach Brown on the show anymore,'' Robinson tells viewers as the commercial ends. Another ad in the series, called ``Kick Butt,'' is being held until fall when the new inflatable Nike Force shoes are on the market. The shoes have a built-in pump to inflate the collar around the ankles; the shoes replace Nike's Air Pressure shoes that required a separate pump. Nike's arch rival Reebok International sells a shoe called The Pump that is inflated by pressing a marked spot on the tongue of the shoe. In the ad, Robinson demonstrates how to tie them _ ``Mr. Robinson likes double knots'' _ and to inflate them _ ``Mr. Robinson likes six pumps.'' ``Then Mr. Robinson likes to take his special Nike shoes onto the court and kick some butt,'' the athlete says in an innocent voice. ``Can you say `Kick some butt?''' he asks as the words flash on the screen, interspersed with more shots of Robinson in action on the basketball court. Ms. Dolan said Nike feels viewers will understand that Robinson is talking about playing agressively, and doubts youngsters will read more into it. ``I think everybody will get the joke,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Approve Name Change, Announce Purchase From GTE, Earnings Up 41 Pct
DOC.TEXT: United Telecommunications Inc. said it will buy the remaining 19.9 percent of US Sprint and change its name to Sprint Corp. to cash in on the high profile of the nation's No. 3 long-distance carrier. United Telecom on Tuesday also reported a 41 percent rise in first quarter profits, but it said revenue growth was slower than expected at US Sprint and that competition was intensifying from rivals AT&T and MCI. US Sprint was formed in 1986 as a joint venture of United Telecom and GTE Corp. and has grown to control 8 percent of the long-distance market. United Telecom bought a controlling interest in 1988 and was given an option to buy the remaining 19.9 percent. The company will notify GTE by the end of May that it is ready to exercise the option and take full control, William Esrey, chairman and CEO, told Telecom shareholders at Tuesday's annual meeting in this Kansas City, Mo., suburb. The agreed selling price is about $500 million, Telecom spokesman Jerry Cosley said. Esrey said United Telecom's name would change July 1, when the transaction with GTE is expected to be completed. Shareholders approved the name change at the meeting. ``It's obviously not without some mixed emotions,'' retiring Chairman Paul Henson told shareholders. ``We think that Sprint Corporation tells the financial community more clearly what we are about. In addition, it has very high public recognition.'' The company also will shorten the long-distance subsidiary's name to Sprint, reflecting its attempts to expand overseas, Esrey said. Telecom's local telephone service subsidiaries, such as United Telephone of Kansas, will remain unchanged. Sprint's revenues were $1.2 billion in the first quarter vs. $984 million in the same quarter last year, an increase of 22 percent. But revenues increased only about 2 percent from the last quarter of 1989, less than the 4 percent to 6 percent forecast by company officials, Cosley said. ``This is an area that we are somewhat disappointed in, and that we are addressing,'' Esrey told stockholders. Cosley said some revenues from contracts already won by Sprint simply did not materialize during the quarter as expected because equipment wasn't installed. ``But those revenues will show up down the road,'' he said. Esrey told shareholders Sprint will introduce about 55 new products this year as competition in the long-distance market heats up. He noted that both American Telephone & Telegraph Co. and MCI Communications Inc. are developing fiber-optic telephone networks similar to the one Sprint built a few years ago and now touts in its advertising. ``Day-by-day, that advantage tends to shrink on us,'' Esrey said. ``We must now use our system to help us develop new products.'' He said the company would consider buying smaller long-distance companies as MCI did recently when it bought Telecom USA Inc. of Atlanta, the fourth-largest U.S. long-distance carrier. But Esrey said Telecom would proceed with caution. ``Certainly, if we can acquire customers by buying them, cheaper than we can through other ways, we will do it,'' he said. United Telecom said it earned $107.6 million or 51 cents a share on revenues of $2.02 billion in the first quarter, compared with $76.4 million or 36 cents a share on revenues of 1.77 billion a year earlier. The company's stock closed 25 cents lower at $39.87{ on the New York Stock Exchange. Also at the meeting, Henson, who had announced his retirement more than a year ago, officially stepped down after 31 years. He came to the company in 1959 as a vice president, was named president in 1964 and chairman in 1966. He is given much credit for helping to form Sprint in the mid-1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Domestic Vehicle Sales Drop 11 Percent in Early April
DOC.TEXT: Early April sales of North American-made vehicles skidded 11.2 percent, and analysts say auto dealers may not get the usual spring surge of buyers on their lots. ``While we think we've seen the worst, it's not clear when it's going to get any better,'' said Steve Girsky, auto industry analyst for PaineWebber Inc. ``We see it muddling along for another month or so.'' Chrysler Corp. on Tuesday reported the biggest decline, a 29.2-percent drop in car sales from levels of last April 1-10, when the No. 3 automaker offered interest-free financing on some vehicles. Ford Motor Co.'s car sales slid 20.7 percent and General Motors Corp.'s were down 13.6 percent from the year-earlier period, the companies said. Sales from Japanese-owned plants in this country continued to grow, however. The latest figures were measured against a strong year-earlier period, when sales rose more than 28 percent. Along with Chrysler's interest-free loans, GM and Ford announced interest rates as low as 2.9 percent just before the early-April 1989 surge. This year, the Big Three have been offering various combinations of rebates and low-interest incentives. The lowest rates currently available are 6.9 percent on some GM vehicles and 2.9 percent on some Ford and Chrysler models. But the incentives have lost impact, and with inventories trimmed by first-quarter production cuts, the companies have little reason to spend more money on them, said analyst Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. ``We think that sales are going to remain at these levels for some time,'' he said. ``Everybody's gotten used to the incentives. They ask `What's on this month?''' said Len Gossman, sales manager at Blackwell Ford Inc. in Plymouth. Gossman blamed his dealership's 10-percent drop partly on the mid-April Easter holiday that had people planning vacations rather than buying cars. The cold spring also repelled shoppers, he said. GM, Ford and Chrysler said their cars and light trucks sold at a combined average daily rate of 29,832 in the April 1-10 period, down 14.6 percent from a rate of 34,931 vehicles a day in early April 1989. Total U.S. sales of North American-made cars were down 13.3 percent and light truck sales slid 7.5 percent. All but one of the eight Japanese companies that make vehicles in this country reported stronger sales in early April. American Honda, the biggest, maker, said sales were up 17 percent at 9,455 cars. Toyota USA and Mazda USA, which are gearing up production from a lower base, doubled and tripled their sales, respectively. Nissan USA's car sales fell 6 percent in early April, but its light truck sales were up 14.2 percent. For the year to date, U.S. sales of North American-made cars are down 2.4 percent and light truck sales are off 0.4 percent from last year. Combined domestic car and light truck sales are down 1.7 percent for the year so far. GM said its light truck sales edged up 2.2 percent for early April. For the year, the No. 1 automaker said car sales were down 4 percent, while light truck sales were up 3.8 percent. Ford said its early April light truck sales sagged 9.3 percent. Ford said car sales were down 10 percent and light truck sales were down 3.5 percent for the year. Chrysler reported a 24.9 percent drop in early April light truck sales. For the year, Chrysler said its car sales were down 14 percent and light truck sales were down 1.5 percent.
