DOC.HEAD: Comptroller Approves Mobile Branch Bank for Rural Tennessee County
DOC.TEXT: Like many people in rural America, David Armour has trouble doing his banking. ``It's 15 miles from my office to the bank,'' said Armour, sales manager at a Ford dealership in the heart of West Tennessee's rolling farm country. ``If something comes up and I can't get loose, it's tomorrow before I can deposit my check,'' he said. Starting next month, the bank will come to Armour and other rural residents of Madison County. That's when the First National Bank of Jackson's mobile bank _ a converted armored car, appropriately enough _ hits the roads. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency notified the bank on Monday that it had approved its request for a mobile branch. The new rolling branch office will have two teller windows in its side. Customers will be able to cash checks, make deposits and buy certificates of deposit from the tellers, who will park the truck at grocery stores, truck stops and other gathering spots. ``It's gonna be great,'' Armour said. ``They're saying they might pull in here once a week and let the mechanics and salesmen deposit their checks.'' Eventually, First National Bank president Ernest Vickers III said, customers will be able to apply for loans or a mortgage or drop off valuables for their safe deposit box. Those plans may require a converted motor home, though, he said. ``We felt there was a large segment of county that is not adequately served by traditional banking,'' Vickers said. ``I figured if Federal Express can come to your door, who are we as banks to tell customers, `You've got to come to us.''' Vickers says the idea was born more from his marketing and sales background than his 14 years of banking experience. But he says service is the name of the game, whatever the industry. Many agree. ``It sounds like a real good idea to me,'' said Nathan Pride, a Madison County attorney and spokesman for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Jackson. ``I've talked to people who have trouble getting into the bank and they said they'd like it if it would come to their neighborhood just once a week,'' he said. Whether Vickers and First National can meet the county's demands is another matter. Vickers says the rolling bank's schedule is being worked out. Moveable bank branches have been approved before, said J. Michael Shepherd, senior deputy comptroller for the Officer of the Comptroller of the Currency in Washington. ``But Mr. Vickers' plan is quite rare,'' he said. ``I approved one in Arizona that was used at concerts, football games and big events. It was kind of a rolling automatic teller machine.'' Shepherd said Vickers' plan was laudable because it would provide a banking service to people who otherwise must drive long distances to make a deposit. Approving the bank's plan was easy once the comptroller's office determined Tennessee law was silent on the question of banks on wheels. Industry analyst Henry Coffee of J.C. Bradford Co. in Nashville applauded the move. ``Anything that brings in more deposits at a lower marginal cost is positive,'' he said. ``It sounds like this will be cheaper than building a branch.''

DOC.HEAD: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Division Settles with SEC
DOC.TEXT: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. agreed to pay back $5.6 million to customers for stock sold in partial tender offers without prior client approval, federal officials said. The New York-based securities firm and a managing director, Michael Dreitlein, agreed to settle _ without admitting or denying wrongdoing _ an administrative action alleging they violated Securities and Exchange Commission anti-fraud and record-keeping rules. The settlement was disclosed Tuesday. The action, brought by the SEC's New York Regional Office, accused Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette's Pershing Division of making $4.3 million in tender offer profits from the ``unauthorized and undisclosed'' sale of shares from customer accounts. A tender offer is an offer to buy a corporation's shares _ often as a means of acquiring the concern _ usually at a premium price. According to the SEC, the Pershing Division, then-headed by Dreitlein, tendered shares belonging to customers who had not given any instructions to do so. The shares were later replaced, usually with stock bought at a lower price after the tender offer. DLJ kept any profits from the difference between the sale and repurchase price. The alleged activity, known as overtendering, took place between January 1982 and April 1988, the SEC said. ``Securities transactions are predicated on trust. DLJ misued that trust when it confiscated customers' securities for its benefit,'' said Martin A. Kuperberg, the SEC's associate regional administrator in New York. Kathryn Ashbaugh, broker-dealer enforcement branch chief in New York, explained that while the misappropriated securities were replaced with no quantifiable loss to customers, the increased number of shares DLJ sold in 104 partial tender offers effectively dilluted the number shareholders could sell to the acquiring company. In a partial tender offer, the acquirer isn't seeking 100 percent of the corporation's stock, and therefore not every shareholder can sell stock. As part of the settlement with the SEC, DLJ agreed to pay $4.3 million plus interest for a total of $5.6 million to customers whose shares were used in the overtendering. Dreitlein consented to a 45-day suspension from any SEC-regulated securities operations and an 18-month ban from supervising any department that handles partial tender offers. ``These are practices that date to the early and mid 1980s,'' said Catherine Conroy, a spokeswoman for the Jersey City, N.J.-based Pershing Division. She noted that DLJ has instituted several steps to upgrade and strengthen the division and ``this brings the matter to a satisfactory close.''

DOC.HEAD: Business Leader Says Corporate Fears Were Exaggerated
DOC.TEXT: Those fearful predictions of 20 years ago that environmental demands would cause unemployment and economic stagnation have turned out to be overstated, a business leader says. Experience has shown that combating pollution is compatible with economic growth, said Alexander Trowbridge, a former secretary of commerce and chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers' Industry Coalition for the Environment. ``Environmental improvement has been a corollary to economic growth and has not come in spite of it,'' Trowbridge told a news conference Tuesday. He said the ``dire predictions about environmental improvement coming at the cost of jobs and national economic strength and high prices'' have proven to be exaggerated. At the same time, he said, environmentalists' warnings ``that Lake Erie would be dead, urban dwellers would be wearing gas masks, rivers would be reaching a boiling point,'' also were overdrawn. Trowbridge said he was not contending there will not be tradeoffs between jobs and the environment. But, he said, the record since Earth Day 1970 ``indicates that economic growth, moderate but real, has taken place in these 20 years and environmental improvement has also taken place.'' ``My judgment is that we've made progress both in the economy and the environment and I think we'll continue to do so,'' he said. Trowbridge presented a report that said production of six major pollutants has dropped sharply since 1970, while employment, productivity, per capita income, industrial production and the overall size of the economy have grown steadily. Environmentalists said they suspected that Trowbridge had made an Earth Day conversion. Earth Day is being commemorated on Sunday with events scheduled nationwide. ``Talk is cheap and action is not cheap,'' said David Gardiner, legislative director of the Sierra Club. ``It's the don't-worry-be-happy message at the same time the NAM and their members are spending millions of dollars lobbying against changes in law which would do a better job in improving the environment. ... What we're seeing from industry is Earth Day earth-hype.'' ``It is an encouraging-sounding message, but just in the last month and a half we've seen from the Business Roundtable and other industry groups the most apocalyptical hype about how the Clear Air Act is going to kill the economy,'' added David Doniger, senior attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council. ``It will be interesting to see if, next time there is a piece of legislation to be acted upon, the NAM will take a more enlightened line,'' he said. But Trowbridge said a fundamental change has taken place in corporate America. Environmental considerations are now being taken into account in business decisions, he said. ``Environmental quality is a very key element of planning, designing, building and producing,'' he said, ``and this has been growing not only as a psychological factor but as a point of stated policy.''

DOC.HEAD: Confusion Reigns Over What's a Japanese or American Car
DOC.TEXT: If your car is made by American workers in Michigan, Tennessee, Kentucky, Indiana, California, Illinois or Ohio, that makes it all-American, right? Not if it's Japanese. More than 1.5 million 1990-model Hondas, Nissans, Toyotas, Mazdas, Mitsubishis, Subarus and Isuzus will be made in the U.S.A., and a new study says the Japanese plants have brought significant changes to an industry once dominated by Detroit. The growing automobile ``transplant'' industry is making it more difficult to determine the true nationality of cars on the American road _ or on the Japanese road. In Japan, the Ford Probe is made by Mazda, which is partially owned by Ford, in a Michigan plant, using both American and Japanese parts. It's sold as an American car. To add to the confusion over automobile nationality, you can buy a Chrysler product made in Japan or a Pontiac or Ford made in South Korea. And some Japanese transplants are starting to export their U.S.-made Japanese cars to Japan. In a study financed by the import auto industry, researcher Robert Z. Lawrence said Tuesday that expected growth in direct foreign investment in U.S. auto manufacturing will create 110,000 jobs and lower the U.S.-Japan trade deficit by between $9.3 billion and $15.2 billion below what it otherwise would be at the end of 1992. Lawrence said assembling foreign cars in the United States benefits consumers by increasing competition and spreading auto manufacturing beyond Detroit. ``In less than a decade, the U.S. auto industry had been transformed from a virtually self-contained, highly concentrated sector with limited competition from imports into an internationalized industry with Japanese and U.S. producers competing head to head,'' Lawrence's study said. The Commerce Department projects that more than 1.5 million foreign cars will be made at seven plants in the United States this year and 2.25 million passenger cars will be imported. New-car sales are expected to exceed 8.5 million. Lawrence, who performed the study while on leave from the Washington-based Brookings Institution, said he fears the advantages of U.S. manufacturing may decrease if the value of the dollar continues to climb in Japan, What began as an effort by Japanese automakers to head off U.S. protective measures against imported vehicles became more economically viable with the decrease of the dollar's value in recent years, Lawrence said. He cited studies showing that when the dollar dips below 140 yen, automakers can make more by building in the United States than in Japan, but when it goes above 150, the U.S. operations may become less viable. The rate on the Tokyo Foreign Exchange Market on Tuesday was 159.83 yen to the dollar. Complicating the analysis is the fact that some U.S. automakers have a partial interest in Japanese companies. Honda started Japanese assembly of motorcycles in the United States in the late 1970s and cars in 1981. Today's plants do more than just assemble Japanese parts, however, Lawrence said. Some build engines and other components for export and the trend is to use more U.S.-built parts, with some Japanese parts companies also setting up U.S. operations. The study notes the following arrangements: _Chrysler buys the Conquest, Dodge Colt, Vista and Eagle Summit from Mitsubishi and markets them as Chrysler products. _General Motors markets the GEO Prizm built in partnership with Toyota in California, the GEO Tracker built in Canada with Suzuki and the GEO Storm built in Japan. _GM's Pontiac LeMans is built by Daewoo Korea. _Ford's Festiva is built in South Korea. _The Mazda Miata was conceived at a Mazda design faility in California. _Nissan and Ford plan vehicles developed by a Nissan operation in Ann Arbor, Mich., to be built by Ford in Ohio with parts supplied by a Nissan plant in Tennessee and to be marketed by both Nissan and Ford. By 1992, Lawrence said, Toyota and Honda are expected to export 50,000 cars each from the United States to Japan. In addition, 20,000 U.S.-built Toyotas will go to Taiwan, which has resisted increased Japanese imports.

DOC.HEAD: Savings and Loan Failure Blamed on Fraud and Abuse
DOC.TEXT: The failure of the $2.2 billion Silverado Banking Savings and Loan was brought on by fraud and abuse _ not a struggling Colorado economy, according to federal documents. Documents obtained by The Denver Post through the federal Freedom of Information Act said the failed Denver thrift repeatedly violated federal banking laws, the paper said in a copyright report in today's editions. Regulators said that the December 1988 failure resulted from ``massive amounts of poorly underwritten loans, imprudent loan concentrations ... and excessive compensation to senior management.'' Authorities had alleged that the thrift paid its top executives millions of dollars, showed false profits, hid loan problems and schemed to deceive regulators. ``Silverado has suffered due to violations of laws, rules and regulations. The depressed condition of Colorado's economy has served to exacerbate the losses incurred, but it is not the reason for Silverado's insolvency,'' the regulators said. Officials said the situation illustrates the nation's $325 billion thrift crisis. ``There is a similarity that has emerged at all these (failed) thrifts,'' said Tony Adamski, chief of the FBI's Financial Crime Unit in Washington. ``In each case, rules and good management were simply abrogated.'' Reports show that Silverado's troubles began in 1980 just a year after chairman Michael Wise took control and changed its name from Mile High Savings. Regulators warned then of increasing problem loans, conflicts of interest regarding an insider loan and ``deficiencies in internal control.'' The next year, regulators said Silverado was in danger of falling below minimum required levels of capital. Then from 1983 to 1985, Silverado doubled in size each year, pouring loans into real estate projects, seemingly without regard for the quality of the loans, regulators said. During that time, the thrift's apparent profits almost entirely came from fees generated from making loans, not the loans themselves, regulators said. ``Typically, such a reliance on fee income is a red flag for regulators,'' said Ronn Carr, of the federal Office of Thrift Supervision in Topeka, Kan. ``It indicates there isn't an ongoing source of income from loans.'' In 1985 foreclosures rose 10 times to $17.7 million and nonperforming loans quadrupled to $88 million, regulators said, but instead of setting aside reserves, which would have produced a $20 million loss that year, Silverado reported an $8 million profit. In 1986 worried regulators set limits on Silverado's expansion. Other reports then followed until the failure in 1988 of ``imprudent business practices'' and even attempts to hide escalating troubles in its loan portfolio, the documents said. In a cash-raising effort, Silverado issued $4.5 million in Silverado stock to its senior officers, telling regulators they bought it, the reports said. In fact, Silverado accountants just issued the stock free of charge and recorded the purchases as future pay, the reports said. Silverado also lumped all bad loans and real estate it acquired through foreclosure into a $1.1 billion pool of major assets and then reported to regulators the loan pool was a health asset, reports said. The effect was to ``manipulate financial statements to report a more favorable condition,'' regulators said in the documents. When federal marshals moved in in 1988, losses had reached $1 billion, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Panel OKs Antitakeover Bill to Protect Norton Co.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with Dukakis signing the bill; picks up 5th graf pvs `Norton faces ...'
DOC.TEXT: With lightning speed, the Norton Co. received a weapon today to help fight a hostile takeover bid from a British firm. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a bill this morning designed to stall a proxy fight for control over Norton's board of directors. The bill, which takes effect immediately, was signed in Worcester, the home of Norton. The measure sped through the Senate and House on voice votes Tuesday, hours after a legislative committee endorsed the bill. ``We must do all we can to protect our best corporate citizens and their workers and families from having their livelihoods wiped out,'' Dukakis said in a statement. ``This bill gives companies a well-deserved fighting chance against hostile raiders.'' John Nelson, the chairman of Norton, told an enthusiastic crowd of workers that the company ``will continue to fight to remain independent.'' Norton faces a proxy fight at its annual shareholders meeting, currently scheduled for April 26. But Norton is asking a federal Appeals Court to allow the company to delay the showdown until June 26 so executives have more time to plan a defense strategy. Norton last month rejected a $1.6 billion, $75-a-share offer from BTR. But the British conglomerate says it will try to take control of Norton's board at the shareholders meeting. The new bill attempts to stall that strategy by requiring Massachusetts companies to elect their boards of directors over staggered terms. A company, however, could opt out of the requirement. Under the bill, only one-third of the directors would be elected at a time, which means BTR would have to wait at least a year before it could place a majority of directors on the board. Currently, a two-thirds vote by shareholders is needed for a company to change to a staggered board. The United Shareholders Association, based in Washington, issued a statement saying the bill ``would strip the right of shareholders in Massachusetts companies of their ability to vote on the board of directors annually.'' State Sen. Lois Pines, the committee co-chairman, acknowledged that Norton would have trouble shifting to staggered board terms under current law because approximately 70 percent of its shareholders are big institutional investors. But she insisted the bill protects shareholder interests. ``It is important for a company that has served the community like Norton has to have the opportunity to make its own judgments as to how to move forward within a reasonable amount of time,'' Pines said. BTR officials have vowed to continue their takeover bid even if blocked from wresting immediate control of the Norton board. With the collapse of the junk bond market and other sources of takeover financing, bidders increasingly are turning to proxy fights, which makes the new legislation necessary, legislators said. The bill also includes an amendment that would protect worker severance benefits if Norton succeeds in defending itself but is forced to lay off employees. The measure guarantees that the additional protection afforded to the board of directors would ``not be misused at the expense of workers who have most at stake,'' Pines said. Under current state law, workers would receive severance benefits if the takeover fight is successful and a new owner takes control of the company. But legislators said that if Norton succeeds, the battle could become quite costly and the company may have to cut its payroll. ``The first round has gone to the workers,'' said state Sen. John Houston, D-Worcester.

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Reports Higher Quarterly Profit
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. today reported a 16 percent rise in its first quarter profit over a year ago despite lower revenue, as cost-cutting efforts began to pay off for the nation's largest brokerage. For the first three months of 1990, Merrill Lynch earned $41.3 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with earnings from continuing operations of $35.5 million, or 29 cents per share, last year. However, revenue fell from the year-ago quarter to $2.66 billion from $2.79 billion. Commissions, principal transactions, insurance and asset management and custodial fee revenue increased, while interest and dividend, investment banking and other revenue declined. ``Quarterly results improved despite a 5 percent decline in total revenues, reflecting solid progrss in cost reduction, with operating expenses down in virtually every category,'' Chairman William A. Schreyer said in a statement. Schreyer said he expected a previously announced restructuring program, which includes a downsizing through sharp staff reductions, to positively impact earnings for the rest of the year. Merrill Lynch said quarterly expenses totaled $2.60 billion, down 5 percent from the $2.73 billion reported in 1989 Merrill Lynch and several other brokerage companies have been retrenching because of slow business since the October 1987 stock market crash. The company's restructuring includes divesting some product lines and business activities, such as abandoning the European commercial paper business; consolidating and relocating some retail, institutional and other facilities; and reducing the size of other operations. Merrill Lynch plans to eliminate about 3,000 jobs by the end of 1990 through layoffs, attrition and selling off businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing, EEOC Reach Agreement on Pilot Age-Discrimination Case
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. and the federal government have announced an agreement to resolve a 1984 age-discrimination lawsuit filed on behalf of company pilots removed from flight duty after age 60. The consent decree announced Tuesday calls for raising the age limit to 63 and annual testing of older pilots' physical and mental condition, the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Boeing said in statements issued in Seattle and Washington. The agreement also provides $4.4 million to be distributed among 29 pilots covered by the case. ``With this agreement, EEOC is breaking new ground in dealing with age discrimination, specifically age ceilings for pilots,'' said EEOC chairman Evan J. Kemp Jr. ``The agreement calls for a totally new testing procedure that may provide us with better tools to fight employment discrimination based on age.'' Seattle-based Boeing is satisfied with the proposed pact, which is subject to approval by a U.S. District Court in Seattle, said company spokesman Paul Binder. Under the five-year consent decree, Boeing would conduct the tests in coordination with the EEOC until 1995, when the company will decide whether the results warrant permanently lifting the age-60 ceiling. If Boeing decides to reinstate the limit, the EEOC reserves the right to sue, the agency said. The tests will include enhanced medical and performance examinations as well as standard and experimental neurophysical examinations used by the Federal Aviation Administration, the EEOC said. All company pilots will take the tests at first, the agency said, then they will be given annually to determine flight fitness of pilots aged 57 to 63. EEOC general counsel Charles A. Shanor said he is confident the tests will show modern testing and evaluations ``are a far more accurate means of determining pilot competency and safety than the use of chronological age.'' ``The older, well-evaluated, medically cleared pilot brings to the job experience and judgment vital to the safety of our airways,'' Shanor said. Binder said Boeing would not have signed the agreement if it left any doubts about pilot safety. A company statement said testing techniques have become more proven in the 10 years since the previous age policy was adopted ``and individuals are generally more health-conscious now. By moving to age 63 and adopting an enhanced medical-testing protocol, we will continue our tradition of safe flight operations while drawing on the flight experience of our long-service pilots.'' In 1986, a U.S. District Court in Seattle decided the EEOC case in Boeing's favor, saying the age-60 limitation was justified under an occupational qualification exception to the Age Discrimination in Employment Act. That exemption is based on the FAA rule that commercial pilots must be removed from flight status at age 60. But the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in 1988 that the policy's validity for non-commercial pilots should be decided by a jury. If approved, the consent decree will resolve the case, which had been set for trial this week. A fairness hearing on the decree is scheduled May 11 in Seattle. The agreement would go into effect 30 days after court approval.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Drops Dramatically in February
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts new 7th-8th grafs to provide White House reaction, picks up 7th graf pvs, Many private economists. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit shrank dramatically to $6.49 billion in February, the smallest imbalance in more than six years, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said that the 30 percent improvement from a $9.32 billion January deficit came primarily from a big drop in imported oil. Total imports fell by 7.6 percent to $38.12 billion while U.S. exports, which had hit a record level in January, edged down a slight 1 percent to $31.63 billion. The trade deficit is the difference between what America imports and what it sells abroad. The changes gave the United States its lowest monthly trade imbalance since December 1983, when it was $5.68 billion. The February deficit was significantly better than had been expected, but economists said the good news was likely to be shortlived. That would be a blow to the Bush administration, which is counting on further gains in U.S. exports to lift the fortunes of American manufacturers and provide a boost to a sluggish U.S. economy. But at the White House, Michael Boskin, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, hailed the decrease in the trade deficit as ``very good news indeed.'' At the same time, Boskin said, ``We can't yet tell the extent to which it is a temporary or permanent phenomenon.'' Many private economists said that the trade deficit may actually begin rising again this year as the United States grows more dependent on foreign oil and demand for exports weakens because of the strength of the U.S. dollar. A stronger dollar makes American goods less competitive on foreign markets. Analysts were particularly disturbed by the fact that there were widespread declines in a variety of U.S. export categories. The 1 percent overall drop wold have been even larger except for a huge jump in shipments of aircraft. However, analysts said that was a temporary surge attributed to a backlog in shipments at Boeing, which was idled late last year by a strike. Donald Ratajczak, head of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University, said that he was looking for a 1990 trade deficit of $105 billion, down only slightly from an $109 billion imbalance in 1989. ``American competitiveness is not improving at the present time and that is going to make it very hard to make further gains,'' Ratajczak said. In February, oil imports, which had surged by 44 percent in January, fell by 20 percent to $4.71 billion as both the volume of shipments and the price per barrel dropped. The big swing in both months was weather related. A severe cold snap in December depleted supplies and forced record imports in January. However, unusually warm weather in January reduced oil demand in February. Analysts said with domestic oil production now at 25-year lows, they expect foreign oil shipments to resume rising in coming months with the price expected to climb as well. ``There is no question that we are going to import more oil in 1990 than in 1989 and it looks like we will import that oil at a higher price,'' Ratajczak said. In addition to the drop in oil shipments, imports of consumer appliances and other durable goods fell by 7.5 percent while imports of clothing and other consumer nondurable goods dropped by 10 percent. However, imports of foreign cars were up by 25 percent to $2.56 billion in February. That was a primary reason that the deficit with Japan rose during the month to $3.12 billion, accounting for close to half of the overall deficit. The increased Japanese deficit is coming at a time when the Bush administration is applying heavy pressure on Tokyo to make trade concessions in order to ease tensions between the two countries. The February figures showed a $1 billion trade surplus with America's other large trading partner, the countries of Western Europe. President Bush met with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu in early March to discuss trade tensions between the two nations. Since then, several trade agreements aimed at lowering Japanese barriers have been announced. However, many in Congress remain unimpressed. They are demanding that Japan be targeted once again when the administration releases its list of priority countries for negotiations under a tough section of the 1988 trade law known as Super 301. The Japanese have been arguing that they should not be cited when the administration releases the new target list April 30 because of the concessions they have already made. But Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., urged Bush on Tuesday to target Japan for a second round of priority negotiations. ``The progress that has been made toward opening the Japanese market has been made because the United States has put on pressure,'' Baucus wrote. ``Regrettably, if that pressure is removed, I believe progress will stop.''

DOC.HEAD: Heileman Negotiating New Debt Agreement With Creditors
DOC.TEXT: G. Heileman Brewing Co., burdened by a heavy takeover debt, is seeking to negotiate an arrangement to give major creditors partial ownership in the company to discourage any move toward liquidation. Company spokesman Bill Eiler, repeating statements made by Heileman President Murray S. Cutbush on Monday, would not comment Tuesday on the share of equity the banks might receive. Cutbush also declined to name the banks involved in the negotiations. He did say that talks between Heileman and its debt holders started some months ago, and that an accord has not been reached. Cutbush told the trade journal Advertising Age the banks have decided their chances for recovering funds are much improved by letting Heileman continue to market beer instead of selling off parts of the company, perhaps at bargain prices. The financial pressures on Heileman stem from Australian businessman Alan Bond's debt load. Bond Corp. bought Heileman in 1987 in a highly leveraged $1.3 billion deal. Analysts late last year estimated Heileman's debt at $850 million despite the sale of its profitable bakery division and other smaller assets. Last summer, Heileman negotiated a deal with creditors under which it does not have to make any principal payments on outstanding loans until June 30. Heileman has already begun cost-cutting measures to keep ahead of debt collectors. Earlier this month, the company scaled down its advertising operations by consolidating all of its advertising with one or two agencies. Cutbush also said the company will take a hard look at making corporate sponsorship programs ``cost effective.'' Eiler said Heileman breweries in St. Paul, Minn., and Frankenmuth, Mich., are still up for sale. But he added they were the only assets Heileman planed to put on the market. Beer industry sources put Heileman's total worth at $250 million to $350 million. But Jerry Steinman, publisher of Beer Marketer's Insights, a trade publication, said that figure falls woefully short of Heileman's liabilities, which he said may have prodded the company's debt holders to come to the negotiating table. ``The banks were in a bad position,'' Steinman said. ``Heileman owes over a billion dollars, which is more than Heileman is worth. So the banks were in a position where they would lose a lot.'' Steinman added that any restructuring of Heileman's debt would be beneficial for the company. ``The company certainly comes out ahead if they don't have to pay the old loan payments,'' he said. Steinman said preliminary numbers on 1990 sales for Heileman suggest a 10 percent decline from sales a year ago. Heileman sales in 1989 were down about 9.7 percent after suffering an almost identical decline in 1988. The 1989 decline was the largest of America's major brewers.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Says Liquidation Would Net Creditors 7 to 14 Cents On Dollar
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new 11th graf to UPDATE with Texas Air denying speculation on Bakes; picks up 11th graf pvs bg'ng, Smith will ...
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for Eastern Airlines fought off creditors' attempts to have a trustee take over operations, saying a liquidation of the carrier ``is likely to become self-fulfilling'' if a trustee is named. Lawyer Zack Clement also told a bankruptcy hearing Tuesday that Eastern's unsecured creditors would recover only about 7 percent to 14 percent of the money they're owed if the carrier is liquidated. Miami-based Eastern is resisting requests by its unions and unsecured creditors to appoint a trustee for the financially sagging company and take control away from Frank Lorenzo, chairman of its parent Texas Air Corp. Judge Burton R. Lifland heard a third day of testimony over the proposal and Eastern's request for release of $80 million from escrow to help finance its second-quarter operations. The hearing was scheduled to continue today. Eastern attorney Bruce Zirinsky said Friday that Eastern needed the cash by Monday or Tuesday. But he told The Associated Press after Tuesday's hearing that ``there's no immediate need for cash.'' Zirinsky declined to elaborate. But a source close to the companies, who spoke on condition of anonymity, suggested that Texas Air had committed to covering Eastern's second-quarter expenses. Separately Tuesday, Eastern made a pension fund payment of around $14 million that was due this week to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., a government agency. In addition to its other debts, Eastern has about $830 million in unfunded pension liabilities, according to the agency. Also Tuesday, Jose Smith, Eastern's senior vice president of operations, resigned from the company. Eastern spokesman Robin Matell said Smith had accepted a job at Coca-Cola Co. and his departure was unrelated to Eastern's bankruptcy proceeding. Smith, who has worked for Eastern for 23 years, could not be reached for comment immediately. But Eastern President Phil Bakes, asked by a reporter today about Smith's departure, said his decision ``has something to do with what is going on here, in this courtroom.'' Bakes declined comment on speculation that Texas Air could offer Bakes' resignation as a compromise to the creditors. ``There's been a lot of negotiations, a lot of discussions ... I'm not going to discuss it,'' he said. Texas Air later issued a press statement calling the speculation about Bakes ``totally untrue.'' Smith will not be replaced and his position will be eliminated, Matell said. The vice presidents of flight operations and maintenance, who have been reporting to him, will now report directly to Joseph Leonard, Eastern's executive vice president and chief operating officer. At the hearing, Clement said an analysis by Eastern financial adviser Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. indicated the unsecured creditors would receive 6.7 cents for every dollar owed if Eastern were liquidated now. They would get 14.3 cents on the dollar if Eastern were liquidated following completion of the proposed sale of its South American routes to American Airlines. Eastern owes $980 million to the unsecured creditors, who are mainly suppliers of equipment such as aircraft and engines. The group rejected a recent reorganization proposal from Eastern that would pay them 25 cents on the dollar, including 5 cents cash and the remainder in notes. Earlier in the hearing, Eastern's top marketing official warned that appointing a trustee would shake the confidence of travel agents and the flying public in the airline at a time Eastern is desperate for business. George Brennan, Eastern's vice president of marketing, also said such a move could prompt many Eastern managers to resign. ``I know, like myself, many of them would consider the appointment of a trustee the end of the line for that team,'' he said. The unsecured creditors' committee has insisted it does not want to liquidate Eastern but says it might seek a buyer for all or part of the airline. Eastern's preferred shareholders, who are owed $680 million, still are seeking to liquidate the airline. Lifland reiterated that if he named a trustee, that person would be charged with operating the airline. ``Liquidation is not some of the baggage that a trustee necessarily carries with him,'' Lifland said. Elliot Seiden, a vice president and associate general counsel of Texas Air, said appointment of a trustee also could delay government approval of Eastern's proposed $349 million sale of its Latin American routes. He said such a delay would be nearly as serious as a rejection of the sale because Eastern is in severe need of the sale proceeds. James L. Garrity, an assistant U.S. attorney, told the court the Department of Transportation has not taken a position on the trustee issue. He said the appointment of a trustee in itself would not delay a final decision on the route sale, to which the department has given tentative approval. But Garrity said if there was a ``clear indication'' that liquidation would follow the appointment of a trustee, approval likely would be delayed. Eastern's pilots, Machinists and flight attendants unions struck Eastern on March 4, 1989, forcing the Miami-based airline into bankruptcy protection five days later. The Machinists union remains on strike.

DOC.HEAD: Merck Reports First-Quarter Net Income of $404 Million
DOC.TEXT: First-quarter earnings for pharmaceutical giant Merck & Co. increased 19 percent in 1990, boosted by growth in new product sales, the company announced Wednesday. For the three months ended March 31, income rose to $403.8 million, or $1.03 per share, from $340.4 million, or 86 cents a share, during the corresponding 1989 quarter, Merck said. Sales for the first quarter of this year were $1.76 billion, a 12 percent increase over the nearly $1.6 billion for the same three-month period in 1989. ``Sales growth for the quarter was led by new products,'' chairman and chief executive officer P. Roy Vagelos said. ``Both our domestic and international operations reported unit volume gains. Sales outside the United States accounted for 45 percent of Merck's first quarter sales, compared with 49 percent during the same period last year, Vagelos said. Strong showings by the company's human and animal products divisions also helped first-quarter sales.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMs version planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT after close in New York
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell against most major currencies in European trading Wednesday despite figures showing a narrowing U.S. trade deficit. Gold prices rose. Currency dealers said they were surprised the market reacted negatively to news that the U.S. February trade gap had shrunk to a six-year low of $6.49 billion from a revised $9.32 billion in January. ``There was the wildest speculation about the trade figures and many people were apparently even more optimistic than the data allowed,'' said a trader at a large European bank in West Germany. ``A lot of the market had heard the rumors of hugely improved trade figures and set themselves up with that (in mind),'' added David Brown, senior spot foreign exchange dealer for the Royal Bank of Scotland. Some dealers said the trade data, when viewed against the backdrop of recent sluggish jobs growth in the United States, didn't provide sufficient fundamental support to encourage the market to push the dollar higher and encouraged some profit taking. Despite the decline, dealers said they expect the dollar to firm because of political tensions in the Soviet Union and weakness in the Japanese yen. ``The dollar's general stability hinders any sharp moves,'' said the West German trader. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose to a closing 159.87 Japanese yen from 159.83 yen Tuesday. Later, in London, it fell to 159.15 yen. The dollar traded at 158.75 yen at midday in New York. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6347 from $1.6340 late Tuesday. At midday in New York sterling sold for $1.63725. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday: 1.6720 West German marks, down from 1.6770; 1.4876 Swiss francs, down from 1.4900; 5.6315 French francs, down from 5.6370; 1.8855 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8885; 1,230.50 Italian lire, down from 1,232.00; and 1.1640 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1680. Other midday dollar rates in New York, included: 1.6710 West German marks, 1.47975 Swiss francs, 1,227.75 Italian lire and 1.6225 Canadian dollars. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $375 a troy ounce from $374.05 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold rose to $375.50 an ounce from $374. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold gained 48 cents to $375.87 an ounce. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $5.11 a troy ounce from $5.07 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 28 Percent Profit Increase for 1st-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Capital Cities-ABC Inc. said Wednesday its first-quarter profit jumped 28 percent, including a sharp improvement in the performance of the ABC Television Network, especially for its prime-time lineup. Capital Cities-ABC said it earned $106.3 million, or $6.08 per share, for the three months ended April 1 compared with $82.8 million, or $4.59 a share, a year earlier. First-quarter revenue rose 13 percent to $1.26 billion from $1.12 billion in 1989. The media company said its overall operating income rose 29 percent to $211.5 million, with income from broadcasting operations rising 35 percent. It said the ABC Television Network reported ``a very significant profit'' in the latest quarter compared with a ``modest profit'' in the same period in 1989. The company attributed the improvement to the network's ``strong prime-time revenue performance.'' Revenue was up significantly at the network because of ``strong advertising demand and a continuation of satisactory audience delivery in all dayparts except daytime,'' the company said. On Tuesday, ratings figures for the three major networks showed ABC held second place in the 30-week TV season ended Sunday although it gained ground on the leader, NBC. ABC averaged a 12.9 rating, the same as in 1988-89, while NBC's ratings fell 9 percent to 14.6. CBS averaged a 12.2 rating, down 4 percent. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. Last week, CBS Inc. reported a 52 percent increase in its first-quarter earnings to $85.3 million on a 16 percent revenue increase to $851 million. It said its ad sales were strong mainly because it telecast the Super Bowl football game and the NCAA basketball playoffs. CBS called its prime-time ratings disappointing. NBC's earnings are not broken out separately by its parent, General Electric Co. In addition to the network, Capital Cities-ABC's broadcasting operations include eight television stations, the ABC radio networks and 21 radio stations. The company said operating earnings improved slightly from the TV stations declined at the radio stations on modest revenue gains. Operating income from video operations were well ahead of a year ago on significant revenue increases, the company said, while publishing earnings decreased slightly on an acquisition-driven 6 percent increase in revenue. The company publishes daily and weekly newspapers, shopping guides, specialty and business periodicals and books.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Finish Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing stock figures.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished lower Wednesday on London's Stock Exchange after a dull session. Shares were propelled higher early in trading after a buoyant performance in Tokyo, but the rally soon withered. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index fell 8.6 points, or 0.4 percent, to 2,205.9. The Financial Times 30-share index was off 3.7 at 1,732.6 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 1.93 to close at 1,195.11. Volume rose to 352.5 million shares from 254 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 9.1 Percent Increase in First Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co. reported Wednesday that its first quarter earnings increased 9.1 percent from last year, with the soft drink maker's biggest gains continuing to come overseas. Earnings for the quarter were $283.5 million, or 83 cents a share, compared with $259.8 million, or 72 cents a share, during the same period in 1989. Operating revenues were up 12.4 percent to $2.1 billion from $1.9 billion last year. Gallon sales of concentrates and syrups outside the United States increased 9 percent and case sales to retail customers were up 10 percent over the first quarter last year. Sales were particularly strong in Europe, the company said, with a 23 percent increase in gallon sales and a 14 percent increase in case sales. In the United States, case sales increased by 3 percent and gallon sales were up 2 percent. In the first quarter of last year, U.S. gallon sales had increased 7 percent. ``We have started the decade of the '90s where we left he decade of the '80s _ on a roll,'' said Coca-Cola Chairman Roberto C. Goizueta. ``Our company's focus on strengthening its global soft drink system continues to produce outstanding worldwide volume results on top of a superb performance in the same period of the prior year,'' Goizueta said.

DOC.HEAD: American General Posts First Quarter Profits
DOC.TEXT: American General Corp., an insurance company in a proxy fight with Torchmark Corp., on Wednesday reported 10.2 percent growth in its first-quarter earnings. The company, which is based in Houston, earned $101.14 million, or 90 cents per share, on revenue of $1.04 billion for the three months ended March 31. During the same period last year, the company had earnings of $97.17 million, or 77 cents per share, on revenue of $1 billion. ``The improved earnings in the first quarter are the hard-won rewards of a very complex and difficult restructuring program. We believe these results signal the beginning of a new era of progress for American General,'' said Harold S. Hooks, American General's chairman and chief executive officer. American General, with subsidiaries that operate in 50 states and Canada, is in a battle with Birmingham, Ala.-based Torchmark, best known for its Liberty National Mutual Insurance subsidiary. Torchmark made a surprise $6.4 billion offer for American General last month and a week later withdrew its offer, opting instead to solicit proxies to elect its own nominees to American General's board of directors. A Houston federal judge issued a preliminary injunction that had kept Torchmark from lobbying American General's shareholders in support of theirv slate. But a three-judge panel from the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last week stayed the injunction. American General shareholders are scheduled to elect six directors at American General's May 2 annual meeting. American General mailed a letter to its shareholders Tuesday to support its nominees and reject Torchmark's shareholder resolution calling for American General to hire an investment banking firm and appoint a committee of independent directors to evaluate acquisition proposals.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 8.7 Percent Increase in First-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: United Technologies Corp. said Wednesday its first-quarter earnings rose 8.7 percent, citing strong performances by its Pratt & Whitney engines and Otis elevator operations. For the quarter ended March 31, UTC said its net income increased to $134.5 million, or $1.01 a share, compared with $123.7 million, or 95 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 6.7 percent to $4.8 billion from $4.5 billion last year. Robert F. Daniell, chairman and chief executive, said strong performance from Pratt & Whitney and Otis more than offset lower operating results at Carrier, UT Automotive and the Flight Systems segments. UTC's business backlog reached a record $21.2 billion on March 31, up from a record $18.2 billion a year earlier. In the quarter, Pratt & Whitney announced $3.1 billion in commercial engine orders, including options. Quarterly operating income for UTC's power segment _ which includes Pratt & Whitney's commercial engines, government engines and Canadian operations _ grew to $251 million from $179 million a year earlier, primarily due to higher spare parts sales, continuing cost reduction efforts and lower spending on research and development. UTC's buildings systems segment _ which includes Otis _ earned $92 million, compared to $76 million a year earlier. Company officials said the improvement was due to the strong international operations of Otis. UTC's flight systems segment reported a loss of $11 million for the quarter, compared to operating earnings of $12 million a year ago. The company said Sikorsky and Hamilton Standard, two divisions in the flight systems segment, had lower profits because of less favorable product mix and reduced royalty income. UTC's industrial segment also had a profit decline, dropping to $16 million from $53 million. The decline was attributed largely to production of fewer automobiles and light trucks in North America as manufacturers reduced dealer inventories. United Technologies manufactures high-technology products and support services to the aerospace, building systems and automotive industries.

DOC.HEAD: EC Critcizes US Trade Barriers, Urges Conformity with GATT Rules
DOC.TEXT: The European Community on Wednesday questioned the U.S. commitment to international trade accords and cited a wide range of trade barriers. In its fifth annual report on the matter, the EC Executive Commission listed nearly 50 tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade imposed by either Washington or individual U.S. states. These included quantitative restrictions, discriminatory public procurement policies, unreasonable requirements for product testing, labeling and certification as well as high customs fees, export subsidies and tax barriers. The EC report said these ``raise doubts whether the United States is sufficiently committed to the multilateral system which provides the main reference point for resolving disputes.'' The report said the U.S. must bring its trade legislation ``fully in conformity with multilaterally agreed rules.'' It criticized Washington for adopting trade laws that ``conflict with multilateral rules'' and for adopting ``clearly illegal'' trade measures. ``Contrary to popular belief in the United States,'' the U.S. government was guilty of the types of trade barriers it accuses other nations of erecting, the report said. In addition, it accused U.S. officials of tardiness in complying with rulings of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based international trade body. ``The Community is concerned by the extent to which non-tariff barriers to its exports now seem to be more and more at the state rather than at the federal level,'' the EC report said. It blamed state regulations on taxation and on financial and professional services, among others, for creating ``serious handicaps to doing business in the U.S. market.''

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Announce Breakthrough In Corn Genetics
DOC.TEXT: Two teams of researchers say they have produced genetically altered corn plants capable of passing on their newly acquired genes to the next generation, an advance that other scientists hailed on Wednesday as a breakthrough. The technique should allow scientists to develop new strains of disease-, insect- and herbicide-resistant corn much more quickly than they can using traditional cross-breeding techniques, the researchers said. Genetic engineering of corn, the largest and most valuable U.S. farm crop, has long eluded researchers despite their success with such crops as soybeans, cotton, tobacco and tomatoes, said Michael Fromm, a molecular biologist at an Albany, Calif., research center operated by the Agriculture Department and University of California at Berkeley. Fromm headed a research group that also included Monsanto Co. scientists and which announced its findings Monday at a conference in Keystone, Colo. Researchers from DeKalb Genetics Corp., a seed company based in DeKalb, Ill., announced similar findings Wednesday at the Colorado conference. Both groups of researchers used a ``gene gun'' to shoot microscopic gene-coated bullets into corn cells, which were then grown into mature plants. Those plants were then fertilized with pollen and produced a new generation of seedlings which were shown to have the same genetic traits that had been engineered into their parents. ``The technology is now here to begin applying genetic techniques to corn,'' Fromm said in a telephone interview. The scientists said it would be several years before genetically engineered corn products are ready for commercial marketing. ``It is the gene transfer technology that is important,'' said Catherine J. Mackey, director of the DeKalb research team, in a news release. ``This development is the result of many years of research by a team of scientists,'' she said. Genetic researchers have been successfully engineering new strains of soybeans, tobacco and some other crops for several years, using a technique involving bacteria that do not work well with corn and other cereal crops, Fromm said. He said the invention five years ago of the Biolistics gene gun at Cornell University paved the way for genetic engineering of corn. In the USDA-Monsanto project, scientists transferred two genes: one that allows corn cells to grow in the presence of a growth inhibitor and another, derived from firefly genes, that causes corn cells to glow very faintly _ too faintly to be seen with the naked eye. The DeKalb scientists transferred a gene that makes corn cells resistant to a certain herbicide. Alan Kriz, an assistant professor crop molecular genetics at the University of Illinois, said the findings did indeed represent a breakthrough. Kriz said genetic engineering could produce plants resistant to pests and disease and nutritionally superior to today's varieties. ``Corn grain is deficient in certain amino acids,'' Kriz said. ``We should be able to begin altering for those traits as well now.''

DOC.HEAD: Media General Posts 77 Percent Plunge in 1st Qtr Earnings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with reports from Multimedia Inc. and McClatchy Newspapers Inc.
DOC.TEXT: Media General Inc. on Wednesday reported a 77 percent drop in its first-quarter profit from a year earlier as newspaper earnings contracted due to a downturn in advertising. Meanwhile, two other media companies cited advertising weakness in reporting their quarterly results. Regardless, Multimedia Inc. posted a 30 percent earnings gain. But McClatchy Newspapers Inc.'s profit was cut in half. Media General said income in the first quarter of 1989 was boosted by a gain. But excluding that one-time gain, earnings this year still were off 56.3 percent. Total revenue slipped slightly, by less than 1 percentage point. ``Although 1990 revenue growth is expected, the uncertainty of the economy currently is clouding the earnings outlook,'' said James S. Evans, the company's president and chief executive officer. Net income fell to $2.7 million, or 10 cents a share, from $11.9 million, or 46 cents a share in the first quarter of 1989. First quarter 1989 net income included an after-tax gain of $5.7 million, or 22 cents a share, from the sale of a California newsprint recycling mill. Revenue declined to $148 million from $149.3 million last year. Media General said newspaper profits were 44.2 percent lower in the first quarter than a year earlier. The company blamed the decline on faltering national, retail and classified advertising sales caused in part by consolidation within the retailing industry. In particular, a Media General spokesman pointed to the bankruptcy of Miller & Rhoads Inc. in late 1989. The retailer was once Media General's largest advertising client, a Media General statement said. The media company is the parent of the Richmond Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader and other daily newspapers as well as several broadcast operations. Broadcast operation profits increased 2.5 percent. Multimedia, which is based in Greenville, S.C., earned $6.05 million, or 49 cents a share, in the first quarter, up from $4.64 million, or 37 cents a share, in 1989. Total revenue rose 3.3 percent to $109.83 million from $106.30 million. The company said newspaper revenue and operating cash flow were behind last year mainly because of a sluggish retail advertising environment and a downturn in automotive advertising. The Easter advertising season will be credited to this year's second quarter rather than the first because the holiday fell in April this year instead of March as it did in 1989. Multimedia publishes 13 daily and 49 non-daily newspapers, owns and operates 4 television and 7 radio stations and operates more than 100 cable franchises in 4 states. It also produces and syndicates television programs including the Phil Donahue and Sally Jessy Raphael shows. McClatchy Newspapers, which is based in Sacramento, Calif., reported income of $2.36 million, or 8 cents a share, in the first quarter, down from $4.85 million, or 17 cents a share, in 1989's first quarter. The major factors causing the deterioration in profitability were a weakening in ad linage at most newspapers, startup losses from a newsprint mill partnership and costs related to the acquisition in January of six newspapers bought in South Carolina. Revenue rose 9.4 percent to $95.1 million from $86.9 million. McClatchy operates 11 daily newspapers, eight non-daily community papers and several senior citizen tabloids.

For release Sunday April 22
DOC.HEAD: Speculation, Tax Laws Make Land Prohibitively Expensive
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Many Japanese have luxury cars, diamonds and a penchant for some of the most expensive delicacies, but find one coveted item out of reach _ land. Property prices have driven up business costs, widened the wealth gap between landowners and landless, and made home ownership impossible for the average Japanese. Some banks offer 100-year loans that can be passed down through generations, a mortgage unheard of elsewhere. Land inflation has given Japan 60 percent of the value of all real estate worldwide, though it comprises 0.3 percent of the world's land mass. It's not that there's an acute shortage of land on the island nation that became the economic miracle of the 20th century. Rather, it's a murky combination of bureaucracy, tax shelters, lobby interests and unbridled speculation that has made Japan the planet's priciest piece of real estate. Moreover, the enormous value attached to Japanese land has potential economic consequences that go far beyond the borders. For example, property prices affect the financial strength of speculators and other large investors, who have used their land as collateral to buy stocks. As much as half of Japan's phenomenal stock market growth of recent years is rooted in the value of Japanese real estate. Some economists fear a fall in real estate values could devastate the stock market, which already has dropped dramatically this year for other reasons, and send financial shock waves around the world. But others contend property prices must fall as part of a broader reform of Japan's economy. In talks on changing business practices that have contributed to the longstanding U.S. trade deficit with Japan, the government promised earlier this month to curb land inflation. Besides U.S. pressure, there also was recognition that drastic measures are needed to control real estate speculation and prevent the divide between property owners and non-owners from upsetting Japan's social stability, said Kisaburo Ishii, a Construction Ministry official involved in the talks. Land prices in Tokyo soared 23.8 percent in 1987 and 65.3 percent in 1988 before the increase slowed to less than 2 percent last year, the National Land Agency reported. Nationwide, however, they jumped 17 percent after climbing 21.7 percent in 1988 as speculative inflation spread to other major Japanese cities. Last year in Osaka, Japan's second-biggest city, commercial land prices surged 43.9 percent and residential prices 58.6 percent. The world's most expensive commercial property, in central Tokyo's Marunouchi and Ginza business districts, is valued at about $23,700 a square foot. Office space in Tokyo rents for an average $191 a square foot, vs. $156 in London and $64 in New York. With vacancy rates hovering around 0.2 percent, it's a landlord's market. After touting the ``my home'' dream for years, newspapers now feature tales of families who scrimped for decades only to find even a modest home 90 minutes outside Tokyo well out of reach. An average-size house of about 960 square feet about an hour's commute from central Tokyo costs $316,000. Inside Tokyo, prices shoot above $632,000 for houses and about $378,000 for smaller condominium apartments. Although mainstream wage-earners now earn an average of $50,000 annually, many are doomed to a renter's life, since banks generally will lend only four times an annual income for a conventional home mortgage. Competition for new homes in Tokyo's vast suburbs is so intense that hundreds apply for each opening. Many homes are sold by lottery before the foundations are laid. Some families, giving up on ever owning a home, instead are spending on cars, travel and other luxuries. Nationwide, an average of about 60 percent of all households own their homes. In greater Tokyo _ home to around 30 million of Japan's 122 million people _ only 40 percent do. ``The government must deal with this problem,'' said Susumu Ichihata, senior managing director of the Urban Research Institute in Tokyo. ``Now that most Japanese live in cities, these problems could cause political unrest.'' While rents on older apartments have been controlled for decades, newcomers to the housing market face rents prohibitively high. Spacious Western-style apartment rentals fetch $3,140-$9,500 a month. A 650-square-foot Japanese-style unit rents for about $820. Landlords customarily demand at least four months' rent up front _ part refundable deposit, but about two months' rent in nonrefundable ``key money,'' paid for the privilege of becoming a tenant. Renters find the home scramble a nightmare. ``I've just returned to Tokyo and we need to move to a bigger flat. I'm really in a bind because there's no way we can afford to buy a home,'' said Tadao Aoki, a government aide who recently returned from a posting abroad. Most real estate purchases in Tokyo today are by people with property to sell or to borrow against and by brokers buying and reselling land to profit from price increases. Real estate investment, with its various writeoffs, is seen as the easiest way for many high income earners and landowners to avoid high income and inheritance taxes. The incentive becomes great for property brokers, supported by bankers anxious not to miss a fast-growing market, to jack up prices. ``Banks accept the unrealized value of property as collateral and provide financing the same way a casino shucks out poker chips,'' said Tokunosuke Hasegawa, head of the Research Institute of Construction and Economy. Real estate lending is so lucrative that banks apparently have ignored repeated Finance Ministry warnings to cut back. The government also is considering tax reforms aimed at shifting about 148,200 acres of farmland and underutilized acreage in the Tokyo metropolitan region to residential use. Farmland owners pay less than 0.0001 percent of the assessed value of their land in taxes, compared with 70-80 times that rate for residential land. Farmland also is virtually exempt from inheritance taxes, which can rise as high as 80 percent of inherited assets. Tax reforms promised in Japan-U.S. trade talks, however, face strong opposition from the powerful farm lobby and inertia among people accustomed to paying low taxes, even if it means living without sewer lines. Although many Japanese fear falling land prices could hurt the economy, some economists contend that lower land prices would allow the Japanese to build bigger, better houses _ a development certain to boost the economy in the long run. Others say a property-market decline would squeeze out the worst of the speculators who have profited enormously from the cycle of land inflation. ``This is a bubble economy, and it's time for the bubble to burst,'' said Hasegawa. ``The real, productive economy won't really be hurt. Land and people won't disappear, but phony wealth will.''

DOC.TEXT: The stock market posted a broad loss today, registering little enthusiasm over the latest news on the nation's international trade balance. The Commerce Department reported that the U.S. trade deficit in February shrank to its narrowest reading in more than six years. Imports exceeded exports by $6.49 billion, down from $9.32 billion in January. Analysts said that held out the prospect of stronger-than-expected growth in economic output, and improved profits at many companies with a substantial international business. At the same time, however, the figures touched off fresh worries about the outlook for interest rates. In the credit markets prices of long-term government bonds fell more than $10 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the 8.84 percent-8.90 percent range.

DOC.HEAD: Oxy Pete Earns Up 62 Pct for 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Occidental Petroleum Corp. said Wednesday its first-quarter profit rose 62 percent despite a $96 million tumble in earnings from its chemical division. Combined results from oil, natural gas and gas transmission operations rose by $98 million, offsetting the lower chemical division profits, Occidental said. The big oil, chemical and agribusiness company said it earned $108 million, or 37 cents per share, compared with $67 million, or 24 cents per share, in the same period in 1989. Revenue increased by 2 percent, from $5.1 billion to $5.2 billion. Higher worldwide crude oil prices, higher domestic natural gas and natural gas liquids prices, and the resumption of oil production in the North Sea helped push oil and gas division earnings to $100 million, compared with $35 million in the same period a year earlier. Natural gas transmission earnings were $94 million, compared with $61 million for 1989, reflecting lower operating costs, a rate refund and a $12 million benefit from an adjustment to certain tax reserves. The chemical division's earnings fell from $282 million to $186 million, reflecting lower margins in petrochemicals, polymers and plastics, mainly due to industry-wide lower prices, Occidental said. The 1990 results also reflected a $36 million pretax gain from the settlement of a claim against Venezuela stemming from the 1975 nationalization of Occidental operations.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Statement Unable to Halt Slide in Oil Prices
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 16th grafe to UPDATE with close, uppicks 17th graf pvs: It had ... SUBS grafs 1-2 to characterize decline, uppicks 3rd graf pvs: ``It's a ...
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices continued to slide Wednesday despite a vague call by a trio of OPEC heavyweights for cutting back on the the overproduction of crude oil. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the near-term crude contract settled at its lowest level in 16 months despite a statement from the oil ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates urging production restraint. ``It's a fairly empty statement,'' said Nick Antill, an analyst at County NatWest in London. Rumors swept the markets that Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, had privately agreed to slash their output. But, Lucy Mullins, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd in London, said the market ``is taking all of this with a large pinch of salt.'' ``If they wanted to reduce (production), they would probably have included it in the statement,'' said Pierre Terzian, editor of the Paris-based newsletter Petrostrategies. Moreover, Mullins said previous promises by persistent cheaters Kuwait and the Emirates to trim supply have ``not meant very much at all.'' The two Gulf countries have been pumping well above the quotas OPEC sets for each of its 13 members, creating a world oil glut during the often-weak second quarter of the year. Analysts estimate OPEC output at more than 24 million barrels a day, exceeding the ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day in effect for the first half of the year. Prices began plummeting sharply last week, prompting hurried discussions among OPEC nations about whether to hold an emergency meeting. No session has yet been called, but a source close to the presidency of the cartel, who demanded anonymity, said it remains an option. Algerian Mines Minister Sadek Boussena is the current OPEC president. There was no mention of a special meeting in the statement issued by the oil ministers who met Tuesday evening in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. ``It seems that the Jeddah message is the following: Do not meet for the moment unless prices collapse,'' said Terzian. The average price of a basket of seven crudes monitored by the cartel plunged to $15.38 per 42-gallon barrel last week, well off the organization's target of $18 a barrel. The basket price was $17.12 a barrel in the first week of April. On New York's Merc, the contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark American brand, fell 48 cents to settle at $16.96 a barrel. The contract, which lost 41 cents on Tuesday, had been off as much as 84 cents during the day. It had been trading in the range of $20 to $21 a barrel early in April. Antill predicted prices would continue slipping in advance of the regular OPEC meeting in late May, when the oil ministers are to set their pricing and output guidelines for the last half of the year. Mullins said the excess of oil will ``continue to keep prices depressed'' in the next few weeks. OPEC officials had been expecting prices to decline in the April-June period, when demand for oil normally weakens with warmer temperatures in the United States and other consuming nations. But last week's sudden fall was a surprise. In their statement, Saudi Arabia's Hisham Nazer, Kuwait's Ali Khalifa al-Sabah and the Emirates' Mana Saeed Otaiba expressed ``grave concern about the recent developments in the market.'' They blamed the fall in prices on increased crude production by both OPEC and non-OPEC countries. ``The solution, which would guarantee relative market stability, is for OPEC members to commit themselves to respect the production ceiling and the individual production quotas set out for the member states,'' according to the statement carried by the Saudi Press Agency. Analysts estimate that Saudi Arabia, the world's leading oil exporter, is producing about 300,000 barrels a day above its quota of 5.4 million barrels. The Emirates is pumping about 2 million barrels a day, double its quota, according to the estimates. Kuwait is believed producing about 1.9 million barrels a day, over its cap of 1.5 million barrels a day.
