DOC.HEAD: Democrats Unveil 1991 Budget With Defense Cuts, Domestic Boosts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs with details of proposal; picks up 8th graf pvs; edits below to tighten
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats unveiled their own $1.2 trillion budget for next year on Wednesday, a plan that calls for $8 billion less in military spending than President Bush wants. The package, which the House Budget Committee plans to vote on Thursday, would also increase spending by $6 billion on programs that include child care, NASA and aid to Central America, Eastern Europe and Africa. The proposal is the first detailed response by Democratic leaders to the 1991 fiscal year budget Bush requested in January. At the time, Democrats complained Bush's spending blueprint was not a serious effort to reduce the deficit, and was too generous to the military at a time of lessening tensions with the Soviet Union. ``The world has changed greatly,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., who outlined highlights of the plan at a news conference with other top Democrats. ``The United States is obviously now in a position to look more intensively at the problems that lie within our own country.'' House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., predicted approval by his Democratic-dominated panel. He said the package reflects ``a transition from military confrontation to economic leadership, from a Cold War economy to a peacetime economy.'' Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the budget panel, called the proposal ``a typical Democratic budget without discipline.'' GOP lawmakers will vote aganst the Democratic plan, he said, and continue pressing for talks between Congress and the administration as the best way to close the budget gap. The Democratic proposal claims to trim the 1991 deficit by $36 billion to $63.8 billion. That would be just below the $64 billion target set by the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction act, which requires a balanced budget by 1993. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office has said the administration is underestimating next year's deficit by $70 billion. It expects the 1991 budget deficit to be $161 billion before budget reduction starts. The Democrats would slice $11.5 billion off the amount the military would need next year to stay abreast of inflation. That would leave defense spending at $295 billion _ $8 billion less than Bush wants. They would shrink defense spending by $251 billion over the next five years, about a 25 percent cut. The Democrats would spend $106 billion of that on domestic programs, and count $145 billion against the deficit. The Democrats would also cut next year's military budget authority to $286 billion, $30 billion below the total needed to keep up with inflation. Budget authority is the amount of spending an agency can enter into over a number of years. The reduction is crucial because it would signal the start of a long-range decline in Pentagon spending. Panetta's plan would raise taxes by $13.9 billion, the same amount Bush proposed in January, and collect an additional $5.6 billion in new government fees. The anticipated growth of Medicare and other federal benefit programs would be slowed by $4.2 billion. Other savings would include delaying a federal pay raise for three months and improving the efficiency of tax collection. The plan would also boost spending in several areas of science, including NASA; improve federal health efforts for children, and increase expenditures for education, road building and anti-crime intiatives. The congressional budget process was getting its formal start after weeks of closed-door meetings among Democratic budget-writers and party leaders. They spent much of their time fashioning a compromise on Pentagon spending _ which represents one-fourth of the budget _ between conservatives seeking levels similar to Bush's request, and liberals who wanted deeper cuts. Panetta and other leaders also had to sound out their members about two well-publicized budget plans released by two top Democrats earlier this year. In the end, they decided to ignore both proposals. Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee had proposed saving $55 billion next year with a wide range of spending cuts and tax increases. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., suggested cutting the Social Security payroll tax by $55 billion to intensify concerns about the budget deficit. Because these decisions had to be made, Congress again missed the April 15 legal deadline for completing its budget. The requirement is routinely ignored year after year. Budget work is also going slowly in the Senate, where Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., is having trouble rounding up enough votes to move a spending plan out of his committee. Sasser favors cutting defense by $15 billion, about $3.5 billion more than Panetta wants. The budget resolution need only be passed by Congress and does not need the president's signature. It is only a blueprint for spending and savings. Later bills will determine how the government spends its money and which taxes _ if any _ will be raised.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Tumbles Again
With AM-OPEC,Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures settled lower Wednesday, but bargain hunters on a last-minute buying spree helped lift prices from their worst levels. Still, traders remained largely bearish amid disappointment that a recent meeting of OPEC ministers failed to produce any tangible results. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, slid 48 cents to $16.96 per 42-gallon barrel after plummeting 41 cents on Tuesday. The contract, which traded as low as $16.60 a barrel, hasn't settled as low since December 1988. But other contract months took far less of a hit. June crude was off just 30 cents a barrel while the August contract was down 34 cents. Analysts are reluctant to attach too much significance to declines in the May contract since it expires Friday. As a contract nears its expiration, its price becomes increasingly more volatile. The May contract closed $1.13 lower than the June contract when a more typical discount is closer to 30 to 50 cents a barrel, noted Bob Baker, senior energy analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Refined petroleum products traded on the Merc fell sharply after finishing mixed on Tuesday. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline lost 0.89 cent to settle at 59.55 cents a gallon after rising 0.23 cent on Tuesday. Home-heating oil for May delivery dropped 1.51 cents to 52.69 cents a gallon after losing 0.52 cent in the previous session. Traders were disappointed that a meeting of three OPEC ministers failed to result in a plan to cut ongoing overproduction by some cartel members. Analysts estimate OPEC output at more than 24 million barrels a day, exceeding the ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day in effect for the first half of the year. After a meeting late Tuesday, oil ministers of Saudi Aabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates issued a weak statement saying they were gravely concerned about market conditions. The triumvirate said the solution would be for members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to hold to agreed-upon production ceilings. But the lack of any clear-cut plan ``brought out cynicism that OPEC can't handle their affairs,'' Baker said. The market got ``nothing more than vague assurances that for two months they won't overproduce,'' said Peter Beutel, an assistant director at Elders Futures Inc. ``There's a great deal of skepticism that that will actually come to pass and that it will have that big an effect on the market,'' he added. Crude futures prices reflected the pessimism throughout the session. But about a half hour before the close, prices turned higher as bargain-hunters began to buy. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery settled at $1.583 per million British thermal units, off slightly from $1.585 on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar lost ground Wednesday against all major currencies in heavy trading despite new data showing the nation's huge trade imbalance had improved significantly in February. Gold prices rose worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $376.10 a troy ounce, 90 cents higher than late Tuesday's close. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $376.30 an ounce, up $1.30. The Commerce Department reported that the U.S. trade deficit narrowed in February to a six-year low of $6.49 billion from a revised $9.32 billion gap the previous month. Imports fell by 7.6 percent, to $38.12 billion, while exports totaled $31.63 billion, a modest 1 percent decline from an all-time high set in January, the department said. While the report would be considered bullish for the dollar, since it means further reductions in the currency may not be needed to improve the balance of trade, dealers showed little enthusiasm. ``The numbers were certainly strong ... but people expected stronger numbers,'' said J. Thomas Stanley, manager of corporate foreign exchange for Chemical New York Capital Markets Group. Stanley said the dollar had firmed prior to the trade report but fell back after its release. ``There was the wildest speculation about the trade figures and many people were apparently even more optimistic than the data allowed,'' added a trader at a large European bank in West Germany. Also depressing the dollar, traders said, were rumors that some Japanese financial institutions might be considering selling more of their U.S. bond holdings. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose to 159.87 Japanese yen from 159.83 yen Tuesday. It traded at 159.15 yen in London, and at 158.125 yen in New York, down from 159.685 Tuesday. The dollar was weaker against the British pound. Sterling rose to $1.6347 from $1.6340 in London, and to $1.6400 from $1.6383 in New York. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6720 West German marks, down from 1.6765; 1.4785 Swiss francs, down from 1.4895; 5.6200 French francs, down from 5.6360; 1,228.25 Italian lire, down from 1,231.75; and 1.16135 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16485. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday: 1.6720 West German marks, down from 1.6770; 1.4876 Swiss francs, down from 1.4900; 5.6315 French francs, down from 5.6370; 1.8855 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8885; 1,230.50 Italian lire, down from 1,232.00; and 1.1640 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1680. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $375 an ounce from $374.05 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold closed at $375.50 an ounce, up from $374. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold gained 48 cents to $375.87 an ounce. But silver prices were mixed. Silver bullion for April delivery settled at $5.065 a troy ounce on New York's Comex, down 2.8 cents from late Tuesday. Silver rose in London to $5.11 an ounce from $5.07.

DOC.HEAD: First Quarter Earnings Decline
DOC.TEXT: The Dun & Bradstreet Corp. on Wednesday reported its first-quarter earnings fell 23 percent partly because of declines in two business units. Net income for the quarter ended March 31 totaled $110.31 million, or 60 cents a share, off from earnings of $143.30 million, or 77 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. Operating revenue increased 8.5 percent to $1.15 billion, from $1.06 billion a year earlier. Revenue growth for the quarter amounted to 4 percent when adjusted to reflect the acquisition of Management Science American in late 1989 and the divestiture of Thomas Cook Travel USA a year ago, the company said. Operating income was off 25 percent at $168.78 million, compared with $224.82 million a year earlier. Dun & Bradstreet, which markets business information worldwide, attributed the declines in both profits and operating income to a decrease in revenue at its U.S. Credit Services, its commercial credit information business. The company also was adversely affected by the expiration of a contract with Chesapeake & Potomac Telephone Co. Dun & Bradstreet's Donnelley Directory sold advertising space for the phone company's Yellow Page directory. Separately, the company's marketing information services, financial information services and business services units each posted revenue gains. Last month Dun & Bradstreet annouced it would divest a number of operations, including Datastream International and Interactive Data, Neodata Services and Petroleum Information to simplify the company's ``business mix.'' During the first quarter, the company purchased 2.64 million shares of its stock under a 10-million-share repurchase program approved in November 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor Reports Higher Profits, Sales
DOC.TEXT: General Dynamics Corp., the nation's second largest defense contractor, reported Wednesday that first-quarter profits were up 64 percent thanks to a one-time gain from the settlement of an antitrust litigation. Without the big boost, General Dynamics net earnings would have slipped 17 percent. The company, headquartered in St. Louis, had profits of $123.7 million, or $2.97 a share, for the quarter, which ended March 31. That compares to $75.4 million, or $1.81 share, for the same period in 1989. Sales for the quarter were $2.5 billion, up 5 percent from $2.4 billion in the first quarter of 1989. The one-time gain in the quarter of $61.5 million came March 22 when General Dynamics and American Telephone & Telegraph Co. settled a 7-year-old lawsuit in federal court in Chicago. The lawsuit alleged that AT&T tried to monopolize the market for business telephone systems and other equipment with several unfair business practices. The settlement included a denial of all allegations by both parties. Stanley Pace, chairman and chief executive officer, said profits declined in every defense-related segment of the company including military aircraft, submarines and missiles, space and electronic systems. He said that the company had reduced its earnings expectations on its F-16 program because of higher costs and transfer of employees to other projects and in its missiles, space and electronic systems segment because the company earned fewer contracts than expected. On the positive side, Pace said, the successful market acceptance of Cessna's Citation V business jet was the key factor in a dramatic increase in sales and earnings in the company's general aviation sector. Cessna delivered 16 Citation Vs during the first quarter, nearly half of the total delivered last year. Pace said Cessna holds 92 additional orders. The CEO said an increase in interest expense to $19.4 million from $14.1 million in the same period a year ago reflected the higher level of company borrowing. The increased borrowing was made necessary by accelerated tax payments required by changes in accounting methods and for continuing investments in advanced programs, he said.

DOC.HEAD: AMR Blames Higher Fuel, Labor Costs For First Loss In Nine Quarters
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines' parent AMR Corp. posted a $19.3 million first quarter loss Wednesday, blaming higher fuel and labor costs for its first loss in more than two years. ``Our results can only be called unsatisfactory,'' said Chairman Robert L. Crandall. AMR, whose American Airlines is the nation's biggest airline, is the first of the nation's major airline companies to report earnings for the traditionally slow first quarter. Analysts expect most airlines to report losses or smaller profit than last year. AMR's loss was less than many industry analysts had expected. AMR said it lost 31 cents per share on total operating revenue of $2.69 billion. In the same period last year, AMR had a profit of $156.7 million, or $1.60 per share, on revenue of $2.45 billion. Expenses increased by $402.1 million, the company said, with 26.5 percent coming from higher fuel prices. Fuel jumped from $322.3 million in the year-ago quarter to $428.7 million this year. Labor costs also rose $85 million while other expenses were up $210.7 million. American Airlines, which accounts for almost 94 percent of AMR revenues, lost $23.6 million, compared with a profit of $158.4 million last year. The loss wiped out profit from other AMR subsidiaries, which include American Eagle commuter airline, and several subsidiaries related to the travel and information industries. ``Cargo volumes are strong,'' Crandall said. ``The growth of passenger traffic in the international markets, particularly Europe, the Caribbean and Asia, was outstanding, but growth in domestic markets was weak.'' During the quarter, American expanded its operations in Europe and Australia. The company also agreed to buy the Latin American operations of Eastern Airlines, a deal which is still pending federal review. AMR also has 14.6 percent more employees this year than last year. The company flew 17.5 billion passenger miles compared to 16.2 billion in the same quarter last year. ``When a company is growing like that, there're a lot of upfront costs,'' said analyst Mark Daugherty at Dean Witter Reynolds. ``They've invested a lot in planes, employees, and training for the long term. The unfortunate result is in the short term it involves a lot of expenses.'' AMR said its revenue yield per passenger mile, a key measure of performance, was unchanged at 12.73 cents. The passenger load factor also was unchanged at 59.9 percent. However, the break-even load factor _ the percentage of seats that must be occupied for the airline to break even _ moved from 54.8 percent last year to 60.6 percent this year.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Futures Hit 16-Month Low On Weak OPEC Response To Oil Glut
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices settled below $17 a barrel for the first time in nearly 16 months Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as prices fell in response to the lack of a strong OPEC response to the worldwide oil glut. On other commodity markets, sugar futures surged; grains and soybeans were mixed; precious metals were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 21 cents to 48 cents lower in New York with the contract for delivery in May at $16.96 a barrel. It was the lowest settlement price for a near-month crude oil contract since Dec. 29, 1988, although crude traded as low as $16.25 on April 11. Heating oil futures finished .87 cent to 1.51 cents lower with May at 52.69 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .45 cent to .94 cent lower with May at 59.55 cents a gallon. Oil traders were unimpressed with a vague call by three OPEC heavyweights for cutting back on the overproduction of crude oil. Production by some members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in excess of their OPEC-imposed quotas has been cited by some analysts as a major cause of a global oil glut and the resulting 22 percent drop in prices since early March. The oil ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates met Tuesday evening in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and later issued a statement urging production restraint. ``I think that given the circumstances, the market was looking for more,'' said Andrew Lebow, an energy analyst with E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc. Traders had little reaction to Tuesday's weekly U.S. oil inventory figures from the American Petroleum Institute. The trade group reported a modest 814,000-barrel increase last week in U.S. supplies of crude oil. Randall Rothenberg, an energy broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the oil market ``remains in a bearish mode'' in the absence of a stronger OPEC response to the situation. Sugar futures prices leaped on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange as rumors circulated that the Soviet Union was quietly buying physical sugar on the cash market. Prices were further supported by talk that India and Mexico may enter the market as buyers later in the year, analysts said. Sugar settled .21 cent to .48 cent higher with May at 15.40 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures settled mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade amid light profit-taking after two days of gains. The soybean and soybean oil markets posted the steepest losses after exhibiting the greatest strength in the two previous sessions. Soybean oil for delivery in May settled 29 cents lower Wednesday at $22.71 per 100 pounds. The contract had gained a total of 99 cents in the two previous sessions. Wheat futures ended 1} cents lower to { cent higher with May at $3.65\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1\ cents lower with May at $2.73} a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower with May at $1.57{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 3{ cents lower with May at $5.94\ a bushel. Gold futures rose slightly on New York's Commodity Exchange, supported by falling stock prices. Silver futures fell moderately. Gold finished 90 cents to $1.30 higher with April at $376.10 a troy ounce; silver was 3 cents to 3.1 cents lower with May at $5.078 a troy ounce. Livestock and meat futures ended mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with strength centered in the near-term contracts, reflecting higher cash markets. Live cattle futures settled unchanged to .15 cent higher with April at 79.87 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .15 cent higher with April at 84.10 cents a pound; live hogs were .35 cent lower to .35 cent higher with April at 56.80 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents lower to .37 cent higher with May at 59.42 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Union Presidents Oppose Icahn's USX Plan
DOC.TEXT: Forty-six union presidents representing 18,000 USX Corp. employees said Wednesday they oppose Carl Icahn's proposal to break up the company's steel and energy assets. However, a statement on the issue won't be released until it has been reviewed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, said Gary Hubbard, spokesman for the United Steelworkers of America. Icahn, USX's largest shareholder, has proposed spinning off the company's steel business, saying two separate companies will be worth more than one. His proposal plan will be put to a non-binding vote of USX stockholders at the company's May 7 annual meeting in Findlay, Ohio. The union's statement will be mailed to shareholders after it has been cleared by the SEC, Hubbard said.

DOC.HEAD: Union Protest, Abortion Controversy Mark AT&T Annual Meeting
With AM-Earns-Phones
LaserPhoto LA8
DOC.TEXT: AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen defended his company Wednesday against protesters who accused it of caving in to abortion foes and union members who said it pushed workers out of jobs to boost profits. Union workers picketed outside as Allen delivered an optimistic message to shareholders at American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s annual meeting. The workers accused AT&T of achieving profits by unnecessarily laying off 13,500 workers in 1988 and planning to discharge another 9,000 this year while raising some executives' pay by 35 percent. ``Jobs with justice!'' the protesters chanted as about 1,000 stockholders of AT&T, one of the most widely held and largest of U.S. companies, filed into a huge hall at the Los Angeles Convention Center. The demonstrators accused AT&T of exporting jobs to countries with cheap labor. Allen said that was done only when absolutely necessary to stay competitive or to sell products in the foreign countries themselves. Allen also faced questions about AT&T's cutoff of funding to Planned Parenthood Federation of American Inc., to which AT&T had given more than $200,000 over the past 25 years. AT&T said last month it would not give the group a donation next year due to the controversy over abortion. This year, AT&T donated $50,000. Planned Parenthood accused AT&T of ``corporate cowardice'' in full-page ads in New York and Los Angeles newspapers. The group said AT&T's donations have not been used for abortion services, and that the company's recent contributions have been restricted to teen pregnancy prevention programs. Typical of the complaints was a letter from New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, who wrote on behalf of the city's employee pension fund, which owns AT&T stock. ``... By providing family planning assistance, Planned Parenthood helps to reduce unwanted pregnancies and thus the incidence of abortion,'' she wrote. At a news conference before the meeting, Allen said Planned Parenthood recently shifted its position and became a strong advocate of legalized abortion. He said AT&T could not afford to jeopardize its corporate position of neutrality on abortion. ``We became tainted ... and tarnished among a number of our constituents,'' he said, ``because we became known as (having) a pro-abortion stance.'' At the meeting, shareholders spent about 45 minutes discussing a proposal from one stockholder that would have instructed the company to refrain from supporting any pro-abortion organization. The company recommended that shareholders reject the proposal, citing its wish to remain neutral. Shareholders overwhelmingly turned down the proposal, with 618.7 million shares voted against it to 36.1 million in favor, said AT&T spokesman Dick Gray. As for layoffs, Allen said AT&T has ``unfortunately'' been forced to cut its work force by 102,000 salaried and hourly employees since 1984, when it was required to spin off its regional telephone companies. ``This is not an easy task for any of us but it is necessary if we are to compete in any of our markets,'' he said. AT&T and unions representing 135,000 of its employees reached tentative agreement Tuesday on improved pension benefits designed to encourage early retirements and thus reduce the need for layoffs. Allen told shareholders that the company had its best year ever in 1989 in terms of profits, revenues, earnings per share and stock price. ``AT&T is moving forward into the decade of the 1990s, fleeter of foot, quicker in its reponse to customers and to changes in the marketplace, more alert to new targets of opportunity for growth,'' he said, according to a company statement. He said the company planned to introduce in about five years equipment that would switch phone signals by pulses of light, dramatically increasing the capacity of the phone network. Currently, light is used to send phone signals over fiber optic lines, but the light pulses must be converted back to electrical impulses before they are switched to other lines. Before the meeting, AT&T reported that its first-quarter profit rose 12.5 percent to $668 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with earnings of $594 million, or 55 cents a share, in the first three months of 1989. Revenue totaled $8.89 billion, up 2.7 percent from $8.66 billion.

DOC.NOTE: $adv22
For release Sunday April 22
DOC.HEAD: Environmental Movement Turns Some Companies Green With Embarrassment
DOC.TEXT: For an image-obsessed outfit like the Walt Disney Co., the soiled Mickey Mouse disposable diapers scattered throughout garbage dumps don't exactly proclaim environmental activism. MCA Inc. is making points with a company recycling program and earth-friendly television shows, movies, videos and records. But some critics say the entertainment conglomerate is mismanaging Yosemite National Park, which an MCA subsidiary oversees. Industrial giants from Exxon Corp. to Union Carbide Corp. present fat targets for environmentalists. But the reach of the green movement has grown so much that even Disney and MCA, home of such squeaky clean characters as Snow White and E.T., now must answer to the ecological accountants. Not long ago, the world looked to Hollywood for escapism. In recent years, however, public pressure has led the entertainment industry to reexamine its depiction of alcohol abuse, violence toward women, birth control and bigotry. Now that the environment has become the hot issue, Hollywood once again is trying to set an example. NBC's ``ALF'' is among the most environmentally conscious TV shows. One recent episode had the furry alien battling chlorofluorocarbon polluters. NBC distributed note pads of recycled paper to advertise the show. The episode reflected well on NBC and its parent, General Electric Co. But GE isn't ranked too highly by environmental groups. At GE's annual meeting April 25, for example, shareholder activists have resolutions on the agenda urging the company to devise a plan to stop producing hazardous wastes and cut its own chlorofluorocarbon pollution. These days, the entertainment industry is not content generating ecological programs, such as The Disney Channel's presentation this month of anti-pollution shows. Instead, many Hollywood companies are practicing their own environmentalism. Disney and MCA, for example, say they're motivated by genuine concern. ``We're not out to publicize our efforts,'' said Garrett De Bell, MCA's environmental consultant. Last month Disney appointed a new environmental czar, Kym Murphy, who reports directly to company chieftains Michael Eisner and Frank Wells, and says they realize ``the amazing responsibility we have.'' ``Our ability to influence is remarkable, and the perception people have of us is really hard to live up to,'' Murphy said. Has Disney done so? Not entirely, he acknowledged. ``I think if you ask people, `Does Disney recycle,' they would say, `Gee, they must if anybody does.' '' In fact, Disney does not. Disney is anxious to start a better program, he said. One of Murphy's first chores was contacting the Procter & Gamble Co., which buys licenses rights to print little Disney characters on the adhesive strips that hold Disney Babies disposable diapers to infant bottoms. Disposable diapers are among the fastest-growing components of landfill rubbish. About 16 billion are dumped each year. Environmentalists say they can take decades to decompose. Murphy said Procter & Gamble researchers are ``pulling out all the stops'' to make their products more environmentally safe. His other chief environmental headache has been Disney's quasi-city government that exercises near-total power over 27,000 acres surrounding the company's Florida operations, home of Walt Disney World and other fun parks. For the past two years, Disney has come under heavy criticism from some local community leaders who say it doesn't pay the environmental costs generated by millions of tourists. Disney finally agreed to pay $14 million in additional property taxes, but then angered locals even more by announcing construction of seven more hotels, 29 new attractions, a fourth amusement park and 19,000 more workers. ``They can go out there and pave over anything they want to do without going through any kind of environmental review,'' said Bill Donegan, an Orange County, Fla. commissioner who'ss led an effort to make Disney more accountable. ``We don't know the real impact environmentally. We don't know how many woodpeckers' nests have been destroyed, how many eagles, how many ospreys.'' MCA has been trumpeting its attention to the environment, both on the Universal Studios lot and in film and TV. At MCA offices in Universal City, the company began a company-wide recycling program using containers decorated with a Woody Woodpecker logo. The staff at MCA subsidiary Universal Television met last fall with representatives of the Environmental Media Association, an organization that promotes earth-friendly messages in the entertainment industry. Andy Spahn, EMA director, said producers asked how recycling themes could be incorporated into storylines. ``This is not a problem that can be solved by government action alone,'' he said. ``Through film, television and music, the industry is in a unique position to reach millions of people and show them they can make a difference.'' Others say the real test of a company's commitment to the environment is not whether it makes shows about recycling. More important, they say, is whether a company's decisions do more for the planet than for profits. ``High profile companies cannot change the world single-handedly, but they can set an example,'' said Richard Branson, chairman of Virgin Records and Virgin Atlantic Airways and a long-time environmental activist. ``It's so often people will talk about causes without doing something that actually affects themselves or their business,'' said Branson. Sleeves for Virgin's records (artists include Paula Abdul, Soul II Soul) are recycled paper. Virgin Atlantic says it will plant a tree for every passenger flying between London and Los Angeles in the next 12 months. At the Hard Rock Cafe chain, employees sort waste paper and beverage bottles, said founder Peter Morton. ``We're not suddenly converts to the environmental movement now that it's fashionable,'' he said, noting that the phrase ``Save the Planet'' has been part of the company's logo for 10 years. Despite earning millions of dollars at Yosemite on a concession fee of $600,000, MCA's Yosemite Park and Curry Co. is as committed to the park as it is to shareholders, the company says. Environmental consultant De Bell, who lives in Yosemite, said that when Yosemite switched from polystyrene cups to recyclable paper containers, it cost MCA about $20,000. ``We want to do good business and improve the environment as much as possible,'' De Bell said. Dan Jensen, executive vice president of MCA's Curry unit, said the subsidiary declined an offer worth hundreds of thousands of dollars from a automobile maker wanting to call itself Yosemite's official car. ``We would have been preying on the name Yosemite which is not ours to own,'' Jensen said. Environmental critics say MCA has spent too much marketing the California park and doesn't spend enough money maintaining it. De Bell said the criticisms have been blown out of proportion because ``Yosemite is a shrine of the environmental movement.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday April 22

DOC.HEAD: Liquidating Firm To Sell Asset Management Group for More Than $6 Million
DOC.TEXT: Thomson McKinnon Inc. agreed Wednesday to sell its interest in an asset management subsidiary for more than $6 million, as the parent of the failed Wall Street firm Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. continues liquidating. Thomson McKinnon said it was selling its 63 percent interest in its remaining operating entity, Thomson McKinnon Asset Management LP, to a group of the subsidiary's managers and two Boston investment firms. The asset management unit is a mutual fund and private account money manager for $6.7 billion in assets. It operated as a separate entity since a public stock offering in 1987. Under the proposal, Greylock Investments, TA Associates and key managers of the unit will form a company to acquire the asset management subsidiary. The new company will pay $800,000 for 200,000 general partnership units in the subsidiary and $5.4 million for an option to buy the balance of Thomson McKinnon's units at a price of $4.53 per unit. Thomson McKinnon Securities, the firm's brokerage unit, filed for Chapter 11 federal bankruptcy court protection from creditors last month. The 105-year-old firm had sought a buyer since the 1987 stock market crash. The firm stopped doing business last July after selling its retail brokerage offices and customer accounts to Prudential-Bache Securities Corp. for about $60 million. The deal followed a collapse of a proposed merger. Thomson McKinnon said in a statement that the sale of the asset management division anticipates a renewed marketing effort for its mutual fund activities. The new company also will acquire Thomson McKinnon Fund Distributors Inc. from the brokerage subsidiary. The investors' proposal requires approval of the creditors of Thomson McKinnon, the brokerage subsidiary and a U.S. Bankruptcy Court judge. The asset management division includes the mutual funds Cash Accumulation Trust, Thomson McKinnon Investment Trust and Thomson Accumulation Plan Trust. It also advises private accounts through its Columbus Circle Investors division and Foxhall Investment Management division.

DOC.NOTE: $adv22
For release Sunday April 22
DOC.HEAD: Recycling the Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous
With BC-Corporate Ecology
DOC.TEXT: Do celebrities really care about spotted owls, the ozone layer and rain forests? Or are they simply tree-hugging the cause of the week? The evidence suggests that while numerous entertainers _ actor Ed Begley Jr. and singer Jackson Browne among them _ have adapted environmentally friendly living practices, many others are slow to practice what they preach. At a recent Beverly Hills benefit for the Brazilian rain forest, an array of Hollywood celebrities _ superstars like Jane Fonda and agent Michael Ovitz _ were warned of the dangers of global warming and pollution. The 1,000 or so guests dined on organic foods. They raised $1.2 million for the environment. Then they went for their limos, idling patiently, stretching for blocks. Exhaust filled the evening air. It was scarcely an isolated slip. When Hollywood's blue-ribbon Environmental Media Association held its first organizational meeting at producer Norman Lear's house, EMA founders arrived in Mercedes, BMWs, Rolls-Royces and other gas-guzzlers. Producer Ted Field and wife Susie, who hosted the Beverly Hills rain forest benefit, are longtime contributors to the Natural Resources Defense Council and charter members of EMA. They also have been known to fly to their spacious Aspen home in a private jet. ``It's great celebrities are getting involved,'' said Bob Hattoy, a lobbyist for the Sierra Club. ``But it's not about doing lunch. It's about changing the way that we live. Lifestyles of the rich and famous are often lifestyles of the wasteful and indulgent.'' ``The entertainment industry is symbolic of the values of everyone in our culture,'' said Bonnie Reiss, who founded the Earth Communications Office. ECO seeks to add environmental themes to television shows and movies. ``We have to get the rich and famous to truly examine their lifestyles,'' Reiss said. Environmentalism has yet to become Hollywood's flavor of the month. All the same, the nation's trendsetters are catching on slowly. Hollywood has long been the land of excess, and tradition does not die easily. At an April news conference for ABC's Earth Day special, celebrity performers were ferried to the event in _ you guessed it _ limousines. Tom Cruise has visited the Amazonian rain forest and is a member of the ECO. So is his next movie about global warming? Not quite. Cruise stars next in ``Days of Thunder,'' a movie about the hardly fuel-efficient sport of auto racing. Scientists reckon a third of all global warming gases are transportation-produced; neither Paramount Pictures nor Cruise's publicist could say how many thousands of gallons of fuel were used making ``Days of Thunder.'' Olivia Newton-John, a top environmental activist, is damaging a stretch of the Southern California coastline, her Malibu neighbors have charged in a civil complaint. Newton-John and her husband have polluted the ocean with tons of dirt and sand removed during the construction of their 6,000 square foot home overlooking the beach, the complaint charges. ``It's blown way out of proportion,'' Newton-John said. ``I had an environmental specialist look at the property. I care about the environment.'' Die-hard environmentalists don't wear furs or leather. So how did people dress at the Beverly Hills rain forest benefit? Singer Don Henley, who performed at the fund-raiser, said he had visited the cloak room before coming on stage. What did he see? ``About a quarter of a million dollars' worth of dead animals.'' Actor Begley is one of the handful of personalities who has reordered his life to save the planet. He rides a bicycle or takes the bus to work, has a compost heap in his back yard and has installed 15-watt bulbs in his house. ``We don't need any more definition of environmental problems,'' Begley said. ``We need action.'' David Zucker, co-director of ``Airplane!'' and the director of ``Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad,'' now drives an electric car. Dennis Weaver, star of the TV series ``McCloud,'' has designed an ``ecologically balanced'' house in Colorado. ``We're building it out of old tires packed with dirt,'' the actor said. ``The electricity will come from solar cells and all water will be heated by the sun.'' Other leading earth activists include Ted Danson, Lloyd Bridges, Hart Bochner and Melanie Mayron. Reiss said that Cruise organized a recycling program on the ``Days of Thunder'' set, lives in a modest house and rides his motorcycle to save fuel. ``I feel Tom Cruise is extremely committed,'' Reiss said. ``Does he have room to grow? Everyone has room to grow.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday April 22

DOC.HEAD: Sprint Plans to Proceed with IRS Information Service
DOC.TEXT: US Sprint Communications Co. said Wednesday it will go ahead with a disputed proposal to offer special 800-number calling for taxpayers seeking information from the Internal Revenue Service. One of Sprint's major rivals, MCI Communications Corp., had challenged the ``enhanced'' toll-free offering, saying the service fell outside the scope of the contract for the new federal long-distance system known as FTS 2000. Sprint is providing 40 percent of FTS 2000; AT&T has 60 percent. MCI lost out in the bidding for FTS 2000, estimated to be worth $25 billion over 10 years, and has been ready to pounce when any federal agency has sought to add services not explicitly outlined under the FTS 2000 contract. After the FTS 2000 contract was awarded in December 1988, the IRS said it needed special call-routing service to handle the huge volume on its incoming 800 lines. The agency planned to let AT&T provide the enhanced 800 service, but when MCI protested, it agreed to open up the bidding to outside companies. But the General Services Administration, which oversees FTS 2000, told the IRS it could have the service under FTS 2000. Because Sprint's share of FTS 2000 system included the IRS, the GSA said Sprint could offer the additional service. MCI claimed the GSA's decision in favor of Sprint amounted to an impermissible sole-source award. But the federal Board of Contract Appeals rejected MCI's claim on Feb. 27. The appeals board action allowed Sprint to sign a letter of intent with the government for the enhanced 800 service, Sprint spokeswoman Janis Langley said Wednesday. The taxpayer assistance service handles more than 60 million calls per year, according to Sprint, which valued the contract at $450 million over 10 years. Sprint plans to have all the voice traffic in its FTS 2000 contract switched over to Sprint's network by the end of the month. Langley said the special 800 service should be in place by the end of the year. MCI spokeswoman Pam Small said the company still was considering an appeal on the Feb. 27 decision in the U.S. Court of Appeals. The FBI confirmed in February that it is investigating claims that Sprint illegally obtained competitors' confidential bid information to win the FTS 2000 contract. Sprint has denied the allegations, which were contained in a suit filed in Washington by two former Sprint employees.

DOC.HEAD: Allied Closing Two Jordan Marsh Department Stores
DOC.TEXT: The Jordan Marsh Co., the New England department store chain owned by Allied Stores Corp. is closing stores in Lowell, Mass., and Danbury, Conn. Cincinnati-based Allied and Federated Department Stores, which own 260 stores nationwide, have been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy law protection from creditors since Jan. 15. ``Because of our Chapter 11 status, it is incumbent upon us to review all contracts, all services and all store operations with a keen eye,'' Jordan Marsh chairman Richard Van Pelt said in a prepared statement issued Tuesday. He said the Lowell store, which needed major renovation, would close on June 20. The Danbury store, which he said was becoming less competitive in the market, was scheduled to close by July 15. Van Pelt said the 42 full-time and 40 part-time employees at the Lowell store, and the 60 full-time and 69 part-time employees at the Danbury store would be offered jobs at other Jordan Marsh locations. Jordan Marsh, with 26 stores, is New England's largest department store chain and employs about 10,000 people. Allen Questrom, chairman of Federated and Allied, issued a statement saying that the retailers were reviewing each store's profitability and determining which to close. ``We can reaffirm at this point, however, that we expect to close only a small number of our 260 stores nationally as a direct result of the ability to reject leases under Chapter 11,'' Questrom said. He said that in the past two years Federated and Allied have opened 12 stores in high-growth markets and closed 10 stores in other areas. ``Store openings and closings are a normal part of the retail business,'' Questrom said. ``The operations review process now underway is no different from that of any other year, with one exception. Because this year's review is being conducted under the auspices of Chapter 11, we have the added ability to reject certain store leases that otherwise would have bound us to lower-profit locations.'' Questrom said decisions on store closings would be announced as they are made. ``We have indicated from the outset of the Chapter 11 process that we intend to take advantage of the additional flexibility provided by the filing,'' he said. ``At this time, however, we have no elaborate master plan or precise corporate timetable for doing so.''

DOC.HEAD: New Coke Anniversary Marked With Ads; Pepsi Signs Boxer in Coke's Backyard
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co. is marking the fifth anniversary of New Coke with advertisements thanking consumers for rejecting it. The full-page ad, scheduled to run Friday in seven major newspapers, does not mention New Coke by name, but notes that five years ago consumers responded to the arrival of the reformulated drink by demanding the return of Coca-Cola's original formula. ``Five years ago, we learned what `back by popular demand' can really mean,'' the ad says. New Coke was introduced on April 23, 1985. Meanwhile Wednesday, Pepsi-Cola Co. announced it has signed its latest celebrity promoter in rival Coke's backyard: boxer Evander Holyfield of Atlanta. Holyfield, heavyweight boxing's No. 1 contender, will participate in various local promotions for Purchase, N.Y.-based Pepsi, the first of which will provide tickets to sporting events for youngsters who stay drug-free and have good school attendance. ``It allows us to really reach out into the community and demonstrate our commitment to the Atlanta area,'' said Mark Smalls, Pepsi's area marketing manager. After the consumer outcry greeted the introduction of New Coke, the soft drink maker brought back original Coke under the brand name Coca-Cola Classic that summer. It has regained the position of the nation's best-selling soft drink, while New Coke has slipped out of the Top 10. ``Some say that this was the best example of the wisdom and power of the American consumer, and we certainly agree,'' says the ad, which features a photograph of more than 3,000 Coke employees. ``That's why we gathered together all of The Coca-Cola Company employees in Atlanta to salute you and thank you for telling us exactly what you wanted,'' the ad says. Coke's ad will appear in The Wall Street Journal, USA Today, The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune, The Washington Post and The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. Industry analysts have said that by replacing original Coke with the reformulated version, the company committed a major marketing blunder. But the attention given to the consumer revolt and the return of original Coke has been credited with helping to revitalize the soft drink business.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Loses $915 Million; Merrill Earnings Up Slightly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Shearson earnings; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said Wednesday it lost $915 million in the first three months of 1990, the biggest quarterly loss in Wall Street history. Merrill Lynch & Co. reported a 16 percent increase in first-quarter profit despite lower revenue, as cost-cutting efforts began to pay off for the nation's largest brokerage, which lost money in 1989. The loss at Shearson, which the firm forecast two weeks ago, was attributed to a $630 million charge against earnings to pay for a restructuring that included thousands of layoffs and the elimination or reduction of several businesses. The restructuring was implemented after parent American Express Co. moved to seize tighter control of the nation's No. 2 investment firm, which has struggled during a bad period on Wall Street following broad expansion in the 1980s. American Express plans to acquire all Shearson stock it does not own. Shearson also said it took a $157 million charge against first-quarter earnings because of an accounting change in the way it pays for development of computer software. Excluding the one-time charges, Shearson still lost $128 million for the quarter. ``The first-quarter operating loss before the restructuring charge stems from a slowdown in overall business activity and other first-quarter 1990 events,'' Shearson said. The overall first quarter loss before the accounting change equaled $8.75 per share. That compared to a loss of $15 million, or 24 cents a share, in the same 1989 period. Total revenue fell 15 percent to $2.6 billion from $3 billion a year earlier. Shearson said it increased litigation reserves by $50 million; added $32 million to a loan loss reserve primarily related to the portfolio of its Boston Co. subsidiary; and lost $34 million because of fluctuations in the high-yield bond market. Shearson said it had $54 million in income related to the settlement of litigation in connection with the suspension of trading in tin by the London Metal Exchange in 1986. Merrill Lynch said it made $41.3 million, or 34 cents a share in the first quarter, compared with $35.5 million, or 29 cents per share, last year. Revenue declined to $2.66 billion from $2.79 billion. Commissions, principal transactions, insurance and asset management and custodial fee revenue increased, while interest and dividend, investment banking and other revenue declined. Merrill Lynch took a $470 million charge against earnings in the previous quarter to pay for a major restructuring, which gave the firm its first annual loss since going public in 1971. Merrill plans to eliminate about 3,000 jobs by the end of 1990 and is divesting some product lines and businesses. Merrill, Shearson and other Wall Street firms have been struggling because of declines in stock market activity and key businesses such as stock and bond underwriting and mergers and takeovers since the 1987 stock market crash. ``We're saying that in these weak market conditions, firms that generate profits are doing pretty well,'' said Jeffrey Bowman, who follows the securities industry for Standard & Poor's Corp. Merrill and Shearson reported lower investment banking revenue as business remained sluggish in stock and bond underwriting and merchant banking. Merrill's business fell 26.7 percent and Shearson's 25 percent. Brokerage commission revenue was up 4.2 percent at Merrill, and down 5.3 percent at Shearson. At Shearson, revenue from market-making and principal transactions also fell sharply, attributed in part to volatility in the collapsed junk bond market. Shearson is selling its portfolios of junk bonds it holds for investment. Merrill Chairman William A. Schreyer said in a statement that he expected a previously announced restructuring program, which includes a cut through sharp staff reductions, to positively impact earnings for the rest of the year. Merrill said quarterly expenses totaled $2.60 billion, down 5 percent from $2.73 billion reported in the 1989 period.

DOC.HEAD: Seamen's Bank For Savings Insolvent
DOC.TEXT: The Seamen's Bank for Savings, one of the city's oldest banks, was declared insolvent and closed Wednesday by the Federal Deposit Insurance Co., partly because of bad real estate loans. Customers at the failed bank automatically became depositors at The Chase Manhattan Bank, which assumed the $2.1 billion in Seaman's accounts under an FDIC-backed agreement. All 13 branches were expected to reopen Thursday as Chase branches. ``For the depositors, it will be business as usual,'' FDIC spokesman Alan Whitney told a news conference in Manhattan. Next door, at a Wall Street branch of Seamen's, a steady stream of people crowded around the bank's locked doors, reading notices from the FDIC about the bank's insolvency and Chase's takeover. ``The ship is sinking, the ship is sinking,'' muttered one elderly man as he hurried away after reading the signs. ``I know that it's protected, but still, you don't like to walk by and see that sign in the window,'' said depositor Janet Cullimane. ``I've got a lump in my throat.'' Seamen's was chartered in 1829 to encourage saving by seamen and others connected with the seafaring trade. ``The values of the assets were less than the values of the liabilities,'' said Nick Ketcha, a FDIC regulations director. ``There were some poor investment decisions made.'' He said a portion of the bank's portfolio was in loans in the Southwest, primarily mortgage-backed securities. A number of banks have experienced problems with loans made in that part of the country, where the depression of oil prices has contributed to an economic slowdown, including business failures and a soft real-estate market. The last bank to fail in the city was First City National Bank, which was closed down in December.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T's First-Quarter Profit Up 12.5 Percent, MCI's Jumps 22 Percent
With AM-AT&T Meeting
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Wednesday its first-quarter profit rose 12.5 percent, while MCI Communications Corp. reported its first-quarter net income jumped 22 percent. Also Wednesday, BellSouth Corp., a regional phone company, reported its first quarter earnings dropped nearly 6 percent. AT&T said its profit for the quarter ended March 31 was boosted by improved long-distance revenue and higher equipment sales. The company earned $668 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with $594 million, or 55 cents a share, in the first three months of 1989. Revenue totaled $8.89 billion, up 2.7 percent from $8.66 billion. Its operating income increased 21 percent, while costs and expenses were about the same as during the last year's first quarter, the company said. AT&T, the nation's largest long-distance phone company, said its long-distance volume rose nearly 7 percent in the quarter compared with a year ago. Among the leading gainers were international calls and specialized business services such as WATS lines and ``800'' toll-free lines, it said. Product sales increased 1.2 percent. Growth was shown in network phone equipment and consumer phone products, while sales dropped for some products, including small-business phone systems. The results were released in conjunction with the company's annual shareholders meeting in Los Angeles. Charles Nichols, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said AT&T's earnings were a bit shy of Wall Street projections. He said the earnings could have been hurt slightly by AT&T's network problems Jan. 15 that blocked millions of calls. AT&T stock lost $1 to close at $41 a share Wednesday in the New York Stock Exchange trading. Nichols said the drop probably was due to the slightly lower-than-expected earnings and general softness in the stock market. MCI, the nation's second-largest long distance company, said its first-quarter profit totaled $156 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with $128 million, or 51 cents a share, in the same period of 1989. Revenue increased 20 percent to $1.8 billion from $1.5 billion, said MCI, which is based in Washington, D.C. The results in last year's first quarter reflected a pre-tax gain of $18 million from previously negotiated antitrust settlements and an after-tax extraordinary charge of $10 million for early debt retirement, MCI said. MCI's stock lost $1.62{ a share to close at $35.12{ in national over-the-counter trading. Atlanta-based BellSouth reported its first-quarter earnings totaled $423.2 million, or 88 cents a share, down from $449.6 million, or 97 cents a share, in the same period of 1989.Revenue was $3.52 billion, up from $3.37 billion. Chairman John L. Clendenin blamed the profit drop in part on an accounting change and BellSouth's acquisition of Mobile Communications Corp. of America. The accounting change boosted 1989's first-quarter results by 15 cents a share, Clendenin said. Clendenin said 17.1 million shares that were purchased to acquire MCCA were reissued. The reduced number of shares outstanding in the first quarter of 1989 increased that quarter's earnings per share by about 4 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Lorenzo Details Latest Proposal To Creditors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 new grafs to UPDATE with Lorenzo testimony, editing to conform. Picks up 5th graf, Bakes said... SUBs 12th graf pvs, Texas Air... to reflect testimony.
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines creditors would receive 30 cents on the dollar under the latest reorganization proposal offered by the airline's parent Texas Air Corp., Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo said Wednesday. Lorenzo _ in his first testimony yet before the bankruptcy court supervising Eastern's reorganization _ spoke at a hearing over unsecured creditors' request to remove him from control of Eastern in favor of a court-appointed trustee. Eastern argues that putting an outsider in charge would hurt its chances of financial recovery. The company has been attempting to reach an agreement with the creditors to forestall such a move. Earlier, Eastern President Phil Bakes testified that appointment of a trustee would spark employee departures, hurt business further and heighten the chance Eastern eventually would have to be liquidated. Lorenzo said that under a reorganization proposal made Monday, unsecured creditors would get 30 cents on the dollar, about 20 percent of that in cash and the rest in securities. Creditors also would get about 8 percent of Texas Air's stock. Creditors recently rejected an Eastern reorganization proposal that would have paid them 27{ cents on the dollar, including 2{ cents cash and the rest in securities. Texas Air also would guarantee payment of the claims by year's end, regardless of Eastern's condition at the time, if the reorganization plan was not confirmed by Nov. 1, Lorenzo said. Furthermore, Texas Air would cover one half of Eastern's projected losses through June 30, up to $40 million. ``Texas air would be totally responsible for the feasibility of the corporation (Eastern),'' Lorenzo said. The proposal was conditioned on bankruptcy court approval of Texas Air's previously announced sale of 50 percent of its System One computerized reservations system to Electronic Data Systems Corp. for $250 million. It also was conditioned on approval of Texas Air's payment of $280 million to Eastern to settle potential claims raised by a report by bankruptcy examiner David I. Shapiro. The report suggested Texas Air had underpaid by hundreds of millions of dollars for Eastern and some of its assets. In addition to the trustee request, Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland is considering Eastern's request for $80 million from escrow to finance its operations during the second quarter. Bakes said the money would be needed in the next week to 10 days, although sources close to Texas Air have said the company is committed to covering Eastern's short-term expenses. The creditors, who are owed about $980 million, claim Eastern's inability to make viable business projections and halt its financial losses indicates current management should be replaced. But Bakes said putting a trustee in charge of Eastern would make it tougher for the company to improve its performance, citing earlier Eastern testimony that such a move would shake the confidence of consumers and travel agents in the airline. ``I believe that there will be a much heightened risk of a liquidation of the company, whether intended or not...'' Bakes said. Bakes also said many employees _ particularly in the maintenance, engineering and flight operations areas _ would quit their jobs if a trustee was appointed. Bakes conceded that Eastern had missed on many of its financial projections, but said much of the airline industry experienced the same uncertainty, especially in 1989. ``There's been a lot of negotiations, a lot of discussions ... I'm not going to discuss it,'' Bakes told reporters earlier Wednesday. Sources have said Texas Air also has agreed to possibly remove some top managers in order to placate creditors. But Houston-based Texas Air issued a statement labeling as ``totally untrue'' rumors that Bakes' resignation had been offered as a compromise to the creditors. ``We have made no proposals to creditors which would involve Phil Bakes' replacement, nor is any such proposal planned,'' Lorenzo said in the statement. ``Phil and his team have done admirably under very tough and trying circumstances.'' The committee representing unsecured creditors asked Texas Air several weeks ago to inject funds into Eastern. Texas Air's refusal helped precipitate the creditors' request for Lifland to appoint a trustee. Eastern has been reorganizing under bankruptcy court protection since shortly after a March 1989 strike by its Machinists, pilots and flight attendants. The company has operated on a much smaller scale but has suffered from millions of dollars in business it lost and has had trouble regaining since the strike. Bakes, who also is Eastern's chief executive officer, reviewed in his court testimony the labor strife and financial losses that marked his tenure. Bakes took the job at Eastern in October 1986, after Texas Air acquired the carrier. Before that, he had been president of Eastern's sister carrier Continental Airlines, which reorganized under federal bankruptcy laws starting in 1982. Bakes also said there is considerable debate within Eastern's ranks about the wisdom of the proposed sale of its prized South American routes to rival American Airlines. On Tuesday, one top Eastern official resigned, apparently motivated at least partly by the trustee issue. Eastern spokesman Robin Matell said Tuesday that Jose Smith, the airline's senior vice president of operations, had accepted a job at Coca-Cola Co. Smith, who has worked for Eastern for 23 years, could not be reached for comment. But Bakes, asked by a reporter Wednesday about Smith's departure, said his decision ``has something to do with what is going on here, in this courtroom.''

DOC.HEAD: First Interstate Net Off 4 Pct; Losses Staunched in Texas, Arizona
DOC.TEXT: First Interstate Bancorp said profits fell 4 percent in the first quarter but its troubled Texas unit turned a $9.1 million profit and losses ended at its Arizona bank. First Interstate earned $127.2 million, or $2.23 a share, in the first three months of the year compared with $132.2 million, or $2.81 a share, a year earlier. Earnings per share declined sharply, reflecting the bank's issue of 8.6 million new shares of common stock in February to replenish its capital. First Interstate took a staggering $400 million in special charges in December, mainly to cover losses at its Texas bank. Just a few weeks earlier, it took a $350 million charge for third-quarter losses in Arizona. It also began an accelerated program to dump its troubled assets in Texas. Those moves resulted in a $124.5 million loss for all of 1989 and sent the bank's stock price tumbling. They also increased speculation that First Interstate might become a takeover target for a big healthy bank because of its $57 billion in assets and sprawling system of offices in 21 states. The bank holding company's actions last year, particularly the sell-off of bad loans in Texas, were beginning to pay off, Chairman and Chief Executive Joseph J. Pinola said. ``Our Texas bank is reporting earnings, while our Arizona bank is now slightly above break even and meeting our expectations,'' Pinola said. Excluding a one-time tax gain in 1989 and accounting changes, operating earnings were $97.1 million for the latest quarter, up from $94.3 million in the first quarter of 1989. Net interest income fell 8.7 percent to $581.6 million, largely due to the sale of assets, First Interstate said. The net interest margin, the difference between what the bank earns on its loans and what it pays depositors, increased to 4.76 percentage points in the latest quarter from 4.67 points in the fourth quarter of 1989. Non-interest income fell 6 percent to $243.7 million in the first quarter from $259.9 million in the 1989 period. Bad loans totaled $2.05 billion on March 31, down from $2.08 billion a year earlier and $2.11 billion at the end of 1989. ``While modest, this is the third quarter in which the level of non-performing assets has been reduced,'' Pinola said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slides, Stock Prices Move Higher in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar slid in early trading against the Japanese yen Thursday and share prices moved sharply higher on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The dollar started tradingdown 1.52 yen from Wednesday's close of 159.87 yen. It finished at 158.12 yen in New York overnight, down from 159.68 yen on Tuesday. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 402.96 poin at 158.35 yen, ts, or 1.37 percent, shortly after the market opened to move to 29,652.02. The index gained 787.46 points Wednesday. Currency dealers said the dollar's slide followed its downswing in New York Wednesday, despite a report of a sharp improvement in the U.S. merchandise trade figures for February. The U.S. Commerce Department said the nation's trade deficit narrowed in February to a six-year low of $6.49 billion from a revised $9.32 billion deficit in January. ng like those of the past, when young workers were housed in unheated concrete buildings, often four or five to a room, and enthusiastic supervisors tried to instill company values of group living and personal sacrifice. Such privation is no longer tolerated by Japanese who have grown up in comfort. Major corporations also are taking on a greater role as landlords as workers demand more help to cope with housing costs shooting up much faster than average pay levels. In a recent Economic Planning Agency survey of 1,781 of Japan's largest firms, 51.3 percent of the 1,211 that responded said they intended to remodel or build new dormitories for unmarried employees in the next three years. Watabe, who has worked three years for Sumitomo Corp., a trading company, has a carpeted, furnished 140 square-foot room with heating and cooling. The $50 monthly rent is about one-tenth the cost of similar rooms in the neighborhood. Moreover, those rooms don't offer some of the other features of his dormitory _ a deep, hot Japanese bath ready at all times, a billiards room, an outdoor tennis court and a cafeteria with steak on the menu. To meet demands for greater privacy and comfort, Nissan Motor Corp. remodeled a university dormitory outside Yokohama for the staff of its main research facility, the Nissan Technical Center. The brick, seven-story ``Parc Vert Nissan'' overlooks a verdant country club. Each of the 165 men and women residents has a single room furnished with bed, desk, dressers and bathroom. They can use a large kitchen, computer room, garden patio and ``karaoke'' equipment, a popular entertainment system with recorded musical accompaniment for amateur singers, who croon into the attached microphone. Company dorms formerly were meant to house bachelors or young families temporarily while they saved enough to buy homes. Employers structured income scales and benefit policies to permit home purchases just as workers were starting families and facing greater costs. Now, however, Asahi Mutual Life Insurance Co. has calculated that if Tokyo-area land prices continue rising at their average annual rate of the last 15 years, 9.6 percent, a 20-year-old today will not be able afford to buy a one-room apartment before he becomes 40. This has led to a profound shift in company benefit plans. In the Economic Planning Agency survey, the number of companies that said they intended to build new company housing rose by 17.9 percent from last year. But those planning to increase housing allowances decreased by 11.9 percent and those planning to extend low-interest loans for mortgages fell by 8.9 percent. Toshiya Yamamoto, manager of Nissan's employee welfare section, said his company's compensation system still is aimed at enabling a worker to buy an apartment of comfortable size within 90 minutes' commute by age 35. But Yamamoto acknowledged that Nissan's assistance _ $233,000 in low-interest loans _ is insufficient to buy a home. Under such conditions, workers are staying in company housing even after marriage. At companies that lack housing, particularly foreign firms, Japanese are increasingly pressing their employers to acquire it. Yamamoto said that in erecting new housing, ``we first consider who among our staff is in greatest need and we devise a system to fit their needs.'' Luring new recruits ``by creating beautiful showpieces'' is not an aim of company housing policy, he said. Nevertheless, recruiting specialists say that among the growing number of Japanese changing jobs, the housing question is becoming more important in choosing new employers. Watabe, employed in Sumitomo's personnel division, said many college students looking into future employment ask about housing conditions. Watabe said he probably won't start thinking about whether to buy a home until he gets married. Standing on the artificial turf of his dorm's tennis court, he pointed to his feet. ``If I wanted to buy land right now, all I could get would be the land I'm standing on,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Apple Reports 134 Percent Jump In Second-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. said lower component costs, success of new products and improved overseas sales helped it more than double earnings in the three months ended March 30. The world's No. 2 personal computer maker said Wednesday that net income for its fiscal second quarter was $131.8 million, or $1.04 a share, compared with $56.4 million, or 44 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 8 percent to $1.35 billion from $1.25 billion. ``It was a very good report by any standard. It was way at the far end of anyone's expectations,'' said Steven Ossad, an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive officer, said the company was enjoying lower component costs and strong sales of computers introduced last year. International sales also rose, representing 47 percent of net sales during the latest quarter compared with 40 percent for the same period a year ago. ``During the quarter the percentage of revenues coming from outside the United States reached an all-time high,'' Sculley said in a statement. For the first six months of the fiscal year, earnings rose 30 percent to $256.7 million, or $2 a share, from $196.8 million, or $1.54 a share a year ago. Revenues rose 7 percent to $2.84 billion from $2.65 billion. Despite the quarter's ``staggering'' performance, the company was correct to be cautious in its forecast for the second half of 1990, Ossad said. Apple told analysts it was unlikely it would achieve 10 percent growth in the second half, he added. Apple needs to increase the number of less expensive products, particularly in light of the growing demand for computers among consumers and schools, Ossad said.

DOC.HEAD: Northrop Net Up 900 Pct Due to Sale of Headquarters Buildings,
DOC.TEXT: B-2 bomber builder Northrop Corp. said its earnings rose nearly nine-fold in the first quarter, mostly reflecting a profit on the sale of its headquarters in Century City. For the three months ended March 31, Northrop earned $96 million, or $2.04 a share, compared with $9.7 million, or 21 cents a share, in the same period last year. Sales were unchanged at $1.28 billion. Excluding the gain on the sale of the headquarters, Northrop said it would have earned $28.9 million, or 62 cents a share. The aerospace company said a slight increase in aircraft sales offset a small decrease in its missiles and unmanned vehicles business. Northrop's order backlog was $5.7 billion, up 24 percent from $4.6 billion a year earlier. The first-quarter earnings included $67.1 million from the sale of the headquarters complex. The balance of the after-tax gain on the sale, $22.8 million, will be amortized over the 10-year life of the lease under which Northrop remains in the same offices.

DOC.HEAD: Supercomputer Maker Reports $12.4 Million Net Loss For First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Cray Computer Corp. said it lost $12.4 million in the first quarter because of expected equipment and construction costs for the development of its Cray-3 supercomputer. The loss amounted to 73 cents a share. Neil Davenport, president and chief executive officer, said Wednesday the latest loss was expected. ``During the first quarter of 1990 we completed the acquisition of certain machinery and equipment and process technology from GigaBit Logic Inc., which will allow us to manufacture our own GaAs circuits,'' he said. ``We also commenced construction of a 40,000-square-foot addition to our existing facility to house the GaAs foundry, which is expected to be completed in July 1990,'' said Davenport. Cray Computer was spun off last November from Cray Research Inc., the nation's largest supercomputer maker, to develop founder Seymour Cray's planned Cray-3.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Agrees to Pay up to $27 Million in Hazardous Waste Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force has agreed to pay as much as $27 million of the cleanup costs at two hazardous waste dump sites used by The Boeing Co., court papers revealed. In a deposition taken for a lawsuit between Boeing and its insurers, Stephen Trautwein, a local Air Force contract manager, said the cleanup was considered part of ``ordinary and necessary business costs.'' Trautwein said the cleanup costs at the two sites _ Western Processing in Kent and Queen City Farms in Maple Valley _ were negotiated as a separate item between Boeing and Air Force contract officers. A Pentagon spokesman in Washington, D.C., told the Seattle Post-Intelligencer Tuesday that ``it is not standard procedure'' for the Defense Department to reimburse a contractor for hazardous waste cleanup costs. However, a spokeswoman at the Air Force Contract Management Division in Albuquerque, N.M., said the Air Force agreed to pay a portion of the costs at the two sites because the service considered the cleanups ``necessary and normal business expenses.'' A Boeing spokesman said, ``in general, those costs are recognized as usual and accepted costs of doing business. It was something we worked out with the Air Force,'' the Post-Intelligencer reported, without naming its sources. Boeing dumped about 24 million gallons of hazardous waste at the sites between 1957 and 1977. The company has estimated the cost of cleanup at more than $80 million. Boeing signed a consent agreement with the Environmental Protection Agency to pay most of the cleanup costs after the EPA closed the two sites in the early 1980s. Boeing already has spent about $40 million to clean up the sites, but it was not known whether that amount included Air Force funds, the Post-Intelligencer reported. A federal judge ruled this week that a jury will have to decide whether Boeing must pay for the cleanups or if it can pass the costs on to its insurers. The insurers claim Boeing is liable because their policies were designed to cover cleanups from accidents. They introduced evidence in federal court last week indicating the company failed to heed warnings made as early as the 1950s that its dumping would cause pollution at the two sites. Boeing has maintained that it did not knowingly pollute the two sites. Boeing has told its insurers it could be liable for cleanups in 13 other toxic waste dumps sites around the United States. Those sites include several that contain waste from its military work.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 32.89 points to 2,732.88, giving back nearly all of its 36.04-point gain over the three previous sessions. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 477 up, 1,056 down and 473 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 147.13 million shares, up from 127.99 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 179.79 million shares. The Commerce Department reported that the U.S. trade deficit in February shrank to its narrowest reading in more than six years. Imports exceeded exports by $6.49 billion, down from $9.32 billion in January. Analysts said that held out the prospect of stronger-than-expected growth in economic output, and improved profits at many companies with a substantial international business. At the same time, however, it touched off fresh worries about the outlook for interest rates.
